entry.title: Week 443AZ: Busy Magic Chair Parents
entry.content:
This week has been B-U-S-Y. Tori's got a play going into tech which means she's pulling 12 hour days, and my work is getting busy  as we get close to Turkey 5 (it's fun being in retail as you get to see neat words). To make it more interesting, there is a magic conference this weekend (which is where I'm writing this).  It's my first magic conference, and I'm inspired with some new material (3 months from now watch out!).

Next week should be busy too, but looking forward to things calming down in early November.

Problems are opportunities though, and Zach got a chance to start walking home from school and hanging by himself at home for a few minutes.  He digs it! Amelia didn't want to be left out, she asked Mom: d
A: I want to walk home from school!
T: Well, your school is a 3 hour walk
A: It's OK, you can drive behind me in the car, and when I get tired, you can pick me up.

Amelia loves being active, and after a few months of not wanting to ride her bike, she asked if we could take her on a bike ride (who knows, maybe she's desperate for attention since her parents are slammed), and I did in the dark as well, Amelia doesn't care and either do I (fear not, we went to the school playground).

Let me explain a few pictures.

Me and that other bald guy - he's Mike Pisciotta and having watched his lecture, I'll be studying his magic carefully for my next round of magic.



 Mouse (the truck)  full of chairs - Tori's play requires like 100 chairs. These ones are "generic" but the first 70  had personality.   Our house has been as I imagine Santa's workshop, or atleast the part of the workshop where the kids who want crazy chair's wishes are fulfilled.

Feet in the hot tub.  This is my first magic conference, and at the end of a *very* long week, so snuck out a lecture that didn't suite my personality and plopped into the hotub - ahhh.



ps. Some of you may be thinking - if Tori's working, and Igor's magicing cards to every surface - where are the kids? They're at Miga's off course! Once our lives calm down we'll have weekends full of the Miga kids so we can pay them back.

pss. This week I'm super proud as I've been told two things 1) From a magic busker after I came back to our table having performed a magic trick - "Igor, I love that you're fearless". 2) From one of my co-workers - "Igor, you're the best boss ever" (OK, I did just buy a team lunch for appreciation of tall their hard work).

entry.title: Week 442AZ: Amelia day
entry.content:
Sunday Tori ran off with Zach, and Amelia and I got a spend a wonderful fall day together.   We started by face painting.   Then we enjoyed a walk in the arboretum, where we ran into Ryan walking Kirby (his dog) and Amelia took the leash for a bit.

When we got home we did some pumpkin carving (which might be the first pumpkin I remember ever carving myself - well technically with Amelia).

When Tori and Zach got home, Zach was inspired by a new enterprise - smelly marker making. See Tori got Zach a 'make your own smelly marker set' and this tickled his entrepreneurial spirit.  He's now scheming to sell markers to everyone, starting with free samples. Baba - lets hope your deluxe set isn't confiscated at the border.

entry.title: Week 441AZ: Strawberry milk shots
entry.content:
In our home the kids have a habit of midnight snack. It's a final snack before going to bed (I know, it need some work to get healthy, but we'll get there).  Usually it's Tori or I grabbing something but last night Zach took command.

He gathered his sister, he got out my expensive whiskey shot glasses, and his specially requested private reserve strawberry milk.   After some perfect pours and satisfying clinks with his sister, he decided he was hungry, and so got out some pita bread, tomato  sauce and an assortment of salami and pepperoni.  Finally he sliced the pizza up (with scissors) for himself and his sister.


Bon Appetite

ps. Not only was Zach a perfect chef and server, but Amelia was also a fully engaged and appreciative guest.

entry.title: Week 440AZ: Pumpkin Patch
entry.content: Every year we go to a pumpkin patch - and this being a year, off we went.  As usual, it's better with the Miga's so we we followed them there.  Everyone had a hoot, don't let the boys expression fool you - they enjoyed it too.

entry.title: Week 439AZ: A perfect day in the life
entry.content:
Today I nailed my perfect day. That day when I live my priorities.
                                                                                                         
Physical Health - I woke up @ 5am, and went to the gym @ 5:30am                                            
Family - I got home @ 7:30am to walk Zach to school, the came back to give Amelia a hug                    
Not driving - I biked to the subway                                                                      
Magic - I did a magic trick for a family on the subway who loved it.                                      
Not driving - I biked up the main drag of downtown                                                        
Work - I got to work @ 8:15am and started my work day                                                      
Work - I worked with HR to establish a common bar for the leadership team to assess all employees        
Work - I cleared a bottleneck for my employee on a charity related project at work                    
Family - I got home @ 5pm, a solid 8 and a half hour work day.                                                                                  
Family - I went swimming with the family @ 7pm                                                              
Family - Because Zach did 14 laps at the pool, I took Zach and Amelia to Beths for milk shakes.
Family - Home @ 9:00pm for sleeps.

Tori would call out the day ran a bit long as the kids (and their dad) should be in bed by 8.  Amelia agreed, the next day she said:

Amelia: The milk shake was good, but I was too tired to drink it all.

Igor would call out there were no explicit emotional health practices in there, but fear not, they’re getting put back in.

link.title: Week 439AZ: A perfect day in the life

entry.title: Week 433AZ: Canada Vacation 2018
entry.content:
For this year's vacation we hung out with Yelana, Justin and Sam in Muskoka at a giant house. Then we hang out with Baltasar, Rada and their family.

Yelana and Justin booked a giant house on a resort. It was awesome staying at a resort with a pool, lake, free boat rentals and nightly shows. While we were Amelia lived in the pool, and the whole family got out boating on the lake. I took my first stab at paddle boarding, zach took his first stab swimming in a lake, and Amelia took here first Kayak ride (with Zach and I).

The resort had shows every night, and one night the guy brought animals, and Amelia got a bird to stand on her shoulder. Zach and I got to spend some time programming, which is super cool.

For the Baltasar leg of the vacation we ran our standard play book - Canada's wonderland followed by a feast at their place, where the kids get along like bestie's just like their parents. When Zach and Ben (Baltasar's sun) were racing around at the grocery store, it was a flash back to Baltasar in College. Ben was racing in the "exit only door" and Zach was screaming at him "Stop. You can't do that! Come back". It was awesome.   Baltasar reminded me of something important this trip as well.  I said "Baltasar man - we're all grown up."  He turned to me in disgust and said "Grown up? No, we've just gotten old!" Right he is.

We spent lots of time in pools, which the kids love. Doing this I saw a few things I'd never seen before: Zach helping Amelia float, and Zach doing 40 laps. To get Zach to do laps I had to pay 25 cents a lap but totally worth it to see him doing the physical activity.

To get us to Canada Tori, figured out we'd save a bunch of time by getting Nexus, and OMG she nailed it! We flew out of Vancouver and that let us breeze through the border, and the lines at the airport.  Woohoo! Nice job again Tori!!

entry.title: Week 432AZ: We're off to see the family
entry.content:
Every year we make a pilgrimage to see my sister.  Sometimes she comes to our neck of the woods, and every other year we go to hers. This year we're heading to Ontario, where we'll be staying in a family beach resort. In fact I'm there getting sunspots from watching the pretty orange sunrise.

Huge callout to Tori for getting us our Nexus cards.  Because we flew out of Vancouver we had to cross the canadian border by car and the Nexus card let us whip through. Similarly for our flight,  we got to go through the short line.

Because we flew out of Vancouver we got to enjoy the fantastic sushi/teriyaki restaurants. I'm not sure why but the bento boxes in Vancouver seem to have Tempura and a weird vinegar rice noodle soup that I'm really enjoying.

I published my first linked in article about work life balance, and I'm very proud of that. The genesis of the article was realizing that when I change jobs, I have one remaining insecurity (the last ones was failing relative to my peers). The insecurity was not being able to maintain my work life balance. So, I wrote a post enumerating my thoughts for myself and my team. Even though the article is super long, I'm impressed by how good a reaction it's had.   Also, it's been able to help me make decisions - for example pushing to take my holidays, and pushing to leave work on time.


Yea to Tori! Yea to Nexus! Yea to seeing the family!

And OMG, Zach has been super helpful with Amelia. As an example, here he is helping her swim in the pool. WOW!!!

link.title: Week 432AZ: We're off to see the family

entry.title: Week 431AZ: New Job, New Health Kick
entry.content:
I started my new job this week. It's always fun to get a new set of challenges, but also very energy consuming to learn a whole bunch of new things.

Since I'm starting new things, I'm also starting a new health kick. I'll pause it for my upcoming vacation, but now that I'm almost back to 200lbs, I need to put energy and weight back on the top of my priority list.

It's also stinking hot in Seattle right now, the hottest, longest, heat wave in the time I've been in Seattle. The heat adds sucks the energy out of the whole family, which also drains our patience.  We're all looking forward to cooler better, and nicer moods all around.

Zach has gotten super helpful around the house - he'll clear the table, get drinks, make nachos with humus for snack, open popsicles for his sister, try to calm down his sister when she's upset. Both because he's accepting more responsibility, and because he's being paid in hard currency which he uses to play video games.   Zach's also writing some choose your own adventure games, and I'm trying to get him to do a typing tutorial. A sample conversation:

Z: You know, instead of me having to ask you to buy video games every time, we don't you just load up my account with money once, and I won't have to bother you.
I: I don't know, , OK, OK, how much should we add?
Z: 40 dollars.
I: What?! - 10 dollars.
Z: OK, 30.

I: Woah? you can't add 40, we said 30.
Z: Oh, I thought we agreed to 40.
I: No, we did not. 30.

Amelia has been coming into her own, and dreams of being bigger. I think in her mind bigger means being a mommy. Sample conversations with Amelia:


A: When I become a mom, you'll have to listen to what I say.


The kids :



My new team at work. They're a fun lot and we've already gone for a BBQ, picking up supplies on my bicycle.

link.title: Week 431AZ: New Job, New Health Kick

entry.title: Week 430AZ: Hanging with the Tori clan
entry.content:
This week was the first Tori clan family re-union it was great!

Amelia had a few awesome conversations this week:

A:  I can't wait to see how big I am tomorrow?
I: How do you mean?
A: I get bigger every single day, I wonder how much bigger I'll be this week.
I: I bet this big (make hand gestures)
--
A: Dad watch me do my trick
I: OK (not paying attention)
A: No Dad, watch with your eyes.

Zach has started making choose your own adventure games, he's currently bottlenecked on his dad typing, but I'll get him setup with a typing tutorial on his own computer.


It's also an exciting week for me.   I start my new job making it easy to shop on Alexa, and I kick off my third wave of health kick!

link.title: Week 430AZ: Hanging with the Tori clan

entry.title: Tori and the technicolor patio
entry.content:
When you're visiting our backyard, you might wonder about our technicolor patio. You might wonder how one ends up with such a thing.  It's a great thing to wonder and I wish I had pictures for the whole journey.

In the very beginning it was the front porch:


 And in the end it was lots of painting:


Most of the  journey though, when Tori was regrading our back yard, chiseling bricks, cutting stones and building our retaining wall, never got memorialized in photos. I'll do better next time.

entry.title: Week 429AZ: The perfect is the enemy of the done
entry.content:
Monday morning, time to blog.

The Tori clan has begun to descend on Seattle for their first ever family re-union. It's exciting to meet her family!   The re-union begins next week, and we're all looking forward to it.  They've done cool things like removing the door that was supporting our back porch. I'm a bit worried about the remaining structural integrity of the porch, but I'm usually a bit paranoid about these things and it's nice to unlock a new storage area.

It's crazy hot in Seattle (well, 90 degrees) and popsicles are especially popular.

 
I've been pushing hard on my magic, and hung out with a busking magician (Busking is street performing). The magician let me open for him, which meant I get to draw the first few people into the crowd, and do some opening tricks. Once the lady tried to pay me the busking magician jumped in and said "He works for Amazon and doesn't need the money, watch me and give the money to me".  I was all for it!

Tori's patio is done, and I'll send a separate post on the topic!

And of course - some bonus photos!

link.title: Week 429AZ: The perfect is the enemy of the done

entry.title: Week 428AZ: Swimming in Canadia
entry.content:
New rule, every week, rain or shine,  we get a post, even if it's nothing but a few pictures and a few paragraphs of gibberish - reflecting - that might be what I do normally :)  

We did a 2 day trip to Vancouver this weekend and it was an incredible impromptu vacation. We went swimming at Stanley park's second beach (The greatest swimming pool of all time) and also at the North Vancouver motel's parking lot pool (Which to the kids was the second  greatest pool of all time).    

Coming back from Vancouver, I realized we could "beat the system" and skip the line at the border crossing  by driving up to the duty free store! Tori was skeptical, but supportive as usual. We skipped a 30 minute line getting to the border crossing, but when we got there it didn't go so well: 

Border Guard: When did you go to Canada?
Igor: Yesterday
Border Guard:  Hymn, only one day?
Igor: Yes
Border Guard: Any alcohol?
Igor:   Yes Sir, just a bottle from the duty free. 
Border Guard: Sir, if you haven't been in Canada for 48 hours, you need to pay duty. 
Border Guard: Please park your car, and go to secondary inspection. 

We then spent 40 minutes standing in line so we could pay 2.14$ in duty on our "duty free" alcohol. 

Live and learn. 

Have a great week, and remember  Better a post that is crap, then not getting a scrap  - ZiaT

entry.title: Week 424AZ: Happy 40th Birthday to me
entry.content:
I've been skipping birthdays since I've been 14, but this year Tori threw me a birthday party for my 40th birthday. Zach and Amelia running up to my bed wishing me a happy birthday felt great. Because I've never celebrated my birthday, I've never had that experience before. At first it was irritating to get the birthday wishes, and to get them on the wrong day, but as the day went on I started enjoying the wishes, it was really nice.

Many of my old friends showed up. I enjoy seeing folks I've known for more then 5, 10 and 20 years. I'm lucky to know so many folks for so long! Thank you powers that be!!

Tori throws a mean party, and this was no exception. We met at Carceek park, had perfect weather, and I got to BBQ up a storm[^bbq]. Tori took care of all the details, from ordering the picnic shelter, to handling the invites, to making yummy salads, to co-ordinating the various food vendors, to getting there early to get everything setup. Thank you Tori, you make everything better!

In other news

It's summer and we finally bought our plane tickets for our Canada trip. Looking forward to our upcoming vacation!!
In Tori news
I'll respect her privacy and skip this section.
In Zach news
It's really cool to see Zach growing up. For the first time this week I saw him in his glasses. Zach in glasses give me flashbacks of wearing glasses when I was his age.

Zach did his annual school singing show, and it was great to watch him singing Cecilia by the beetles. He really enjoyed himself. I'm so grateful to have Zach at a great school that's only a block from our house.

In Amelia news

It feels like I say this ever week, but it's true. Amelia is a ball of positive love, who loves to be physically active. At every opportunity she's handing out hugs and hanging from trees. It's a great way to live, and I'll encourage her to do this her whole life through.
In Igor news
My group of 50 at work merged with another group of 50 and I got to serve breakfast for about 100 folks. I really enjoy industrial cooking and this time I cooked almost 100 eggs and 8 lbs of bacon, and a whole lot of waffles (another manager was operating the waffle station, so I'm not sure the waffle count). Every time I run the breakfast I get better at it. This year, I was proud to carry the eggs and bacon on the touring pannier of my bicycle. Everything else I needed, including a second griddle, I had deliver by one hour delivery service (Prime Now). It's amazing how convenient the world has gotten.

My knee has been bugging me for months, and I finally got a knee brace. Not as good as going to a Dr, but I conclude the knee brace (and knee strengthening exercises) is all a Dr would have recommended. Day 1 of the brace has been fantastic, I didn't realize how much I've been babying my knee and how nice it is not to have to.

I've been exploring latte art, but I have a way to go. I'm also using an auto-foam maker, so it's possible I have the wrong tool for the job. I suppose the best thing to do is find a barista and get a hands on lesson.

In house news

Tori continues to cut through (pun intended) the patio, she's down to the final row of half bricks. There's something oddly satisfying and standing on a patio made from the bricks of your porch. Tori has also been able to admit that our front yard, filled with wheat, is funny, and has started harvesting the wheat for bread. I wonder how much wheat you need for bread.

Footnotes

Have a great week and remember, When ever you turn forty, it's more important to be sporty - ZiaT

entry.title: Week 423 AZ: Memorial Day
entry.content:
Happy Memorial day! It's been a fun week. We're dog sitting Kirby, Ryan's dog, which both Amelia and Tori love. I've been cognitively productive, which always make me happy.

The highlight of my week was biking Amelia to preschool (and it has its own blogpost).
In Tori news
I'll respect her privacy and skip this section.
In Zach news
My thoughts on Zach continue to oscillate between "My god he's a wicked smart young man", and "he's an 8 year old kid". Yesterday Zach made a YouTube tutorial on getting access to a web browser on his kindle from the login screen. He'll have no trouble being a 'hacker' in future.

Later the same day, after he'd used up his Kindie minutes, he laid on the ground with thirty green plastic army men making the same shooting noises I did as a kid.

Earlier in the week, as a pre-requisite to play SIMS (his favorite video game) I made Zach write a story. He wrote his story(future me, it's stored in OneDrive) in 1.5 inch tall wobbly kid letters, complete with an illustrated cover page and inline illustrations. Best of all - he was so proud, he read me the story, showing off the illustration, and pointing out stuff that wasn't clear in his writing. My gosh I'm proud of that. Here's the full text:

One day at Freddy Fasbear's pizzeria, a monster storm appeared out of nowhere. Then an evil animatronic named Edwards appeared. Edward hated everybody and everything except other animatronics. Just then a gigantic missile hit the hotel.

In Amelia news

Amelia is so athletic. I recall a teacher saying "Zach's body doesn't bring him joy". Amelia is the exact opposite. Every time I see her she's hanging off something do some gymnastic moves. While I wasn't paying attention she started picking up Kirby's ball and playing catch with him. She can throw really well. I'm so proud of her.

Amelia is always full of Joy. She's always smiling, laughing, and giving hugs. It's hard to articulate how pleasurable it is to have a ray of sunshine in your household, but it's easy to enjoy it. And I am.
In Igor news
It turns out there's a large magic community in Seattle, several of whom are professional, and some of whom are are so famous they lecture at magic conferences. It turns out one of my super powers is making stuff happen activator in the self help lingo. The last few weeks I've been "convening" the magic community by saying "Hey lets get together" and they all show up. That's some serious magic.

It also turns out there's a large quantity of cool places in Seattle I never go to. Self remember - go to new places instead of just going to the same old places.

Speaking of reminding myself of things, self - I have several kinds of health: physical, emotional, cognitive and identity/spiritual. It's not enough to focus on 1 type of health at the exclusion of the others. Need to balance all of them - for example this week, need to get back to diet and exercise.

In house news

Our video doorbell caught on fire(technically fire was on the video doorbell). Luckily Tori was home and was able to figure out what was going on and turned off the circuit breaker.  I'm also proud of myself because I was able to diagnose and fix what was going on (a short in the 100 year old door bell wiring).

Tori's been making steady progress on the patio. In case I haven't talked about it before it's a really cool project where Tori is building a patio out of all the bricks that were apart of our old 100 year old porch. It's not an easy project - she needs to clean the bricks, and cut them, and cut the outline - I
think I'll devote another post to this.

After years, eight years to be exact, of thinking my god its hot upstairs, I should really get a portable air conditioner, I got a portable air conditioner (OK Tori got tired of my whining and go the air conditioner).  Walk upstairs and being comfortable is , unsurprisingly, infinitely better then going upstairs and roasting as you'd imagine imps would in hell.

Conversations with Amelia

On Kirby ...
I: Do you like having a dog here?
A: I really want a dog at home that we can keep for each and every day and each and every night
I: Why is that?
A: Because we get to feed him treats and food and milk. Did you know this is dogs dinner.
I: Yup looks tasty.
A: That's why I want he dog.
I: Are you going to walk the dog?
A: Did you know one time we want for a walk and the dog pooped on his foot.
I: Oh my gosh.

On why we like gymnastics ...
I: Why do you like gymnastics?
A: I do like it, but I figured out how you like me doing gymnastics?
I: How do I like it?
A: Well you saw me and baba doing gymnastics.
I: Yes I did.

On healing...
I: Amelia lets wake?
A: Dad, leave me along, I don't want to wake up. I want to heal me foot.
I: What do you mean? I'll give you a hug.
A: Dad hugs don't heal feet, sleeping heals feet.

Conversations with Zach

I need to record more of these.


Have a great week and remember, There are 4 types of health, and having them all is true wealth - ZiaT

entry.title: Achievement Unlocked: Subway biking Amelia to Pre-School
entry.content:
One of the biggest quality of life improvements I've made is walking Zach to school.  We live 5 minutes from school, so it's pretty easy.  I've always wanted to do the same for Amelia but her school is a 30 minute drive away, so it wasn't really practical.

A few times I've driven Amelia to school  in Sparky, but I don't find driving especially satisfying.   I've always had this idea that I could take the subway to close to Amelia's school and then bike the last mile.

Today I did it, and it was as awesome as I imagined!  Amelia and I had a riot, and I even kept our bags in my back packs in my bike bag.

Unfortunately, it's a long trip, almost 2 hours from leaving till when I get to work (probably 90 minutes if I didn't get lost in the middle).

Even though it's long, it's quality time that I really enjoy, so maybe I'll make it a quarterly or monthly activity.

link.title: Achievement Unlocked: Subway biking Amelia to Pre-School

entry.title: Week 421AZ: Camping
entry.content:
Seems like every time I post one of these, I'm apologizing for not writing more, or not doing a good job. I'll continue the pattern today!

This was a fun week.

I went to my first magic show, and it was an awesome one, David Blaine at the Paramount. First, I'd never been to the paramount, and second I'd never been to a magic show. I'm told David Blaine is as good as it gets, and it was pretty frickin cool. What really amazed me is that what he was doing could easily boring - like watching him hold his breath for 10 minutes, the show was able to really make it interesting. For the last several minutes people were screaming and almost standing.  Very impressive.

The other thing I loved about the show was how engaging it was, how warm and audience embracing it was. I'll need to remember this as I think about my magic.

This week, I also decided I'll be putting together a variety show (magic and circus) for a women's shelter (Mary's Place). It's something I've never done before, but it feels like something I"ll find very satisfying, and will be proud of.

In family news we went camping this weekend. We were joined by some folks from Amelia's pre-school. It was fun to meet some new friends. One of them was especially woodsy and was able to string up tarps by using a giant piece of plastic and chopping up fallen wood he found in the forest. Pretty frickin' cool, and especially important given it was th

Also, an incredibly cute story from Amelia, when I drove her to school (which I almost never do):

A: Can you come in and meet my boyfriend?
I: What? You have a boyfriend?
A: Yeah,but he's really mean to me. Luckily my friends protect me from him.
I: What?!

Later I asked Tori about this.

I: Did you know Amelia has a boyfriend?
T: Yeah, but she never told him.
I: Ah, well that's better I suppose.


And a bonus story from last week.

Last week, I ended up buying a rainbow suit (although I don't really remember why).  Tori asked if I was going to wear it, and I thought, geez I'm too old for that. Then I thought, my god, too old - it's essential that I wear it now!!! So of course I did!!!!

entry.title: Real world math milestones: Conveyer belt sushi
entry.content:
Zach loves sushi and math, I love natural opportunities for learning, so Zach, Amelia and I went to conveyer belt sushi.  The cool thing about conveyer belt sushi is the plates are color coded with each plate having a specific price (e.g. blue is 1$, red is 2$).  This is a fantastic opportunity for multiplication, and for the first time, Zach was able to compute the price.  It warms my heart to see the pride on Zach's face when he was able to figure out the total.


Speaking of pride, Amelia was also here to enjoy sushi, and it was great to see Zach and Amelia tag teaming to get the sushi off the conveyer belt. It warms my heart to see them co-operating.

link.title: Real world math milestones: Conveyer belt sushi

entry.title: Achievement Unlocked: First Chaperone
entry.content:
Most memories of my child hood have faded, but one that burns bright is a field trip where my father and sister were chaperones. What a great way to reinforce how important Zach and Amelia are by making time to be with them on their special days.

The lead up …

A few weeks ago, I got mail inviting parents to chaperone Zach’s class on their field trip to the Pike place market. The idea of chaperoning flittered in my mind, but I dismissed it as I had to work. Sipping my coffee a few minutes later I stopped and thought: What’s more important - being at work or getting to see Zach enjoying himself on his field trip. Through that lens, I booked some time off work, and got excited to go on the field trip.

Even though Zach is 8, he puts on a tough guy bravado. When I told him I was going on the field trip he grumbled and said he’d rather have Mom. As the field trip got closer, I was really anticipating getting to see Zach with his class (1), and every day I’d ask Zach if he was excited to go on the field trip. Maintaining his tough guy persona - Zach would say “No”. I figured he was indifferent, but I was really excited. Finally, the night before the field trip, Zach asked me if I was excited and I said Absolutely!!! I asked Zach if he was excited, and he said yes.

The big day …

The day of the field trip was great. I got to see Zach in class and hanging out with his friends, and how much happiness and innocence there is in a pack of 8 year olds. While I enjoyed the wonder in my troop of young charges, and as a chaperone I needed to stay focused to ensure none of them got left behind. I don't think I've counted to 7 that many times in my life.

I really enjoyed watching the kids interact, and showing them all magic tricks. My magical 'style' has the spectators doing the magic, and I like to give them a card to remember the magic they performed. The kids loved, it and they loved getting their cards. Unfortunately, I hadn't told the other chaperones the kids could keep their cards and one of the parents rounded up the cards and gave them back to me. Oh well, next time I'll warn the parents.

To my surprise, I learned a few things about the Pike place market, and got to enjoy the samples. Some learnings for the next time you're at the market. You need to Rachel's'(the gol pig's nose for good luck. There is a big open garden near the seniors center. There's an art installation called Seattleites on the big stair case between 1st and the market. There's also a pig in the original Starbucks called Pork and beans. The gum wall which I'd heard about and never been to.

Afterwards …

After the field trip, Zach didn't say much, and I figured his Bravado was back in full force. Later in the evening Zach came down to my office and said "I really appreciate you came on the field trip", I was momentarily touched, and then he added "So, can I get to play computer games"? Dang I thought the kid was using me. Then, later that night, he just gave me a few spontaneous hugs (very rare for Zach). At bed time he also asked me if I could give him 10 minutes of dedicated snuggling - Absolutely I said!!

Even better, the next few days Zach and I have been way more open, he's telling me stuff that's happening at school. Awesome.

Reflections

My sister always tells me Zach and Amelia's world revolves around Tori and I, and while it's obvious to say, it's easy to forget. Especially easy to forget when your son has the bravado of a hardened criminal. Don't worry though, it doesn't matter how tough your kids (or anyone else) are - when you care, and put in time, relationships will flourish.

While I've built all this credibility up with Zach, I need to do the equivalent is with Amelia

Notes:

1) Anticipation is something I actively avoided because it could lead to disappointment, but I’ve had a change of heart anticipation lets you maximize the satisfaction of an event.

entry.title: Week 411AZ: Back on the horse!
entry.content:
I'm not sure why I've been making excuses for eating poorly, not exercising, and not doing my family newsletter - but this week, maybe it's the sun, maybe it's the constellations, or maybe it's the virtuous circle of goodness begetting goodness - but this week has been fantastic.

This week I started exercising again in the morning.  I've done cardio in the morning 3 out of 5 days, I've been eating better, meditating, and getting back into magic.   Post run or walk I've been taking the rent a bikes home, and I've now got a stack in front of my door.  The coolest thing is we now have electric rent a bikes - which are super fun! Hopefully one will still be in front of my house tomorrow morning when it's time to head to work.
Tori's been working on her play, and describing the situation with  some creative license - she's been chased away by island natives as she tries to harvest drift wood,  she's hunted out burly men to help her lift trees, and she's enlisted Amelia to go dumpster diving for coffee grinds, and she's got a hydroponic farm in our basement. 

The kids are fantastic. Zach's been taking me biking, and Amelia and Zach have been working on art. I've realized Zach now knows stuff I don't, which is such a cool thing. I never would imagine I'd be learning how the world works from my 8 year old



The kids often fight, but when they're playing together it's adorable.  Today Zach wanted to hold Amelia's hand - and Amelia was so happy - she didn't even want to hold my hand so she could walk with her big brother.



Have a great week, and remember -To get Igor into a virtuous cycle, he needs to be riding  his bicycle - ZiaT



.

entry.title: Week 409AZ: Biking and pot pori
entry.content:
They say perfect is the enemy of the good. I'm not claiming this post is good, but sometime you just gotta quit the excuses and ship it. 

Zach and I went biking, and got caught in a hail storm - he was not a fan.



I *finally* set up the computer for Zach, and he's really getting into it. Amelia loves it too. 

Today I wiped out on my bike. It doesn't happy often, but when it does, I look bad ass, and being male, even a 40 year male, that makes my day. Speaking of bad ass I have a sign in my office to do epic shit - and that's important too. 


 Amelia is a fascinating young lady. She likes to have stuff. Here's a big pile of her stuff.  She also likes horses, she likes those too.


One of the greatest pleasures of multiple kids, is when they do stuff together. Her's Zach reading a story to Amelia


And here's one where Zach's so happy playing on the computer that he's letting Amelia share a chair with him.

entry.title: Week 400AZ: Happy Holiday 2017
entry.content:
2017 was great year, and we spent the last two weeks of the year enjoying the family.

We finished the year with our first New Years party since we had kids. It was great!!!

The day before I stopped at the Russian store and got 7 salads, 4 smoked cheeses and meats, and dried and pickled fish.   Add to that Tori's fantastic mouse cake and rainbow jello squares and we had a perfect party.

The highlight of the party was blow-torch lit sparklers and a double sleep over for Amelia and Zach. We also had a a person over who has never seen my magic tricks, and she actually screamed when she saw the finale of the magic trick (which made my day).
In Tori news
I'll respect her privacy and skip this section.
In Zach news
A few weeks ago Zach saw 'Mr Poppers Penguins', and fell in love with it. Zach watched the movie, asked for the book for Christmas, and then actually read the book!

Luckily for us, there was a 'Mr Poppers Penguins' drama camp, and Zach was able to get in. To give Tori a break, and get some quality time with Zach, I decided to be charge of getting Zach to camp.

Even though it took an hour on public transit, I decided I'd take Zach to camp using the subway and monorail. This was the SMARTEST THING I DID! Zach and I got two hours of distraction free time together, and we got into some deep conversations.

I got a chance to practice the Socratic method to help me be a better coach and him to be a better independent thinker.  We also got to talk about some deep subjects.

One of my favorite conversations was around good crazy and bad crazy. Good crazy - believing you can do things which others say are uncomfortable or crazy. E.g. Dad jumping in the lake, Elon Musk making a rocket ship to mars. Bad crazy - hurting other people, and mental illness like schizophrenia.

One night as we drove home from one of our adventures Zach started a very interesting conversation:
Z: Mom, how did your dad die?
T: He died of cancer, and he was getting sicker and sicker, and wasn't going to get better. 
Z: I know what he should do.
T: What should he do?
Z: Kill himself.

We then proceeded to talk about do not necessitate, and euthanasia, and various other deep topics. Amazing discussing this with an not yet eight year old.

I started to teach Zach about negotiating. For example, we agreed that if he was willing to go for a bike ride while I ran, he could get 30 minutes of TV. He decided 1 minute of TV for 1 minute of biking wasn't enough, so he negotiated 2 minutes of TV for 1 minute of biking. Great deal!

This was actually the first time we came up with an exercise activity which worked for both of us. I also started teaching Zach about odds e.g. I'll give you 4:1 odds because I'm pretty sure of the outcome.

Zach's getting great at Math, and loves conveyor belt sushi. In conveyor belt sushi, sushi goes around on a convener belt with the different colored plates representing different prices. As you eat, you stack up the plates, and at the end the waitress counts the plates by color, and gives you a total bill.

I gave Zach the chance to win an hour of TV by figuring out the cost of the meal. Zach got the total wrong, so I asked him to check his work, and he did better (actually within 50 cents). But I wanted to teach him the importance of checking his work, so I didn't give him the TV time, even though he was pretty close.

Zach also did lots of reading. I gave him a Kindle paper white, which allows him to read after lights out.  But then Zach lost the kindle paper white and now sits in bed reading with a 2 inch long flashlight (sigh).

Finally, Zach got enamored with our new TV. Being 'clever' he tried to hide the remote so no one else could watch it. Unluckily for him, Tori's great at finding things, and I can control the TV with my phone.

In Amelia news.

I didn't get nearly as much time with Amelia, but we stall had a blast. To help me rectify this I took Amelia on a Saturday morning date to the coffee shop, and I'm planning on making that another 'quality of life' habit.

I got to see Amelia at gymnastics for the first time and it was incredible. She can do the rings, and jump and reach the bar. At dance class she was working on hand stands, but couldn't nail it. 

Amazingly at home, just over the winter holidays she was constantly practicing her handstands (with the same determination I practice magic and juggling before that) and within two weeks she's nailed it. I'm so impressed by her physical abilities.

Amelia loves dresses and dressing up. In our four hour holiday party, Amelia changed clothes 5 times. When we went on our date Amelia was asking for help closing her purse. When I went to help her I realized the problem - she had a dress stuffed in her purse. I tried to remove the dress and Amelia chastised me, telling me that was her emergency dress and that it needed to be there in case she spilled something on her self.

Amelia is also working on some alter egos. She started with Emily the kitty, and just a few days ago she added Luna the unicorn. I wonder if as she starts to fight back against Zach if she won't add a Boris the bear. Time will tell. Speaking of Amelia's alter egos, I've learned to draw kitty's and unicorns so I can share them with her. We both really enjoy spitting out an emergency unicorn.

Amelia is also learning a bunch from Zach's vocablary and Zach's interations. For example she'll now have conversations: 
A: Hey, stop that or I'll punch you in the face. 
...
A: I don't want to pay Wack-a-Mole.
In Igor News
My holiday's had a rough start as I had a soul sucking cold which robbed me of my energy. I need to remind myself that if my energy is drained, I may just be sick and need to set expectations that I need to rest and recover to speed up the healing process

Over the holidays, and reflecting over the year, I had pretty poor physical health. My diet was poor, and my exercise non-existent, and I barely biked.

My emotional and cognative health was great. I continued my meditation habit, reviewed my eulogy and life goals, and started re-reading the 7 habits.

I started using an iPad Pro with a pen and my primary device. I love the long battery life, and pen input. It's a wonderful device, I should have gotten one earlier.

I haven't been drinking in a long time, and went over to Shannon and Andrew's to catch up. I had a few drinks, and while Tori was driving me home I thought - I think I'm drunk The next morning I woke up in Amelia's bed with a huge kink in my neck, and an entire day of not remembering where i left things. More practice required.
In house news
Tori setup our epic Christmas decorations. The decorations were so good cars literally drove around the block to get a second viewing of our decorations. I think every neighbor stopped us to tell us how cool our decorations were.

Tori also took the time to replace all the parts in the toilet as it was leaking. We can add plumber to Tori's any hats.

For my house contribution I got a nice big TV and stereo system. The kids, including the big one named Igor, are very happy with the TV as it helps augment our family cave.

Have a great week and remember, Happy Holidays, share some praise - ZiaT

entry.title: Happy jump in the lake day 2018
entry.content:
Every year I jump in the lake to remind myself that "the resistance" is a lie I tell myself to prevent me from making my greatest contribution.

For the first year ever, Zach agreed to come in the lake woohoo

As luck would have it, I observed a very valuable lesson this year watching a video of Zach and I running into the lake.

When I ran into the lake with Zach, I didn’t help Zach, I just ran into the lake myself.   I need to remember to decide if I’m doing something for the kids, or for myself.  In this case, I should have done the jump with Zach, helping Zach, and then gone in a second time for me without Zach.   In fact, I did go in a second time for me, I just didn’t make the most of the time i went in with Zach.




In less “deep” lessons we saw a family dressed as a group of dinosaurs, I don’t think dinosaurs are my family’s thing but certainly group costumes are.

I’m excited to see what we’ll do and look like next year.

Happy jump in the lake day and remember a few things: 1) The resistance is something that we make up to keep us from doing great things.  2) Decide if you’re doing something for yourself, or for others. If it’s for others,  know it may not be as pleasant, but you can have satisfaction knowing you’re are acting in the service of others.

link.title: Happy jump in the lake day 2018

entry.title: Batkid Begins: Everyone coming together to make a wish.
entry.content:
I cried for the entire 90 minute movie.  A few things really impressed me:

  • At the core a few folks had a dream. 
  • Because it mattered, everyone stepped up to do the thing they could do their best at
  • Even the crowd can be incredibly decent.
http://www.imdb.com/title/tt3884528/

link.title: Batkid Begins: Everyone coming together to make a wish.

entry.title: Week 398AZ: Lightning Trip to Canada
entry.content:
I decided to make a solo trip to Canada to see my family. It was great to see my niece, mom, sister and brother and law and best friends from college.

The highlight of my trip was getting to hang out with my niece and interact with her as an adult (well young adult). She’s in grade 8 and already dreaming of becoming a physicist. She’s doing advanced math placement tests and blaring out the jazz in her all-star jazz band. I was very lucky to be able to catch her band concert.

To be honest, I video call my sister and mom for 30 minutes to an hour every week, so it feels like we know what’s going on in each others lives. But, it’s still nice to catch each other in person and enjoy some pickled hearing, eggplant puree, and some good old fashioned hugs.

When I come to Toronto, I spend a night with my best friend from college -  Baltasar, his wife, Rada, and their 3 kids. As usual we feast on steak, whiskey and desserts.   This trip was no exception - I had such a good time I forgot my coat and charger, luckily you can always ship things. 

While in Canada, Amelia and Zach were able to video call with FaceTime, drop in with Alexa, and use the ring doorbell  so even though the kids were 5,000 miles away, I still felt they were close.  Tori was a trooper holding down the fort while I was out of town.  Among other things she got an x-mas tree picked up, setup and decorated.

Often when I go on vacation, it takes me weeks to forget about my responsibilities at work. Amazingly on this trip I didn’t think about work from the moment I stepped on the plane (Maybe it was the whiskey, steak and weed).

I was going to bring my bicycle, except it wouldn’t fit in my suitcase. See, I borrowed a bike suitcase from a friend with an identical bike, but my bike didn’t fit, because, clearly, our bikes were not identical. His bike is the 2018 model which is 2 inches shorter, so I couldn’t bring my bike. Honestly, I likely wouldn’t have ridden my bike so it wasn’t a loss - but you know - pride and all.

I got a bunch of time to work on my magic. I did card tricks for lots of people and it felt great. I’ve now practiced enough magic that most technical errors I can recover from on the fly, which feels great.

My favorite magic trick was having my niece pick a card,  and pretending the card would appear in a sealed card case.  Instead of containing her card, the card case contained her new iPhone.   The iPhone misdirection was so strong she forgot we were doing a card trick and was speechless.   In the card case was a card saying “always believe in yourself” hopefully she remembers that.

While my magic is getting good, I need to start pushing myself from having fun into “am I getting the most growth from my time investment”. It’s  a brutal question to ask about your hobbies, but honestly, being a better magician feels great.

I got the 7 habits audio book and started listening to it. That was great. I and I really enjoyed it.  Funny thing I was really struggling to buy the audio book for 8$. Pretty goofy given how much I spend and how the 7 habits is the foundation of my personal growth.

I brought my meditation bench, and actually used it.  I haven’t been meditating lately, so it was good to reset the habit.  As usual I’m amazed how hard it is to sit for even 8 minutes, and how much more focused I am when I start meditating.

entry.title: Week 393AZ: Halloween 2017
entry.content:
Halloween is our favorite holiday and this time we out did our selves. For the first time ever we got lots of kids coming to our house, and many of them telling us we had the most awesome house they've seen. Our costumes were awesome too. While biking Amelia to work (to show her off) in my frog costume many cars honked, waved and gave thumbs up.

As usual, Halloween is mostly a result of Tori's hard work, so thank you again!!!

In other news

We're establishing a new habit - weekly swimming. We have a swimming pool that's only 10 minutes away and we're going to use it. It's sort of amazing what happens when you decide to make something work.

For example my 3 excuses to not use the pool were: 1) the water is pretty cold 2) the pool is less exciting then our fun far away pool 3) the hours go past the kids bedtime.

Because we decided to make this pool work we solved our excuses by 1) Getting a neoprene t-shirt 2) realizing the kids find playing with us most important and 3) leaving half way through the swim.

My last new habit has been great - walking Zach to school. At first I came up with reasons I'd need to skip this, but I've decided walking Zach to school is a quality of life improvement and I can make it work 95% of the time. The only downside is the trip to school is only 4 minutes, so I'm thinking augmenting the habit by driving farther away to make our walk to school longer (amazingly, Zach figured out I want to do this is not thrilled by the idea).
In Tori news
I'll respect her privacy and skip this section.
In Zach news
When he's not on Kindie or TV, Zach loves making books, taking over the world, and having play dates. It's a good life. Zach is starting to get homework, including learning to type, mad libs, and square roots. Growing up, growing up, growing up.

Zach's also starting to really help Amelia, he'll get her breakfast, pour her drinks, and re-assure here when Mom isn't around.

Of course the kids mostly fight and can't be beside each other, with one exception. When Zach is out of Kindle minutes, but Amelia still has some, Zach and Amelia snuggle up close agree on a Kindle show to watch and are adorable.

In Amelia news

Like Zach, Amelia now wakes up and makes a b-line for her Kindle. She's still a bit young to figure out how to unlock it and change the volume but she's close.
Amelia has also potty trained! Thank you Tori!
In Igor news
Work is busy and chaotic as my second major product is about to ship. My team is doing a great job, but shipping is only a bumpy ride.

Increasingly I'm adding habits that improve my quality of life. Biking, Magic, walking Zach to school, and taking the kids swimming. This makes me happy, and reminds me of something a wise woman told me: At 20 you try everything you can, at 30 you learn what you don't like, and at 40 you start doing what you enjoy. Surprise, surprise, I'm 40.

While I am biking to work, I haven't been biking hard, and my eating has been "pleasure focused" instead of "mission focused". I'll try again next week. I'm also slacking on my meditation and other EQ practices. It's time to double down on them as next week will be stressful form shipping.

Unlike my physical and emotional health practices, my magic practice has been fantastic! I've been going up to random parents on the subway and asking if I could show their kids tricks - and everyone loves it. I'm also forcing myself to learn new tricks to put in my repertoire. I'm so grateful for getting into magic and finding a magic club - After family, and not driving, magic is my favorite thing.

Even though it interferes with my desire to not use my phone, I got lucky and my co-worker bought an extra iPhone X and sold it to me at cost. The camera on the iPhone X is incredible expect new photos to come up!

In house news

Beyond the new Halloween decorations (which the house loves), we also upgraded to a bigger TV which made Zach and Amelia very happy. Annoyingly the tankless water heater we installed 3 years ago has started leaking. The water heater company which offered a 15 year warranty went out of business, so this will be an expensive fix.

If the kids are doing "office work", and I'm home, I'll let them share my office. The kids love it and so do I. Zach is less thrilled about sharing his desk with his sister, so has created his own cubicle with my many cases of diet caffeine free coke.

Conversations with Amelia

It kind of blows my mind that Amelia who is 3, already says "Text Mommy" - I guess that's just what we do now.

Amelia is very emotionally aware - when she got in trouble: 
I: Amelia, go into time out.
A: I'll do my timeout, but don't be rude, or I'll do my grumpy face.

Amelia and I often go biking together, when we often sing together (which is awesome). These rides are a great way to have a chat as well.
I: What's it like biking with your dad?
A: It's like biking with your family. Except being a ballerina.

The other day Amelia was sitting on the floor kind of funny:
I: Amelia, what are you doing? 
A: I'm meditating.

Conversations with Zach

Before we get into a chat with Zach, there are some very good conversations this week:
Zach wanted to know Amelia's career aspirations
Z: What do you want to be when you grow up? 
A: A mommy. 
Z: No a real job. 
A: Mommy is a real job.
Z: No, I mean the kind of job you can quit.

Zach thinks I'm getting over the hill
Z: Do you consider yourself a senior? 
I: What do you ask? 
Z: Because you should have a jitter bug senior phone.

On commitments
 Z: Do you promise? 
 I: Sure
 Z: A pinky promise? 
 I: Sure
 Z: Are you sure, if you make a pinky promise and you don't do it, you need to cut off your pinky.

I got a sign for my office to remind me of doing things that matter, it says "Do Epic Shit". Zach is internalizing this
I: Zach go get me my juggling balls from upstairs
Z: (Gets balls and comes back)  OK, here's some epic shit.


Have a great week and remember, When you dress up in a costume, your personality will bloom - ZiaT

entry.title: Week 388AZ: Back on the newsletter horse
entry.content:
There's lots going on in our lives, but most of it isn't getting written down, so I'll go back to the newsletter format.

In other news:

In Family event news
We went to a show called Go.Dog.Go it was true to form representation of the book by the same name. Go. dog. go is a book that only uses 75 different words, and the word dog is repeated 60 times. When I got to the play I was groaning in my head, but no matter how hard I tried to dislike the play, I really enjoyed it, and highly recommend going to see it. Given it's a play with only 75 different words I'm very impressed.
In Tori news
I'll respect her privacy and skip this section.
In Zach news
We've discovered he needs glasses.



Last week end, we got Zach a bike at Walmart and this week we went on our virgin journey. As we were about to leave, Zach noticed he couldn't really turn the handlebars, and sure enough, the bike was very incorrectly assembled. Luckily, I was able to be all "Daddly", getting out Tori's wrenches and fixing Zach's bike. With Zach's bike fixed Zach and I went on a bike ride. You might think Zach is building an intrinsic love of bicycling (which I suspect he is), but for now he's still doing it for the extrinsic motivation of TV time.

This may not sound true, and it may not be true, but it's definitely what Zach wants me to write. You know how Dad says the bike broke, well it wasn't assembled incorrectly, it was aliens. The aliens have been messing with people's brains, and they're making them go crazy. When I say crazy, I don't just mean loco crazy, I mean coo-coo crazy. That's all for now, but keep in touch - call my Dad.
In Amelia news
She loves her preschool and has been working on potty training. Saturday night was Amelia's first night not peeing in her bed (with Tori waking her at night and carrying her to the Potti). Speaking of peeing, Amelia loves nature peeps, and like her father would often rather pee outside then inside.

When Amelia and I were at the library, she decided she wanted to work on the computer. While she did this I got a bored, and found an octopus puppet. I hid behind the computer screen where she couldn't see me, and had the puppet peek out from behind the monitor. Amelia chided me - "Dad - be quiet, I'm working".
In Igor news
It's been a fantastic week for my health. I've been biking hard to work every morning, and my eating has been perfect. I've dropped 5 lbs/month for last 2 months and looking forward to doing it again next month (although I am still 23lbs over my 5/16 weight).

As part of this health kick, I decided I should measure my heart rate during exercise. I needed a gadget for this, and wanted modern technology so I bought a bluetooth chest strap heart rate monitor. 

I always enjoy showing off my toys, so I brought it to work and showed it to my much younger co-workers. They laughed at me and said "Old man, that's like a VCR - no a day we use Apple watches to measure our heart rates". I now have an Apple watch, and it's awesome.

In house news

Tori's been working on our patio, and I've been working on home automation. After many, many hours, our house can do some cool tricks. Three of my favorites:
  1. Super bright overhead light turn on at 5am to wake me up.
  2. I can tell my phone to turn on my foot warmer, and it automatically turns it on, and then turns it off 20 minutes.
  3. I can tell my phone make it a color, and my multi color light changes color - it's fun for me, and the kids LOVE IT
To set this up I had to replace electrical sockets, set up a linux VM and run crazy software. I think my conclusion of home automation is it's a time intensive relaxing hobby - the modern version of stamp collecting.

Conversations with Amelia:

At the library with an octopus sock puppet
I: The octopus is shy, but wants to talk to you
A: Tell them it's OK, I'll be nice. 
I: Would you like to go to the park? 
OK, but first we need to go the ball

I didn't understand, so I asked several times what she meant. Finally in frustration she said: A: The ball, the place where people dance.

Conversations with Zach:

I wanted a bit of candy

I: Zach, I bet mom has candy hidden somewhere. 
Z: Oh, I know where it is, i'll tell you , but only if you promise to only eat one piece. 
I: Well, in that case why don't you not tell me and get me one. 
A: Returns with a mini kit kat bar.

I split the chocolate in half and give him half. Zach takes his piece, breaks it in half and gives half to his sister, who eats it. Zach says: 
Z: Did, lets get this treat. 
Z: (Pauses) Oh Amelia likes these too, lets get some for her. 
I:  Zach,I'm super proud of you.

Now that's Zach old enough, we can do conversations with Zach with Zach watching me type. Here's our first installment. 

Z: Why is your name Igor?
I: Because that's what my parents named me. 
Z: 
Z: When did they do that? 
I: 39 years ago, maybe 40. 
Z: Tell me, what is the square root of the square root? 
I: Actually it's called a cube root? Maybe a quad-root, not so sure. 
Z: Do you know the national anthem of antartica? 
I: No, I don't but I do know it'd be really cold there. And it's probably talk about penguins. 
Z: Well, it's the best country in the world.
I: How do you know? 
Z: It has this cool leader who wants to take over the world and has an army of minions.
I: OK, not sure interesting conversation tonight. I'll let you off the hook. Anything else you want to add?
Z: Do you know about how the cow jumped over the moon? He must have been good friends with the spoon. 
I: Did you like Go.Dog.Go? What was your favorite part?
Z: I'm not sure, I think it sounded a lot like fire station 7. 
I: What's that? 
Z: It's a school play we went to. We went to lots of plays and  Firestation 7 was probably the second one when I was in first grade. 
I: OK, I love the live conversation section - we'll shoot for another one next week. You're free to watch TV now - go! 
Z: I'm outta here, setup my movie.

Have a great week and remember, Bike from Walmarts? Double check all the parts! - ZiaT

link.title: Week 388AZ: Back on the newsletter horse

entry.title: Week 387AZ: Blogging w/Zach 2
entry.content:
(Finger nails courtesy of Amelia; Bizarre Blog Format courtesy of the school of get it out first, then make it better)

Small talk with Zach:

Z: You should really get generals.
I: What do you mean?

Z: Like, you know the army. I think you want more people so you should get someone who is really really good, and assign them a really good rank so they can talk to some people, and watch over people. Then you can expand more since you have a general also watching.

I: That's a good idea, but what will I do if I have Generals? 
Z: You will make it so that they watch over your men and maybe if they really do a really good job you will give them extra money.  

I: Do you have generals?
Z: Well, I don't have a gang of people yet, and also I don't have a job like you, but if you mean in charge of what I do,  I do have generals in charge of math and writing and art. Well arts is a commander.  And math is the highest rank you can get.


Z:Have you heard the story?
I: What story?
Z: The one about the guy who buys milk.
I: Nope, tell me.
Z: The man goes to the store and buys milk, he pours the milk, he drinks the milk, the end. Did you like the story
I: Meh. Not the best.

Bicycles: 

Saturday, Zach, Amelia and Dad went for our first multi mile bike ride  to the mall (Tori didn't join us but I'm sure she's just about ready).   Zach did a great job, and had a great time. His bike, may it rest in piece,  fell apart, so we went to Walmart to get Zach a new bike Sunday morning. 

Zach really enjoyed  picking his bike up at Walmart because Zach got chicken nugget pizza for breakfast.  

Managers Making Morning Meals:

For the first time in my career I organized a Managers Making Morning Meal Event.

It was a riot, we served over 80 eggs, 5lbs of bacon, and umpteen waffles.  This was an Igor organized event so, you can imagine we had some minor glitches like blowing electrical sockets, but you can also imagine, I thought of that, and had the appropriate recovery kits.

Health:

Good week for the health. I'm back on the weight pledge, and this is my second month in a room doing 5 lbs drops. Hard in the short term, but totally worth it in the long wrong.   I also started to bike hard in the mornings, and did my first 4 miles on a treadmill in months.

House News:

Giant monitors, home automation, shelves, and patios.  I don't have any patio pictures yet, but they're coming.




Have a great week, and remember - Giant Monitor? Run a few more kilometers - ZiaT

entry.title: Week 386AZ: Blogging with Zach
entry.content:
Today Zach is helping me write a blog post. Today is Tuesday the 19th, tomorrow, Zach's the calendar helper, which means he'll get to chance to change the calendar to 20.  Miss Jonson says there's money in it.

Conversations with Igor

I: Zach tell me about the colors at Montlake?
Z: In Miss Johnson's class you can either get red, which is sent to the principal's office. Yellow, which is normal, or green which is worked extra hard.

I: What was the most fun you had at school today?
Z: I think my favorite part of school today was lunch/recess.

I: What did you enjoy most?
Z: I enjoyed doing absolutely nothing.

I: What was the part other then lunch and recess.
Z: I don't I actually have another favorite thing, unless you count morning recess.

Z: What was your favorite part of work?
I: Tuesday is my one on one day, which means I spend time meeting all my employees talking about how we can work better.  I believe the most important thing I do is help develop my people, so I always enjoy Tuesdays.

Z: That doesn't answer my question - what was your favorite part.
I: Today I got my 43" monitor at work. It made me really happy to show all my co-workers my giant monitor.  That was my favorite part.

Z: Can you put this on the internet?
I: It's already on the internet.

Z: Does that mean anyone can read it?
I: Yeah, but no one does. Like, in theory anyone can walk in our front door, but in practice nobody does.

Z: Is there anyone so that in theory people will, but in practice they will too?
I: Actually, that's often my job to figure out how to get people to do stuff. But it's really hard.

Z: Well, can you advertise it?
I: Zach, when you're older you'll understand how much of my job that actually is.

Zach is now reading over my replies over my shoulder, and I'm not speaking. As he reads this he laughing loudly behind me. 

Z: Here's a solution to make your blog more popular. Can't you just put posters up? You know on the busy streats? Then many people will see it. And they'll want to read your blog, and then you'll get a big boom.
I: Yup, that's a great idea.

Z: So are you going to use it?
I: You're talking about a subject called "growth hacking" we'll talk about it more another day.

Z: Yes or No?
I: No.

Z: Are you ever going to use it.
I: No.

Z: That's a lot of no's you need to be more positive.
I: Yes.

Z: That's the spirit, I want more yeses.
I: Yes.

Z: OK that's enough for now.

Last week in pictures


Zach, Amelia, and our neighbors Malcolm and Isaac go for a subway adventure.


Zach and Amelia aren't usually found this close together, except Zach ran out of Kindie minutes so he looks extra kind to his sister, but in practice he's just trying to get close to Kindie.

 
Zach and Amelia getting their first pumpkins of the season.  Zach wanted the big one, Amelia the little one.



Getting ready for Halloween.
Enjoying grapes from the vine.

entry.title: Date Night and the home of my dreams.
entry.content:
Saturday Night, Tori booked a sitter and we went off to see a play. The play was great, the date was great, and as we drove home late it was great to realize that the kids would be in bed, and we could just chill together.
As we were walking up the steps of our new porch,  I looked in our front door and thought

"Wow, if I didn't live here, I'd kill for this to be my home"

Thank you Tori for making our house the home of my dreams!

link.title: Date Night and the home of my dreams.

entry.title: Week AZ: Eclipse
entry.content: For holiday we went down to the eclipse

entry.title: Week 381AZ: I want to play - don't goof off.
entry.content:
Hot of the press -  As I'm goofing around after writing this post Amelia tells me: 

A: I want to play - don't goof off.
I: Sheesh, alright kid.




This week, Amelia and Zach went camping for a few days while I stayed in the city. I was surprised how lonely it was to be at home without the family, even for a few days.  Luckily with the power of video calling, I could just ring the camp site and see the family.

In case I don't write up something better, let me share some pictures from the last few weeks.
