entry.title: Week 377 AZ: Long week, BUT the porch is done
entry.content:
Before
After
This was a crazy long week at work as I finished a big task and got ready for my vacation. Luckily I can write about the porch being done!!!! For those that don't know, the deal Tori and I made was by marrying me, she'd get a porch.  As Tori says a promise made is a debt unpaid, and this debt is paid!
During

The porch includes purple and pink highlights, a new door,  a rainbow colored downspout made of cut up wine bottles,  and under porch storage with a concrete floor, and a touch pad door that can be unlocked and locked from the internet.

Huge thank you to Tori for driving the project from design, to bidding, to project management to finishing touches - hooray.  As a reminder here are some of the before, during, and afters:



Have a great week and remember: "Wife won, porch done"  - ZiaT

link.title: Week 377 AZ: Long week, BUT the porch is done

entry.title: Week 376AZ: Happy 4th of July
entry.content:
It's been a while since I wrote so there's lots of stuff blended into this post - I'll do better next time. 

This week was the fourth of July and marked like 20 strait days of 
sunshine in Seattle.  I'll post lots of pictures. which is easy because these last few week I "invested" (ha) in a selfie stick, a ring light, and a 360 degree camera.

Thanks to the selfie stick, I can be in the picture, which makes me happy.  Tori and Zach are less excited, but Tori is playing along. Zach on the other hand has started hiding whenever I get out my selfie stick, that's something we'll have to beat out of him.

In porch news, it's almost done, we're getting the painting touched up, then we can unwrap the house. The porch looks awesome, but it took much longer then expected, which when it comes to remodels should be what is expected.



In house news, Tori has been a busy bee, knocking task after task off the to do list. This week Tori bought a concrete saw, finished our retaining wall (really the first step to a patio), and Tori has now finished painting the living room.  Amazingly I even cleaned up my office, which Tori says is less amazing since I squirreled away many of the boxes into the attic.

In physical health news, I was eating pretty badly for a while, but wasn't really getting fatter.  Turns out, I was getting fatter, it just took a while for that to show up on the scale. Now it's not only on the scale, but also around my middle.  Sigh.  On the bright side, I know the drill. Time to dust off the running shoes, and the popcorn maker.   In fact, today I went for my first run in a while, and I had lots of veggies, popcorn and decaf coffee..

As part of cleaning out my office, I found a bunch of harmonica stuff, excluding a harmonica I could play of course. So I ordered a harmonica on Amazon, and turns out it's  as fun as I remembered it. I can still kinda play the 3 songs I knew (you are my sunshine, happy birth day to you, Mary had a little lamb).

Ryan and Rupali were out of town for a while, and lent us Kirby, their dog. Kirby, was a dream, easy to walk, never barked,  great personality, and we all loved him.  Zach was even comfortable walking him, and it got the whole family out of the house (who doesn't want that?).  I'm not sure when we'll get a dog, but when we do, I hope it's a dog like Kirby.

On the fourth of July we went canoeing which was super fun. Instead of the usual complexity of hauling our canoe onto our truck, and then dragging it to the water, we just 4 minutes to the UofW boat rental place and rented a canoe for 12$.  Using the "rent a boat" method of canoeing, we were on the water in minutes with no muss or fuss.  Definitely the better way to do it.

 
Have a great week and remember - When you eat lots of food, and don't exercise, your belly will grow in size - ZiaT.

entry.title: Week 373AZ: Non stop activity weekend
entry.content:
This was a great weekend - lots of activities I'll just enumerate for future recollections.

Friday night, the Montlake community center had  it's annual carnival - and the kids got to enjoy dinner, bounce in the bouncy houses, and trade their tickets for prizes.  Tori and I got to chat with some parents, which is always nice.

Saturday, we split up - Zach went to his first "drop off" birthday party, Tori started building her retaining wall, and I took Amelia to the Fremont Parade on my bike.   Amelia really enjoyed watching the show from the bike, and after the parade we headed to Gasworks park to watch the hoolahoopers and do some juggling.  Amelia was trying to throw me juggling clubs, and she made some progress - it won't be long before she can toss me the first juggling club, we'll be a busking duo soon enough.

Sunday was father's day, and Zach gave me a really nice present he made at the school.  It talked about things "Dad enjoyed doing" and things "Zach enjoyed doing with Zach". The thing that came up several times was biking. We both enjoy biking, but it's time to diversify my Zach activities ;)

Sunday we also did a BBQ marathon, starting off with a BBQ at Uncle Ryan's and then heading over to Miga's where we got to have an amazing meal, and a final goodbye to Miga, Kai, and Ciel before they take off for the big summer trip to Mongolia.

Instead of watching TV we also did some marathon book reading - we devoured a nice chapter book called "Gregor the Overlander".   We both really enjoyed it (and I think I may have seen a movie about it as a kid).
--

Usually, Zach messes with Amelia, but this week it was great to observe Amelia "messing" with Zach.  Zach freaked out at Amelia because Amelia had messed up his train set. Zach discovery this while Amelia was in my lap, and as Zach was yelling, Amelia very quietly, and very unsure of herself, was sticking out her tongue raspberrying (that's when you stick out your tongue and blow for teasing).  Great job girl.

Conversations with Amelia:

A: You can't brush your hair you don't have any hair
 






Have a great week - and remember -  Even though you really, really, enjoy your bike, don't forget there are other things you like -ZiaT

entry.title: Week 371AZ: Progress on all fronts
entry.content:
Some weeks are glorious and exciting, and others are the steady progress. This week was lots of progress.

Our porch is coming along swimmingly. You can see the whole structure, and the door is incredibly cool.   Along side it, we're cleaning up our yard, and Tori has fixed the damage to our retaining wall caused by some of the construction work.

On the health front, the 7 commandments from the nutritionist are having a really positive impact.  The rules are on the wall, and are causing our family to make meal time a special time we all slow down for. It's very enjoyable, and it has the side effect of making us eat better. Sure we have lots of work to go here, but now that we have a good model for success, it's easier to know what to aspire to.

On the biking front, Zach is now comfortable using his bike with gears and hand brakes.  Stopping is still jarring for him, but he's even requested bike rides on his own, which is a great sign.

Amelia, the adventurer, also loves biking, and loves the bike/subway mix. Last night we took the bike down to the subway (where she used the hand holds as rings to do tricks) so that we could get some frozen yogurt in capital hill. Did I mention how much I 1) love living in the city 2) we're get better at our diet plan, but still have a ways to go :)

Yesterday on the family fun plan, Tori took us to an indoor petting zoo. It was incredibly cool, but a touch crowded from all the kids (both the human and goat variety).  It's hard to describe how soft the bunnies, and alpacas where, and how cool the kangeroo sleeping in a pouch was - but it was a really nice place to visit.

Today, we're off to see a play, I'll add the extra adventures as they happen.

entry.title: Week 370AZ: Memorial day at Camp Orkilla
entry.content:
This weekend was memorial day, and we had perfect weather which we spent at camp Orkila

Camp Orkila is a camp where the whole family can hang out and do all the camp activities. We got to try rowing, and archer and bb gun shooting and archery and gaga ball, and life in the forest.

Camp Orkila is designed as  a kids camp, so the food is meh, the cabins have no water, electricity, doors or windows.  For us, the food was still meh, but we stayed in the resort center with our good friends so we had showers, electricity, heat and lots of friendship.

At camp, Zach was really into Gaga ball, which is a variant of dodge ball you play in a pit. He also really enjoyed life in the forrest, a kind of a  team based "tag" in the forrest with carnivores, herbivores, and dinosaurs.

Amelia loves the potter and arts and crafts. She was especially proud of a beaded bracelet she made, and she's still wearing it a week later.

To my excitement Zach wanted to go for a polar bear plunge, and we both raced into the freezing water. It was jarring, and I hope it means Zach will be proud to join me in upcoming Jump in the lake days.

If you live in the Seattle area I highly recommend you check out Camp Orkila.

link.title: Week 370AZ: Memorial day at Camp Orkilla

entry.title: Week 369AZ: Summer has arrived!
entry.content:
Sigh, a pretty ugly post, but wanted to make sure I wrote something and got the pictures out! Who knows, maybe one day I'll even get Zach, Amelia and Tori to help write this so it's more coherent.

It's been a long winter but summer has finally arrived in Seattle. It's warm enough that my 5:30 am ride to work is light, warm and enjoyable.  And this weekend, has been our first all sun weekend in the high 70s (20 C)!

This weekend  started at the nutritionist.   See our family wants health and nutrition to be a core part of our lifestyle, and the nutritionist helped us make a 7 step plan (none of which includes food choices) that should make us healthier, happier, and a stronger family. I suspect this will be a long journey, with lots of ups and downs, but glad to be starting.

Saturday, Tori took Zach to a play, so I had some Amelia to myself. Because of the fantastic weather,  Amelia and I took off for some wheeled adventures.

First, we got Amelia roller blades and I pulled her around on those. After a while she was tired of roller blades so went for a bike ride. We started biking around the neighborhood, stopping at the little neighborhood park. Amelia soon got bored of the little park, and wanted to take the subway to Cal Anderson - so off to the subway, and then off the subway to Cal Anderson we went.  After a few minutes at Cal Anderson, Amelia was bored and demanded we go to the next park (Volunteer park).  On our way, Amelia saw lots of people and waved at most of them. When I asked Amelia why she was waving at folks, she said it was her job - which I thought was great!! Nothing cuter then seeing a kid on her dad's goofy bike smiling and waving at you -- totally awesome.


Finally after all that parking (ha!) we biked home, at which time I blow torched our souse vide steak. If you haven't a clue what I'm talking about, be sure to ask, as this is a life changing method to cook meat.

In porch news,  progress continues. The decking is in, as are the stairs. Rumor has it we're less then 2 weeks away from done, which will be awesome as I miss using the front door, and I can't wait to see what it'll look like.

Have a great week, and remember - Seat Drop, Bumper Crop- ZiaT

entry.title: Week 367AZ: Big brothers at Trader Joe's
entry.content:
For as long as Zach's been able to come to the grocery store we've had a pretty consistent ritual of one or both of the kids joining me grocery shopping at Trader Joe's.

On this trip, Zach really stepped up his game as a big brother.  First he did up Amelia's seat belt. The he watched Amelia when I went to the bathroom, and of course he pushed Amelia around in the cart and finally when we got the stickers at the checkout he shared them with Amelia. 
Amelia loves Trader Joe's too, some of her favorite things about the store are getting her sucker, and dancing to the violin player who plays at the store entrance. 

In Zach news, I figured out how to adjust Zach's hand brakes, and Zach has completed is first hand brake based bicycle stopping. We've still got a ways to go, but it's a start. 

In Amelia news, she's getting the hang of playing hide and seek and counting.  I'm not sure why I find kids counting so cute, but I do

A: Lets play hide and seek - you hide. 
I: OK, I'll hide
A: 1,2,3,4, 13,11,9

In Igor news, there's a cool bench I can stop at on my bike ride home.

Any who, have a great week and remember - When there's stink in the air, nose plugs prepare - ZiaT

link.title: Week 367AZ: Big brothers at Trader Joe's

entry.title: Week 366AZ: Glamping with our Friends
entry.content:
Now that I work downtown, when we go on an after work adventure involving a ferry, I can meet the family strait on the Ferry. The way this works is I bike to ferry dock and walk onto the ferry. This lets me get a table and find a spot while Tori's parking.  Then Zach, Amelia and Tori come up from the parking level and find me.  When Zach and Amelia find me, the excitement and pleasure in their eyes is so genuine, raw and sincere - it reminds me how awesome it is to be a parent.

This weekend we took the ferry to spend the weekend glamping with our good friends at Fort Worden.   The best part was watching all the kids play.  The older kids are all 7 now, and were constantly trying to get a parent (usually me) to take them down to the beach where they could work together to launch ships to war (e.g. throw drift wood back into the water).

The seven years old, were not just content with war, but also explored love.  Zach,  I'm told, was playing "true love".  I'm not certain, but I suspect this is a game related to kissing. While Zach was acting a bit chivalrous all weekend, no lipstick was found, so it's hard to know what actually happens.







Speaking of Zach, he loves being "grown up".  He'll pace about with his hands clasped behind his back, and a pocket watch clipped to the front of his pants.  Periodically, he'll stop pacing and check his pocket watch (which for the record doesn't keep time).  He'll then drop the pocket watch and keep walking.    This weekend Zach answered another parent's question "would you like beef for dinner" with  "I'm not sure yet, I'll bring you my final decision within the hour".


Speaking of Amelia, she's adorable. She, unlike Zach and Tori, loves posing for pictures, loves giving wonderful snuggles, and loves getting all dolled up.  She's also fearless.  At the pool, she almost lowered herself into the pool by herself, even though she can't swim and certainly can't touch the bottom.  She does have some minimal sensibility. If she isn't sure I've seen her leave, she won't leave, but as soon as she see's I've seen her, she'll take off and do what she wants.

A few Amelia conversations:

I was scribbling some note on a napkin:
A: Dad - you can't write a napkin it's not a book. 

I was lying down
A: Dad - can I walk on your back? 

I was tired
A: Dad - can we play doctor? She then proceeds to stick her popsicle stick into my mouth

Playing horses
I: Does the horse talk?
A: Yes
I: How do we make it talk?
A: We pretend


Healing
I: I'm sore
A: I can fix it
I: How?
A: I can give it a kiss


    In house news, the remodel is going off without a hitch. I guess sometimes you pay a lot more, and you get a less headaches.

    Have a great week, and remember - Dump out some good memories, you'll want them in future centuries  - ZiaT

entry.title: Week 365AZ: Porch and Birthday Time
entry.content:
It's that time of year again, Zach turning 7, and Amelia turning 3.  This year, Zach refused to give us birthday details, so we decided to have a nice quiet birthday part at home. That turned out lucky because if we did our annual birthday in the park it was poring rain (which we've now avoided 5 years running).

Zach was super excited at school, because it was his birthday he got to bring in cookies, and kids gave him a nick name which he's super proud of. Zacookie.  I dunno why he's so proud of that, but I'm glad for it.

After years and years and years, well technically 6 years, we've finally begun our porch rebuild,  and we're super excited about it. It'll have under porch storage, as well as lots of cool details - we're super excited. Tori has been running the entire porch project, and I"m incredibly grateful (as would be the kids if they knew how much work it was). Thank you Tori for making that porch happen!

For me, it's been a busy week, I took a good chunk of last week off, so I had lots of work. And I'm doing new stuff at work I've never done before, so this week I've been going non stop.   Also, there's lots of porch work, and a lot of birthday celebrations.   I didn't realize how tired I was, but  Saturday night I crashed falling a sleep at 6:30pm, and not waking up till 5am (wow!).

Even though I've been pushing hard, I'm damn proud of myself as I've been doing lots of magic tricks for others, riding my bike home from work, meditating, and getting my diet under control.  Congrats to me!

One last thing about me - turns out my shortest ride home is 30 minutes, which is pretty darn short, so instead of going the fast way, I can go the medium way 40 minutes, or the really long way 80 minutes. It's nice to have choices!

In card news games, we've discovered a new game - rat-a-tat cat, which Zach is excited to try, and so am I.




Have a great week and remember - If you don't have front steps destroyed, your mail man will be annoyed - ZiaT

entry.title: Week 364AZ: Baba in Seattle 2017
entry.content:
Baba came to visit this week and we had an awesome time. The kids loved seeing Baba and so did we.



Thanks to Tori we had a week packed with Adventures. We went to the Kids Museum, the SciFi Museum, an eater egg hunt, the kitsap steamers ,the kids museum on bainbridge, the Tulip Festival and of course, Pike Place Market. Timing was great because Zach was on spring break so we were able to do all the adventures as a family. Baba stayed in a hip part of town so she was able to experience a new Seattle neighborhood, which is always awesome.

Another really cool thing that happened is Zach and I discovered a card game we both enjoyed - exploding kittens. It's nice to finally have a "physical" game we can play as a family. Exploding kittens is the first card game I've played since I've become a magician though, and it's hard to remember not to do some improper things with the cards as we play.











Have a great week and remember- If you're drinking lots of coffee, you'll probably have to pee -ZiaT

entry.title: Week 361AZ: Spring is in the air
entry.content:
It's been a long winter, but finally the days are getting longer, and the trees are starting to bloom. I see the daffodils coming up, and Amelia and Zach are finishing the winter session of circus school:


This was a great week for Igor. Two weeks back Igor's work was a little rocky, but Igor's team really came together this week and got everything working -- Woohoo!

Speaking of work, one of Igor's coworkers, Jon,  decided Igor needed a treadmill desk, and Jon brought it in for Igor turns out Jon is right - a treadmill desk is wonderful.  

Speaking of Igor, Igor  met an old coworker, Jay,  at a coffee shop.  Jay challenged Igor to do a magic trick for someone new every day.  Igor's been doing it - and it feels great.  Igor's even starting to learn new techniques to make his magic invoke more wonder.

Have a great week and remember - hire great folks for the job, and your life will be like eating a kabob!

link.title: Week 361AZ: Spring is in the air

entry.title: Week 360AZ: This week in pictures
entry.content:
Amelia putting on her balloon jewelry
Zach and Amelia having post Teriyaki Dinner
Dinner w/ Miga and Brian
Taking Zach and Amelia to the magic show
Tori playing monopoly with the kids
Zach being Amelia's trusty steed.

entry.title: Zach Week 359AZ: Biking w/Amelia
entry.content:
This week, I got a new bike seat for Amelia. The seat is awesome since it's designed for my folding bike, and is super easy to setup. Amelia loves biking with me, and Zach enjoys taking his bike as so we now have a super fun Igor and the kids activity.

I used to say Amelia skipped the terrible two's - well turns out Amelia is simply a late bloomer.  We've got full on terrible twos. Just today Tori freaked out because her plate didn't match her dress.   Amelia is also an incredible princess, she is constantly getting me to put on her high heels and getting me to paint her nails.  I now understand why Dads call their little girls princess.

As I write this Zach and his buddy Kai (cool hair color kid in the photo) are upstairs playing Lego.   Before Kai got here I was like Zach, give me a hug - and he said "gotta be quick dad, I gotta get my homework done before Kai gets here" -- wow.

Amelia is also getting lots of words - she loves sharing and she's very encouraging. She'll frequently tell me "Good Job", for example, just yesterday as I loaded her into our her car seat she said "Great Job dad, you didn't bonk my head".

I'm very excited for the longer days caused by daylight savings - should be a great reason to bike home from work!



Have a great week and remember - As long as you're rhyming, you'll be styling - ZiaT

entry.title: Zach Week 358AZ: It's been a good week.
entry.content:
It's been a fun week. Lots of good stuff for me to spit out:

Zach, Amelia and I have been going on subway adventures!! Which both the kids love. We got Zach his own subway card (see it around his neck) and he's very proud to use it!

My friend Greg got a membership at my gym, and as a result, I've been back to running at the gym - woohooo!

Zach is becoming more and more helpful. He's now carrying in some groceries, and helping unbuckle his sister from her car seat.

We've started Sunday evening family adventures, usually a trip to the pool, but this week it might be a trip to family dance.

I found a magic club with real life professional magicians! They also do a magic show, which I'm looking forward to attending

Work has been dandy!  For what I want in my career - Amazon has been an upgrade in every way. The things I miss about Microsoft are my many friends on the east side (which I will start visiting), and the fact that after 15 years at Microsoft, there were very few things about my companies cultures I didn't know.   Luckily, making new friends and super charging my learning are two of the reasons I wanted to join Amazon.




Have a great week and remember "To live long and prosper, maintain good posture" -ZiaT

link.title: Zach Week 358AZ: It's been a good week.

entry.title: A smile at the grocery store
entry.content:
Most weekend mornings, I take the kids to the grocery store. For a reason that isn't important I went to the grocery store myself. The clerk at the counter said to me:

"I wasn't sure that was you, I figured it wasn't because there weren't cute kids, and there wasn't a goofy hat, but then I saw all the radishes and was like - yup - that is you"

That put a huge smile on my face.

link.title: A smile at the grocery store

entry.title: Week 352AZ: Choosing
entry.content:
Ugh, I was sick all week, which meant other then work, I was mostly sleeping. 
Even though I wasn't awake at home much, I really chose to experience the kids and have fun with them. It feels awesome!

In other news

In family news, I was probably sleeping while Tori did stuff with the kids.  

In house news, Tori is building a model of the porch so we can get a good mouth feel for what it looks like.  Also, our toilet fish died, so it's time to get another one and try again.

In Zach news, he's been building more potions, and he's been reading more. I was blown when he was sitting quietly looking at a book on my iPad.  It sounds obvious when I say it now, but incredibly he was reading silently in his head - gosh he's growing up.   Zach is also continuing his potions exploration, this week there's been a love potion brewing on our bathroom sink.  

In Amelia news, she's been absolutely adorable carrying around her little ponies. She keeps them in a bag or a box, and takes them everywhere she goes.  She also has a little unicorn night light, and she loves getting under the covers with me and turning on the night light - the only word I can use is adorable.  This Saturday I found out Amelia can count to 5, and we went tricycling to the hop-in market, where she rushed to get her shopping cart so she could carry the milk back. 

In Igor news, I've been really reflecting on a few concepts. 1) I don't have to do anything - I choose to do things. 2) If I'm not careful, I'll miss my once in a lifetime opportunity to enjoy my children.   I also realized one of the reasons I don't spend more time with my family, is that it's a muscle, and it's a muscle that's for me is under developed.

Have a great week, and remember - You get kids once, don't be a dunce. - ZiaT

entry.title: Week 351AZ: A Perfect Weekend
entry.content:
This is a post from January. I'll move it to the right order in a few weeks, but leaving here for now so my audience sees it!

Some weekends are so good, even though you're covered in your two year old's vomit, you'd still call it a perfect weekend. This was one of those weekends.

This weekend was awesome because:

  • The place we went (Meany Lodge) was totally down to earth, we had chores and we had to be patient.
  • We spent the weekend playing in the snow.
  • Our friends were there, so the grown ups, Zach and Amelia had folks to play with.
  • Tori took care of all the details, so we could just show up and have an amazing time.
  • Zach and I played in the snow, making snow chairs, and snow shoeing and just being all about merry.
  • I got to ride on a snow mobile (we got an emergency evacuation as no one wanted baby puke in the hostel).
  • When Amelia was sick, she just curled up in my arms and napped (she'll normally never sleep with me).
  • A 12 year old girl playing with the two year olds, and volunteering to be a baby sitter.
  • Discovering I really enjoy brewing coffee - I spent the entire trip buzzing around the coffee machine making sure we always had 4 pots of coffee ready for folks.
  • Zach and I got to go swimming (after we got back from the lodge), and Zach can swim now. It gave me a chance to be a kid in the pool with my son. AWESOME!

Stories

Our transportation to the lodge broke down, and while everyone was huddled in their cars trying to stay warm, I came out to help the guy fixing it (GFI).

GFI: Are you mechanically inclined?
I: Nope, I'm just here for emotional support
(although I did help)
GFI: Are you canadian?
I: Yup.

Zach is starting to build his 'manage up' muscle, this weekend while watching Kindle Zach had a few good lines:
Z: Dad - you look tired, why don't you take a nap. (He wanted to watch his Kindle in peace)
Z: Dad - can you sit in that other chair (He wanted to be near the chair with the charger)

Tori didn't experience snow till she was 20, so she gets extra prepared for any snow adventures.




T: I got chains, an emergency winter kit, and even cat litter.
I: What's the cat litter for?
T: Not sure, the internet just told us to have some.



Amelia is incredibly adorable, she was here with her friend Ciel, and the two of them ran around meowing like kitty cats. Amelia loves to give gifts, so she gave 30 some strangers at the lodge pictures.

entry.title: Week 350AZ: Christmas Break and Mr. Plumbean
entry.content:
It's been a great year, so many things to be grateful for, so much to be proud of. A highlight for me was New years eve.

This year, our new year's posse had the courage to leave our combined pack of 10 kids with 2 baby sitters while we went off to eat tapas and have some grown up time with our friends. Now, we still came home at 8:30, and fell asleep at 9:30, but still that's a huge upgrade.

Hanging out with grownups was fun, but even funner was when we got home at 8:30. Zach read Mr. Plumbean to me.

The best part of this was Zach understanding the message of Mr. Plumbean - do what it most important to you, even if there's lots of peer pressure. I'm so glad that Tori and I have instilled this into Zach, it's such an important lesson.

In other news

In family events news, we did all the standard events, skating, science center, downtown carousel. This year we upgraded a few activities by doing zoo lights instead of just going to the zoo - and going to the science center with a set of friends.

In house news, Tori got me a microwave for Christmas. This is something I've wanted for the last 6 years, and I can already feel an increase in my quality of life. Improving quality of life was a theme this month, so we also bought a remote car starter, souse vide, and standing desk. Quality of life takes a lot more then just buying stuff, it's also the discipline of focusing on things that are important to you, so I sent away stuff stuff which wasn't bringing us pleasure - several garbage bags from the basement, and threw away almost everything from my closet.

In Tori news, I'll respect her privacy and leave this section blank.

In Zach news, he's becoming a Lego master builder. It's so cool watching him do Lego. He starts by sorting out his pieces by color, and then he starts building according to instructions. I'm thrilled he's got that ability focus and follow directions - it's not a strength of mine. He's also become rather enamored with building out a new enterprise called "potion lotion". It's a company staffed by his friends at school, with potion recipes including high demand products like "love potions". Zach's also getting his swimming flippers. He was able to skip one of his swimming lesson levels and he's now comfortable going into deep water. Zach's got a funny perspective as well. The other day, Zach asked me - "How long I can stop using a car booster seat", I answered "Not till you're twelve". Zach looked at me exasperated - "Another lifetime".

In Amelia news, she's getting a touch of terrible twos. She'll be mad at me, or mad at Mom and storm off for no good reason. Compared to Zach and other children though, she's fit free. Amelia is also becoming fond of gifts. She's gotten unicorns and horses, and she loves carrying them around. She's gotten a mermaid tail blanked, and she loves wearing that too. Amelia is now getting into the 'the words I say is much larger then the words you'd expect phase' meaning I have no idea what she's saying. Luckily, Zach can translate. Amelia came upstairs the other day saying I want to watch "mergm" on Kindie, after repeating it 4 times and being ready to through a fit, I came downstairs and asked Zach to translate - he said - "Mermaids, she wants to watch Mermaids" - ah!

In Igor news, I took care of lots of things that have been dragging on me. I bought lots of things I knew I was gonna buy eventually, but that I kept hyming and hahing and researching. I threw away lots of things I was knew I was gonna throw away eventually, but kept thinking I might need. I'm also totally digging my new gig at Amazon. The people I work with are better then I can imagine, the domain is better then I imagined, and working downtown is better then I can imagine, and being downtown is awesome.

Have a great week and remember, Happy 2017- ZiaT

link.title: Week 350AZ: Christmas Break and Mr. Plumbean

entry.title: Happy jump in the lake day 2017
entry.content:
Every year I jump in the lake to remind myself that "the resistance" is  mostly a lie I tell myself.   I also force my family to come and "I pretend" the family is enjoying themselves as much as I do.

This year, due to my lack of planning, I got to the lake late and had to have Tori drop me off so I could race off to the lake, strip and jump in while she found a parking spot.

Being rushed took some of the pleasure out of the event, as I enjoy seeing all the folks in their costumes and basking in the positive energy of the polar bear plunge.

But, not having to drag my family to the lake, made my family a lot happier, and that made me a lot  happier.

After the plunge,  Amelia and I built sand castles and took some pictures, and after that our family went out for a BBQ lunch.

As I look over the pictures from this year's jump in the lake day, they are very different - instead of being about me and the awesome energy of the jump - they are about the family.

Hopefully this is a sign of some deep "maturation" coming in 2017 :)

link.title: Happy jump in the lake day 2017

entry.title: Week 346AZ: Name butchering
entry.content:
"Zachary Dwanzik?, Is there a Zachary Dwazanik"

It took me a few minutes to realize this was an especially poor mispronouncation of Dvorkin, and that Zach had won the grand door prize at a kids rendition of the nutcracker. I don't think Zach realized his name was being called, but we urged him to the stage to pick up his 3 foot tall "king nutcracker".




This weekend was filled with family traditions, including the nutcracker, our annual gift giving, and the pathway of lights.

For gift giving we did chocolates, this year over 40 boxes. The whole family really gets into the spirit with this, and we're all grateful that Tori does so much of the hard work to make it happen.

The pathway of lights is a 3 mile walk around Greenlake in the dark. The path around Greenlake is lined with candles, and often the walkers will be lit up in LEDs, and sing carols. This year was especially fun as we got to go with our friends we haven't seen in several years. It was great to catch up with them, although it was really cold that night, and the kids were freezing, and pretty happy when the pathway of lights were done.

I really appreciated my working downtown this week, this week we had snow in Seattle, which made it extra fun to bike into work. Although to be honest, I'm looking forward to biking in when the weather is better.

This week I also got a cool new device called a tile. It's a little thing you stick on your keychain which lets you "ring" your keys from your phone, or let you "ring" your phone from your keys. As I often have one of my keys or phone, but not both, this is perfect!!

Anywhoo, have a great week, and remember - working downtown, feels like having a crown - ZiaT

entry.title: Skipping and walking bare foot makes me happy.
entry.content:
It's so easy to forget the many things that make me happy, so I write them down to make sure I do them later.  Sometimes I write them down in obscure places,  and forget them for years on end.  Today I found one such place and am moving it to the blog.

So future Igor: Skipping and walking bare foot make you happy go do them.

link.title: Skipping and walking bare foot makes me happy.

entry.title: Week 345AZ: Amazonian!
entry.content:
This week is Christmas tree week, and as usual we walk our wagon over to the school. As we observe all the parents tying their trees to the top of their minivans, we giggle as we know we'll just stick our in our wagon and pull it home.

Zach's been working on his knock knock jokes, and I was surprised to hear Amelia had picked one up. It's a mixed bag of course, much like the rest of parenthood.

    A: Knock Knock
    T: Who's there?
    A: Poopoo head
    T: (Frowing) Poopoo head who?
    A: Poopoo head Zach.

At least it was funny!


As a mini family adventure, Amelia came downtown with me to bring Joey (my orangutan) to my Amazon office.   After we dropped off Joey, we went for a ride on the Christmas Carousel - working downtown is Awesome!


In other news

In house news, nothing new.

In Tori news I'll respect her privacy and skip this section.

In Zach news, he's started making "books", by taking a bunch of blank pages and stapling together. He'll then find a grown up (like me or the baby sitter) to write in his books. Some of them have been quite good, I'll need to make a copy.

In Amelia news, she's becoming self sufficient. Tori slept in while I was writing this blog post and Amelia wanted breakfast. Here's our conversation.

    A: I want something to drink
    I: What would you like?
    A: Uhm, Apple juice, I'll go get it.
    A: (Placing it on the table), here I go.
    A: (Comes back with raisins): I should eat these since I found them.
    A: I want Kindie
    A: (Comes back and turns it on)
    A: Yeah, I turned it on.

In Igor news, I started my new job Monday, and I LOVE IT. I wanted a business and customer focus, and Amazon embodies those. At the same time, the 'overblown scary rumors' about frugality and burn out seem completely over stated.  My office is right downtown so I can either take the subway or take a 30 minute protected bike path bike commute.  Your commute to work has such an impact on your quality of life, and my commute could not be better.

Small things can have a big impact - for example, at Microsoft to get a coffee you put your cup under the machine, press the button and wait two minutes for it to fill. To save two minutes, I'd put my coffee cup under the machine, press the button, go to the bathroom then come back and get my coffee.  At Amazon, the coffee is ready right away, so now I put my coffee cup under the machine, fill it, and then bring my coffee to the bathroom, and get strange looks from my coworkers.

Oh yeah, and after letting myself off the hook on my weight loss pledge (and gaining like 10 lbs) I'm restarting the pledge - time to embrace the hunger.

Have a great week, ZiaT.

entry.title: Week 344AZ: American Thanksgiving
entry.content:
I realize the last few post have been worse then usual.  That's on purpose to get me writing again, once it's a habit again, I'll start focusing on making the posts better.

Every thanksgiving we make a 500 mile pilgrimage from Seattle to Ashland. In "what are the odds of that news" as we pulled into Tori's Aunt's driveway in Ashland Sparky hit the 100,000 mile mark on the nose. CRAZY.

As well as being our thanksgiving retreat, Ashland is the retirement destination for Tori's family. Beyond her sister and two aunts living here, Tori's Mom flew in so we got to see most of Tori's family.

Every year the kids look forward to the random job at the ranch. This year Brian took Zach out to do some Bobcat work, and Amelia wanted to join in aswell, which of course Brian accommodated - we're incredibly lucky to have Maureen and Brian - thanks y'all!!

As we age, we learn our path in life, in this case, we've figured out that on the way to Ashland we overnight in a hotel so we're wide awake when we go through the mountain pass. On our way home, we tackle the windy mountain road when we're awake so we drive strait through. Now kids can't make 7 strait hours in the car so Tori made a list of all the McDonalds with play spaces on I-5 so we can stop when necessary and get the kids YaYas out.








In house news, we've green lighted our porch rebuild - now we're waiting to get on the contractor's schedule. We also got a roomba, which we should have gotten earlier as it does a fair bit of cleaning, with zero effort.

In Tori news, I'll respect her privacy and skip this section.


In Zach news, 6 months ago, he  had a pretty bad bike crash into the wall. Since then he hasn't wanted to get back on his bike.  I'm persistent and I've been hauling Zach's bike everywhere we've gone for the last 6 months. This week, Zach decided to get back on his bike, and he loved it.  He was still *very* cautious on down hills, and it's hard to blame him. He'll rebuild his confidence and we'll be biking full speed again - can't wait. In slightly sad news, in hopes of getting Zach to bike a bit faster, I challenged him to race - and he had a mini freak out - saying "I don't want to race - I hate it when people want to race - I tell them I don't want to race, and they still say I'm a loser". Yikes, kids are mean.  It's an interesting balance of reminding Zach I wasn't very physical as a kid, and got teased as a lot. But at the same time we need to practice so we get stronger and faster. Parenting is hard.


In Amelia news, she knows what she wants and she's assertive.  On the cute side, she'll come in and demand to be tickled, and to be given more tickles. On the not cute side when other kids annoy her she'll scream "NO" at them with great effect.  Amelia has also gotten her screen time legs under her, and she's watching Danial Tiger lots on her Kindle. She was almost able to turn the TV on her own, but that'll still take a few more months I imagine.  I'm reminded of the term digital natives - and the kids certainly are. Finally Amelia watches her mom and copies her - Amelia loves to clean and has started making grocery lists. She makes the lists just like Tori - it's adorable.

In Igor news, I feel really good when I wake up and go to the gym, and/or hit a coffee shop to do some writing/learning.  Every year when we come to Ashland, I think I'll do this, and every year that becomes a "growth opportunity". This year I did it - I got a one week gym membership at the Y and came to the gym at 6am two days.  I also got to a coffee shop most mornings before the kids woke up. In fact, it's 6am and I'm writing this at starbucks before we make our 10 hour return journey to Seattle at 10am.

On the flip side, excited about my new job, I spent a TONNE of time on the computer studying for the new job. Nothing is free, and I paid for that learning by not being especially present.  While I got a bunch of learning done, my family and I would have benefited from me being more present.

Have a great week and remember, *Eat too much turkey, and you wont be perky*- ZiaT

entry.title: Week 342AZ: Canadian Thanksgiving 2016 Edition, and catching up on Zach conversations
entry.content:
Every year we go to Canadian thanksgiving and this year was no exception. This year we stayed in Levenworth and the place even had a built in Movie Theater, the kids loved it.

I was pretty excited as I just excited as I'd accepted a job at Amazon, and with my joining Amazon more then half the folks at Candian thanksgiving now work at Amazon -- much talk of work can now be had. An interesting thing about Amazon is there is a lot of bad press about work life balance.

While this is a concern, it was interesting to see the Microsoft employees on their laptops, which the Amazon folks were able to stay off their phones.

In house news, we're now "Go" on the porch, and are waiting for the contractors to be able to get us into the schedule. It's somewhat amazing that in Seattle the building market is so hot that all the contractors are booked out for months.

In Zach news we had quite the sad at Canadian thanksgiving when Zach discovered someone had "drawn" on 2XL. 2XL is a robot from the 80's that plays cassette tapes. Zach was incredible upset. When I asked him why he answered - "Because 2XL is my favorite robot - well except Alexa, although technically Alexa is just a speaker".

Zach was really upset the next day on the way home Zach piped up with - 
Z: I wish I had a frying pan 
I: Why is that? 
Z: Well I could have hit the people who drew on 2XL over the head
I: How would that have helped? 
Z: It would have been funny, and made me laugh,  which would have made me feel better.

We though this was the end of the story, but Zach's teach showed us Zach's journal entry which was a page full of 2XL ruined, no, no, no no, with no repeated for the entire page. Not much of a journal entry, but it certainly clarified Zach's mood.

In Amelia news she is starting to talk as well. She's been saying things that don't make a bunch of sense - for example: 
I: All right we're going to the zoo
A: Can I come? 
I: Of course, you always come.

And on another occasion.
A: I'm not a bad girl, I'm just two.
It took us a while to figure out, but I suspect it's Zach's been whispering nasty grams into Amelia's ears.



Amelia is also now a ballerina, and she loves wearing tutus. She also loves dancing to the nutcracker, and she'll get quite angry if you don't play the nut cracker for her. Amelia also LOVES having her nails painted, and I have to admit I kind of enjoy painting her nails - being a girl can be fun.

Zach's had lots of other things he's been saying, and I've been negligent in writing them down, here's a dump of Zach dialog, much of it several months, or maybe even a year old.

Z: Girls have to sit peeing down because they have a pagina, not a penis.

Zach wouldn't put on his foot cream. His feet are shredded, cracked and bleeding. Tori normally puts on his foot cream, and I freaked out. 
I: Stay in the bathroom until you're ready to put the cream on your feet. I don't care if you sleep in the bathtub.

Zach slunk off to his bed room crying. I dragged him back to the bathroom and told him he could stay there till he put cream on his feet. He cried for a while, then silence. After a while he came out said he hated getting his hands slimy. I felt bad, so offered to help him. After we got his feet creamed - he quietly said...
Z: Dad, you didn't respect my crying
I: HOw do you mean? 
Z: Look, I had a cry, and you're supposed to say I don't have to do it. 
Z: I had a really big cry and you didn't do it.

On another occasion:


Z: Dad, I think you might be mad at me?
I: Why's that? 
Z: Well, I broke my foot. 
I: Oh, does it hurt, 
Z: No, not really 
I: OK the, I'm not mad.

Zach might be an engineer when he grows up, for example:
Z: I think the englines broken
I: What engine? 
Z: THe engane under the house attached to the rocket blaster is broken, I know because the house isn't moving. 
Z: Dad, you're lucky to have me because I’m really smart, and can fix the engine.

When Zach first met his cousin Sammy, he spent a bunch of time talking her ear off: 
Z: I'm going to fient. 
I: Why is that? 
Z: Well, there's been too much talking ..

One day I caught Zach littering and reprimanded him - his response:
Z: It's not litter it's garbage treasure
Back when Zach was potty training: 
Z: Do you know wwhy I'm wearing a second pair of underwear on the outside? 
I: No - why?
Z: In case I pee on the first pair, I've go the second pair ready to go.

I love getting to walk Zach to school on one such occasion: 
I: Zach, why am I carrying yoyur lunch?
Z: Two reasons 1) Adults believe in ghosts 2) because you made me wear shorts

Just like me as a kid, Zach's not much for physical exercise, but I try to encourage him.
Z: I'm not very good at running.  I: Well what do we need to do to get better at that? 
Z: I Know practice.
I: Well lets do it.
Z: I want to keep my normal speed.
Z: It'll be hard to practice with a broken leg.





Have a great week and remember - Eat lots of greens, it'll keep your insides clean - ZiaT.

link.title: Week 342AZ: Canadian Thanksgiving 2016 Edition, and catching up on Zach conversations

entry.title: The squirrel was swimming towards me.
entry.content:
It's pretty amazing to see how much of the world Zach, even at age 6 understands. It's also pretty damn enjoyable.  Tonight, Zach was reading me a book being narrated by a fish who lived in an aquarium in the second grade classroom.

First Zach wanted to read me the opening joke - the fish was in a school, in a school (get it, a school of fish, in a school) - ha!

Then the fish described a squirrel swimming through the air towards him.  I asked Zach why the squirrel was swimming,Zach explained that from the fishes perspective, all locomotion would be swimming.

Probing, I asked Zach how the squirrel would describe the fishes movement.  Zach replied matter of factly that a squirrel is much smarter then a fish, and understands that fish live in water, and therefore are swimming.

Smart kid.

In other news, Zach week posts will be commencing shortly.

link.title: The squirrel was swimming towards me.

entry.title: Total High: Booing
entry.content:
Lets be honest, as a parent, most nights are a grind.    Lets be more honest, kids are like hard drugs - they ruin your life, but the highs are worth it.   Today, we hit a total high.

First, I got home and Tori and Amelia took a nap and Zach and I talked for like 2 hours. Zach was asking what it was like when I was a kid. Zach was explaining some of the insights he'd had in the world, like the fact that 24 hour restaurants probably have multiple shifts, and some of the cool stuff they were doing at school.

After 2 hours of gabbing - Tori and Amelia woke up, and Tori ran off to hit the gym.  

Earlier this week though, Tori set us up for booing.   Booing is like a giant anonymous gift bombing pyramid scheme.   You make gift bags, and stick them to cards which say - "You've been booed - go boo someone else".

So,  Tori goes off the gym, and I throw Zach and Amelia in the car, and we go booing through several Seattle neighbor hoods. Zach is getting to be a super ninja running out of the car, and sticking cards on peoples doorsteps without them knowing.

After 2 hours, the kids and I get back from booing, and Tori gets back from the gym, and we reward the kids with some ice cream, while Tori and I setup our new skeletons, and figure out the best configuration of black lights for our halloween party!


Score!

entry.title: Week 338AZ- Mindful walking edition.
entry.content:
Last Sunday, while circus training on the trampoline, I pulled a muscle in my lower back. At the time, I knew it was bad, but didn't realize how bad. The next several days I was unable to work, or walk for that matter.
   
Instead of focusing on the negative, I realized there was some opportunity here, and I tried to appreciate:


  1.  Mindful walking (pain makes it easy to pay attention) 
  2.  Empathy for the old and those with difficulty walking
  3.  Use my rabbit headed cane. 
  4. Brag about having an injury while training for the circus.


This morning, as I moaned about my back, Zach was giving Amelia horsy rides - check out the video.

Seven days later, I can walk again, and feel pretty good, although my back gets sore if I stay in the same position for too long.  But enough about me.

Tori has been an Energizer bunny, and has been getting a tonne done. She's finished painting the family room, she's put up bathroom shelving, and now she's prepping the basement for the rug she bought.

Zach is as always a riot. This week he started karate, and became rather fond of monopoly. Sadly, I can't bring myself to play monopoly, so I'm hoping to get Zach to play Go fish.

Amelia is a sweet heart as usual, lsat week we went to a puppet show, here's Amelia playing with the bunny.

Conversations with Amelia:

A: Dad, where did the cat go?
I: He went outside
A: (pouting) But I need to pet the cat!


Have a great week and remember - Train on the trampoline, might have consequences unforeseen -  ZiaT

entry.title: Week 335AZ: The pusher and the hand holder
entry.content:
Saturday mornings Tori goes to the gym, and I take the kids to Trader Joe's. We've been doing this since Zach was tiny, and I love it.

We've even got a bit of a routine down. Amelia eats half a banana, I drink some free coffee. Zach and Amelia get a sucker.  It's great.

Today, Zach was on cart duty, and for the first time, he did all the cart pushing. While I was checking out Zach wondered off.  Once I'd paid I yelled to Zach.  "Cart pusher, your services are needed" and he ran up and grabbed the cart.  And then I yelled at Amelia "I need a hand holder", and she ran up and held my hand.

It was awesome.  Here are some photos from this morning. Zach holding the lego airplane he made, and Amelia holding her favorite umbrella while dressed up as a princess.

link.title: Week 335AZ: The pusher and the hand holder

entry.title: Signs from the toilet
entry.content:
These signs spoke to me today.

The sign on the left reminding us to live like we mean it. The sign on the right, reminding us that nothing is perfect and certainty is ambiguous.

entry.title: Zach on Grade 1
entry.content:
On my first day of school, it was just like the days of kindergarten. The parents could stay in the classroom for a bit, there was a volunteer.
The new thing was the first week was 3 days. In kindergarten the first week was 2 days.  And then after that week, it's 2 days of weekend and then 5 days of school.


The first day we did not have jump start, but in kindergarten we did. When we were in lunch, each class had to sit in the place where there teacher's name was on the table.  For instance, Adam's had to sit at Adam's table, and Stump's had to sit at Stump's table.


We heard Mrs. Adam's talk about Judy B. Jones, a book actor who is naughty and bad, and says some bad things. Mrs Adams read it while we sat on the carpet.

Charlie Harris is my best friend, well one of my best friends, but for now, pretty much my only best friend.

Music is a weird thing, and now it's at the CDSA portable(actually it's now called the LAUNCH portable, sorry), and it's a lot harder.  Music isn't really hard, but it's not very great. See last year we would do music, then come in for math, and then recess - but now we have recess before music, and it' still not very fun.  Music is the same not fun, it's just a bit not funner, since we can't touch anything and we have lots of limits.

I: What was you favorite subject;

Z: My birthday - You know why I'm so happy about my birthday? Because I only have 1 or 2 more weeks till I get my prize. I like my birthday so much, cuz then I get a bracelet, a pencil and a bookmark - I don't think there's anything else biut there might be.

I: Sure, but what did you like most, reading, or writing?

Z: My favorite is choice time, and now we only have it once a week, and now it' sboring since there is no toys.  If I brouth junior monopoly or something, I bet the whole class would like ot place, since there aren't any other fun games.


I: After choice time, what's your favorite subject?

Z: Well, Recess. I don't really like recess because I once got really really hurt. Wood went through my pants, into my knee, and it hurt wicked, and Mom had to pull it out.


I: After choice time, and recess, what's your favorite subject?

Z: PE

I: Why do you like PE

Z: Well once in a while, we don't have to do anything, and sometimes we just play music the entire class.

I: So you like the classes where you don't have to do anything, or you choose.
Z: Yeah, but there aren't classes like that.

The End.

entry.title: Week 333AZ: Zach can read
entry.content:
Last year, when kindergarten ended, Zach was a very weak reader. He was reading books like "Run. Run Spot Run" and hating it.   Tori and I were supposed to work on his reading in the summer, but you know how it is - homework is hard, and we didn't.

Last night, as I was reading Zach a story, I read a few words, and then asked Zach to read a word.  To my surprise, Zach had no trouble doing this on several pages.  On a whim, I said "Zach why don't you read the next page" - and he did.  I was blown away, and tried  "Zach, why don't you read the whole book"  - and he did.

I don't know how this happened, but it is an incredible feeling.  Not only does it feel great for me, but Zach can sense my beaming pride, and he feels great about it to.

Score one for serendipity.

Amelia is adorable too, she has now has emotions. Most days I get a scornful "Dada, you hurt my feelings".    An interesting thing about Amelia, is when she's hurt, both physically and emotionally, her first instinct is not to run to me or Tori, but instead to run away and be alone.    So different from Zach and I - as all parents tell us, your kids are such different people.

Have a great week, and remember - Plant the seed, kids will read - ZiaT

entry.title: Little Miss Spider Man 2
entry.content:
This is number 2, the first story is a good story, you can read it here. Any who, now on with our story.

Mrs spiderman had the whole thing happen again to times. Then, she did not marry her next anybody, she married a rock, and then they had baby rock spiders. Baby rock spiders if you want to know are very contagious. The rock spiders destroyed the red reaper. Serious red survived, Serious red made a 100 new henchman, but a black reaper.  The destroyed Mrs spider man, and most of the rock spiders, except for two of them.

The two made billions of rock spiders, it was a big army, and they destroyed mysterious red's hench men.

Then mysterious red escapes - the end.

entry.title: Week 332AZ: This is Zach's Story - Little Mrs Spider Man
entry.content:
I didn't write a  story for this week, but luckily Zach did - here's his story ...

The name of this story is little miss Spider man.

A long time ago in a far far away land, the land was called spider man woman and spider man land.

Mrs spideman, called to Mr spiderman, I'm having baby spider mans.  And then Mr Spider man's friends showed up, just in time cuz a bad guy showed up.

The bad guy was the grim reaper. The bad guy was so dangerous he could defeat anyone.  Any one who breaks into his lair dies from the spider defense.

Spider man + friends were captured by mysterious red, and his associate, the grim reaper.

As soon as Mysterious REd's 11,000 army men attack spider man dies.

But, Mrs spiderman escapes and has her babies.

The End

ps. I know this was a v
ery sad story - I'm sorry.

link.title: Week 332AZ: This is Zach's Story - Little Mrs Spider Man

entry.content:

To re-ignite my "proactive muscle", I got the back-up camera I bought 5 years ago installed.


(Sure the car was broken into, and I needed to get the dash fixed anyways, but hey - take the momentum where you can get it) 



I haven't decided how I'll post our summer adventures, but I want to maintain my momentum - so here are some pictures to get us started.

Have a great week, and remember -If you wait a long time it'll end up being winter time, - ZiaT

entry.title: Things that make me happy: Zach and Amelia working together
entry.content: I bet if you have it kids, it'll make you happy too!

link.title: Things that make me happy: Zach and Amelia working together

entry.title: Things that make me happy: Unlimited Decaf Coffee
entry.content:
It's so easy to stop doing the things that make me happy, so I'm starting a series of post to remind me for the times I forget.

Unlimited decaf coffee makes me happy. I like drinking as much as I want calorie free, I like being able to sleep at night, and I like the taste of coffee. 


The instant coffee machines at Microsoft make me happy.  The  hotel I'm writing this from has giant urns of coffee, that make me happy. And at home I drink of instant coffee 

For many people, coffee needs to be a fancy latte, or an artisan espresso from a certified barista. I won't complain if I get one of these fancy things, but, I'm equally happy with my favorite instant decaf Fred Meyers coffee.

link.title: Things that make me happy: Unlimited Decaf Coffee

entry.title: Week 323AZ-B: Camping at Denny Creek
entry.content:
Seven years ago, Tori and I came to Denny Creek with a tiny tent, a few possessions, and a twinkle in our eyes. On that trip, I proposed, and Tori agreed to marry me.


Fast forward till today, and we are heading back to Denny Creek, hauling 3 bicycles (notice the fancy bike packing job) 2 children and a giant tent.


The giant tent is awesome, but it does get a little cold, so we huddled up in blankets.

Near Denny creek there was a very cool train tunnel that was used by trains that was converted into a bike tunnel.


Zach and I went through the tunnel. I was super proud of Zach for going through because the tunnel was freezing and pitch black. Zach had a fun time and so did I.



On our way home from camping, we checked out an old growth forest, it was fun seeing the old trees, but the coolest thing was the water fountain, which was really and old hand pump...








Zach is now commandeering this post - in his words ...

We went under bridges, and I fell once, and I found a walking stick, and was crowned king. I enjoyed the hike, and we got domino's Pizza when I came home.

Let the force be with you! You are an ice cream cone, and you earned a domino's pizza.

Your pit is an it that smells like a tit.

-- ZiaT

entry.title: Week 323AZ: Kindergarten Finished
entry.content:
This week Zach is the co-author of our blog post.

 
Based on a kid named Zach, a dad named Igor a mom named Tori and a baby named Amelia, and all their names were Dvorkin, except Tori the mom, whose name was Stephens.

This was a big week. Zach finished circus school, and regular school. As usual, I well up with pride at these events.


At Zach's Kindergarten ceremony, all the kids sang "take me out the ball game", which was adorable, and right on schedule I teared up with joy.

Zach wants to stop going to circus school, and is very excited to say this was his last day of circus school. I hope to change his mind and get him back in circus school, but maybe that's my dream and not his.

[Zach adds] But you're definitely not going to, hahaha.

entry.title: Daddy you're silly
entry.content:
Amelia's been talking for a while, and she says very adorable things. Time to start writing them down: 

I was looking at these old pictures of Zach, and here's what Amelia said: 

A: Dada, who's that cutie? 
A: It's me!
I: Actually Amelia, that's Zachie?
A: Zachie?? Dada - you're being silly
A: Hahaha

entry.title: Week 322AZ: Father's Day #6
entry.content:
Today was a great fathers day -- the perfect weather was  a fine backdrop to a great day.  Here's my blow by blow of why it was awesome.

I got up early and caught up on some work. At 8am, the grocery store opened,  and I biked over, where I could use my folding bike as a shopping cart.

Once home, and done shopping, Zach was up, and we played magna-tiles until Amelia awoke.  When Amelia woke up, Zach realized he could watch TV, so he disseapred, and  so I had some quality time with Amelia. We took a short bike ride to school where we played on the equipment.

When we got home, Tori was up, and I became inspired to cut down some trees, that were better named giant weeds.  I'm not sure what got into me, as I'd never done that before, but I went into the basement and got out a big hand saw, and spent the next 2 hours sawing through trees.

With that complete, well complete is an over statement as Tori needed to help me by cutting the trees into small enough pieces to go into the compost bin, I called my Mom and Sister and caught up with the rest of the Dvorkin clan.

At this point, Amelia was off for a Nap, so I took Zach on the Subway Down town for a humbow. After our humbows Zach wanted to go to Seattle Center so we jumped on the monorail and headed over.   We played at the kids museum for a while,  where among other things Zach created a crown, which we he used to coronte himself "King Zach".

Took the monorail and subway home, and then too lazy to walk the last 10 minutes, waited for a bus to get us a block from our house.

At home, I grazed on our backyard berries before firing up the BBQ to make some yummy steaks Tori had bought for Father's Day.

Five minutes ago, Amelia was sitting on my lap while I was eating my ice cream, and now Tori's downstairs reading the kids stories as I put out this blog post.

Oh yeah, it was a fun week too.

Saturday was the Fremont solstice parade, which tori was kind enough to take me to.

Friday, was the Mont lake carnival, a cool event for the kids where they fill our local community center park with bouncy houses, giant slides, and carnival games.

I'm sure lots of stuff happened during the week too, but it's been a long day, and I'm off to read the kids bed time stories before dozing off myself.

Happy Fathers Day - ZiaT!

entry.title: Week 320AZ: Great starts
entry.content:
I woke up at 5, biked down to Madison park, setup my meditation bench and basked in the hot sun while focusing on my breathing and listening to the waves the water skiers sparked as they got their morning thrills.

Then I explored some neighborhoods I'm not too familiar with before ending up at a coffee shop to write this blog post, practice magic, and do some personal development

Weather has been hot in Seattle, so we setup the air conditioner in the kids, room, and I started sleeping in the basement.

Yesterday Zach had a music concert at school, and he did a great job singing and doing the hand motions.  It's so cool seeing him grow up.

Being a dad is great, waking up early is great,  having a supportive wife is great.  Life is great.

entry.title: Week 319AZ: Family Level Up: Memorial Day Camping
entry.content:
This weekend was memorial day, and we unlocked a new level in our family skills.

Most important we went with another family:  Melissa, Shane and Sylvia joined us on our adventure.

It was raining the first day of camping so we decided to spend our first night in a hotel. Brilliant move as it let Zach show off his new found swimming abilities in the pool.    Zach is now totally comfortable in the pool, and we were able to throw quarters to the bottom of the shallow end and Zach was able to pick them up.    Because we had another family with us, we were able to hang out in the hot tub while the kids played in the pool - Score!

The next day the weather improved so we headed to the camp site. At the camp site, Zach was totally into biking, and was doing laps all around the camping trail.  Zach was so so into biking that he even wanted me to raise his seat so he could go faster.

Zach got into a 'band' of other boys who were all doing laps around the cap site loops doing little boy things and screaming loudly - it's hard to describe the sense of satisfaction that provides.



Amelia really enjoyed the camp site too. She's now talking in short sentences and is able to say the cutest things. For example, Zach was on his bike, and I had Amelia on mine, as we followed Zach Amelia would scream 'Zach - we coming, we coming!'.  Totally adorable.

Unfortunately, the last day of the camping trip Amelia got sick and started puking.  For Amelia it was inconvenient, but nothing more - which was cool.

The second night of camping Zach decided to put on a variety show with the other kids.  Zach was the MC and entered a singing act, I did juggling, Sylvia did a skipping act, and Desmond another boy did a club banging act - totally wild.

Tori got into the biking action this trip as well, which was awesome!

link.title: Week 319AZ: Family Level Up: Memorial Day Camping

entry.title: Week 310AZ: Birthday, Birthday, Birthday.
entry.content:
Zach turned 6, Amelia turned 2, and we had our annual birthday party at the park. This year, the weather was perfect, and we had about 50 people turning up.

Organizing the birthday party is a lot of work, and Tori normally books the picnic shelter at the park months early. This year something went wrong with the booking and a few weeks before the party, Tori realized we didn't have a confirmation for the picnic shelter.

I was fretting, and listening in as Tori talked to the park service:





Tori: I think we didn't get our picnic shelter booked, is the shelter still available to rent?
Park Service: I'm sorry Ma'am, someone else has rented it.
Tori: Hym, how about the other shelter in the same park?
Park Service: I'm sorry Ma'am that's rented as well
(at this point, I'm panicking)
Tori: Hym, can you tell me, who has booked the picnic shelter?
Park Service: A Mrs Tori Stephens
Tori: Ahh, perfect, that's me - have a great day!

A cool thing about the park we host Zach's birthday at is it backs up onto a forrest, and Tori used this fact to her full advantage. She designed a 'find all the hidden things' course, and got Zach's help to distribute the things in the forrest. It was a huge hit with the kids, and one of the Mom's even mentioned this was the coolest Birthday party she'd ever been at.

As is often the case at 6 year olds birthday's the birthday child had a bit of a melt down. In Zach's case, everyone got mini-cupcakes, except for him, who got a full sized cup cake. Everything went fine till they starting singing happy birthday (which Zach does not like), and then Auntie Allison tried to chase Zach to give him a hug. In the hug chasing process, Zach dropped his cupcake and stepped in it, and much crying ensued.

As for two year old's, the notion of a birthday is basically lost on them, and Amelia was just happy to be at the park, and play with all the hdogs.

Tori thank you so much for raising our children, and making there birthdays the best party anyone could imagine!

Have a great week, and remember - step on your cupcake, often a mistake ZiaT

entry.title: Week 309AZ: Glamping with Friends
entry.content:
This week we had our first camping trip of the year. Calling it camping is a bit of a stretch, we stayed at a campground that is was a military base in its former life, Fort Flagler. Instead of staying in tents we rented out the officers quarters for ourselves and some of our good friends who all have kids Zach's age.

Zach and the other almost six year old kids discovered Monopoly



, and Tori was patient enough to be the banker for the kids - for over an hour. Tori - you're a saint.

Amelia spent a bunch of time with her good friend with Sylvia, and they especially bonded over whoppie cushions.  Zach wasn't impressed by the fake farts, but Amelia went nuts. Amelia spent many an hour getting a grown up to inflat her whooppie cushion, and then doing a belly flop onto it to make a farting noise.  Amelia also discovered t-ball, which she did pretty well it. I'm excited to have a child who enjoys sports, and I'll have to learn how to encourage her interest in them.

I am super proud of myself, as while we were camping, I got myself up at 4:30 so I'd have enough time to journal before going down to the beach for a meditation session at sunrise.  After meditating I took a bike ride to get in some exercise before I came home to face a fun day of family activities.

Tori and I were even able to leave Zach with the mob of kids and go for a nice walk with Amelia asleep on my shoulders. Quality time is fantastic.

entry.title: Things that make me happy: Biking!
entry.content:
It's so easy to stop doing the things that make me happy, so I'm starting a series of post to remind me for the times I forget.


Biking makes me happy. I knew it in 2012   and forgot, then I started biking again in October 2015, and in the last few months, I've been happy, and healthy, and biking helps a lot.

Here are some pictures to remind me.

link.title: Things that make me happy: Biking!

entry.title: Week 308AZ: Long commutes don't suck, crappy commutes suck
entry.content:
Now that I have a folding bike, I have a 20 minute bike commute. It's short, hilly, and mostly lacking in views. The lack of a view is especially apparent as at this time of year, I'm biking in at sunrise, but facing south with big houses to the west, so I don't get to see much of the sunrise. For the last few weeks, I've been imagining how nice a ride into the sunrise would be. This morning, I acted. At 5:40am, I jumped into a car2go, and drove to where I'd have a beautiful,

but too long, bike commute into the sunrise.  It was AWESOME.  After I had my fill of sunrise, and tired legs, I stopped at a bus stop, folded up my bike, and hopped on the next bus to work. Start to amazing day - check!

Now that I'd mentally unlocked making my bike commute longer, I've had an even better idea, I can take the ferry during sunrise to let me watch the sunrise over puget sound. Right now, I'm writing this post from the ferry. It's a cloudy day, but this is a successful idea that will be amazing when the sky is clear. I think my favorite part of the morning was I was riding into the ferry passenger area a person tried to stop me and tell me they won't let bikes come on from this entrance, I explained it'd be OK because my bike folded up. He appologized and I just smiled and smiled.

The other great thing about this week is Magic. I've been able to put together a fantastic card routine that is leaving people amazed.  Using a routine has much more impact that a few "card tricks", and I think I'll find a director to help me make it more dramatic, and help me put together some more routines.

link.title: Week 308AZ: Long commutes don't suck, crappy commutes suck

entry.title: Week 307AZ: In love with subway
entry.content:
Today was perfect summer weather, and a once in a lifetime event where you could walk on the newly built 520 highway bridge. I was super excited about walking on the bridge but unfortunately, when we got there, the bridge was already closed to tourists. I was pretty grumpy. Salvaging the day, Tori, knowing how much I love riding the subway, told Zach to pick a Subway adventure for us. Zach picked Bainbridge Island, which meant we got to ride the subway to the ferry, hang out on the island and then reverse the process.

As you can imagine - getting to do all this without getting in the car is a dream come true. For most of the trip Amelia got to ride on my shoulders, which gives me immense pleasure, and on the Ferry Zach and I played hide and seek. To be honest, I'm not sure how comfortable I am playing hide and go seek in large area's but, I'm learning.

On Bainbridge island, Tori let me wander the whole downtown before letting Zach pick were we'd eat. Zach choose mexican, and Tori, Amelia  and I shared a huge mexican dish. Zach, who wanted Mexican food so badly ordered a cheeseburger :)   We stayed at dinner a bit too long and missed a Ferry sailing so we wandered to a coffee shop and relaxed with a cup of coffee while enjoying the sunset.

To make the day perfect, although probably to Tori's chargin, I did some pullups on the subway hand rails.  My Dad would be proud, so was I, and I'm pretty sure 30 years from now, Zach will be doing the same thing.

entry.title: Week 306AZ: Fantastic Friday
entry.content:
Friday was perfect. It's been incredibly summer like today. First, a perfect sunny day with a high of 70 (21C). Then I left work @ 3:30 sharp to get my fill of sunshine. When I got home Tori had a pounding headache, so I got an opportunity to give her a well deserved nap. I took the kids off for dinner, and, you guessed it, we took the light rail. Our destination was china town where we ate @ one of Zach's favorite restaurants. The best part of the trip was Zach and Amelia playing together.

On our way to the light rail, Zach and Amelia where playing chase around my body, including tunneling through my legs. The kids were so adorable a man came by and asked me how old the kids where. As we talked more, he told me he was trying to convince his girlfriend to have kids. On the subway Zach and Amelia continued to play together, and Amelia was so happy she kicked me off the subway seat so she could sit with Zach.


At the Restaurant, Zach had a conversation with the owner, telling him it wasn't his favorite restaurant but it was his 3rd favorite. Even though the owner didn't get top position, he was still happy with his bronze medal in Zach's books.

Amelia held Zach and my hand as we walked home and was happy as a clam.

 Back at home, I practiced juggling my new unlit torches and my magic. For magic I"m working on a really hard magic trick, and am really getting it down.
I was even able to get the kids to bed without waking Tori (although she did wake up).

In other news

In house news, we're taking it easy.

In Tori news, I'll respect her privacy and skip this section.

In Zach news, we had an assessment done at Zach's school because he was having some difficulty with fine motor control and pronunciation. Tori and I met with the people who evaluated Zach and it was a feel great meeting. The School Psychologist told us about how fun it is to administer tests to Zach, and the jokes Zach was telling. It was such a glowing description I teared up a little bit. For the evaluation Zach is smart, scoring at the 95th percentile for logical reasoning, 84th percentile for overall intelligence, 44th percentile for hand writing, and the 1st percentile for pronunciation. Zach's really improved at his reading and writing, so much so that he doesn't need special help from the school. The pronunciation will need help, and Zach with start getting speech therapy from the school. On the funny side, Zach had to draw a person, and he included boobies and a bum, which everyone thought was adorable.

Reflecting on Zach's assessment, it seems in line with my memory of my own childhood. I think I was incredibly good at reasoning, and terrible at hand writing. I don't recall terrible pronunciation, but I do remember people complaining I talked to fast and was sometimes hard to understand.

Zach has also gotten much better at reading, and drawing, and will bring us pictures and read me books. It's really impressive to see his progress in these areas and I'm so grateful to have such amazing children.

In Amelia news, she's getting more words, she now asks for pieces of things, to open things and says hi, by and thank you to us and strangers. She also loves playing with Zach, and Zach often obliges.

In Igor news, a great week. Lots of magic practice, a tonne of productive time at work, and best of all, a bike seat for Amelia for the folding bike. Even though I rushed to get Amelia on the bike seat, she has refused to get on, so I still have some awesomeness in my future when she tries. I also broke down and bought the final accoutrements for my folding bike, a special lock and rack -- once these come in, I'll have everything I need for the perfect (except for price) folding bike!

Have a great week and remember, Kids playing between your feet, strangers wanting us to meet, life is freakin' sweet- ZiaT

entry.title: Week 305AZ: Subway - I mean light rail
entry.content:
This week the light rail (which I stubbornly call the subway) station opened by our house - and I love it. In the 7 days it's been open, I've ridden it 10 times, and I'm looking forward to riding it more as I learn what's at stops further down the line. A great thing about taking the family to the subway is it gives us a chance to hang out without hurry or distractions. For example, last night we took 30 no pressure minutes to our destination - frozen yogurt, where we hung out and ate a taste desert before turning around and repeating the process. Because there's no hurry or distraction, we can talk and listen to each other.

A great thing about taking the subway in the morning is it greatly extends my bicycle range of city exploration. For example, this morning, I popped my bike on the subway and headed over to capital hill, from where I'm writing this blog post.

This weekend had a rough start as we had a friday puke-o-rama. Upon reflection, perhaps this is an earlyc coming of our annual April puke-o-rama. By Saturday we were mostly feeling better, and I took Amelia to a Holi celebration with uncle Ryan.

In magic news, my class has ended, but I'm confident that magician has become enough a part of my identity that I'll continue to work at it. To that end, I've discovered some local magic clubs, and have even journeyed to Fife to check one out.

In other news

I'll get back to that later.

Have a great week and remember, Subway Riding, Kids Hiding, Dads Smiling- ZiaT

link.title: Week 305AZ: Subway - I mean light rail

entry.title: Achievement Unlocked: Watch the queen.
entry.content:
