I love magic. I love practicing it, I love performing it.  Everytime someone asks me how do you do that, I say "practice, practice, practice".  I've been practicing this move for over a year, and finally this morning after one year and a 3 hours practice session, it's finally working:


#pride, #rock on

entry.title: Week 304AZ: Will you play with me?
entry.content:
I think you had to be there to enjoy this, but I was there and really enjoyed it

I had a very long, but productive, day at work on Friday. After working 12 hours, I came home late, and Tori was exhausted as she was coming down with a cold.

Because I was so late, I decided to make a big effort to be present for my family. (Luckily for me, I’d lost my phone, so it was much easier)

Also, because I was late, and Tori was coming down with a cold, she was beat, so went for a nap before the kids bedtime routined started.

I started the evening by asking Zach if we could play together. Zach agreed:
I: Zach, can I play with you?
Z: Yeah, lets play hide and seek
I: OK.
Z: Have you played before?
I: Yeah, but how do you play again?
Z: I close my eyes, and count to 20, and you hide.

Zach proceeded to tell me the rules. At first Zach hid, and I tried to “not find him”, but then Amelia got into the game, and found Zach. Next it was my turn to hide, and Amelia found me while Zach was still counting up to 20. After a few more rounds Amelia kept finding Zach and I and was having an incredible time. Then, Amelia started going to the corner where Zach and I were counting, faced the wall and started saying “1, 2, 1,2,1,2” and then she’d run out and try to find us.

What a lesson, even though I got home late, and Tori was feeling exhausted, I was still able to have an incredible time by just asking Zach if he’d play with me - wow. The other lesson might be, turn off my phone when I get home.

In other news

In family events, we’ve been doing lots! It’s been a kids museum every weekend, and several trips to the community center park in the evenings.

In house news, we had an internal french drain installed. Hopefully, this’ll be the end of our basement flooding troubles. Huge thanks to Tori who organized everything from doing the research, to picking contractors, to clearing the basement, be home to deal with the issues that came up.

In Tori news, I’ll respect her privacy and skip this section.

In Zach news, he’s growing up, and he’s even learning to read. Sometimes I get super impressed by the words he knows, and then I realize he’s just memorized the book - but you know what - that’s OK, incredible memory is great too.

In Amelia news, her words are really coming in. They’re still a bit hard to understand but they’re coming. I’m going to start writing down what she says so I can remember it for when I write this up. Amelia also loves getting out of the house, she’ll per shoes on, and bring me my shoes and say walk - and that’s awesome. I love getting out of the house, and it’s great that Amelia encourages it.

In Igor news, my coin magic is really getting solid. I’m practicing lots, really upping my game, and showing lots of magic tricks at work. I’m also biking lots. I probably bike into work 3 days, a week, and bike out 2. The only problem with biking to work, is the route is a bit too short. I’ll need to figure out a way to make the route longer without making it too long or getting silly. Work has been busy, I’m doing LOTS of programming. It’s not stressful, but it is tiring, so when I get home after working a long day, I’m pretty drained. I need to start enforcing leaving on time.

Have a great week and remember, Amelia’s Walking, Amelia’s Talking, Fatherhood’s rocking!- ZiaT

link.title: Week 304AZ: Will you play with me?

entry.title: Week 302AZ: Family Vacation 2016 - Pheonix
entry.content:
A few months ago ...

"Hey Tori, this is Scott, I'm trying to get Le Anne the perfect gift for her 40th birthday"

Scott is LeAnne's husband, LeAnne is Tori's best friend, and the last time we saw either of them was 5 years ago at thief wedding.

Scott schemed that a surprise visit from Tori, LeAnne's best friend, would be the perfect 40th birthday gift, we agreed, and wanted to be a part of it.

Monday night, at a rental condo in Sunny Phoenix ...

"Scott, this silly, can I take off my blind fold now?" 

"OK, go ahead" 

"Scott, you're so silly .... Tori? What!?!"

And thus began the best vacation I've had in my life. The wonderful 25C/80F sunny days was a
perfect backdrop for the wonderful vacation.

The vacation was awesome for lots of reasons, many related to stuff outside of my head, but lots related to stuff inside my head. My notes for inside my head are TBD, but in a nutshell, I was able to be present with my family and really just enjoy spending time with them.

The highlight of the vacation for me was the pool. Multiple times a day, every day, we hit the pool swimming, floating around, and shooting water guns.

I remember bouncing around the pool with Amelia on one hip, Zach on the other, and all of us singing "Row, Row, Row your boat".   A few minutes later, seeing Zach being brave enough to jump into pool, and I thought "Wow - this is it, this is the highlight reel of my life".

After the time in the pool with family, the best part of the vacation for me was the cuisine. We stayed in a condo with a full kitchen and we were able to make our own food. Most nights I Bbq'd steak while Tori made gourmet sides and salads. We ate like semi healthy kings, and several nights we were even able to feed LeAnne and Scott before they joined us for an evening dip in the pool.

We also had a few family adventures.  Being in desert, we went on a short (OK, incredibly short) desert hike, complete with Cactus pictures. Interestingly, while I couldn't help myself form touching the cactus needles (which hurts), Zach had no trouble avoiding the temptation.

We spent a day at the Phoenix Children's museum. The museum contains an incredible indoor 3 story climbing structure and a pool noodle forest - if you're ever in Phoenix I highly recommend it.

Have a great week and remember, Pheonix is hot, we liked it a lot!- ZiaT

entry.title: Week 301AZ: Date Night
entry.content:
Back in 2006, I met Tori and I started the “life chapter” I like to call “the rest of my life”. Like all relationships, it started with courtship and dating, but after a while, I got caught up in the hustle and bustle of life - especially work and child rearing. I started forgetting how much I enjoyed Tori’s company. Our early relationship wasn’t fireworks, nor daring high energy activities, but instead calm low key adventures where we relaxed and comfortably enjoyed simpler things.

This weekend, Tori and I went on our first date in a very long time, and it was wonderful! We saw a a musical review of Jonny Cash (a play with lots of songs) , and then we went to a wonderful vegan restaurant. The musical review was great, I got a depth of appreciation of Johnny Cash’s music. At the restaurant, as Tori and I enjoyed crispy fried tofu, I reflected on how happy I am to share my life with Tori. How happy I am that we share a common desire for what we want our life to be: simple, relaxed, creativity, while bringing complementary skills to “how” we will achieve it.

To add some color to this post, I should tell the story of how we ended up on this date. Back in Decemember, Tori sent me a mail asking if I wanted tickets to a jonny cash concert. I replied saying it sounded fun, and that we should get a sitter, and go together.

As we got closer to the concert, I was telling my friends that I was going to a Jonny cash concert and they reminded me that in fact, Jonny cash was dead. I figured the concert must be a tribute concert, by a local cover band. As Tori and I got ready to leave on the day of the “concert”, I asked Tori if the event would be indoor or outdoor, and Tori gave me a very strange look and said indoor. Great I thought, not giving it another thought. When we got to the venue, I was surprised at how old everyone was, when I mentioned it to Tori, she said, what did you expect? I reflected that Johnny cash is old, so it makes sense to have an older audience. Finally when we got into the auditorium, I realized that in fact we were at a play, not a concert. Suddenly everything made sense.

I won’t go into Tori’s perspective of the date, with the exception of her complaint that the person beside her at the musical review was so excited for the music that he spent the entire time thumping his foot so aggressively that she was bounced around in her chair.


Have a great week and remember, To enjoy your life, enjoy time with your wife- ZiaT

entry.title: Week 300AZ: Business trip to New York, and a few shots of Love
entry.content:
I glanced at my phone, 6:30, dang. I've got to get this post written quickly, I thought.

As I started typing, I heard the patter of Amelia's feet, and a few Amelia squawks of discomfort. 
Amelia putured over, saw me, and came up for the briefest of hugs, before continuing her puttering and squawking on her way to get a wake up booboo from Tori.

The love Amelia bestowed in that 3 second hug, has put a smile on my face, which I don't think will come off for a while.  The love that the kids bestow on me is the theme of this post, and just telling these stories to others makes me feel great.

This week I had a very short business trip to New York. I only had a few minutes for sightseeing, but I had some great memories and learnings:

The first night, I decided to go for a walk (with no idea of where I was going), and didn't bother looking at a map since I had my phone with me.  Even though I didn't know where my hotel was, or even the name I didn't care since all the details were in my phone.  Twenty minutes into my walk I got cold and glanced at my phone for directions home.  But, the phone batteries were dead. After I took a minute to panic, I thought hard and was able to retrace my steps, with a vague idea of what street the hotel was on.  I made it home with not too many wrong turns, but for the rest of the trip carried a phone charger.

The second day, I had a few hours before going to work so I decided to go for another walk. This time I decided to look at a map first, and it turned out I was only a 30 minute walk from times square, so I verified the charge on my phone and headed out the door. Early on a cold winter morning, Time square was mostly empty, but I imagined what it must feel like when it is packed with people - Wow! Heading back to the hotel, I took a different route, and accidentally walked past the most incredible new york library main branch.  If that wasn't awesome enough, across the street was grand central terminal  a majestic  train station.

Times square, the library and grant central terminal, are all incredible by the modern standard of 2016. It boggles the mind to imagine how people in the early 1900's must have felt when they saw these spectacles.

On the second afternoon I got incredibly lucky. A giant snow storm was forecast for New York, and not following the news, I had no idea. A colleague, sent me an e-mail saying Dude, if you don't change your flight you'll be stuck in New York because of the blizzard. Honestly, I debated if I should change my flight, after all, the news is always  sensational, and being a Russian born Canadian, I have no fear of a little snow. Luckily, I did change my flight, as every plane on the east coast was grounded that weekend.

The second night, I was already missing my family and called home to talk to Tori and the Kids. After I'd talking to Tori, she gave the phone to Zach. Unlike previous times I've talked with Zach on the phone, this time he was crystal clear. He was having a discussion, and asking questions. It was like talking to another grown up. As our conversation was ending, Zach words were something I should take to heart:

Z: Dada
I: Yup
Z: Go have fun!
I: Thanks buddy. [huge smile]

On my third, and last day, I woke up early and went for a run 6 mile run around central  park. It's fantastic having good enough habits that unprepared, I can wake up at 5am, and go for a fast 6 mile run with no need for will power.

But the best part of my trip, and just thinking about this puts a smile on my face, was coming home.

On the third night, I got home around 10, and Amelia was still awake. As soon as I walked in the door she ran over, as best she can, and gave me a huge hug. Hugs are Amelia's forte, but this hug was even deeper and better then usual. AMAZING.

The next morning, while I was writing in my journal upstairs, I heard a tenantive thump, thump, thump up the stairs. "Hey buddy, I'm up here" I called down, and Zach raced up the stairs at full speed, and wrapped his arms around me: 

:  [while hugging]
I: Zach, I so missed you, and I really, really mean it. 
Z: Me too Dad. Me too.
I: [huge smile]

Have a great week and remember, New York, New York, I'd rather hugs from my little bugs- ZiaT

link.title: Week 300AZ: Business trip to New York, and a few shots of Love

entry.title: Week 298AZ: Zach on Licorice
entry.content:
Zach frequently talks about a place called licorice. It's a pretty fascinating place, so I asked him to elaborate:

Zach, tell me about licorice:
Licorice is under water and it is very cool.

Who lives in licorice?
Everyone who hasn't existed yet, and angels live in space. But some angels go into the licorice hotel. The hotel in licorice is pretty big. If you tried the hotel you'd really like it, but you can't try it, because you'd have to be not alive.

What do they speak in licorice?
They speak ha, fa, too, gah, mah tah. They speak lots of different ways in licorice because it's one of a kind. If you're hearing me, this is really it.

What do you hear in licorice?
You hear sounds like fa, too, moo, ha, foo an cah, and lots of them. Let me give you an example. One time there was some people and the car crashed - and it sounded like "fverasdkjbewr1" and then we are done.

What happened yesterday in Licorice?
I can't tell you because we aren't in Licorice.

Do people in licorice swim?
Yes, well they swim a very strange way because they live underwater. See they have to go on land to swim in the sand. But you don't usually see it because it's a secret place only licorice people know about. They go to a secret place, but it's really a pain in the butt, trust me.

Are there little sisters in licorice?
Everyone starts as a baby, and when they turn into a grown up they turn back into babies again.

Are there frogs in licorice?
Yes, yes, no, no.

At this point, Zach told me to write "this down", these are his words:Dad you are special to me. I love Igor. I love you from Zach.

Talk about huge smile on my face.

In other news

This section will return to its regularly scheduled programming next week.

Conversations with Zach:

This section will return to its regularly scheduled programming next week.

Have a great week and remember, Listen to your kids, it's pretty frickin' awesome. - ZiaT

entry.title: Week 297AZ: All's well that ends well
entry.content:
The writing in this post doesn't do justice to what a perfect day today was. But, I know how perfect it was, and this post will be enough for me to remember it.

Today ends our Christmas vacation. I'm writing this as I wait for our Chinese food take out order, I'm exhausted, the house is full of kids and grown ups, and it's been an amazing day.

Today started as a post worthy day, but got better and better. I'll run this post in chronological order.

For me the day started at 4:45. As I came down stairs, Amelia and Tori were already awake. Tori, exhausted, and Amelia wide awake. Tori tagged me and headed off to bed. Amelia, petrified she'd be stuck with me putting her to bed, ran up to follow Tori and fell asleep within minutes.

Alone downstairs, I meditated, and journalled for a few hours, until 6:30am when inspired from jumping in the lake, I biked up to capital hill to watch the sunrise (first time ever), it was perfect.

 By 8am I was home, and Zach caught me playing video games on my Kindie when he woke up (a very rare event):
Z: Hey, what are you doing?
Z: Oh wait, you took my advice. 
I: What do you mean? 
Z: Well, I told you, you learn lots of good stuff from video games. 
I: What good stuff do you learn?
Z: Like how to read, and how to do lots of stuff. 
I: Nah, I'm just relaxing.

Wanting to make the last day of our vacation count, I said to Zach, "Dude, today's it, the last day of our vacation. Lets do some stuff together, so turn off your kindie, and lets go to the grocery store". To my surprise, Zach got his purse and said -  Dad, Today I'm going to buy my first thing.

Zach and I had a great time at the grocery store, and in the end, Zach bought a banana. While buying the banana, he a great conversation with the clerk: 

Z: Hey, why are you putting that lady's stuff into boxes? 
Clerk: Well, have you heard of reduce, reuse, recycle.
Z: Duh, of course, but what, do you want?
Z: You want the whole world to be taken over by forests?
Z: Do you want the world to look like Endor? 
Z: Do you want to be eaten by bears?

After we'd returned home and restocked our fridge, Tori whisked us away to swimming at Montlake Terrace.

Zach had a riot, and for the first time ever Amelia came into the pool, with Tori. Amelia wasn't swimming yet, but she was waist deep in the water, and only looked slightly concerned. Zach on the other hand was making huge leaps into the water. Zach's hair was soaking wet, and he was even comfortable enough to take a shower.


As if our day wasn't good enough at this point,  after we got home and took a 30 minute nap, we headed out to go skating. Tori, Zach, and even Amelia got into skating. By the time we got kicked off the ice, Zach was skating walker free by holding my hand, Amelia was walking on the ice in her shoes pushing the walker, and Tori and I had both done several laps without falling.

After ice skating, we invited our friends (who we were skating with) over for dinner, and I was sent off to pick up chinese!

Two words - Family Success.

(Regular sections return next week)
Have a great week and remember, All's well that ends well, unless you fall in a well, in that case ring a bell. - ZiaT

link.title: Week 297AZ: All's well that ends well

entry.title: Happy jump in the lake day 2016
entry.content:
Cold? Check!

Zach wanted to skip? Check!

Igor wanted to skip? Check!

Igor did it anyways? Check!

Tori tweaked her back so it was Zach and I representing the Dvorkin resistance fighting squad for 2016.

I didn't expect Zach to jump in the lake with me, but I did expect him to watch. Instead, Zach brought a paper notebook, sat far from the bustle of the lake and doodled in his notebook.   That reminds me of someone ....

Ammon came out to jump with us this year.  It was nice to celebrate this ceremonial win over the the ever present resistance together.

Here's to 2016 being a year where Ammon, me, my family, and everyone who wants to,  battles bravely against the resistance.

link.title: Happy jump in the lake day 2016

entry.title: Week 296AZ: Sledding in a winter wonder land
entry.content:
Z: " Yeah! Lets do it again"


For the first time ever, Zach and I went up to the play in the snow. For our virgin snow foray I decided sledding was the way to go,and we picked up a sled at home depot on our way up to the mountains. Zach was hesitant at first, but when we started throwing snow balls, snow planting, and even sliding down gentle slopes by himself he loved it.

Note for my future self: One of the reasons it was awesome was we 'quite while we were ahead', by leaving after 45 minutes even though we were still had lots of fun.

In other news

In family events, more puking, and some sore backs to boot. The good news is if you're sick for long enough, it stops being an event and you just keep on going, just more tired. With Igor off, we've been trying to sneak in at least an activity a day, library, swimming, dumpling house, going to to the snow to name a few.

I've also started to notice my behaviors are becoming Zach's behaviors, and if I don't want Zach to have these behaviors, I'll need to change my owns.

The first behavior is screen time. Like me, Zach watches as much screen time as he can. I use the execuse "I'm doing something productive", but Zach probably does too (more on that later).

The second behavior I noticed is the lack of the sacred/celebration. I've never been big into making days "special", as a result, Zach couldn't care less that it's Xmas, sure he has some interest in getting toys but otherwise he's in different. I need to reflect through how I think about this.

In Tori news, I'll respect her privacy and skip this section.

In Zach news, his reasoning is getting sharper and sharper. I'll share some stories in conversations with Zach. Also for Xmas at school, Zach made us a pottery mushroom bell - it's adorable and Zach is incredibly proud for giving it to us, and we're incredibly proud for receiving it.

In Amelia news, her talking is getting clearer and clearer, and she's getting more nouns. It's funny, Tori and I always tried to tell Amelia ZaZa so she could pronounce Zach's name, but she ignored us and has been saying Zach since day one. Amelia has also become an ice cream addict. She'll devour as much ice cream as you'll give her, and she'll often pull you to the freezer and point demanding more ice cream. If your out of ice cream that's a problem, but luckily you can show her there's no ice cream, and even though she's grumpy about that she'll let it go.

In Igor news, I've been super disciplined, introspective, and reflective all in a good way. I'm incredibly proud that I've been up everyday while on vacation @ 4:45, on the first ding of my alarm clock (which is the total anchor for my discipline). I've been doing lots of magic practice, and am not even nervous when I do my 'easier' impromptu tricks now. I've also become quite excited about empathy, and trying to see things from other people's perspectives. I guess you'll have to ask Tori how well I'm doing there ;)

In house news, it's been slow going, but we're making progress. We got our basement TV wall mounted which clears up a bunch of space on the basement floor, and I've been throwing things away (which is hard to see, but drip drip drip as they say).

Conversations with Zach:

Zach and I are starting to philosophically spar, I'm already being outsmarted ....
After spilling milk: 
Z: Sometimes accidents need to happen.
I: Well, they don't need to, but sometimes they do happen. 
Z: Look dad, what if you could push someone, or you'd have to die - what should you do. 
I: Alright

After Zach had blamed the video games for not eating dinner:
I: Zach I'd like to teach you an important word - responsibility.
Z: That's not an important word. 
I: I see, what are more important words?
Z: Well -  family, calmness, and focus, 
I: Ok, those are good words too.
Z: Yeah
I: So anyways, responsibility, means when something doesn't happen the way you want
I: you don't blame someone else, you take action yourself.
Z: Dad, that's silly.
I: How do you mean? 
Z: Dad, lets say someone comes in and kills you. Is that their fault, or your fault? 
Z: Are you going to make it better?
I: Touche..

Although he doesn't yet claim responsibility, he does appreciate structural solutions:
I: Let's try again ...
I: Whose fault is it that you're hungry?
Z: It's your fault.
I: .... I ramble for  while ...
Z: You need to make a rule.
I: What rule? 
Z: You should have made a rule that if I like something, I need to eat more then 5 bites.

Sometimes though, his wisdom hasn't fully matured yet: 
Z: Dad, do you have your pen, this is important
I: OK, yup, I'm ready.
Z: Owls are really rise.
I: Got it.
Z: Now dad, do you remember the most important lesson in life? 
I: Nope - What's that lesson
Z: Old socks are really smelly.

Have a great week and remember, Socks smell, owls are wise, what's in store is a surprise - ZiaT

link.title: Week 296AZ: Sledding in a winter wonder land

entry.title: Week 295AZ: What letter does Orange start with?
entry.content:
Zach and I have been working on spelling. We do it in a "What letter does Orange start with" type game. As you'd imagine Zach doesn't want to spend all his time answering, he wants to ask questions as well. Sometimes he asks hard questions

I: What letter does cat start with? 
Z: C.
I: Exactly, your turn.
Z: What does I I start with.
I: Uhm, Zach that's not a real world.
Z: Sure it is, it's an animal and it starts with A.
I: Dude, that's  not fair, that's a frickin' hard word.
Z: It's just an animal, you ask animals.
I: Sigh.

In other news

In family events, we've had a bit of a puke-o-rama. Zach volcano'd, amelia volcano'd, and Tori and I got into the volcano spirit ourselves. Who says family is all roses :) In less explosive thoughts, We gave out our christmas chocolates, we went swimming at the pro club and Amelia and I did some downtown adventures. Next week I'll be on vacation and am looking forward to it.

In Tori news, I'll respect her privacy and skip this section.

In Zach news, he's starting to recognize words on signs, which is pretty cool. He loves swimming and I hope to make that a weekly activity. Zach's also figuring out cause and effect, and lots of self help quotes like "Dad all that matters is you try.

In Amelia news, her opinions and anger are developing. She's also blossoming into a "little lady" with a strong desire to have accessories, and to dress her self with accessories. Amelia has also discovered "screen time" and greatly enjoy's Masha and the Bear. I'm not sure why Amelia picked a russian cartoon, but it's currently her favorite. Like me, Amelia loves to get out of the house. She'l frequently grab her boots and come over to me to get us out of the house. I love this as well, I also want out of the house. Unlike me, Amelia will demand that she get particular socks, a particular coat, and sometimes even matching clothes. Sheesh, girls have demands. Now, girls are also wonderful in that she wants to give really nice hugs and kisses.

In Igor news, I've been distracted by work. Some stuff went a lot worse then it could have, and as a result I spent a lot of time stressing, assigning blaming, introspecting, and trying to figure out what to do better. The stressing and blame assignment wasn't helpful, but lets be honest, I experienced it, and had to work through it. Acknowledgement is the first step to healing :). My stress was hightened because I was doing the final sprint of my weight in. I'm now 149 pounds. I have to say I'm very proud of my physical fitness, and am looking forward to developing my emotional fitness in 2016. In hobby news I'm working on a magic routine where three coins "fly through" a spectators hands. I'm very excited by the routine because it's intimate, realistic, and awe striking.

In house news, Tori has been working on our porch drawings like a bunny. Every morning when I get up at 5, I see Tori with her ruler, pencils and light table. I don't understand drafting, but it sure looks impressive and professional. Tori's skills are impressive. We also got a giant mirror for my office, which is awesome as it encouages me to practice my magic.

Conversations with Zach:

On hidden candy and sharing: 
I: Zach, I bet mom has candy hidden somewhere. 
Z: Oh, I know where it is, i'll tell you , but only if you promise to only eat one piece. 
I: Well, in that case why don't you not tell me and get me one. 
Z: Returns with a mini kit kat bar.

I split the chocolate in half and give him half. Zach takes his piece, breaks it in half and gives half to his sister, who eats it. Zach says: 

Z:  Oh Amelia likes these too. 
I:  Zach, I'm super proud of you.

While we visited Tori's Aunt Anita in Oregon, we tried to watch TV, but Anita was having trouble getting it to work:
I: Do you need help with the TV? 
Anita:Sure
Z: Yup, dad's an engineer he can fix it.

It's easy to forget what's scary when you're 5:
Z: Dad, are you woried abbout mom being gone?
I: Nope
Z: Well, she's been gone a long time. 
I: It's OK she's just grocery shopping.
I was going to tell Zach why I was lucky, but he decided to out do me :)
I: I'm lucky
Z: I'm luckier then you?
I: Oh yeah, Why's that? 
Z: Because you have to go to work.
I: Well, you're right. But atleast I like my work

Bad dreams, Kindie and Being Evil:
Z: Moma
I: Mom's asleep but I'm up. 
Z: Well, I want moma, I had a bad dream.
I: Well, what does mama usually do?
Z: She sleeps with me so I can go back to bed and get a good dream
I: Tell me your dream
Z: I dont want to. 
I: OK, well go upstairs to be with Mom
Z: Well, I'd do another way today
I: Oh yeah, what's that. 
Z: Well, if I watch Kindie I forget my dream.
I: OK. 
Z: Hey wait, is it the weekend. 
I: Yup
Z: Yeah!!
Z: I guess the bad dream might have been OK because I am Darth Vader
Z: I guess i could kill them.
I: That's not nice.
Z: Well, Darth Vader is a bad guy
Z: Except, he takes orders from the emperor who's an even badder guy
Z: And then he gives orders to the storm troopers.
Have a great week and remember, Christmas Cheer, Too much beer, Oh Dear - ZiaT

link.title: Week 295AZ: What letter does Orange start with?

entry.title: Week 294AZ:Sight words
entry.content:
In kindergarten they teach kids to read via sight words. Sight words are words kids memorize, often without even learning the sounds of the individual letters. Zach doesn't really enjoy school work, or home work, so when we have to do sight words for homework, it's often a pain. For example, a typical night goes like this:

I: Zach - you need to do your sight words. 
Z: I'm trying
I: No, you're not come on, lets spell these out. 
Z: I can't, I'm tired.
I: You can lets do it.
Z: OK
I: What letters are in this word
Z: w-i-t-h
I: Great, what is it?
Z: At?
I: Sigh. Lets try again.

After several nights of this I tried a new strategy. I said, buddy I know you can do these sight words, lets see how fast you can get them done.

At that I showed Zach only the easy sight words, and let Zach race through them. Zach nailed them in 2 minutes and he was super proud of himself.

After being successful once, Zach is much more interested in sight words. Just today Zach said:

Dad, dad, get the stopwatch so we can do the sight words quick!

In other news

In family events, we're bootstrapping our family traditions. Zach had his first school Christmas concert, and thus begins a new era in our parenthood! Last night, we did the Green Lake pathway of lights. It was cold, with blustering winds, but we did it anyways, because pounding through stuff is practice for life. Today, Zach did his first "fun run" it was the Jingle bell run and walk. This fun run, which we walked, is in downtown Seattle and everyone has bells, and on occasion people break out into spontaneous caroling.

In Tori news, I'll respect her privacy and skip this section.

In Zach news, Oh my god (OMG)! Zach picked up OMG at school on Thursday, and has been saying it what feels like at least 3 times and hour Ug.

In honor of hour of code, Zach and I did some programming together. He's still a bit young for it, but we enjoyed playing on the computer together.

Finally, Zach decided to dye himself with food coloring, and was rainbow colored from head to toe. Tori and I didn't complain and let Zach go off to school. The next day, still rainbow colored, Zach decided to wear his coat. This is odd as Zach usually claims to be a polar bear and never wears a coat. Another mom caught on to the ruse and whispered to Tori, I bet he got teased really bad at school yesterday for being multicolored, so today he's hiding.


In Amelia news, she went to her first gymnastic class, which Tori said she loved. I wasn't there, but
Tori sent me a picture of Amelia sound a sleep in the car seat as soon as she got back from the class. Amelia got to watch Zach at circus school today, and it was hard keeping her off the circus equipment, I suspect as soon as Amelia's ready she'll be a might acrobat.

In Igor news, I'm back at work. For the first time in my career I'm in open space, and so far, I've been pleasantly surprised. The energy is great, and the ambient distraction hasn't been a problem. Using work busy-ness as an excuse, I haven't been keeping up with my emotional intelligence practices, but I'll try harder next week. Finally many months I find new dieting food, and this month's it's radish Kim Chee. If you're not in the know radish kimche is pickled radish in hot peppers and a touch of fish sauce. Yum.

In house news, we had brutal rains, and our basement flooded. Sigh. Tori was on top of it though, and so we had minimal damage.

Conversations with Zach:

.... Stay tuned for stories next week ...

Have a great week and remember,  Tradition, Rendition, Cognition - ZiaT

entry.title: Week 293AZ: Enjoy it while you can.
entry.content:
As we walked up to our favorite Korean place, the owner called out to Zach:

"Hello my friend, what are you getting?"

"The usual, Teriyaki Kids meal!" Zach replied happily.

As I swiped my credit card the owner's eyes met mine and he said quietly:

"It stops you know."

Surprised, I asked "How do you mean?"

"He'll stop talking to you" answered the owner.

"Well, he's only 6, so I've got 4 maybe 6 years left." I answered.

"Who knows -- It's not up to you, it's up to him" said the owner.

As the credit card machine printed the receipt the owner continued - "Enjoy it while you can"

In other news

In family events, we've been doing lots! I'm stoked we now have a family gym membership at ProClub so can go swimming any time. ProClub has family night on Saturday/Sunday where they set up a big kids bouncy house, laser tag, and a giant inflatable slide. We've gone once and hopefully it'll become a habit. We've also been swimming, picked up our x-mas tree, and right now, Tori has Zach and Amelia on the Santa Train -- Ho Ho Ho!

In Tori news, I'll respect her privacy and skip this section.

In Zach news, he will swim with a life jacket!! And he loves it! So far, he's only comfortable being a few inches from the edge, but it's huge step up and worthy of celebration. At the pool, Zach was also finally brave enough to take a shower - pretty amazing! Since I'm not working I've been able to take
Zach to school several days, and he often tells me knock knock jokes. This weeks were "who's the -- interrupting cow", and "who's there? - boo who!". Zach is also really into the spirit of xmas. Helping others, giving to charity, and being nice. In academic news, Zach's quite good at numbers, but he's got room to grow in reading and writing. Luckily we found some kindie games and videos (electric company!!), which Zach seems to enjoy (and if he doesn't well, the Kindie locks him out till he's finished), so I expect Zach's learning will now accelerate.

In Amelia news, I was amazed to realize just how many words she knows. I was reading from a book that has an object per page and she knew more then half the words. The words are still hard to understand, but I'm grateful to see her developing. I also need to spend more time reading her those kinds of books ;) Amelia also has a baby doll which she carries everywhere. She calls the doll "bebe" and gets very upset when you can't find Bebe. Amelia also loves watching me juggle, but she didn't like the idea of juggling Bebe. I guess it's like friends and noses, you can pick your nose, you can pick your friends, but you can't pick your friends nose. Oh yeah, an Amelia's is acquiring anger and outrage. This morning she asked for crackers, which I gave her, then she didn't eat them and asked for seaweed instead. I said no, you need to eat your crackers, so she threw the crackers everywhere. Luckily, she likes to clean up, so I told her to clean up the crackers and she did.

In Igor news, I'm on the last week of my 3 week vacation. I've had some very high value personal development days. I've begun to study and and summarize books on the top skills to develop in 2016:Emotional Intelligence and Essentialisim. Not that it's winter and I'm a normal weight, I get really cold, luckily you can buy stuff to fix that. I've also been stepping up my magic. I'm evolving from single tricks, to "three trick routines", which really increases the sense of wonderment for my audiences.

In house news, our Christmas tree is up! Tori is working on the designs for the porch, and I've got my office setup and ready to use. It's surprising it didn't occur to me that adding more light, and heat would make me enjoy my office so much more!

Conversations with Zach:

This week instead of conversations, I posted a BUNCH of videos, check them out. For my memories, these include the first time Zach and Amelia played together.

Have a great week and remember, Ho, Ho, Ho, Hope for Snow! - ZiaT

link.title: Week 293AZ: Enjoy it while you can.

entry.title: Zach Week: Amelia Round Up
entry.content:
Because of the way our schedules and responsibilities work out, most of my family time goes to Zach and not nearly as much goes to Amelia.  The last week I've been off, so I've been able to hang out with Amelia bunches, and put down on paper the many things I've seen her upto.  Here are some of Amelia's adventures and developments as seen through my eyes over the last few months. I'll think about a good way to merge these into the normal Zach week posts.

Awesomest of all, Amelia will give SUPER hugs. When she hugs, she gets you to pick her up, and then she grabs you and gives you an awesome, I love you with all I've got hug. It's fantastic. Sometimes she'll follow that up with a kiss. The kiss is her getting her face close to your cheek and making a "schmk" sound. Those hugs are priceless.

Amelia is getting more and more words. Yes, No, Hi, Bye, Doggy, apple, and just this week she transitioned from Hi to Hello.

Amelia has lots of teeth now. I'm not counting 'em, but there are more everytime I look in her mouth.  Judging by how tired Tori is, I'm certain the teeth are painful and keeping Amelia and Tori up.

Amelia does a running, skipping shuffle when she's excited. She'll B-line in a direction, and the best part is if you pick her up and turn her, she'll just keep B-lining in the new direction as if nothing has happened.

Amelia was in my lap one day after I'd just shaved my head. She reached up, rubbed my head, and started giggling.

Unlike the males in the family Amelia likes hygiene. She'll clamor for clean shirts, get out the toothpaste and toothbrush and try to brush her teeth - and she'll even try to floss her teeth (although it's usually from floss in the garbage).

Amelia can't yet open foods like apple juice or yogurt, so she'll go pick them off the shelf and bring them to a grown up, in the hopes they'll open it.  Amelia came over with an apple juice, and I said "no you already had an apple juice" and Amelia took the apple juice and put it back on the shelf.

Amelia loves being self sufficient, and going outside, so she frequently gets her boots on. If you're not moving fast enough she'll put her boots on and bring you your boots to indicate it's time to go outside.

Amelia loves talking to Baba, and she loves skype. Everytime Amelia hears the Skype sound on my phone she'll rush over saying Baba.

Before the "book episode", Amelia would sleep on me. For example, she got up early one morning, not ready to wake up yet. So she threw her blanket on me, and then ran off.  She came back a minute later, holding her teddy bear.  With me already covered in her blanket, she curled up on me with her teddy and blanket, and fell asleep - awww.

After the "book episode" Amelia has gotten very determined that I not put her to bed.  When it's bed time, she'll back away from me saying "no,no, no" and then when she's out of my reach, she'll turn and run for Tori.

The other day I changed Amelia, and I left the old panty on the floor. Tori yelled at me to put the Panty away, so I tried delegating - "Amelia, throw the panty away", I said, and Amelia did it! W00t!

On this years Thanksgiving trip to Ashland, we brought Amelia's motorcycle so she could "bike" while Zach and I were on our bicycles. Amelia loved it, every time we got on our bikes, Amelia demanded that we got her motorbike.

Zach and Amelia have started playing together!!!  From simple stuff, like Zach sneaking over to watch an episode of Pocoyo with Amelia, to Zach trying to lift amelia down a slide at the playground, to the coolest thing yet - Zach and Amelia running in circles around a table and laughing and giggling.   AWESOME!!!

entry.title: Week 292: No, No No
entry.content:
No, No, No, grunted Amelia while trying her hardest to use her 20 lbs body to push me out of bed.

Let me rewind, four days ago ...

Tori was attempting to put Amelia down for a nap, and Amelia was showing her lack of interest by screaming until Tori gave up on the idea. Deciding to be helpful, I took Amelia from Tori and forced
Amelia into bed.  Not wanting to be there, Amelia started screaming like a banshee. In a rare moment of fatherly insight, I pulled out my Kindle and started reading Amelia a story. Silence descended and before I finished the second page of the book, Amelia was sound asleep.

With Amelia out like a light, I bragged to Tori: 
I: Wow, I dunno why this didn't occur to me before, but if I just read Amelia a story, she'll fall right asleep.
T: That's great, good work, you can be in charge of putting Amelia down for the next few days.

Three days ago, when Amelia was exhausted, but refusing to go for a nap, I snagged her and re-applied my "force to bed, while reading a story" trick. Amelia wasn't thrilled, but was too exhausted to fight.

Quite proud of my self, I bragged to Tori: 
I: This works awesome, I'm an amazing father. I've got this putting Amelia to sleep thing down cold.
T: That's great, good work, you can be in charge of putting Amelia down for the next few days.

Yesterday, Amelia had fully internalized that I was going to put her to bed, and was determined not to let it happen again. If I was reading in bed, Amelia would take one look at me, say "No, No, No" and wander away. Even worse, if I was walking her around the house, and I tried to walk her into the bedroom, she'd drop my hand say "No", and run off.

Today, I was hoping Amelia would "let go" the fact that I'd forced her to bed, but no such luck. When it was Amelia's actual bed time, Tori was reading Amelia and Zach a bedtime story, and I walked into the bedroom to listen to the story. Seeing me, Amelia started crying, and Tori shewed me away.

Feeling unloved, I grabbed a book, and started reading on the couch.   Twenty minutes later Zach came out of the bedroom, and begged me to come to bed to snuggle him. With Zach pulling one hand, and imagining Amelia would be asleep on the other hand, I snuck into bed with Zach,  snuggling beside Amelia who was sound asleep beside Tori.

Turns out Amelia was only half asleep, and within 30 seconds she was grunting No, No, and trying her hardest to use her 20 lbs body to push me out of bed.

In other news

In house news, not a lot of progress, the house is in maintenance mode as we focus on other priorities.

In family events, we're in Ashland, enjoying thanksgiving with Tori's family. It's such a pleasure being down here, every day we hang out with Tori's family, go bike riding , and go to science works. We're staying at Anita's place in town, but we spent a day on the ranch and we got to see the plans for the woodshed and Zach got to drive some rocks around on the bobcat, one of his favorite activities. On this trip, Zach and Amelia have started to play together. Zach and Amelia will play chase around the table together, and Zach will help lift Amelia up slides and other things she can't get up.

In Tori news, I'll respect her privacy and skip this section.

In Zach news, he can now ride his "big bicycle" all by himself. After Kindie time, biking with Dad is Zach's favorite activity, which I very much enjoy as well. We got to have our first parent teacher conference, and we discovered Zach is smart, funny, but isn't really interested in doing what the teacher wants. Sounds exactly like his father.

In Amelia news, she's growing up fast, and has so much personality for a one and a half year old. I've got a full Amelia post in the works, so I'll keep this short.

In Igor news, I'm on week 2 of a 3 week vacation. This vacation I've realized when I take time off, it's usually not what people call vacation, but instead it's "low key personal/professional development days", or PD Days for short. I'm using these PD days to build some business and empathy skills. Even though I'm deliberately not focusing on technology, I wrote a small Apple game to help Zach do his homework.

Conversations with Zach:

I picked Zach up from school, and this was what he said to his kindergarten teacher on the way out the door: 
Z: Excuse me, I have two questions
Teacher: Yes Zach
Z: One  -  Why did we not get free choice today?
Z: Two - Why was our recess so long?
Teacher: ... explanation ...

On Feelings
I: Do you remember the time on the train when you spilled the water?
Z: Dont' talk about that it makes me sad.
I: What do you mean makes you sad? 
Z: Don't talk about it, it doesn't make me happy. 
I: It's OK that some stuff makes you sad. 
Z: Lets talk about the other thing, the thing that makes me happy. 
I: What's that? 
Z: You know, the thing about the Kindie you said you appreciated.
I: That you shared Kindie? 
Z: Yeah that. 
I: That's great, I like it when you share. 
Z: I was going to share the other day, but I couldn't because you hadn't put the game on Kindie.
I: I see, OK. 
Z: So, to make me happy, and you appreciate, you'll need to put a game on Kindie.

On brains
I: Sorry buddy, I don't remember that
Z: Dad, your'e old, you should get a new brain.
I: But if I get a new brain won't I forget you? 
Z: No, you won't forget me, or you'll remember me right away.

On Acceptance
Z: I can't wait to get to heaven
I: Well, not everyone believes in heaven. 
Z: Yeah, why's that? 
Z: OH I know, because some people believe in different things. 
I: Yeah, that's right
Z: Yeah, like some people, like me, like apple pies. Some people, like you, like chicken pie.
I: Exactly.

On Alexa (Our Amazon Echo):
Igor: Mom tries really hard to make you happy.
Zach: Remember when you bought Alexa, and how that made me happy? 
Igor: Yeah, I remember
Zach: See dad, sometimes buying stuff does make you happy.
Igor: Hym, well it's different because, Alexa's kind of a person.
ALEXA: Sorry,  I don't understand what you mean. 
Z: Yeah, well sometimes Alexa's annoying too.

Zach was supposed to stop watching Kindie, and go to bed when the timer went off:
... Timer goes off ...
I: Zach  - aren't you done watching Kindie? 
Z: Well, the timer went off, but Amelia needed to sleep 
Z: so I didn't want to stop and wake her up.
I: Lets go to bed.
Z: Hey, stop that, I'm not done yet.

On fairness:
Z: Hey, how come you got a handful of chips, and I only gone one? 
I: Well, because you were sitting around watching TV. 
Z: What does TV have to do with anything?

Zach in the kitchen naked getting something out of the fridge:
I: Hym, Zach are you missing something? 
Z: Yup, clothes
I: Uh, aren't you cold in the fridge
Z: Nope, I'm a polar bear - I don't get cold

On healthy eating: 
Z: Dad, you should have a health breakfast. 
I: Sure, like what? 
Z: Apples ,they're healthy. 
I: Yup, they are. 
... Two minutes pass ...
Z: You're welcome for the good advice.

I was trying to get Zach to read the numbers I was drawing on a page, and accidently drew on Zach's hand.
... I draw 19 ...
I: Zach what number is that? 
Z: 12
I: Zach, READ the number, you know better.
Z: I can't answer hard questions because most of my brain is trying to keep my hand calm.
I: Laughing.
Z: Do you have a funny journal? If so, you can write down all the funny things I write

Have a great week and remember, Ashland has some snow, which rhymes with pistachio - ZiaT

entry.title: Week 288: Happy Halloween.
entry.content:
This week I have lots of great Zach conversations, enjoy!

Friday was an awesome day. Let me remind myself why so I can savor this experience for years to come.

I left work early to see Zach enjoying Halloween in his Kindergarten class. It was awesome. I got to see Zach acting normally at school. Simple stuff like seeing Zach writing his letters, and raising his hand so the teacher would help him, was awesome - put a tear in my eye. After 30 minutes of "normal class time" the kids all dressed up in their costumes.

As one of the few Dad's present at the school, I got to help all the boys get dressed in their costumes. Up until this year, Halloween was mostly about me as a dude in costume, but now Halloween is about me as a useful father. Felt really good.

Next up, the kids performed a little presentation of "Super Mario Brothers" and "Thriller". Awesome!

Next up we brought Zach home, then I headed to the gym to hit my weight pledge. That was hard, but as a testament to my will power, I got it done, marking 23 months of consecutive weight pledges.

After hitting my weight pledge and rehydrating, I came home to find Tori had made a fantastic meal of Broccoli Beef. It was delicious. After dinner we went downstairs to watch a family movie. The movie was Chicken run, which my goto "first date movie".

While watching the movie, I was thinking I used to use this movie to find a women to start a family with, and now, I've found that women, have a family, and life is awesome.

With movie done, I had to pick up the car at the mechanic. After waiting 5 minutes, my Uber arrived, and I took the 6$ Uber ride to the mechanic to pick up the car. I love living in a central spot in the city, and every time I take an Uber it reminds me why I love my house.

Finally, coming home after a long day, Tori was making the kids a before bed snack of one of our favorite foods - dumplings.

Lastly, we put the kids to bed, and I went to bed with a huge smile on my face.

In other news

In house news, not a lot of progress, the house is in maintenance mode as we focus on other priorities.

In family events, Tori is making sure we get at least one, if not two adventures per weekend.

In Tori news, I'll respect her privacy and skip this section.

In Zach news, Zach's learning to write his letters, and he's having much more grown up conversations, this week I'll share a bunch of those conversations.

In Amelia news, it's amazing how many "girl behaviors" she has. She likes to play with dolls, she likes brushing their hair, and she likes to give you hugs and kisses. It's adorable. Amelia shares a lot of behaviors with Tori, but she has my desire to be a harmonica player.  Earlier this week we paraded around the block with me playing the triangle and Amelia playing harmonica - Adorable (well maybe annoying for our neighbors)

In Igor news, I'm feeling incredibly grateful. I dunno if it's the biking, healthy eating, meditation, the "five minute a day gratefulness" journal, or trying to practice empathy, but what ever it is, it feels great. I look forward to keeping it up:

Conversations with Zach:

Zach wasn't playing with the kids from kindergarten:
I: Zach, why aren't you paying with the kids from kindergarten? 
Z: Well, because I know,  you'll embarrass me? 
I: What? Dude, you have no idea. Give it a few years, then you'll really be embarrassed.

On Taxes:
Z: What are taxes? 
I: Hym, that's complicated. Lets see.
I: Do you know, police and roads?
Z: Yup
I: Well, who do you think pays for them? 
Z: I know, the government.
I: That's right, now how do you think the government pays for stuff? 
Z: Easy, they sell stuff. 
I: Not quite, they charge taxes, so that means when you buy something for a dollar you pay 10 cents in taxes.
Z: Hym, that's crazy.
I: Yeah, it's really crazy. 
Z: Wouldn't it be weird if they charged tax for Taxis.
I: They do charge tax for taxis.
Z: That's crazy. That'd be like charging taxes for houses. 
I: Yup, they charge taxes for houses too.

While peeing together: 
Z: Boy, you have a hairy penis. 
I: Yeah, when you grow up you get hair on your penis. 
 
Z: You shouldn't have got your penis cover cut off, because your penis is gross.


It's not just Zach who say's fun things about his privates We met a girl from Zach's class biking with her Mom:

Little Girl: Zach, hey, it's Zach from class.
I: Oh you guys are out riding your bike? 
Mom: Yeah, we're just out practicing.
Little girl:   We were riding, but then I hit the pedals and broke my vagina.
Mom: Hand face plant.

On Mounties: 
Z: Do you know in canada they call police mounties.
I: Yup.
Z: Do you know mounties wear red coats.
I: Yup.
Z: Do you know mounties ride horses.
I: Yup, where am I from? 
Z: Oh yeah, canada, that's right.
I: Now, what do you think is faster, cars or horses?
Z: Lets see, cars.
I: Alright, so how do you think mounties catch bad guys? 
Z: Hym, let me think about that.. Oh I know, they drive cars too. 
I: Exactly - good thinking!

On Moms:
Z: Dad, can I borrow money to get a new mom?
I: Where would you get a new mom? 
Z: At the Mom store? 
I: What would you want in a new mommy? 
Z: I'd want her to be less annoying.
I: Sorry, buddy we've already got the best mommy ever.
Z: Oh yeah!

Have a great week and remember, Don't be wasteful, Be Grateful - ZiaT

entry.title: Week 286: Biking, Biking, Biking.
entry.content:
It's been a few weeks since I've written, and there has been lots of activity. The things that come to mind are Canadian thanksgiving and Biking.

Thanksgiving was great. We rented a house that was designed for kids with secret passages and slides in the walls. It was great to catch up with my old friends almost all of which have two kids. It's amazing to think that know many of the people there have known each other for 13 years, and some for 18 years. Wow. Unfortunately, A few hours after Thanksgiving dinner I got food poisoning. I guess the silver lining was I didn't have to pay for the calories since I puked them out.

Biking has been amazing. I love biking, and as I predicted Zach has followed my lead and loves biking now as well. Getting to riding with my son, that's a dream come true.

In other news

In house news, not a lot of progress, the house is in maintenance mode as we focus on other priorities over the last few weeks. One thing I'll say about the house, now that I'm older, and get colder I don't mind spending money on heating the house. So now we tend to keep furnace on more often and space heaters in cold corners. I guess that means I'm getting older and wiser.

In family events, Tori is making sure we get at least one, if not two adventures per weekend. Since the weather has been great, we've been going on hikes (Interlaken, Tiger mountain) and farms. Sometimes when we go on these adventures I'm disengaged, and don't really enjoy them. But when I think like the Kids, and actually put my heart into playing, it's a blast.

In Tori news, I'll respect her privacy and skip this section.

In Zach news, Zach is learning to read, and loves his bicycle. In the evenings, Zach is pushing me to go biking with him, which we both really enjoy. It's so satisfying to see Zach riding, and talking about the importance of practicing. I'm getting used to it now, but it put a tear in my eye when he started. Zach is also learning to read. It's amazing how quickly Zach develops these skills, just a few weeks ago he only knew a few letters, but now he knows most of the letters. He still has trouble with letters that can be upside like n being an upside down u, but otherwise, he's basically got the alphabet. Watching him read is also amazing.

In Amelia news, adorable as usual. Amelia has always given excellent hugs, but now she's learned to kiss too. She gets her face near yours and makes a smacking sound. She hasn't realized her lips have to touch your cheek, but it's adorable. Amelia is also starting to get mad at you if you don't give her what she wants. Yesterday, she brought me her shoes because she wanted to go for a walk, and I wanted to eat my dinner. I put Amelia on the chair and told her she'd need to eat - she responded by breaking out into tears, and storming off to be with her mother. I guess anger/disappointment was bound to appear eventually - I guess now is as good a time as any.

In Igor news, my habits are still going strong. I'll have to make sure the next time I go on vacation, I don't give up on my habits. The biggest change for me is biking. Having this folding bike is awesome. I can always carry it with me, and if I'm getting a cab, or grabbing a ride with a friend I can just throw the folded bike in the trunk without thinking about it. It used to be, I did most of my commute on the bus, only riding a few minutes on either side of the bus route. This week I've started biking more of the commute (I still need a bus to get across the 520 bridge) and I'm really enjoying it. It's so nice to get my heart pumping before I get to work, and to clear my head on the way home. Bike On!

Conversations with Zach:

Zach once he figured out to start riding without a push: 
Z: Dad, I'll teach you, see you start kicking one foot, while your other foot is on the pedal, then you can go.

The first time Zach was comfortably riding:
Z: Dad can I get some advice? 
I: Sure.
Z: What's more fun, bike riding or watching Kindie? 
I: That's easy - bike riding.
Z: Yeah. This is awesome.

One of the first times Zach and I were riding, it started raining so we needed to go home: 
I: Well, it's raining lets stop and head home.
Z: No this is the only time we're riding, we should really enjoy it. 
I: This isn't the only time we ride, we can do it every day. 
Z: Well, we should still enjoy this bike ride as long as we can.

One of the ideas I drill into Zach is you'll get good at anything you practice. It is so satisfying to hear Zach remind me of that:
Z: If you practice stuff you get very good at stuff.

Zach decided he was a Bike Dr: 
Z: I'm a bike Scientist
I: Can you tell me about being a bike dr
Z: No dad, not a bike dr, a bike scientist
I: I see, what do bike scientists do? 
Z: Well the do very important stuff, sometimes they study bikes. 
Z: Well sometimes they get office
Z: Sometimes they even have to be strict about words.
I: Huh.
Z: Yeah, really strict about words

Have a great week and remember, Ride your bike, take a hike, family like! - ZiaT

entry.title: Zach's first poetry
entry.content:
Dictated by Zachary himself:

Bonjour, Beunos Diaz
Chicken, Chicken, chicken
ladder, ladder, cow, cow
The cow was having a nice day
when the chickens made him mad mad mad
The cows go roar, roar, roar, roar
They scream and the chickens die
Bananana Bananas monkey Monkey
It's time to start with a new angle!
Bananas, Bananas eat monkeys
Monkeys try to eat them to have a good life.
Chickens chickens now I fickens we are done!

entry.title: Get Biking - Again!
entry.content:
It's amazing how forgetful we are.  Back in 2012 I wrote:

It's funny how we forget what we want. One of the few life goals I've figured out is the desire to go bike touring.    For a guy that wants to go bike touring, do you know how much I rode in the last year? Almost Zero  miles - LAME.

If you see me, be sure to ask me the last time I went biking. If I don't answer the last few days kick me and remind me how much I love biking!

Excuses are as plentiful as grains of sand, and by late 2013, I'd mostly stopped riding. In late 2014, my bike was stolen, and I didn't care since I hadn't ridden my bike in so long.

A few weeks ago as I was trying to get Zach to ride, I decided I'd treat myself to one of my favorite "goofy ideas" - a folding bike.  I pulled the trigger and bought a Brompton, the Tesla of folding bikes, and I LOVE IT!

Since I've bought the bike, I've taken it to work every day, usually carrying it on the bus. When I take the bus the whole way, my bike ride is incredibly short. Even riding a few minutes a day, I get a lot of pleasure. In fact, biking gives me so much pleasure some times when I get to work early, I'll just ride around the underground parking lot because it's so fun.

Best of all, Zach seeing me on a bike, became more motivated to learn to ride. Yesterday Zach finally rode his bike himself without my assistance. With me riding my folding bike, and Zach on his training wheels free bike, Zach looked at me and asked "Dad, what's more fun bike, riding or playing on the tablet?"  I answered - "That's easy, bike riding", and Zach replied "I think so too".

If you see Zach or I, be sure to ask the last time we've been biking. If we don't answer the last few days,  kick us and remind us how much we love biking!

entry.title: Week 283AZ: Guilt Trips
entry.content:
I'm secure that I'm a good father, but the kids are learning to pull on my heart strings.

Amelia, barely able to talk, uses her capabilities to maximum capacity. When I'm not paying attention to her Amelia will walk up to me, and hug my leg. When I look down, she just looks at me with sad pitiful eyes till I pick her up.

Zach, having mastered speech and experimenting with emotional manipulation, says to me, "Dad, we do some father son time".

In other news

In house news, it's been a busy week, and the house is in maintenance mode as we focus on other priorities this week. Fall has arrived in Seattle which brings cold mornings and sunny afternoons.

In family events, we had some cool adventures. We went to a playspace which included trampolines and ballgun rooms. Zach and Amelia loved it, and Tori and I even spent some time bouncing around. We also went to the Luminata, which is a celebration of the fall equinox. The Luminata is a walk around greenlake in the dark with all sorts of lanterns, cool costumes, and entertaining characters.
Next year, I'll bring my torches. This week's family hike was at dash point, where we enjoyed the salt water beach, climbed up a brief hill, got to practice some juggling.

In Tori news, I'll respect her privacy and skip this section.

In Zach news, Zach is getting used to kindergarten. Even though he still claims not to enjoy it, he's getting into the groove. Every day, kindergarten sends home an assignment he's done. Every day, Zach proudly shows me the assignment. Sometimes it's a coloring, sometimes it's a book, but each time, he's very proud. Zach's also getting steadier on his bicycle. I still hold him, but he's going farther and farther, and now he can nail the start without much trouble.

In Amelia news, adorable as usual. This week, she's figured out that hugging my and Tori's leg gets her almost immediate attention. Amelia's learning how to use the word Hi, and for some reason she's more likely to say hi to a dog then a person. Amelia is also an amazing vegetable eater. She loves radishes, cauliflower, carrots, and everything else Dad lives off of when he's being super healthy.

In Igor news, my habits are holding. Waking up early, daily meditation and journal writing, runs every few days. It's great to be back at full productive capacity after a summer hiatus. I'm now in the final stretch of the month, meaning I'm on a super diet. Luckily, I'm getting better at the super diet, and it takes less will power and produces less foul mood then before. I also had this rather deep thought, that weeks aren't good or bad, there's just events, some of which are unexpected, that can take me closer and farther from my goals. None of these events should be good or bad, and they certainly shouldn't put me in a bad mood.

Conversations with Zach:

Zach on school:
I: What do you want to tell me about school? 
Z: Not a lot, I don't like school.
I: Why not? 
Z: I don't like school because I sit beside the projector, and it makes me all sweaty.

Zach had taken my juggling clubs, and was using them to walk:
Z: Dad, what are these called.
I: Clubs.
Z: No, the other wods.
I: Well sometimes people call them pins. 
Z: No Dad, the hospital word.
I: Oh, crutches.
Z: Yeah, I'm using crutches to walk.

Have a great week and remember, Sun shining, No whining - ZiaT

entry.title: Week 282AZ: Tear in my eye.
entry.content:
Thursday was Zach's first day of "public school" kindergarten. I'm not sure how big a deal this was for Zach, but it was very moving for me.

Tori sent me a photo of Zach at his kindergarten desk, I had to stop and wipe the tear from my eye.

The tear commemorated how much Zach, and all of our family, has grown and developed in the last five years.

In other news

In house news, it's been a buy week, and the house is in maintenance mode as we focus on other priorities this week.

In Tori news, I'll respect her privacy and skip this section.

In Zach news it's all kindergarten and Kindie.  Zach started kindergarten this week, and I imagine this will rock his world.

Kindie, Zach's tablet, has been banned for 3 weeks. As a consequence, Zach has evolved from a teenager class recluse, to an engaging young kindergartner. Zach being kindle free requires Tori and I to step up and provide a lot of extra energy, but it's worth it. We've had more conversations with Zach this week, then in some months. Zach's also been doing more activities, more reading, more bike riding, heck he even tried rock climbing.

In Amelia news, adorable as usual. Amelia started both Waldorf and Coop this week, and Amelia's getting used to the change. Amelia's learning new skills too, she started saying hi, dog, and possibly yes. I'm starting to take Amelia on bus and grocery store adventures, which Amelia is enjoying with her normal gusto.

In Igor news, it been busy, as I reestablish habits, and get into the fall groove. I restarted my meditation habit, and as Zach would say I'm "back on my diet". I'm excited that Magic class has restarted, and I'm looking forward to building a coin routine. So far, our fall schedule has had non stop family activities, and even though it's non-stop, it's worth it.

Conversations with Zach:

Tori puts Zach and Amelia to sleep in their room, while I sleep up stairs. Zach wanted to apply some punishments:
Z: Dad I ban you from my room. I'd ban mama but she doesn't have anywhere else to sleep.

Tori's frequently explaining to Zach voting and democracy, sometime it backfires
I: Zach, you're going to school tomorrow.
Z: I already decided I'm not going to school. 
Z: Mom doesn't want me to, and I don't want to, 
Z: so that's 2 to one we're not going.

I often tell Zach he needs to try to fall asleep for 10 minutes, before I'll come back in. For example in bed:
I: Zach, I've held your hand for 5 minutes, you need to try to go to bed. 
I: I'll be back in 10 minutes if your'e still awake

The next morning at breakfast Zach told me: 
Z: You told me you'd be back in 10 minutes.
Z: But you lied, you weren't back in 10 minutes.
Z: Then I snuck out, and I started whispering to mama.

Sometimes when I vegetate, I'll watch bad YouTube videos about silly things like medieval weapons. Because of Zach's Kindie vacation, Zach decided to watch said videos with me. The next day Zach said: 
I: Alright Zach, what should we do? 
Z: Dad, lets watch those weapon videos again.
I: Sigh.

And even though Zach is more sharing then before, he doesn't always divulge the details: 
I: Zach, What do you want to tell me about school? 
Z: Not a lot, because I don't look school.
Have a great week and remember, Every Week, Every Day. Do the work, resistance slay -ZiaT

entry.title: Week 281AZ: Where did Oliver go?
entry.content:
The mild panic in the woman's voice interrupted my conversation with my neighbor. I was enjoying Tori's lettuce wraps at the neighborhood block party while discussing the difficulties in finding a good plumber when I realized I didn't know where Amelia was.

The situation rushed back to me, Tori was at a doctors appointment while I brought the kids to the block party. Amelia came outside with me an hour ago, and I'd been watching her, but then I stopped paying attention during an animated discussion of sewer systems.

A mild fear helped me focus on the task at hand, I scanned the area. The street was blocked off from traffic, and kids and adults were everywhere. Zach had brought all his toys out of the house and onto the sidewalk, hoping a kid would come out and ask to play with him.  Our house door was open, but I doubted Amelia would have gone back in the house.

As rational panic mounted, I looked everywhere. My panic disintegrated when I saw Amelia. She was carrying her toy medical kit toward a bunch of teenage girls. The teenagers found this adorable and giggled as they played with Amelia and her toys.  With a sigh of relief , I had one last thought before returning to the conversation on pipes.

Zach and Amelia's had very different strategies to make friends. Zach brought out his toys and hoped they would lure other children to him.  While Zach was playing alone, trying to hide his attempts to bait the other kids with his toys, Amelia just grabbed her toys and went to the other kids who were playing.    Amelia was able to get someone to play with her immediately.  Zach, on the other hand took more time to hook the children, but when they came he had some power over them.   Fascinating.

Before we go on, and before you complain to your loves ones that I'm unfit for fatherhood , I assure this story was dramatized to make it more exciting.


In other news

In house news we went camping for labor day, and bought ourselves a giant tent. Having an 8 person tent is wonderful. It feels like we're on safari.  Also, I'm 99% sure we've chosen our porch contractor and once we get the final numbers in we should be ready to go.  It blows my mind that fixing our porch will cost more then adding a bathroom and office to the basement. But, since there are no alternatives it's time to get it done.

In Tori news, I'll respect her privacy and skip this section.

In Zach news, Zach is learning to ride without training wheels. We're getting closer, I predict only a few more rides before Zach can ride without a hunched over dad stuck to the back of his bike. Cognitively, Zach is getting deeper concepts. He understands the notions of best friends, and is starting to find kisses (even from his Dad) icky. Cooler still, as we read stories (now we're reading chapter books), Zach is asking the same questions as the boys and girls in the story. Very fun to watch.

In Amelia news, she's adorable. She can now walk quickly, and the repitoire of things she wants includes ice cream and cookies.  Her communication is now richer, she will now point at something she wants, and if you say no, she'll cry immediately warning you that something are not negotiable. Amelia is also incredibly independent and inquisitive. I have to be very careful to watch her closely or she'll wander off doing something she enjoys with no care of what her father is doing.

In Igor news. It's been a good week. Lots of stuff is coming together at work, and I'm getting back on my habits like writing Zach week posts.

Conversations with Zach:

I think this section is going to evolve, perhaps it'll be a weekly interview with Zach.  For this week, Zach wanted to record a song to play in the song. I'll warn you it's rater PT for potty talk.






Have a great week and remember, Don't procrastinate, instigate  - ZiaT

entry.title: Zach Week: July 2015 - Parental Leave Edition
entry.content:
Pictures and editing is coming.

Synopsis

July 2015, was my parental leave! It was wonderful, with many things to be grateful for:
  • Tori for planning, co-ordinating, and executing, a multi part, tightly packed vacation with several families.
  • Yelena and Justin, who flew five hours to Vancouver so our families got to spend time together.
  • Samantha who showed Zach and Amelia what it means to be an amazing older cousin.
  • Maureen and Brian, who drove five hours to hang out with us on the Oregon coast.
  • Long car rides with Zach quiet and Amelia asleep giving Tori and I opportunity for meaningful conversations.
  • Justin and Tori for watching the kids so Yelena and I could have grown up in person chats
  • The west coast's perfect weather, letting us spend 30 days without needing a jacket.
  • Amelia going from "toddling" to walking when I could watch the entire process.
  • Melissa, our friend, for teaching me how to make Zach comfortable floating with a life jacket. As a result Zach had his first fear free swimming experience.
  • Our vacation house for having "Charlie and the chocolate factory". This is the first chapter book Zach and I enjoyed together.
  • Microsoft for giving me enough time off work, that if you asked me what I did for a living it'd take me at least a minute to remember.
  • Seattle for being an amazing city with so many fun things to do.
  • A cool traveling family who inspired me to have an abundance mindset, and reinvigorated my sense of adventure.
I learned a bunch during this vacation (which I suspect I learn and ignore every vacation):
  • It's not where you go, but who you go with. Have other families with kids.
  • Force myself to wake up early to make time for myself, and anchor my will power.
  • Make time and will power to keep up my healthy habits and discipline.
  • Have a game plan with Tori about how we can both get times for ourselves, and make time for each other.
  • Start the vacation with immersive activities that help me forget work, and be present.

Details

Starting Slow in Seattle

The first two weeks of our vacation started with leisure activities in Seattle. During this time I woke up early, and maintained my habits. We did many festivals, activities, and saw many Seattle sights. The science center, the dragon festival, trips to Seattle's water parks, and even a quick paddle in our canoe, to give a flavor of our Seattle adventures.

The second two weeks of vacation got crazy...

Commencing Camping

Our first activity was camping with the Waldorf kindergarten families. We ended up at Razor state park in a newly constructed group camp site. It was awesome watching Zach interact with all his friends from kindergarten. Razor state park is on a glacial river, and my dips into the river resulted in an uncontrollable scream of shock as I waddled into the snow melt. We didn't bring Zach's bike so while the other kids where biking, Zach was the border guard at the group campsite gate, making sure only people in our party could go to, or from the bathrooms.

Oregon's Ocean

After Razor state park, we packed up the car and headed to the Oregon coast. We rented a house on the Ocean in a cute town called Gearhart (beside Seaside, OR). Maureen and Brian came up to join us in the house and we had a great time hanging out. At this house we found Charlie and chocolate factory and had a wonderful time reading it. I also got a few hours to hang out on the ocean by myself. The ocean, as always, is amazing.

One of our trips to the ocean was blocked by a herd of grazing elk. Even though we missed that trip to the beach, it was worth it to get so close to such huge wild animals. We also got to see the Tillamook diary. The Tillamook diary lets you watch cheese product, and have huge cones of ice cream. Zach and I did both activities greatly enjoyed them. Zach enjoyed the ice ream more, while I enjoyed the tour more.

Vancouver Voyages

After Ocean shores, we headed to Vancouver Canada to meet up with my sister's family who was flying in. Our first Vancouver excitement happened at the border. We warned Zach to be respectful, but I guess that's subjective: 
Border Guard: How many people in the car? 
Igor: Four
Border Gaurd: Sir, I'm going to need you to roll down the window
Igor: Sure
Zach: Why do you need to have the window down?
Border Guard: So I can count the number of people in the car. 
Zach: Well that's silly even I can count to four.
Border Guard: Well sir, the windows are tinted so it's hard to see in.
Zach: I can count for you then: one, two, three, four.

Luckily, we were going into Canada and border guard was friendly and let us continue without troubles.

Vancouver was a whirlwind of adventures, wonderful cheap food, and train rides at Stanley park.

Yelena and Co where staying at the entrance to Stanley park, so we got to spend a tonne of time downtown Vancouver. Sammy was an amazing cousin and spent a bunch of time being patient and playing with Zach - not an easy task. Sammy also got to spend some time with Amelia, which Amelia really enjoyed.

Zach loves trains, so we bought an annual pass for Zach and Sam. I don't recall how many train rides we did, but I suspect it was over 30. Sammy was a great sport and did a bunch of train rides with Zach so Yelena and I didn't have to.

Blunder Brings Bonus

Two days before we were supposed to return to Seattle, we found out we messed up our rental house booking, and our house rental would finish a day before we originally planned. This sucked because Zach was having a great time with Sammy, and I was loving the time with my sister and brother in law. Tori and I brainstormed, and decided Tori and Amelia would go home a day early, while Zach and I would book a a hotel, and then come home on the train.

The extra day let Zach and I cram in a bunch of extra adventures. Most importantly, we got an extra day and a half with sister, brother and law and niece. In this day and a half we saw the festival of light,a firework display so grand they shut down downtown Vancouver so people can walk in the streets. We got to eat at one of the many Vancouver raman restaurants that always has a line regardless of when you come. We also got to go swimming at Kitsalano, an amazing Vancouver outdoor salt water pool. We also got to spend a night in a downtown hotel - Zach's first time, and possibly my second. Lastly, we got to take the train from Vancouver to Seattle, but that is an adventure unto itself.

Train Time

As I prepared to take the train back to Settle, my sister asked me if I had a letter from Tori saying I was allowed to cross the border with Zach. Of course I didn't :) so I became anxious that I would be detained at the border unable to return home. As a result of this anxiety, I ended up going to the train station several hours early, fearing a prolonged interrogation.

As is usually the case, the worry was completely unfounded. We couldn't go through the US customs till an hour before the train left. Going through customs took exactly 1 minute. The conversation went like this:
Border Gaurd to Me: Passports
Border Gaurd to Zach: What's your name. 
Zach: Silence, hiding behind my leg.
Igor: This is Zach.
Border Gaurd to Zach: Who is this man? 
Zach: My Dad.
There is a silver lining to most events, and because we got to the train station two hours early we met an inspirational family. That's an adventure that I wrote up already here.

Finally Finishing - Kanascat Palmer

At this point, exhausted we headed off to the last phase of our adventure - Yurt camping at Kanscat palmer, a campground an hour from Seattle.

Honestly, We were an inch from canceling this leg of the trip as we were exhausted, but we wanted to see our friends at the camp site so we pushed through. I'm grateful we went because this is where we learned how to make Zach comfortable swimming. Melissa Jonas used to teach swimming and put Zach in a life jacket and explained floating to him. Zach loved it, and we did some swimming in the life jacket for the first time ever.

Thank you to everyone who made this an amazing adventure!

ZiaT

link.title: Zach Week: July 2015 - Parental Leave Edition

entry.title: Trust the universe, or so say traveling families.
entry.content:
