Zach and I joined a family with a 4, 6, and 8 year old on the train from Vancouver to Seattle. The family had just flown into Vancouver from England.

The other families next stop was Everett where they'd buy an RV to drive up and down the west coast before selling it 6 months later in Los Angeles.

After selling the RV they were flying to Costa Rica, to have a repeat performance in south america.
I asked the parents if they had more detailed plans. They laughed and said, well they were going to home school, and drive at night smile emoticon

I was totally inspired, and offered to lend them my prime card for the few days they were in the puget sound. Tori and I were leaving to go camping, so I asked where I could meet them the next day (today), and they said the RV dealership.

I expected there could be some trouble finding each other, but if they trusted the universe, I decided I would too.

When I arrived at the RV dealership, they were nowhere to be found. I spent an hour at the RV dealership learning about the different kind of RVs, hoping my inspiring family would return my call or text. Damn universe.

Rather deflated, an hour later there was no family, so I decided to leave. As soon as I pulled out of the RV lot, a bus appeared and out popped a mom dad, and 3 kids toting back packs with stuffed animals hanging off each backpack.

I pulled over, handed them my prime card, and have had a huge smile on my face ever since.

Trust the universe.

link.title: Trust the universe, or so say traveling families.

entry.title: Live from Seattle: Zach Dvorkin
entry.content:
Zach made up this impromptu magic trick while we rode the bus. I made him perform it to a stranger and he nailed. The next morning we recorded it for posterity.

After recording the magic trick video. Zach wanted to create a public service announcement.

Have a great day!

entry.title: Week 270AZ: Medieval puppet shows
entry.content:
At noon on Saturday, we arrived at a little medieval festival. Tori warned it would be small, but 20 minutes later, at 12:20, we were back at the gate as we'd seen everything there was to see. I looked at the schedule, and saw they had a puppet show at 12:30, and declared to everyone I wanted to check it out. Zach was adamantly against it.

The kids were hungry so we decided to eat our lunch picnic first, and if we got lucky we could pop back in and catch the tail of the puppet show.

The picnic was great, Tori packed sandwiches for her and the kids and broccoli for me. We sat in the parking lot, and on the back of the car, enjoying our meal, while other families commented on how clever we were for having brought a picnic.

At 12:55, Zach and I jogged back into the festival and headed over to the puppet show. Zach loved it! He loved it so much he wanted to wait for the next showing. I looked it up, the next show wasn't for two more hours.

Zach didn't care, he wanted to stay till the puppet show, and he just stuck around and toughed it out. If it was up to me, I'd have left, but not Zach, he toughed it out.
Two hours later, Zach watched, and really enjoyed his puppet show, and I learned a valuable lesson. If you want something, pay the price, and you can often get it.

In other news

In house news, refi is done, and we want to get our porch done this summer. The city tells us we don't get many choices so we'll talk to this contractor, and see what he tells us for prices. I should also mention our garden. Our black berries and rasberries are fantastic, and in full bloom. The only downside is that I need to be eating extremely low calories so that I can meet my weight goals, and I really want to eat those fresh berries.

In Tori news, I'll respect her privacy and skip this section.

In Zach news he's now in CDSA, done circus for the summer, and enjoys flying his helicopter. At CDSA, Zach's an expert, no muss or fuss about drop off or pickup, he knows the gig, and he's good at it. We decided to take circus class of this summer as we'll be out so many weeks. I was totally proud at the last week of Zach's circus school, because he did so well. In the past, Zach wouldn't pay attention, and just wasn't doing a great job. This year, Zach was paying a tonne of attention, trying hard, and listening to the teacher. Zach -- I'm totally proud of you. Lastly, at a yard sale, Zach got a remote control helicopter, and we like to fly it around. I was very impressed, Zach was able to fly the copter pretty well on his first try - I guess all that time with the video games has a few benefits.

In Amelia news, she's now able to walk a few steps. It's totally cute, and like Zach, she enjoys walking up and down the neighbor's steps. I'm looking forward to getting more time with her while I'm on my parental leave.

In Igor news, this month's weight pledge is extra hard. I'm not sure what is different, but I'm really having a hard time dropping the weight, probably I'm getting cocky from so many easy months in a row. My parental leave starts mid next week, and I'm really looking forward to it. I haven't figured out what I want to get done while I'm on parental leave, but I'm pretty sure if I don't make a list, it won't happen.

Conversations with Zach

Zach threw some garbage on the ground:
I: Zach, don't through that on the ground, it's littering. 
Z: No dad, it's not litter, it's garbage treasure.

In what I thought was Zach following the letter, not the spirit of the law, Zach responded to Tori asking him to put on his underpants by putting them on outside his pants. Luckily Zach clarified his reasoning: 
Z: Do you know why I'm wearing a pair of underpants outside my pants? 
I: Nope, why? 
Z: Well, if I get pee on my underpants, I'll have a spare pair I can put on. 
I: Good thinking kid.

Today, Zach and I wanted to fly our chopper, but it was windy out. 
I: Hey buddy, it's pretty windy out I dunno if we can fly.
Z: Dad, don't you know that old saying? 
I: What old saying? 
Z: You know, you've got to try if you want to do something. 
I: Well said Zach, well said.

Have a great week and Remember- One month off don't go soft- ZiaT.

entry.title: Week 268AZ: No Screens after dinner
entry.content:
Glancing into the living room at 6pm, Tori saw two lumps on the couch. Both lumps had glowing screens, the left lump was Zach on his Kindie, and the right lump was Igor on his Surface.

Dinner’s ready - screens as done for the night Yelled Tori as she gave the bigger lumps a dirty look.

This was the first night of no screens after dinner rule and it was awesome. With nothing to distract our attention, Zach and I went to the school where we played catch with a bouncy ball.

Sure, Zach can’t really catch, and either can I. But, we got to chase the ball around which was some great exercise. We even lost the ball under a building and had to run home to get a broom to dislodge the hiding ball.

Yup, no screens after dinner is awesome.

In other news

In house news, we’re almost done our second refi. This refi we’re switching to a 30 year and taking some more money out. The reasoning for the 30 year is that the interest is low and I’d rather have the equity for higher ROI investments and have better cash flow if it becomes necessary. The reasoning for taking more money out of the mortgage is that we’ll be adding much more equity to the house when we do the kitchen remodel and I’d rather not have all our savings tied up in the house.

In Igor news, lots of turbulence with my project at work around funding. Lack of clarity can be crippling , but when a leader lacks clarity they have to establish principles and move forward on those principles. I decided my principle is establish customer demand. Customer demand leads to funding, and all good things come from customer demand. When work is turbulent it’s easy to forget the habits that keep me healthy (I should build a product around that :)), and I’ve been forgetting often. So now I’m reminding myself to get running, get meditating and get eating healthily.

In Amelia news, she had a high fever, but it cleared after a few days and she is back to Normal, with a few more teeth. Amelia can now teeter if you hold one of her hands and encourage her to walk with you. Amelia also has a few suspiciously English sounds. For example, she’ll often point and make a sound like ‘What’s that”. The adult plays What’s That, by picking up every possible object until Amelia gets the object she wants.

In Zach news, he has finished Waldorf kindergarten. I think it was an emotional experience for him, even though he wouldn’t admit it. I’ll put in some of our conversations in the conversation section. Since Amelia and Tori were at Dr.’s for a brutual high fever, I got to take Zach to his last day of school picnic. Zach doesn’t like talking about or showing his feelings but he has them. For example,
Zach got hit with a stick, and pulled his hat over his face (so I couldn’t see him), and screamed at me, “Get away from me”, and kept yelling that at me if I tried to get close to him. Looks like Zach will be a push you away if he’s feeling pain personality.

Conversations with Zach

While Driving in the car: 
Z: Is sammy in your family?
I: Yup
Z: Hym, if she's in your family, and I'm in your family, then she's in my family.

Zach has a great memory, long ago we had a power outage, here’s Zach’s recollection: 
Z: Do you remember that time to electricity was out at the Deli
I: Yup
Z:  That was so mean of the electricity to be off, 
Z: It made me not get my regular order.

On the last day of School, I saw Zach turn to the Kindergarten teacher ,Mary , who leaned down and hugged him. Later the teacher told me the conversation
Zach: Hey Teacher Mary
Mary: Yes, Mr. Zach. 
Zach: I bet you'll miss me since I was so messy.  
Mary: No - I'll miss you since you were such a sweet boy.

As we drove back from the last day of school we listened to the radio: 
Z: Can you understand what that song is about ? 
I: You she's saying she cant' stop thinking about you.
Z: Hey, that's weird I don't want her thinking about me. 
I: Well, she's not thinking about you, she's singing about someone she loves, 
Z: Hym, I kind of love Quinn and Nash

Zach’s become quite interested in languages and uses this knowledge wisely: 
I: Zach, you've watched too much TV, you're done. 
Z:  Dad can you read Chinese? 
I: Nope
== Zach gets his notebook of scribbles == 
Z: Well this drawing is in Chinese, it says I can watch more TV.

Have a great week, and remember - be a geek, enjoy your week - ZiaT

entry.title: Week 267Az: How long have you been alive?
entry.content:
As so frequently occurs it's been a few weeks since I blogged. The excuses are always the same, something comes up, I think I'll do it tomorrow, and tomorrow never comes. The excuses are always disguised as good intentions. You know, I'll write a "mother's day special" post, or I won't do the post justice as I don't have enough time, so I'll write it up tomorrow.

37 years I answered Zach when he asked me about my birthday. I'm not big into birthdays, but this year we accidently went to wild waves for my birthday. Wild waves is a big amusement park (think Canada's Wonder Land for my northern blog readers) that's 30 minutes away from our house. As silly as this sounds it didn't occur to me that when going to Wild Waves we should bring swim suits and towels. The name "wild waves", and the pictures of the many water slides, simply didn't click. Even without the water paraphernalia, there was lots to do. Lots of rides for the kids. There were even a few rides that Zach and Amelia were able to do together. Zach wasn't thrilled by the arrangement, but Amelia thought it was a hoot.

In other news

In house news, a lot of excitement centered on the plumbing and the stove. The drain we added to our basement to help us if we had a leak backed up, and so we had to pay to have it fixed. Of course, the estimate started at 5,000, but once we had the side yard dug up, the contractors told us it would cost us 9,000. Not much you can do but get it fixed. Here's hoping our basement flooding troubles are done -- but only rain will tell us. On the stove front, years ago our stove started shooting fire balls, so we threw it away. At the time a friend lent us a stove to hold us over till we got a new stove. 3 years later, we had never gotten a new stove, and our friend needed their stove back. We went the last few weeks without a stove, but now we have a used gas stove. A used gas stove was a compromise between Tori and I. I figured I really wanted gas (and I plumbed the kitchen for it), and tori figured she wouldn't, so we got a used gas stove in case we didn't like it, we wouldn't be out that much money.

In Tori news, I'll respect her privacy and skip this section.

In Zach news, we've instituted an "if you want to watch cartoons, you'll need to earn them rule". I've never seen such useful behaviors out of Zach until he's working for cartoons. He can make his bed, clean up outside, and even put his half eaten lunch in tupper ware. His abilities is exceeding my own. Zach's also getting into magic. Just yesterday he picked y pack of cards out of my pocket, and told me -tada, look what I made appear. Lastly, an amazing thing about Zach is his ability to wait for something he wants. At the amusement park, he wanted to sit at the front of the train, but someone else got the front of the train, so he let everyone else go ahead of him, so he could sit in the front of the train next time. Pretty impressive kid - that kind of delayed gratification will pay off big time!

In Amelia news, she is amazing, and so different from Zach. She loves driving her car, and standing on her musical chair (which baba bought). She's brave too, she will ride the rides at amusement parks with her brother, and even after he leaves, she doesn't mind being there on her own. She's very independent. There are times she wants me to carry her, and she'll crawl into my lap, but many times she doesn't want to be picked up, and demands I put her back down.

In Igor news, it has been a few crazy weeks at work. My project, Smile, become quite successful, and I took some time to make sure everything was done correctly before adding more users, this took more time than expected but was worth it. At the same time, there were lots of reorganizations at work. Reorganizations make it tricky to know what should be prioritized, and whom you should work with, so it takes time to deal with that. Finally, after 13 years of working as an engineer, I finally realized I need to act like "a regular person" when talking to customers. I used to talk like an engineer, and that's not appropriate with customers as that's not what they are expecting. I'm amazed at the difference in people's response. I'm quite knowledgeable in my field, but haven't been representing that knowledge when talking with others till this week. Now that I'm projecting the knowledge I've acquired, it's a very large difference in my interactions. It feels weird to behave differently, but that's to be expected, and after a while, it'll feel natural I'm sure. On the personal front, I'm learning coin magic, and getting a chance to chat with my cousin Sveta. So far, I can do one coin trick, and I've pulled it off a few times, it's not automatic yet, but it's coming. Sveta is my cousin, she's a bit older than me, which makes it fun to hear her stories, and share our lives together.

Conversations with Zach

On a very hot day: 
Z: I'm mad at the sun.
I: Why's that?
Z: Because he made me hot and sweaty
I: Oh, well what are you going to do about it?
Z: I'm going to go in a rocket ship with a bomb, and blow it up.

At a spicy teriyaki place: 
Z: Don't eat that it's really spicy
I: Yeah, I wonder why your mom eats such spicy stuff
Z: Well, it's good for her body
I: How is it good for her body?
Z: I don't remember I'll have to ask her

Have a great day and remember - If you make excuses, then procrastination you'll introduces, and before you know it, nothing gets done, and you'll have no fun -- ZaiT.

link.title: Week 267Az: How long have you been alive?

entry.title: Week 262AZ: Paying attention at circus school
entry.content:
I write these blog posts while Zach does circus school. Usually I don't pay attention to Zach, and often Zach doesn't pay attention in class. Today I was paying attention, and so was Zach. It brings me pride and pleasure to see Zach doing the exercises with the other students, listening to the teacher, and being generally skilled.

In other news

In house news, Tori has rearranged the basement, and it now looks like a living room. I rejiggered my office so I have a nice view of the window, and I enjoy that as well.

In Tori news, I'll respect her privacy and skip this section.

In Igor news, it was a hard grumpy week. I had to cut lots of weight to make my weight loss pledge, and so I was on really low calories. This had me in a foul mood, and I'm grateful Tori put up with me. On the bright side, my weight is really dropping and I feel great.

In Zach news, he has a lot more reasoning. He's now starting to explain to me why his behaviors where not up to par. For example. "Dad, I know you got mad because I didn't listen, but it's because I was watching a show, and it was almost over".

In Amelia news, she has more teeth. Above the bottom two teeth, literally, she has 4 upper teeth buds. She's also a very independent baby, crawling around playing herself, and coming up and asking to be lifted, when she wants to be lifted. She's also incredibly good at giving Zach warning cries. Warning him that if he keep pushing her, she'll cry and Mom and Dad will yell at him.

Conversations with Zach

Zach and I are watching cartoons
I: Zach, what do you think about getting teriyaki? 
Z: STOP, I need to focus.

Zach and I were reading about a high school talent show: 
I: Do you know what a high school is?
Z: Yup, it's a school for really big people.  Like a kindergarten for big kids. 

I: Do you know what a talent show is? 
Z: Nope
I: It's a show where everyone shows what they're good at. 
Z: Oh, I'll do something no one else is good at. 
I: Great idea, like what? 
Z: I don't know yet.

I have a tendency not to wash my hands, which Zach doesn't approve of: 
Z: Hey did you wash your hands?
I: No I didn't; Why Should I ? 
Z: Because your hands have germs on them.

Sometimes, I have deep thoughts too.
I: Zach, who would win between a dinosaur and a bear
Z: Well who is more powerful
I: Well I asked you.
Z: Lets see, a dinosaur is big, and he can throw 10 bears.

Z: Yup, a dinosaur would just take the bears in his mouth, and throw them around so he'd win.

As I practice magic, I often drop coins on the floor.
Zach found some and ran off. I followed Zach, and discovered he put the money in his piggy bank. 
I: Zach, hey that's my magic trick money
Z: Sorry dad, finders keeper, loser weepers
I: That wasn't lost, it was on my floor.
Z: Hey, you lose money, you lose it. I’m just doing my job.
I: Huh, what job? 
Z: You know, my job of finding money.

Zach and I were peeing at the same time: 
Z: Did you get your penis taken off? 
I: Huh?
Z: Well I have a penis cover - but did you get yours taken off
I: Yes, that's called a circumcision     
Z: I bet that hurt.

Have a great week and remember, Cultivate Compassion, it's always in fashion   - ZiaT

link.title: Week 262AZ: Paying attention at circus school

entry.title: Week 261AZ: Birthdays all around
entry.content:
This year was Amelia's first birthday and Zach's fifth. Like last year we did it at a local park, and we lucked out on no rain. This year, we did a bbq, and served almost 30 hotdogs and 40 hamburgers, WOOHOO!

Credits to Tori for getting everything organized and setup, as usual my only job was lighting things on fire and cooking meat.

I never much cared for my own birthday, but I think I'll use Zach and Amelia's birthday as a time to reflect over the year.

This has been a wonderful year. Zach's reasoning has flourished, and I'm constantly amazed at what inference he'll have made about the world. Amelia is on the verge of toddling. Even though she's going through the same developmental milestones as Zach, often wearing the same clothing, she's very much her own person.

It's hard to describe the pleasure of children, but I'll try. Children allow you to forget yourself to the service of them. Children give you another chance to do "right" those things which took you so many years to learn. Most of all, children are an infinite source of it love, both a place to send infinite love, and a place to get infinite love.

Yeah, it's mushy, but at this age, I can say what I mean with pride.

In other news

In house news, we've been backlogged with the party, and spring break but now we'll get it going.

Tori will soon pick a plumber to fix our side sewer, and we'll re-fi the house into a 30 year mortgage as rates are so low, it's worth having the cash available.

The rest of this blog post didn't get written, and I've decided to publish as is, instead of merging it into next week.

 Have a great week and remember, Smile at a Stranger - ZiaT

entry.title: Week 259AZ: Beach House Vacation
entry.content:
This week Tori organized a fantastic vacation. We spent Thursday and Friday on an Whidbey island staying at a beach cabin. It was a perfect few days to be on the beach. We saw rainbows, and the tide was really far out so we had a fun time playing in the sand. Also, the whole time you could hear the waves crashing into the shore, which is a sound I really enjoy.

This was the first vacation I can remember when I was really present (well for the first day and a half) and it was awesome. I was really able to enjoy my time with the family. Zach and I got to sleep together which happens all the time. But the real treat for me was Amelia fell asleep on me twice.
Once at 5am while I was watching the sun rise over the ocean.

While we were on vacation Tori picked an awesome local diner where we feasted on pies, both chicken and desert, and they were fantastic. On our way home from the vacation, we stopped to see the tulip festival. Unfortunately by the time we got to the tulip festival Zach was toast and he was already screaming for us to leave before we got out of the car. At times like these, I need to remind myself if I'm doing something for myself or my family. In this case it was for my family, so I fought down my anger and we headed home.

On our way home, we stopped at a not so tasty diner, but it had an awesome card to take home, which I'll quote here:

Pause for but a moment to offer thanks for the countless blessings you have, for the gift of those people who make your life so rich and for the beauty around you that fills your heart. Look graciously upon this day as you continue life's journey.
Any whoo enough ramblings ...

In other news

In house news, I think we're done with the mice. We have now erected a play structure for Zach in the play room (ex dining room), and after banishing my recliner sofa to the basement for lack of cushioning, Tori fixed the cushioning in under 30 minutes.

In Tori news, I'll respect her privacy and skip this section.

In Igor news, work has been great. I came to terms that sometimes I will do an amazing job, and the outcome will be out of my hands. In this case, the outcome will probably end up OK, but even if it doesn't, I'm very proud of my efforts.

In Zach news, it's so much fun. We sing together, and tell jokes together, and he even reminds me things that matter to me - ike you should eat slower, and you need practice. What can I say? I know - AWESOME!

In Amelia news, she finally has teeth. After 4 months of teether and toother have popped through, and more are a coming. Amelia can also now climb the stairs, so we'll need to get more barricades.

Conversations with Zach

On eating animals:
Z: Do ribs come from creatures?
I: Yup pigs
I: We grow them on farms.
Z: What do you mean grow them.
I: Well you know how we grow fruits?
Z: Huh? Are yous saying pigs grow new skin?
I: Not quite….

Zach came to visit me at work, where I have a stuffed flower on my door: 
Z: What's that on your door? 
I: It's a flower, to keep me happy.
Z: But dad, it's not a real flower.
I: It's OK it makes me happy.
Z: Well, if you want I can get you a real flower from school.

At work my office has a big stuffed orangutan called Joey:
I: What do you think Joey does ? 
Z: He makes sure noone breaks in.
I: Hym, good job. 
Z: But that's not his real job.
I: What's his real job?
Z: Dad, he's not real, he doesn't have a real job.

Our internet was broken, just like at the Deli's: 
I: See the internet at the deli is broken just like at hour ouse
I: That means that we share the same internet with the deli.
Z: Really? Why's that?
I: Well we use the same provider
Z: Hym
---- 5 minutes later - get home ---
Z: Dad, you're wrong our intrent works so we must have different internet 
Z: Our internet works on Kindie so that proves it. 
I: Wow, good experiment buddy, nice job. 
-- 1 minute later --
Z: Oh the internet doesn't work, only games work -- you were right. 
-- Smile --

Have a great week and remember, * Focus on your circle of influence, not your circle of concern" - ZiaT

entry.title: Week 258AZ: Spring Parade
entry.content:
This will be a long verbose post. It doesn't do justice to the week, but it's here to remind me of the event so I can story tell it in the future

This post won't do the event justice, but hopefully it'll remind me of principlies and continuing to prioritize those.

Before the week started, we knew it was going to be a busy one. We already knew next week we're going on a mini-vacation so we had a lot of things that needed to get done. We also knew that Zach's school has some family event on Friday meaning even less hours available for work.

As the week started it got even busier. Everyone, Zach, Me, Tori and Amelia got sick. And if that wasn't enough it got busier - I got asked to pull together a surprise VP presentation, and was completely unprepared.

By Friday, with looming deadlines, and a nasty cold, I was considering skipping that school family event so I could get some more time on the presentation. Luckily, my principles held, so at 4am I drove to work and at 8am I was back home to join the family for the school event.

The school event was called the "Spring Spiral", and it was a sacred experience. The kids all made "gods eyes" and along with their parents formed a parade to walk to the park. At the head of the parade was a bag pipe player -- man a bag pipe can really carry while it's outside.

As we crossed the street, the police where there to stop traffic.

Between the bag piper at the head of the parade and the police stopping all the traffic, we felt super important, and seeing the pride in the kids as they waved their gods eyes was so touching tears were streaming out my eyes.

The parade went to this wonderful meadow and we made beautiful dance spirals and we sung. There is something that is super touching for me about people singing, a large group singing simple melodies is really touching, adding to the sacredness of the event.

When the dancing was done, we had the hot crossed buns that kids made - totally yummy! When I asked Zach if he'd made of the buns he said - well only one because I'm not so good at it.

To compliment the buns, Tori brought us a picnic. This was even more impressive as Tori also had a brutal cold and was exhausted. Tori was even kind enough to bring me a thermos of decaf coffee - thank you dear - you're amazing.

The event was 4 hours, and I didn't glance at my phone, not once. Every time my VP presentation popped into my head, I pushed it out so I could enjoy the moment - and it was awesome.

By the end of the hot cross buns, Zach was off playing with the other boys from his school. They were in some kind of tree fort, and when I came by to see what was going on, Zach pushed me away, very adamantly.

So, while Zach played I watched from 20 feet away.

As I watched, I saw a bunch of boys ganging up on Zach. They weren't hitting him, but they were all aiming their "stick" guns at him and saying get him. I saw Zach get super upset, and run away.

I saw him sulking but game him his space for a bit. After several minutes, I came over to him, he was clearly crying, and got very upset that I was near him. He stormed off. I followed him at a distance.

When he saw me stormed back and, still crying, screamed at me to leave. I told him, I'd always be there looking over his shoulder loving him.

Zach didn't find this comforting, and screamed at me, and headed off to stand on some rocks.

On the rocks, Zach started bashing a really big rock, against the rock face. I was pretty far away at this point, and I saw Quinn, a girl from his school, come up and start talking to him. I'm not sure what she said but she got him right calmed down.

Well I'm guessing you stopped reading already, if you didn't you're a trooper. I'll reward you with some good Zach conversations.

In other news

Skipping for this week as this post is already too long

Conversations with Zach

I usually take "voice notes" by telling my phone "take a note",
Zach has been getting wise to how this works: 

Z: Dad, say take a note.
I:Huh?
Z: You know, say take a note, like you do to your phone.
I: OK. Zach, take a note.
Z: What is your note?
I: Uhm. I love you!
Z: Sorry, we're full, too many of that note?
I: What?
Z: Yeah, look …
Z: I love you, 
Z: I love you, 
Z: I love you,
Z: See full.
I: Well take another one.

Zach's learning to start with shared goals :)
Z: Can we get a healthy snack? 
I: Well, that's good thinking, where? 
Z: At the deli.
I: Hym, what kind of healthy snack?
Z: Oh an apple.
I: Great idea, lets do it. 
-- at the deli --
Z: You know, I know a better snack - lets get a chicken tender
I: Hym, I guess one's OK.
Z: Well, you know, maybe two would be good so we can share with someone else. 
-- at this point I was proud of Zach for tricking me - -
I: Alright sure.


Have a great week and remember, Be present to be free, that should be your decree - ZiaT

entry.title: Week 256AZ: One hundred and sixty eight pounds
entry.content:
Well, not quite, but in a few days I'll be under 170 lbs for the first time in as long as I can remember.

Fifteen months ago I was 210 lbs, and through hard word and vigilance I was able to drop the weight.

I'm proud. Zach, Amelia - work hard, grind through, and you'll hit your goals.

In other news

In house new, we haven't seen mice for several days, and we're excited we're rid of them. It's still early though so our cameras are still on the job. In other house news our front door knob finally fell apart, and Tori did a fantastic job replacing it.

In Tori news, I'll respect her privacy and skip this section.

In Igor news, I've had a cold the last few weeks, and I'm using this as my excuse for less willpower and energy. Today I'm deciding I'm back on the band wagon, and hopefully my disciplines will be in full force this week.

In Zach news, Zach is growing up. He's becoming more sophisticated. He's talking more about more complex things, building more complex things, and figuring out how the world works. It's an honor to watch.

In Amelia news, she's totally mobile. If she wants to go somewhere she does. Even though she still had a 3 point crawl, she moves quickly, can get anywhere, and is pretty happy with the whole affair.

Conversations with Zach

Problem solving: 
Tori: Zach you're in trouble, I'm going to send Kindy to Dadda's work. 
Zach: Dad, can you take me to your work, 
Igor: Why's that? 
Zach: so I can get Kindy back.

Zach got new sunglasses:
Z: Isn't this cool?
I: Sure 
Z: It's cool  because you find gold very often.

Zach was peeing without lifting the toilet seat: 
I: Zach, lift the toilet seat: 
Z: I know, I know, I'm just getting penis out first.

Zach's making up jokes: 
Z: Why did the chicken walk up your back?
I: I don't know.
Z: So he could get into your mouth. 
Z: Hahaha
I: Did you make that up, and tell other boys? 
Z: Well, I did make it up, but I didn't tell anyone else yet.

While I was driving Zach to circus school: 
Z: Dad, did you see the firetruck
I: No
<5 later="" minutes="">
Z: Dad, did you see the school
I: No, 
Z: Dad, you're driving me banana's.
I: Huh, why's that. Well, because you can't see anything when you're driving. We should take the bus.

On Birds:
I:  
Z: When you do that it sounds like there is a bird on your head.

On being appreciated: 
I: Good job buddy. 
Z: You're welcome.

Have a great week and remember, * Lose some weight, you'll feel great. But eat to much food, and your belly will protrude" - ZiaT

link.title: Week 256AZ: One hundred and sixty eight pounds

entry.title: Week 254AZ: Live (the verb, not the noun)
entry.content:
Every day I ride the bus practicing my card tricks.  As I sit there shuffling cards I fantasize I am asking those people around me, all of whom are avoiding eye contact by staring into their phones, to pick a card.


Today a girl on the bus interrupted my fantasy and asked me if I could show her a magic trick!!!

I went over to her and I did the trick. The girl loved it! I did it again, and she loved it again.

When I sat back down, all the people who had been staring at their phones a minute earlier were now looking me in the eye giving me a big smile.

In other news

In house new, the mouse hunt makes progress, and the dining room is transforming into a playing room. For the mice, we have 24x7 infrared cameras setup to assist in the mouse hunt. So far, 2 mice have been "captured" and we're continuing to monitor the situation. In the dining room we have gotten rid of the dining room table, and we're now looking for carpets. Soon we'll have dedicated room for the kids to make a big mess.

In Tori news, I'll respect her privacy and skip this section.

In Igor news, I've been a "sales guy" for the last 2 weeks. Sales is a very different job for me, and it's still uncomfortable, although it's getting easier. I just bought a Bluetooth headset, because I need to spend so much time on the phone. My magic is also getting better, I can now do a "pick a card" routine and I'm getting comfortable enough to do that on the bus.

In Zach news, Zach is becoming a magician himself. His routines are all his own, and they are growing in complexity. His first trick was "Pick a card", and then he'd show you another card at random and say "I turned your card into this card". His latest routine has been a force+color change. Zach approaches you with two cards (a 2 of hearts, and 2 of spades), he then asks you to pick a card. Once you pick the card, and give it back, he shows you the other card, saying "Tada - I changed the color of your card". Zach is also now moving Amelia (motivated by the fact that Amelia is too close to his toys). Zach does the Amelia carry, by standing behind her, and putting his arms under her arm pits and waddling away with her. It's incredibly cute, and even though it doesn't make Amelia look happy, she doesn't complain.

In Amelia news, she's becoming much more mobile. She does a 3 point crawl, which is really a crawl, except she hasn't realized she needs to pull her right leg behind her, so she folds over it (I know, I need a video). Amelia also loves avocado, and if she sees you take out the avacodo she does a little "give me avocado dance". Amelia is also a very chill baby - it's awesome.

Conversations with Zach

In the order which life dealt them

Understanding death
I: Let me tell you about my Dad
Z: Do you get to visit your Dad?
I: No, he's dead. 
Z: How did he die?
I: Well he was sick. 
Z: What did he die from?
I: Well, he was sick in the brain.
Z: Oh, like one of those germs that eats your memories?
I: No, that's actually what my grandmother died of. 
Z: Oh, that doesn't happen very often. 
I: No it doesn't, and usually just to old people.

On being bald:
I: I used to have hair like yours, and laugh at my dad for having no hair. 
I: And my dad told me son, when I was your age, I had just as much hair as you but …
Z: Wait, wait, wait. I can tell you why you don't have hair. I: Sure, why don't I have hair?
Z: Well when you get older, your chest pull down all your hair, and it starts growing up your face, and that's why you don't have hair on your head. 
I: Ahh, that makes sense.

On Hello in French: 
Z: Dad do yo know what bazoor is? 
I: HUh? What? 
Z: You know, hello in french?
I: Oh Bonjour, yeah, bonjour is hello in french.
Z: No dad, it's ball shoe. Ball shoe is how it sounds.

I picked Zach up from school, and noticed he had a brick:
I: Zach leave that brick at school we're going home.
Z: No, I found it on our walk, and I'm keeping it.
I: Zach did you have that brick with you the whole time?
Z: No, of course not, I came back from the walk and I put in my bag, because we were playing inside.
Z: Then I brought it out when we were playing, then we went back in for rest so I brought the brick back in.
Z: But now it's play time so I brought it back out.
I: What are you going to do with that brick?
Z: I'm going to bring the brick home and break it down and make pieces for mom and amelia.
.....  That evening, Zach smashed the brick with a hammer and gave the pieces to Tori and Amelia ...

Have a great week and remember, Smile and be happy, maybe it's sappy, but it's better then feeling crappy - ZiaT

link.title: Week 254AZ: Live (the verb, not the noun)

entry.title: Week 252AZ: Sunny Spring in Seattle
entry.content:
Seattle is having uncarecteristcaly dry, sunny and warm weather, and as a result, all our trees are blooming. It's pretty cool to have spring so early, and to be able to enjoy it with my two charming children, and my one wonderful wife.

In other news

In house news, we've still got a mouse. Traps are set, but the mice aren't so easily captured. We're now setting up WiFi cameras and peppermint bombs in hopes of scaring off the mouse. Even after we rid ourselves of the mouse I think we'll keep the peppermint bombs as we all enjoy the smell.

In Tori news, I'll respect her privacy and skip this section.

In Igor news, work is becoming all about interviewing customers, finding people to interview, and getting people to try my prototype product. This is uncomfortable, and I need to constantly push myself to not do things I'm good at to avoid doing the things i need to get done. I've not been practicing my magic this week, but I should be. Maybe I'll start my interviews with a magic show.

In Zach news, Zach just got a new bicycle and he's super proud to be riding it. It warmed my heart to hear Zach say, "Dad do you want to practice riding a bike with me" - Absolutely kid, absolutely.

In Amelia news, she's in the something new every week phase. She's also still in the none of my teeth have come in yet and I'm super grumpy phase - I guess I'd call that a mixed bag.

Conversations with Zach

in the order which life dealt them
After Zach almost hit his sister: 
I: Zach, you're going to lose kindy. 
Z: You can't take Kindy away, you're not the judge, Mom's the judge.
I: Ok, I'll bring mom the evidence
Z: You can't bring mom the evidence, that's my Job. 
I: Zach, I'm the judge now, you're losing Kindy. 
Z: Well if you take Kindie away, I'll throw away something you like.
Z: Like, I'll throw away your office.

While we drove over a draw bridge
Z: Dad, would it be bad if the bridge opened while a car was on it? 
I: Well, what do you think? 
Z: Well, it'd be bad because they'd fall into the water and get wet. 
I: Hym, why is that bad? 
Z: Well cars are heavier then water, so they'll sink
Z: But, you can open the door and then you can go up and that'd be OK.
Z: But if you open your mouth, you'd get water in your mouth.
I: Wow, good thinking Zach.
Z: Oh, you could get a fish in your eye.
Z: Hahaha, that's funny. That's a great joke!

Have a great week and remember, Sunny Sunny, Funny, Funny - ZiaT

entry.title: Week 251AZ: Building roads in Oregon.
entry.content:
The family took the week off, and flew down to Oregon, where we had a blast as usual. Zach and I spent a bunch of time on the ranch building a road, while Tori and Amelia got to spend a bunch of time with the sisters, mamas, grandmas and aunts.

For me the trip was especially notable since I didn't bring my laptop, and this might have been the longest I've gone as far back as I can remember without my laptop. While the withdrawal pains were brutal at the start of the trip, by the end of the trip I was no longer having phantom "I need to check my laptop pains" and I was becoming more relaxed. I was so much better off that I considered not turning on my laptop for the rest of my vacation - but as soon as I got back, I turned my laptop back on and have been happy ever since.

In other news

In house news, we have a mouse. At first, we just thought we had a mouse, but then Tori saw him, and so did I. Tori was even able to trap the mouse when he got himself lost in a box of rice crispies, but the mouse still got away.

In Tori news, I'll respect her privacy and skip this section.

In Igor news I got to do a lot of magic practice in Oregon. I'm starting to realize that magic and juggling are focusing acts for me and as well as enjoying them, they really help put me in a good frame of mind.

In Zach news his intelligence is starting to show, as is his independence and energy. I wonder what the best way is to harness those attributes in a positive way. Speaking of energy, now that we have nice weather, Zach is skipping instead of running, it's very inspiring, although I'm not yet inspired to skip along with him (but maybe that's a flaw in my logic).

In Amelia news, she's growing up too. She can hold her own cup now, and she knows when she wants advil for her teeth, and she can almost pull herself up, and she can almost crawl, and she almost has teeth.

Conversations with Zach

In the order which life dealt them
On what Zach should be when he grows up: 
I: Zach, what do you want to be when you grow up. 
Z: Ahhh, I haven't decided yet. 
I: Well, how about telling me one of your choices. 
Z: OK. I want to be electricity
I: Hym, Why is that? 
Z: Because then I can control computers without having to type. 
I: Good thinking

Later that evening: 
Z: Dad? 
I: Yeah? 
Z: When you grow up, you should be a train conductor. 
I: Why is that? 
Z: Cuz then I can ride the train whenever I want.

On work life balance (Zach woke up early and saw) 
Z: Dad - why are you awake, it's still night time.
I: well I get up early because I go to work early 
Z: But dad were in Oregon
I: But I keep getting up early or I'll fell bad when I go back to work
Z: Dad remember you don't work every day
Z: If you worked everyday you'd go crazy (while shaking his head wildley for effect) 
Z: And plus, we'd never get to see you.

Have a great week and remember,   Enjoy your kids while they're small, because before long they'll be tall. And once they are tall, they'll put up a wall, and they won't even call - ZiaT

entry.title: Week 249AZ: The emotional ordeals of Trader Joe's and Circus School
entry.content:
This week, I was re-reading the 7 habits of highly effective people chapter 5 - See first to understand. As usual the lessons were very helpful

I really enjoy grocery shopping and Trader Joe's is one of my favorite grocery stores. Often, I can get Zach to come with me, by claiming I need his help to avoid rockets, and that without him I won't remember the bubble juice (pop).

This morning I tried to get Zach to come with me, the harder I pushed the more upset he got:

I: Zach I need my rocket man to come with me to Trader Joe's
Z: No. 
I: But, Zach I need you, otherwise I'll get hit by a rocket. 
Z: No, we should go later. 
I: No, we need to go now.
I: Come on, without you I won't remember bubble juice. 
Z: No ..

Zach was almost in tears at this point, so I remembered to back down.
I: Woah, what's wrong buddy? 
Z: If we go to trader joe's I won't be able to watch my cartoons
I: Alright then, I'll go by myself it's OK.
Zach was relieved, but remembering his goals he said: 
Z: Dad, you need to write bubble juice on the list
Z: If you write it on your list you won't forget it.

After Trader Joe's and before we went to circus school, Zach started having a melt down. After he knocked a chair over and slammed the door I put him in timeout in his room. A few minutes later I joined him in his room: 
I: What's going on buddy? 
Z: Silence
I: Hey, you look pretty upset
Z: I want to watch penguins
I: We need to go to circus shool, we don't have time.
Z: No, I want to watch penguins.

We argued back and forth making no progress, and then I remembered the 7 habits: 
I: OK, well we don't have much time what if you watch circus school for 3 minutes. 
Z: That's OK. 
I: Well here's the deal, you can watch penguins for 3 minutes, but as soon as I say we need to go, you need to go. 
Z: OK.

Sure enough, 3 minutes later, I told Zach we needed to go and he moved with out a fight. Although he did have some opinions on the importance of warm up: 
I: Lets, go or we'll be late. 
Z: We'll get there before the good stuff, but if we miss forward and backwards bear walks that OK. 
Z: I don't like the forward and backwards bear walks.

In other news 

In house news, not much progress, I'm working too many hours, and Tori's making up the difference at home with two kids.

In Tori news, I'll respect her privacy and skip this section.

In Igor news I love my job, but I'm working too many hours. I need to dial it back so I don't burn out, or put too much load on Tori. Luckily I'm set to take next Wednesday off, and then we're off to visit the ranch in Oregon.

In Zach news he's starting to understand leverage, and the importance of effectiveness. We were on the playground and Zach tried to tell another 6 year old where he lived. After a few minutes he came up to me, and told me to tell the boys dad where we lived and to make a date. I was shy and didn't want to, but Zach pushed me to do it anyways.

In Amelia news, she's still bopping to the music, and she's getting more comfortable in other positions, and holding herself up. Crawling is in the near future.

Conversations with Zach

in the order which life dealt them

After going to Trader Joe's without Zach:
I: Hey, you know what they said at the grocery store? They said where is the rocket man? 
Z: They did not. 
I: They did.
Z: You just made that up. 
I: I didn't look, they gave me stickers. How would I get stickers. 
Z: Duh, you asked for them. 
I: If I asked for them, they'd just say mister, you're  not a boy, you can't have stickers.
While watching TV with Zach but working: 
Z: Dad, you should only do one thing at a time.
I: What do you mean? 
Z: Well, you can watch tv, or play on the computer, but you shouldn't do both at once.

On talking to Zach while he watches TV: 
I: Zach - who is that little dog, is that Scooby Do?
Z: Dad, can you please be quiet.

On delaying sleep: 
I: Zach go to sleep
Z: Wait, I need to put my stuffed animals away. You don't want them to not get their sleep.
Have a great week and remember, Work too many hours, your reduce your powers - ZiaT

link.title: Week 249AZ: The emotional ordeals of Trader Joe's and Circus School

entry.title: Week 248AZ: A great way to end the week
entry.content:
I love helping my wife, I love being with my kids, I love riding the bus, I love having flexibility at work, I love living in a place so easy to get to from the bus, and I love making people smile.

I love it when I can combine all these activities into something I really enjoy.

Friday, Tori was feeling exhausted so I hopped on the 3pm bus so I could get home to relieve her. Getting home 20 minutes later I grabbed Amelia and drove over to Zach's school.

Wanting to give Tori a long break, I stuffed Amelia in her carrier, grabbed Zach by the hand and told Zach we could get ice cream. To my surprise - Zach had a favorite ice cream store, knew how to get there, and even had a favorite order.

After we had our fill of ice cream, we wandered around the wallingford neighborhood waiting for a bus home - as we walked, Amelia was cute and beaming, and Zach was providing commentary on the things we saw and the state of the world. The result was awesome! Everyone, including grizzled, sad, grumpy people, tried to avoid smiling but failing miserably. Between Amelia, Zach and my silly hat we got a smile out of everyone.

In other news


In house news,we're still waiting for contractors, and Tori is making lots of napkin sketches.

In Tori news, I'll respect her privacy and skip this section.
In Igor news I love my job, and realized there are only some parts of my job (what I call the emotional labor) which I can't bring home. A bunch of the work (the technical stuff) is super fun, and doing it at home relaxes and charges me up. I'm also getting back into my magic obsession, and am making up a routine I can run on everyone I see.

In Zach news, it's starting to feel weird recording conversations with him because they are no longer cute, but are just normal conversations with people. I'll probably still record them though.
In Amelia news, she loves music. If you play some music, she'll start bopping along. Thankfully Amelia doesn't have my musical ability, and perhaps she'll have Tori's or my Uncle's musical talent.

Conversations with Zach

in the order which life dealt them

Zach wants to know about death: 
Z: Hey, can you remind me why I don't have grandfathers. 
I: Well, they died. 
Z: How come? 
I: Well, they got sick, and died. 
Z: Hym, did the doctors die too?
I: No, the doctors were fine, but sometimes when people get really sick they can't be saved. Oh, I see.

Learning the values his parents live:
Z: You know what everyone is going to do tomorrow?
I: What's that? 
Z: Watching the super bowl. 
I: Ahh
Z: Can we watch the superbowl game? 
I: Well, we could, but I have a secret for you. 
Z: What's that? 
I: If everyone is doing something, you should do something else, because it's a lot easier.
Z: Huh? 
I: Tomorrow, while everyone is watching the super bowl, we can do anything we want because everywhere will be empty. 
Z: Oh, can we go the children's museum with the playground on top? 
I: Absoloutly
Z: Goody.

Learning to take care of things: 
I: Zach go to bed!
Z: I need to do one more thing. 
I: Stop stalling. What do you need to do? 
Z: I need to put my stuffed ansmials away. You don't want them to not get their sleep.

Have a great week and remember, Live the dream, eat ice cream - ZiT

link.title: Week 248AZ: A great way to end the week

entry.title: Week 247AZ: Long Days, Short years, four years later.
entry.content:
Saturday was a wonderful warm day in Seattle, and we went for a walk in the arboretum. Our walk ended at a playground where we were happily pushing Zach and Amelia in the swings.

That park, and that swing set is burned into my memory as that was the place where a woman saw Tori and I burned out and exhausted pushing Zach in a swing.

That woman saw us and said the days are long but the years are short. I don't know who that woman was, but she had a big impact on my life. She taught me to cherish the moments and she kicked off this blog series.

Lady if you ever read this, you have our gratitude!

In other news

In house news, we're once again playing one of our favorite games "disappearing contractors". Tori has plans for how to rearrange our dining room, and I'm looking forward to seeing them. Tori has also scheduled a donation pick up, which will be great as our house seems to be constantly growing things we don't need.

In Tori news, I'll respect her privacy and skip this section.

In Igor news I love my job, but I need to enforce a strict separation of work and home, to make sure it doesn't take over more then it's fair share of my life. In new skills, I had to do intercept surveys (that means walking up to strangers and asking them if they'll answer a few questions). That was really intimidating for me, but I re-read my jump in the lake day and forced myself to do it. It was actually a very positive experience, but I'm still scared to do it again (but not as much since fighting the resistance always makes it easier).

In Zach news, it never ceases to amaze me how he grows up so quickly. Today, Zach was misbehaving so we told him he lost his kindle for the rest of the day. Zach didn't put up much of a fight, which was surprising.   Later in the day I gave Zach a chance to get his Kindle back and he said. "Nah, it doesn't matter I'm out of minutes on the Kindle anyways".

In Amelia news, crawling is starting! So far, Amelia can go backwards, and if you don't watch her, you'll she has ended up moving forward a bit. It's pretty awesome seeing how much Amelia loves being held by her parents, and just cuddling. Kids are awesome!

Conversations with Zach

in the order which life dealt them
Zach and I play Snakes and Ladders, which he always he seems to win: 
I: Zach, how come I always lose? 
Z: It's ok if you lose. Ill let you play again

Zach is also learning to be a magician. 
Z: Do you want to see a magic trick?
I: Sure
Z: OK, do you see this toy? 
I: Yup.
Z: OK, close your eyes
I: .. I look away ...
Z: OK, you can open them now
Z: See, it's disappeared.

Like his dad, Zach loves potato Salad:
I: Zach stop wolfing your food down.
Z: But it's so tasty.
I: Wait, I thought you told me I needed to enjoy my food and eat slower.
Z: Yeah, but dad, that's just for ice cream cuz you want Ice cream  to last longer.

I really enjoy having Zach sleep with me, but I don't like to encourage that behavior, so I'll only let him do it once in a while: 
I: Zach do you want to sleep with me?
Z: Um let me think about it. Well OK.
Z: I'll be half with you/half with mom 
A few minutes later Zach comes upstairs with all stuffed animals.
Z: Zach look what I brought? 
I: What did you bring? 
Z: All my stuffed animals. Do you know why? 
I: Why?
Z: Because they aren't usually so lucky to sleep up here.

Have a great week and remember, Make sure your actions ladder up to your values - ZiT

link.title: Week 247AZ: Long Days, Short years, four years later.

entry.title: Week 246AZ: Drained but worth it.
entry.content:
In other news

In house news, we're still trying to hunt down contractors for the front porch, and Tori has finally gotten sick of my "cardboard" windows, and replaced them with glass. It's pretty sweet being married to a jack of all trades.

In Tori news, I'll respect her privacy and skip this section.

In Igor news it's been a fantastic week that sucked up lots of my energy but paid off. First, I had to pitch my project to my VPs, and they like it and want me to continue. Second, I'm exploring customer development - a methodology for agile, customer driven product development. Customer development requires me to interview customers, which is draining, and making me uncomfortable, but it's table stakes if I want to be an entrepreneur.

In Zach news, his stories are getting more and more sophisticated, and he's able to recall and re-tell them. Zach's also getting interested in girls, and succumbing to their willey suggestions. For example, the other day Zach came home wearing 4 t-shirts. When we questioned Zach, it turned out Quinn, a girl Zach might have a crush on, told him to do it.

In Amelia news, it's been a bit crazy. Amelia had a fever at the start of the week, and that made her very very cranky. A cranky baby makes for a cranky family, and we were stoked when her fever dissipated. Amelia now loves to hold on to things and try to walk. Tori and I are crawling around the floor trying to role model for Amelia, but Amelia just thinks we're crazy.

Conversations with Zach

In the order which life dealt them
Long past bed time:
I: Zach, we need to go to bed. 
Z: OK,OK, But I want to tell a bed time story. 
I: Alright, but it's way past your bed time, you need to go to bed.
Z: Once upon a time there was a really cool Dada, and he had a little boy who he loved very much named Zach
Z: And they were on the couch telling stories
Z: and one day …
I: Alright, now and on the couch I think dada said, it's time to go to bed. 
Z: Oh hold on it, wasn't like that.
Z: And they were very happy and went to bed.

On the vacation we haven't yet had:
Z: Do you remember when we took the escalator form the Eiffel tower?
I: What?
Z: We were on the Eiffel  tower, we were out of gas, so somebody called the escalator people, and they brought a giant escalator, and we went down. 
Z: Wouldn't that be fancy?
I: How did we end up on the Eiffel tower?
Z: We were on a parachute plane, and then the parachute fell off, so we landed, and we had balanced because there were people on both sides. 
Z: The Eiffel tower has the biggest escalator in the world. 
Z: Do you know how they move the escalator? 
I: How?
Z: By turning the nob.

On avoiding bad dreams: 
Z: I don't need to sleep or eat, because I have a power plant
Z: Your power plant is broken, so you don't get energy from it, so you have to eat and sleep. 
Z: Do you know why I have a power plant?
I: Why?
Z: Because I had lots fo bad dreams, so I installed one,

On Quinn, the girl from kindergarten:
I: Why do you like Quinn?
Z: First she makes good jokes
Z: Second, she plays with me a lot
Z: Quin doesn't like Rudy's magic tricks.  She told me Rudy can only turn a stick into a stick. 
Z: I mean a stick into a laptop.
Z: Quinn said she wants to see of my magic tricks because she thinks they're better. 
T: You told me that Quinn like Rudy more?
Z: She likes Rudy more, but she's coming back to me.

On Panda, a girl in Zach's circus school: 
I: Zach tell me about Panda
Z: I know this isn't going to be a nice thing, because I don't have any nice words about her. 
Z: Panda, she uh, wait, wait, wait I never told you the whole story
I: OK - Start again
Z: OK,OK
Z: Take 2 please
Z: The director liked panda's show, so I had to fire him.
Z: And then they had a new director. And I got the old show back.  Panda threw a bomb pie.  Z: The bomb was inside the pie. Then he was dead, so I needed another director
Z: Then I sent her to the desert so her show would never be on again.

Have a great week and remember, Mr. Rogers is my hero - ZiT

entry.title: Week 245AZ: Back to the normal routine
entry.content:
This week it's back to work for me, back to school for Zach, and back to a normal routine for Tori.

In other news

In house news, we've discovered that the columns holding up our porch roof are hollow, and that's awfully sketchy. We're waiting to see how expensive this will make our porch remodel.

In Tori news, I'll respect her privacy and skip this section.

In Igor news I'm really enjoying working in Bellevue and Magic. Working in Bellevue has better buses, has a gym in the building and lets me walk to my Dr appointments. Magic is my new obsession, it's pretty rare to see me without a deck of cards in my hands as I practice my banter, sleights and soon routines.

In Zach news, Zach's just getting more and more mature. He's able to make deals, and hold up his end of the bargain. He's able to articulate what he wants, and be very angry when he's slighted. It's so cool watching him grow up

In Amelia news, Amelia's teeth are still driving her nuts, but she's still super happy and easy going and loves eating everything. Today, Amelia held herself up along the crib. This reinforces the idea that Amelia might skip crawling, and proceed to walking.

Conversations with Zach

in the order which life dealt them

On Death and Santa:
Z: It'd be really sad if Santa Clause Died?
I: Oh, why's that?
Z: Because then I wouldn't get any presents. 
I:

On Junk food and fat pants: 
Z: You know, junk food doesn’t' make you tinyier
I: It doesn't ? 
Z: Nope - it makes you get bigger.

On Love: 
I: Do you understand loves? 
Z: Well there are three kind of loves. 
Z: The fairy love makes you cooc oo
Z: And the monkey love …    
I: Don't stop - keep going? 
Z: I won't tell you.

On Dads in wigs: 
I:Zach should dad wear a wig
Z:No you'd look like a girl
On Bacon: 
Z: You know what I wish? 
I: What? 
Z: I wish there was a bacon dispenser.

On Sweating
I: Zach lets run - come on, we're late 
Z: No dad, it'll make me sweat like a pig in the desert.
Being Brave:
Z: Dad wait for me to go downstairs
I: Why is that 
Z:because your afraid of the dark, and I'll turn on the light for you.


Have a great week and remember, Be free, Feel Glee, Dance with me - ZiT

link.title: Week 245AZ: Back to the normal routine

entry.title: Week 244AZ: Friends and Family
entry.content:
This week we were on staycation, and we had a great time filled with friends and family.

Monday, Greg and Ammon, two of my best friends, came to the court house to witness our marriage.

Tuesday, Zach fulfilled one of his bucket list items for 2014, getting to ride a double decker train.

Wednesday, we rang in the Argentinian new years with our birth friends. It's awesome to see all the kids you've known since birth grow up. Shayna and Melissa (and undisclosed others) made us a brilliant wedding cake -- awesome!

Thursday was jump in the lake Day, which was witnessed by the whole family. Little do they know I think it'll become a family tradition.

Friday we got to see our good friends Andrew, Shannon and the rest of their crew -- it's always wonderful to see how their brood of children growing up and becoming well behaved members of society.

Saturday we went hiking, well play grounding, with Nathan and Cristina. Hopefully they'll become our hiking buddies.

Sunday is today, and we'll be back to our regularly scheduled program of Sunday circus school.

In other news

In house news, we're bringing in the next round of porch contractors, we await their bids. We also have a TV setup downstairs which is transforming into a pleasant family space.

In Tori news, I'll respect her privacy and skip this section.

In Igor news life is dandy. New job is great, magic is my new hobby and I love having a gym in the basement of my office building.

In Zach news, Zach's learning parental manipulation and starting most of his demands with "I have something to tell you -- first I love you. Now ...". Zach's also digging the downstairs, and he's making excellent use of the TV and TV accouterments.

In Amelia news, Amelia's teeth are driving her nuts, but she's still super happy and easy going and loves eating everything. She's getting big enough, or maybe I'm getting brave enough, to come along on Zach adventures -- which is great since Tori can get some kid free time.

Conversations with Zach

In the order which life dealt them

On going to the gym: 
I:  are you going to go to the gym when you grow up?
Z:  no but there are lots of ways to exercise. Like playing is exercise

On angering Tori -- who is certainly the one doing the work: 
T: We can make the house bigger, by expanding it.
Z: Oh we shouldn't do that -- Only Dad should do that.
T: What? Why is that?
Z: Well, Dad is an engineer and we're not.

On understanding euphemisms: 
T: If you do that Kindie will go to vacation 
Z: Vacation ?  It's not vacation it's jail

On the value of money -- after being at the Teriyaki restaurant for an hour:
I: Zach let's go
Z: dada I paid for this and I'm not going to throw it away
I: ok let's get a Togo box
Z: Um for a new order? Let's get a box for a new order
I: No for this order 
Z: Groan -- I guess so

On getting out of work: 
Z: Can you pick me up from school Monday?
I: No, I can only pick you up Tuesday. 
Z: Oh, how come you can only pick me up Tuesday?
I: Well, it's the only night of the week I can come home early.
Z: Come home early? Why not every night?
I: I'm not allowed.
Z: Oh you can use the potty trick.
I: The potty trick - what's that?
Z: Well you say you need to use the potty, and then you leave.

Have a great week and remember, To make a friend, I recommend, the relationship tend - ZiT

entry.title: Week 243AZ: Kick in the pants
entry.content:
I write this blog series because I made a deliberate decision to make "family first" one of my guiding principles.

From this principle I derive the habit of a weekly family blog post for three reasons.

1) To live the lesson of deliberate discipline, because children become their parents.

2) To have a weekly evaluation on my execution of the "family first" principle, because principles without evaluation are just transient dreams.

3) To document our family history for my children because by the time they are interested I'll have long since forgotten.

When you see me not living up to my principle give me a kick in the pants. Hopefully this blog post will be sufficient.

entry.title: Happy jump in the lake day 2015
entry.content:
Today was an awesome jump in the lake day. The thermometer read 29 degrees Fahrenheit, but I had my freshly minted wife, my first time at the event daughter, my super awesome son and my lucky bow tie.

Zach and Amelia, when you read this, remember the reason to jump in the lake is to overcome  the resistance. The resistance is the enemy of your art, it is the overpowering emotion that paralyzes you in the face of doing the things that matter most.

By jumping in the lake you over come the resistance, building the confidence to, and the habit of, defeating the resistance.

Happy 2015!

link.title: Happy jump in the lake day 2015

entry.title: Married -- Check
entry.content:
We're married!   Tori claims she got married because I promised her a new porch and I'm happy with that.

The back story: 

In 2006 Igor met Tori, and have been side by side ever since.

In 2009 Igor got a fortune cookie suggesting marriage agreed with him, so he proposed and Tori agreed.

By 2013, Igor wasn't married, and attempted to induce marriage via a ballad - no dice.  A year later, in 2014, Igor took another stab at marriage induction via rice, but alas no dice.

Finally by withholding a porch, the nuptials are complete.

As usual Zach had some thoughts on the event.


Conversations with Zach

The day before the wedding:
I: Do you know what we're doing tomorrow?
Z: What? 
I: Your Mom and I are going to get married. 
Z: Oh, can I come ? 
I: Sure, of course
Z: Good, I want to hear the man say you can both squish.
T: Huh?  Squish
Z: You know, when you get married the man at the front says and you can now both squish. 
Tori: AAAAAh -- You mean kiss. Yes we'll get to squish.

The story changed a bit when it was time to leave for the wedding:
I: Zach lets go we have to get married
Z: But I'm watching TV.
I: Zach, we need to go.
Z: It's ok, we're already a family.

I love you Tori!

entry.title: Week 238AZ: The missing conversations
entry.content:
Last week I skipped a bunch of conversations, this week I'll skip some paragraphs and have lots of conversations ....


Zach exploring the grown up world of jobs:
Z: Guess What? 
I: What? 
Z: I want to be a director
I: OK
Z: Do you know what a director does? 
I: No, what does a director do? 
Z: He says Cut and Action
I: Ahhh, that makes sense.
I left the chocolate chips open on the counter:
Z: Hey, look there are free chocolate chip samples
The first conversation of the day is always great: 
I: How did you sleep? 
Z: I had lots of dreams. 
I: Like what? 
Z: Bunny turned into a monster, and I turned into a were wolf, but then mom kissed me and I turned back
Getting a grip on classes and instances:
Z: Can we read that on your Kindie? 
I: My Kindie is called a Surface. 
Z: Surface? That's a funny name for a Kindie
Z: Well, I guess they can be called Kindles, Kindies and Surfaces. 
Z: I like Kindie.
Zach slept in my bed, and was very upset when he woke up and I was downstairs:
Z: You need to tell me if you're leaving
Z: It's OK my ears will be open.
I: But Zach what if you're sleeping
On being self-directed: 
Z: You are not the boss of me
Z: I am the boss of me
Z: YOu can't tell me what to with my arm
Z: YOu can't tell me where to walk
Z: And whispering in my ear and dada you can't control my brain.
The reward of a job well done: 
Z: Hey didn't you say I did a good job yesterday?
I: Yup
Z: Do I get a treat?
I: Sure
Z: What is it?
I: You can be proud of what you did. 
Z: Hey, that's not a good treat.
On enforcing order:
T: Igor, can you get mooch off the baby. 
I: Grrr!!
Z: What' going on in here? 
I: Zach, chase mooch out the window.
T: Hey, stop modeling poor behavior Igor. 
*Zach thinks for a minute and faces me*
Z: Alright, Dada you're in time out
*Zach drags me to my room upstairs*
Z: You're in timeout for not being nice to moochy.
On the importance of being nice - after 5 minutes of trying to get Zach out the door:
I: Zach LETS GO!
Z: No
I: LET'S GO
Z: You're not being very nice!
I: Do youn need to go into your room?
Z: Stop being so bossy
*After 5 more minutes of no progress*
I: *Drop to me knees* Zach, I'm storry
Z: Ok, we can go.
On trying new foods:
I: Do you want some Tofu? 
Z: What's tofu? 
I: It's like steak 
Z: What is made of ? 
I: It's made of soy beans
Z: Oh, I like soy beans,  I'll try some.
I'm not sure what my Mom was reading: 
I: Mom, we should go.
Baba: Hold on, there, I'm in the middle of a juicy chapter. 
Baba: Yup, your mom is old, but she's not dead.
The end of many conversations:
Z: I want to buy something here. 
I: You didn't eat dinner at home. 
Z: So?
I: If you don't eat dinner at home, you can't get dinner at the restaurant. 
Z: I don't like that part. 
I: Well, that's the way it works. 
Z: I hate it when you're bossy.
On Redirection:
I: How was class?
Z: It was boring.
I: Why is that. 
Z: I need to tell you something very important
I: What's that? 
Z: I love you?
The trouble with treats:
I: Zach I'm proud of you for doing such a good job at class today. 
Z: Well, I was thinking I'd get a treat. 
I: What do you mean?
Z: Well, I did such a good job, I thought I should get a treat. 
I: Oh,  in that case  we can go swimming. 
Z: No, not that kind of treat, the kind of treat like ice cream.
Understanding trading:
Z: Can someone get me apple juice
I: Well, I can get you apple juice, but what am I going to get?
Z: I can give you 200 kisses.
I: OK.
Understanding the rules:
Z: Don't go without  me.
I: I wouldn't leave with out, even if I wanted to. 
Z: Yeah, even if you want to, you're not allowed to leave without me.
Understanding junk food: 
Z: Can I get a treat when we get home? 
I: No, you need to go home and go to bed. 
Z: Well, I do need to eat healthy. 
Z: How can I eat healthy if I'm asleep
Z: Maybe I can go home and have a healthy snack.
Zach lost his Kindle for being bad, Tori offered him a way to get it back, but Zach wasn't so excited: 
T: Zach, you know what you can do to get Kindie back? 
I: He can, what? 
T: He can clean, Zach - what do you say to that? 
Z: It's not worth it.
Have a great week and remember - Sunny and Cold, global warming behold - ZiaT

entry.title: Week 237AZ: Getting into the groove
entry.content:
After many weeks of visitors, new jobs, colds, teething, and halloween, we're finally getting into our groove.  Here's the whirl wind tour:

Baba came to visit for two weeks and the visit was awesome. Zach and Amelia got to spend a lot of time with their Baba, and Tori and I got some much needed down town. It was really impressive how well Amelia took to Baba because with everyone else Amelia's having Stranger Danger.

After Baba's trip we had halloween, when Tori made Zach an awesome robot halloween costume.  I was a bumblebee for halloween and when Zach saw me in the bee suit, he just started to laugh hysterically.

In other news

In house news, the water heater folks came back and re-did the install as I initially requested. It's amazing how pleasant a contractor experience can be,  when working with excellent contractors.

I also bought a TV for the basement and it is a hit. Zach and I can watch TV together and I really enjoy it.  Sitting on the couch, fighting with Zach for the remote reminds me of my childhood.

On the ground floor, Tori is contemplating a new master plan for the living room - and tells me I need to start practicing discovering which couches I think are most comfortable.

In the backyard, we sold our chicken coop, and that was a strange experience. The man buying the chicken coup was a 40 something grizzled, chirpy fellow, complete with hunting cap and plaid shirt, and beat up F-150 truck. His chicken coop moving helper was his twenty something wife, dressed in a short black cocktail dress.   The chicken coop is covered in chicken poop, weights on the order of 200 lbs and the pickup happened in the poring rain. That man's wife put as much shoulder into moving that chicken coop as I did - weird.

In Tori news, Tori got a dashing new hair cut, she looks fantastic.

In Zach news, he's getting smarter and smart, and more independent.  Zach wants to stay later in aftercare, and when he gets into a pack of boys, it's awesome to see him playing and trying to sway the pack.  Zach is also doing a fantastic job in group activities now, he does the warm up, and participates, and his earlier poor participation is a thing of the past.


In Amelia news, she is totally developing. She loves being tossed and tickled, she loves to play on her musical instruments, and my god she loves food. You can't eat anything near Amelia without her trying to take it away from you.


In Igor news, I've started my new job.  I'm still at Microsoft, but I'm no longer on main campus, instead I'm working in Bellevue. The Bellevue office feels completely different, it's in a sky scraper, and going to work in an urban area gives an energy boost I'd never have predicted.

Conversations with Zach

*I'll update these later, or I'll write them up in the next blog post*

Have a great week, and remember -  A man walks into a bar - ouch!  - ZiaT

entry.title: Week 232AZ:A day on the town with Amelia.
entry.content:
I don't usually get both kids, but Saturday I took Zach and Amelia to a trampoline place by myself. Zach was completely accommodating which I attribute to Tori's fantastic parenting.

On our way to the trampoline place Amelia fell asleep, so as we waited for Amelia to wake up, Zach and I watched some TV In the car. When Amelia woke up the three of us went into the trampoline place. Zach bounced while Amelia and I watched the kids bouncing.

After 30 minutes of jumping, Zach was hungry so we ordered him a pizza, when the Pizza arrived, Zach chowed down, and I fed Amelia with the bottle. Amelia, with her fantastic attitude, was as happy with the bottle as with the boob, and both kids filled their belly.

Recharged, Zach went down for more hopping and Amelia and I followed. This time as Zach bounced, Amelia became grumpy. Even though I was bouncing Amelia she was having none of it.
f
Using my power of elimination I discovered Amelia had pooped and quickly changed her. Full, and dry, Amelia fell asleep on my shoulder as Zach continued to bounce.

The punchline to this story is your life is just a collection of such simple activities - enjoy them.

In other news

In house news, we've decided to move Amelia's crib to the kids room (formerly known as Zach's room). Surprisingly Zach's all for it, but Amelia will take no part in being in her crib. With the protection of her big brother, it's just a matter of time before Amelia finds her place.

In Tori news, Tori says this is my blog and she doesn't understand why I write these.

In Zach news, he's super excited for Baba to arrive, and he's learning the pride of independence. In the past Zach refused to do up his seat belt because he wasn't able to do it.  But early in the week we spent 20 minutes practicing, and now if I try to help Zach with his seat belt, he gets mad at me for thinking he needs help - Awesome.

In Amelia news, she can roll, she can turn her head, she can eat from a bottle as well as from a boob, and she's ecstatic to have Baba her to visit.

In Igor news, I got my first job offer, and I'm interviewing with the final team. As expected learning magic is a hard slog, but I'm practicing for when it's my turn to be a Zaide.

Conversations with Zach

Zach realizes how the taking notes thing works:
Z: Mommies and Daddies aren't the same ... Hey - are you going to write that down when we get home?
I: Sure

Zach and I love our before bed snack:
Z: Um, popcorn and bubble juice make a great midnight Snack.

Zach was taking Tori and I for a walk, and wanted to show us where bees live: 
T: I don't see the bees yet.
Z: Well, they're up here, don't be impatient.

Zach and I were making play Pizza's and Zach stuck a sticker on it:
I: do we really want a pizza on the sticker?
Z: Of course Dad, without the sticker how do we know which pizza place it came from?

Zach has reached the aren't you listening to me stage:
I: Where is your bear bear?
Z: I forgot. 
I: Wait, where did you leave it? 
Z: Oh, don't you remember I told you I forgot.

Have a great week and remember - Baba is coming, we'll go a running- Ziat.

link.title: Week 232AZ:A day on the town with Amelia.

entry.title: Week 231AZ: Not paying attention is expensive
entry.content:
Some weeks everything goes your way, and some weeks it doesn't. This week it doesn't.

I wasn't paying attention to my weight and other commitments, and it became impossible for me to hit my weight loss goals. As a result, I've paid my first 1000$ for a weight loss challenge. On the bright side, this is a great lesson on integrity, carefully committing and monitoring outstanding commitments, and prioritizing your health.

I wasn't payting attention when I was driving, and ended up in a car accident. Thankfully noone got hurt, but Sparky will need some major love. On the bright side, this is a great lesson on what is most important in your life, the importance of being present, and the cost of mindlessness.

In other news

In house news, we're busy trying to get Amelia back on schedule, but the basement is far enough along that baba will have a place to sleep.

In Tori news, bread's a baking, Amelia's a teething, and Tori's keeping the house a running.

In Zach news, Zach is getting smarter.  See the conversations for more proof if it was ever required

In Amelia news, it's about teeth, eat, and strong feet. Amelia has four teeth coming in, and that makes her a bit grumpy. Amelia also has a fantastic appetite, and will try to get any food that you're holding while holding her. Finally Amelia has extremely strong legs - when you hold her up, she can stand. She doesn't have balance yet, but if you control the horizontal, she can control the vertical.

In Igor news, the job hunt goes well. I've crossed some teams off my list, booked interviews with others, and have been practicing my interview question. Also, I'm learning magic.  Magic, like juggling, will be a hard slog for me, but I intend to keep with it, and get steadily get better until I am fantastic at it.

Conversations with Zach

At bed time:
Z: Is tomorrow a work day? 
I: Yup
Z: Well, make sure to give me a hug before you go to work.
I: OK, but you'll be asleep. 
Z: Well, I'll wake up early to give you a hug, and then go back to sleep.

At wake up time:
Z:Are you going to work today? 
I: No 
Z: yippee

At just about bed time:
I: Zach you're going to bed in 5 minutes
Z: OK,OK, I get it.

After doing something bad:
T: Go to your room!
Z: Fine - for one minute only!

On evolution:
Z: Do you know what will happen in a hundred years?
I: Dunno - what? 
Z: Bubble juice will be called mubble juice

On playing parents against each other: 
T: Zach, I told you not to do that. 
T: Kindie is in timeout for 30 minutes.
Z: Dad pretend you didn't here that

On Junk Food:
Z: Do you know where I found these chocolate chips? 
I: No - where? 
Z: The counter. 
Z: And I think we shouldn't move them, because it's free samples chocolate chips.
