entry.title: Mr Rogers is my hero.
entry.content: I don't recall seeing Mr. Rogers saying anything that wasn't awesome.  Watching this put tears in my eyes.  This is Fred Rogers speaking on May 1st 1969 to the senate sub committee.

entry.title: Week 201AZ: Blow
entry.content:
Zach loves going to the pool. I don't think it's because he loves swimming, although he is starting to enjoy it. I think it's because the pool is a time when Zach has my full attention, and I have his. In the pool Zach and I give each other our full attention, I'm not thinking about work, or talking to Tori, or even staring off into space. Zach isn't trying to play Kindie, hit things, or watch TV. We're both present, and so our swim dates are an activity we both always want to do.

When we started going to the pool, Zach would panic when he got water in his eyes. For me, this was frustrating. We'd get into the pool and a few minutes later, Zach would get a few drops of water in his eyes, freak out, and want to leave the pool. To counter act the panic over water in his eyes, I taught Zach that when you get water in your eyes, you just blow and that gets the water out. My reasoning was Zach would be able to "blow" the water out of his own eyes, and be OK getting some water in his eyes.

Week after week, month after month Zach has gotten more comfortable in the pool. Now, he'll blow bubbles, jump off the side into shallow water, float in a life jacket, and even leap into my arms in deep water. It's amazing to watch the progression. Now, since Zach is getting braver and braver I can't take my eyes off him, or he'll take a leap into the deep end. Even though Zach's getting braver, when he gets a big face full of water, I still see him doing some frantic blows trying to get the water out of his eyes.

In other news

In house news, the remodel has started! The contractors have cut out the concrete, roughed in the plumbing, and if we're lucky they're pouring the concrete before you read this. We went with the more expensive contractors, and it's a pleasant experience. Even though the city had some extra requirements, the contractors dealt with it seamlessly, we've had no snafu's and it seems like we're ahead of schedule. They say money can't buy happiness, but it can certainly pay for lower stress situations. Tori's doing the purchases for the project, so we're frequently driving to home depot to pick up toilets, bathtubs and vinyl flooring.

In Tori news, Tori has submitted her application and there's nothing left to do but sit back and relax. In June we'll find out if she's been accepted to nursing school, and based on the letter we'll figure out how our life will change. As sprocket gets bigger in Tori's tummy, Tori's starting to have trouble getting her left sock on. Luckily she has me, who can help with such things.

In Igor news, I've successfully lost another 5 lbs of weight this month. Losing 5 lbs a month is a bit of a roller coaster. The start of the month I always think 5 lbs is easy, and I should shoot for 10 lbs this month. By the middle of the month I'm freaked out that I'll have to lose 9 lbs (the 5 I have to lose, plus the 4 I've gained from eating poorly for the first half of the month), and by the last day of the month, I'm always ready to make my weight loss goals. With luck I'll have a few more months of weight loss before the baby comes, and then I'll shoot to keep my weight stable. Work is great, much less stress than my lost job, and that really lets me enjoy my family.

In Zach news, Zach's becoming rather fond of the video games. We're going to need to put a limit on the number of hours of video games Zach can play in a day otherwise that's all he'll do. I guess this shouldn't surprise me as if I didn't have wrist problems I'd be playing more video games then Zach. Zach's also learning about punishments, primarily that it's much more fun to give punishments than to receive them.

Conversations with Zach

in the order which life dealt them
Lying in bed, Zach screams out to me, while I'm trying to enjoy my morning coffee:
Z: Dada - where's mamma?
Z: Dada -  mamma's not getting me.
I: Stop Whining!
Z: *Emphatically* I'm not whining.

I was planning a date with my good friend Nathan, who has a son Shahar
I: Zach do you want to go for a playdate with Shahar?
Z: OK. Uh wait ...  I'll only go on one condition!
I: What's the condition?
Z: That Shahar comes with his boy
I: Shahar is the boy, Nathan is the dad. 
Z: Oh yeah.

Four year old's are starting to learn about their feelings. Zach and Shahar got snippy in the back seat of the minivan: 
Z: You should come to my house. 
Z: You can come and see the robotics lab
Shahar: Hey, you don't care about me.
Z: No I care about you, but I also care about the robotics lab.

Zach's also learning to copy, Tori sprained her ankle this week. 
 
I: Go in there are play
Z: I can't
I: Why not? 
Z: I broke my ankle.

Zach's getting a bit excited about Sprocket: 
Z: I can't wait for Sprocket to get here.
I: Why's that?  
Z: When Sprocket gets here he can go 'Dun-DaDa-Da' when I do a trick.
I: Hym...

Zach's not totally selfish though, Zach's willing to do stuff for Sprocket:
I: You know, when Sprocket gets here you'll have to do stuff for sprocket.
Z: Yeah, I'll make sprocket baby toys, like robots.

Zach also wants to tell others like Sammy about Sprocket on Skype
Sammy: Hi Zach, how are you? 
Z: I'm getting a new cousin.
Sammy: A new cousin?
Z: Yeah I've cousin Sammy, cousin Kitty, and soon I'll have cousin sprocket.

Zach's learning about boring:
Teacher: You need to wait your turn
Z: This is boring
I: Hey, that's not OK.
Z: But this is boring, I want to go home and watch cartoons.

Zach's still learning how to curse and defame.
I: No, you can't do that. 
Z: I'm mad at you!
I: Why? 
Z: Because you're a sticker head!

With all this boredom and cursing I need to learn to discipline, and Zach needs to learn to be disciplined, we've got some work to do.
Z: Shutup
I:  -- Yelling -- Hey! I never want to here that again!
Z: Sad, and whimpering.
I: I'm sorry. I shouldn’t have yelled at you, you didn't know that was a bad word.
I: I’m sorry, do you accept my apology?
Z: No! I don't! You are punished, and you can't have your ball back till I'm not mad.  
I: Look I said I'm sorry.
Z: You're still punished, no putting me to bed for a week.

Zach goes for Lunch with his Mom a lot, but not with me, so when we go for lunch we end up wasting food.
I: Alright, what do you want for lunch? 
Z: I'll have a mayo Sammy with everything but avocado.
-- I order a turkey sandwich with mayo and it arrives, I give it to Zach --
Z: I only eat the Sammy I really want, and I was kidding when I said I wanted that Sammy.

Have a great week and remember - blow in the eye - makes a happy little guy - ZiT

entry.title: Week 199AZ: Chicken
entry.content:
I fictionalized the story, but trust me, it was dramatic enough in real life too.


Zach won't leave without me, he knows I won't follow - I smirked under my breath as I watched Zach consider going down the staircase alone from my hiding spot behind the rack of clearance jackets.

Arrogantly, I recalled all the times Tori scolded Zach for running away from her. When Zach is with me, I thought with a chuckle, Zach knows if he doesn't watch me, he'll end up alone and afraid, so he stays close.  As I pondered my parental superiority, I looked back at the stair case, and realized Zach was gone. My mind filled with irrational thoughts, and I forced a deep breath. Thinking rationally, I worked out that Zach would realize he couldn't find me, freeze and start crying. Understanding the situation, my fists unclenched, and I sauntered to the staircase, smugly looking for Zach. On the ground floor, I saw no sign of him.

A pit grew in my stomach as I scanned the floor of the giant sporting store. There was no movement in the tents, sleeping bags, or skis. I strained my hearing, and only heard the Beatles playing on the store radio. My fingernails cut into my palm as I realized I had no idea where Zach was. Shit, I thought, Zach might have thought I'd already left and was waiting  for him in the car.

I pushed open the store's heavy oak doors imagining how hard it would be for drivers to see Zach in the three floor parking garage. I looked around frantically as I stabbed the down button impatiently. "Fuck, I'm never going to find Zach before he's hit by a car" raced through my head as I waited for the elevator. Before the elevator doors opened, panic stricken, and certain I'd never find Zach again, I ran back into the store hoping I might hear Zach crying.

While I frantically scanned through the store, I heard "No, my name is Dr. Bug". My legs became wobbly as I ran towards the sound of Zach's voice.  Zach was arguing with a gray haired woman, when I grabbed him into a bear hug. As I squeezed Zach, the lady explained she was with store security, and Zach was found playing with snowboards. As I thanked her profusely, I continued to squeeze Zach tightly to my chest. Suddenly, Zach's lip trembled and he started crying and hitting me.

Zach isn't old enough to articulate his emotions, but I suspect they were the same as mine.

In other news

In house news, we await a permit from the city. The contractors tell us all is good, but work still hasn't begun on the basement. Hopefully we can get a completion estimate from the contractor so we can hold them to their schedule.

In volunteering news, Tori is done! While it was painful not seeing Tori most of the weekends, I would never have guessed how valuable Tori's volunteering has been to my relationship with Zach and my skill as a father. Life lesson here - challenges come with gifts, take the challenges to collect the gifts.

In Sprocket news, Tori thinks I'll be able feel Sprocket kicking. Because of where Zach's placenta attached we could never do this with Zach, so I'm totally stoked. I've also placed Sprocket's car seat in the car, which because of not having a car, I could never do with Zach's car seat. Hopefully owning a car and stuff will be good foreshadowing for our level of Sprocket preparation.

In Igor news, I'm getting serious about photography. Not only have I bought a fancy camera (I know, I do that every few years) but I've also been taking courses on photography, and have a friend who's willing to teach me the art of composition. Next up, I'll need to learn to erase pictures and then my photo feed will be a pleasure to look at.

In Zach news, Zach is signed up for full time waldorf kindergarten. It's not cheap, but I'm rather fond of Waldorf, and I'm thrilled to have Zach in a split grade class where he's the younger side of the class.

Conversations with Zach

When I see Zach having some of my less wonderful traits, I wonder if he learned it from my genes, or from watching me.
I usually don't let the door to door salesman take more then a minute of time. A sales guy rang the bell and I opened the door:
I: Hello? 
Sales Guy: Hi, I'm with comcast, and just talking to your neighbors.
I: Well, I'm sorry ...
Zack: Sorry we're not home (and turns off the light).
I: Sorry about that, we're not interested, have a great day.

I often try to be tough, even when I'm hurt. Zach wiped out at the grocery store: 
I: Ouch, you alright buddy? 
Z: It's ok everyone - the floor caught me.

I like to be the center of attention. It was snowing a few days ago, and we were playing snowmen with some neighborhood boys, Zach was not getting attention.
I: Huh, what's wrong buddy why are you crying.
Z: We're not playing the game I want to play
I: Comeon buddy these guys are playing. Let's go to their snowman.
Z: Only if they say pretty please with cupcakes on top.

I like to be clever and make connections. Zach saw a bunch of large snow balls that were ready to be the base of snow men:
I: Zach, those are pretty cool huh? 
Z: Uhm, who ate up all that snow and pooped out those balls?

entry.title: Week 198AZ: The crying game.
entry.content:
Perfect,we'll be there at 11. I hung up the phone with the reservation office. "Zach, you're going to play at the gym when Daddy runs tomorrow - are you excited?" "bababeepogagoo" giggles Zach as he bounces off to watch tv.

The next morning Zach was excited as we got into the car to go to the gym, but as it was time to drop Zach off, the story changed.

As I gave Zach a hug before heading into the changing room, Zach's lower lip began to tremble, tears streamed down his eyes, and he exuded terror. "Don't go" he begged. Heart in my stomach, I promised I'd come back in two minutes after I'd changed into my gym clothes.

I raced to the locker room and changed quickly. Within a minute, I was back at the daycare. Zach was cowering in the corner, when he saw me, he raced over and gave me a huge hug that he wouldn't let go of. Tears streaming down his face, lower lip still trembling, and looking no less terrified, Zach begged me to come back in two minutes. "I'll be back in 30 minutes when I'm done running", I said, trying to maintain my cool.

My whole run, all I could think of is Zach and his terrified expression. Fifteen minutes into my run I decided I can't put Zach through this torture, and raced back to the daycare to rescue my traumatized child.
Covered in sweat, I pull open the door to the daycare. I see Zach playing with the other children. "Oh dada" he says looking up, but not coming over to me, "Why don't you give me a few minutes, then we can play together". Feeling better about Zach, but not wanting to push my luck, I quickly finished my run and took a 2 minute shower, ready to minimize Zach's traumatic experience.

Now, fully dressed and ready to pick up Zach, I open the daycare door, and see Zach directing 3 older boys, barking directions and demanding they perform tricks. "Let's go" I say to Zach, but he refuses. Why don't you wait outside for 15 minutes, says Zach as he tries to maximize his time at the gym daycare.

In other news

In house news, the basement contract has been signed, a large check has been written, and we await the day when contractors scurry through our basement.

In volunteering news, after this weekend there will only 24 hours remaining of volunteering. Tori has been an absolute machine, knocking out 20 hours per week for the last 4 weeks. That's 16 hours per weekend, and an extra 4 hours on Friday as Zach goes to drop off daycare.

In sprocket news, sprocket is tap dancing in Tori's viscera.

In Igor news, I'm loving my new job. I knew it was a good move for me, but it ended up being even better then I imagined. Also, I've completed three 1000$ 5 lbs challenges, and have signed up for a fourth. Not only do I fit into skinnier pants, but I'm learning the value of sustainable approaches.

Conversations with Zach

Zach's learning to make friends, and him and his friends are learning how girls work, and should be interacted with: 
Z: Let's find those girls before they turn us into snow angels
Other Boy: OK
Z: Haha, found you girl - you're under arrest.
Zach's hasn't yet realized that sometimes relationship are more important then being right:
Z: You can have a lollipop
Other boy:  That's not a lollipop it's a sucker
Z: It's not a sucker, sucker is someone you don't like
Zach's all about negotiating, and sometimes he can be heavy handed. 
I: Zach, we need to go to mail a package, after that we'll play - Deal?  
Z: If you want me to have a not fun deal, I'm not going to take it. I'll destroy it.
In another heavy handed moment: 
Z: If you don't give me chips, you'll all be fired.
Zach isn't always heavy handed, sometimes he'll provide a compromise: 
Z: Dad you can't eat any of my chips, but after March you can share my Halloween candy.
Zach's also learning to negotiate time, but he doesn't have it quite right yet. 
I: Zach, you have 5 minutes left. 
...
I: Zach, you have 2 minutes left.
Z: No no dada I still have 5 seconds left.
A powerful negotiating tactic is making clear generally accepted practices. At the grocery store I only allow Zach to buy one banana (every day we throw away bananas)
Z: I'd rather go shopping with Mom then Dad, since Mom lets me buy as many bananas as I want.
Another negotiating tactic is manipulating emotions, which Zach practices with gusto: 
I: Do you remember the fruit stand?
Z: I remember
I: We should go for old times sake.
Z: ... Bursts into Tears ... It's all gone, it's all destroyed
I: Huh? No it's still there.
Z: ... sobbing ... no it's gone, I know it's gone. 
I: Huh? What is going on?
Z: OHHH, Just Kidding.
Another negotiating tactic is justifying. Zach's four year old friend Malcolm was here, and Zach tried to run him over with his bicycle: 
 I: Zach, stop that right now, no running over guests. 
 I: No no, I'm not running him over, it's a joke. I'm just practicing my jokes.
Another useful tactic is pretending disinterest. Malcolm, still at our house wanted to play with one of Zach's toys.
Malcolm: What is that toy? How do you play it? 
Z: Oh that's just a baby toy, only babies play with it. You really don't want to play it.
Zach summarizes his negotiating tactics:
Z: Tricking is my name, and controlling is my game.
Beyond negotiating it's amazing what Zach understands, in relation to pregnancy:
I: And soon Sprocket will be coming out of Mommy's belly
Z: Mommy doesn't want Sprocket to be taken out of her, she wants Sprocket to grow out.
In relation to anatomy, I stuck my finger into Zach's rabbit finger puppet: 
I: Hello Zach - I'm Rabbit!
Z: Ewww! Dada you stuck your finger in the hole rabbit pees and poops from.
In relation to privacy, Zach likes a parent near the door when he's going to the bathroom but:
Z: You can watch me, but only if I'm peeing, if I'm pooing then you can't look.
Zach even understands personal space: 
I: Well when sprocket comes he'll sleep upstairs
I: But when he gets older he'll sleep downstairs with you. 
Z: What!?!
Z: No, it's OK, he can sleep upstairs with you.
Finally, no one wants to admit they nodded off, and Zach is no exception:
Z: I wasn't sleeping, I was just relaxing with my eyes closed. Sometimes I do that.

entry.title: Tori's Take: January 2014
entry.content:
Tori has graciously agreed to donate her family updates to the blog.   Enjoy her view, voice and writing.

Hello family

Sorry we have been pretty quiet. We survived the holidays - Zach still has presents that haven't been opened and played with and the neighbors got their annual cookie treats. Mostly though we have been trying to prep and get ready for Sprocket and finish up with everything that I need to apply to nursing school. The former involves having a contractor build some walls in the basement for Igor's office to actually be somewhat Zach proof and a new basement bathroom. The latter just involves me spending way too many hours volunteering at the nearby hospital and taking placement exams. Igor also started with a new team at Microsoft in a slightly different job which thankfully has meant less stress.

Sprocket and I have cleared all sorts of testing hurdles as we enter the final trimester. One of us kicks like a mule and makes it hard to sleep. Sadly my placenta is in front of the baby so I don't get to share as much of the kicking as I would like with Igor, Zach, and the cat. I think I have two more lab tests to pass and probably one more ultrasound, ugh. We are hoping to have another home birth but will go with the wisdom of the midwife on that one.

I sign the papers to start construction tomorrow. So far the contractor has not threatened to kill us for our numerous questions. He works with his wife and she has been dying to meet Zach since they don't have grandkids yet. We will see how badly she still wants them after she hangs out with Zach for a bit. 

Speaking of the gremlin, he seems to be becoming more social. I've been able to drop him off at preschool or a drop in care center and he actually plays with other children successfully. I wonder if his plans to take over the world have been thwarted enough after all. I did tell him he would have to clean the planet if he took it over. Cleaning is not really one of Zach's joys.

Pet wise we have a new toilet fish  - our toilet has a section that is a fish tank separate from the part that actually flushes. Toilet fish seem to have a one year life expectancy. The cat is still hanging on. He is come inside for warmth more and more lately and because Zach is off at school two mornings a week. But he is getting older and creakier, as cats do.

I will let you know how the construction progresses. I already foresee a wealth of learning opportunities for Zach on the project. I will also try and keep you updated on Sprocket, who should be showing up some time in mid to late April.

entry.title: Week 193AZ:Some weeks life isn't dramatic, and that's a good thing
entry.content:
This blog post is to remind me that life is the little things
Snow and ice go to the same college - lectured Zach after we told him that even though the car is covered in ice, doesn't mean there is snow on the ground. While Zach continued his lecture on modern meteorology I escorted Zach to the car so we could drop Tori off at the hospital where she'd be volunteering for the next 8 hours. At the entrance to the hospital, as Tori gave Zach his good bye hug, I double checked my todo list for the day. As Tori went to the hospital, we drove to our first chore - bulk grocery shopping at cash and carry.

Cash and carry has giant shopping carts, which Zach likes to ride on. As Zach rides the shopping cart, we often pretend we're garbage men, with me driving the truck, and Zach picking up garbage (The irony here is Tori often complains we've purchased garbage when we get home too).

After Cash and Carry, we went off to the cable store where we dropped off our old cable modem. While we were there, Zach actually counted the computer checkouts - and said wow - there are 10 computers here - as I double checked his count, I was very impressed.

Cable modem dropped off, we needed to mail my broken camera to the repair depot, so we zipped off to FedEx. While at fedex, Zach was excited to see a water fountain, and as he raced towards it, he slipped and bashed his chin. In a shroud of crying we returned home, ending our first round of chores.

Once home Zach demanding chicken on a plate with fries and ketchup. This is chicken nuggets and fries, which is one of Zach's favorite foods. As I try to force my health kick on Zach I negotiated him down to the grilled chicken breast with Radishes.

Next, as I wanted to Veg out, Zach dragged me outside, and we went to the park, and wandered out the tiny secret path.

After that, we watched a cartoon, and then needed out of the house again, this time to the library, the bar (which was closed) the school, and finally to pick up Mom after her 8 hour volunteering shift.

In Other News

Life returns to normal next week, Zach to school, Igor to Work, and Tori to rangle our basement remodel. Sprocket is very communicative, and enjoys banging on Tori's bladder for attention. I hit my weight loss goals for December, and I'll be resetting my goal for another 5 pounds in January, slow and steady is an odd mechanism for me, but it's pretty effective.

Conversations with Zach

Now one of my favorite parts of life, talking To Zach...

We had some sitters in December, which Zach loved, and he always wanted them to come back. Zach realized they don't usually come back, so figured it was because we weren't calling them on the phone:
Z: OK, you should give dada your number, so that he can call you and tell you to come back.
I came down stairs on Christmas Day and Zach and Tori were chatting: 
Z: Hey, it's not snowing - it's an imaginary Christmas. 
Z: What you do is you wait and wait for snow, and that'll be boring. 
Z: Dada - Mama was wrong - it's an imaginary Christmas! 
T: Why? 
Z: Because it's not snowing!
T: You need to be especially good for snow. 
Z: But I was especially good - why is there snow. 
I: They didn't make enough snow, 
Z: OK, Let's watch the movie you made me on Christmas eve. 
Z: Let's make baba and grammy and Malcolm watch it.
As we were giving Zach his Christmas presents: 
T: Kitty gave it to you 
Z: Yeah, thanks kitty
I: How did kitty buy it, he doesn't have a job, doesn't have any money. 
Z: Kitty didn't buy it silly, he told Santa to buy it for me.
The next present we gave Zack came from Sprocket:
Z: Thank You sprocket that's what I've always dreamed of.
A few days later I wanted to see how Zach enjoyed his Christmas video: 
I: Did you like your video?
Z: Yeah, I liked the video you gave me for Christmas.
I: Really, did you like it? 
Z: Well, it was boring. Not super boring, just a little boring.
Zach always wants to turn on my high powered flashlight, which I do not allow. One day as I came down the stairs extra groggy: 
Z: Dadda, can I  test your flashlight
I: No, you're not allowed, it's too bright and dangerous
Z: OH (with stink face) , I wasn't turning it on, I was just testing it.
I'm trying to teach Zach that he we're not his servant, and even though there are things he can't do (like pour milk) he has to do his part: 
Z: I want milk
I: Get it from the fridge
Z: I hate it when you make me do stuff, you'll have to pour it.
Have a great week and remember When you want to be concise, show your love with bowl of rice - ZiT

link.title: Week 193AZ:Some weeks life isn't dramatic, and that's a good thing

entry.title: A message for Tori
entry.content: We've been together for the best years of my life. Today,  you're planning a basement remodel, volunteering at a hospital, raising a 4 year old and growing our next child. I love you.

entry.title: Happy jump in the lake day 2014
entry.content:
Every year I jump in the freezing lake on January first.   This January first, I didn't want to jump in the lake. It was cold outside, I was tired, Tori was feeling icky, Zach was being grumpy.  As I tried to talk myself out of polar plunging,  I realized I was late for the plunge so I herded my family, and quickly drove off to the beach. As I sat at a stop light, already late, I realized I forgot my sandals. I hate walking on rocks, especially when I'm in freezing water, shivering, with numb feet. But I didn't have time to get home, so I kept driving to the lake. 

Naked except for underwear, feet frozen on the rocky beach, I thought, you know I don't need to jump in the lake, I can back out.  

And then I remembered why I jump in the lake. I jump in the lake to cement in my mind  "Get it done, nothing bad is going to happen. Resistance is a debilitating disease you must fight with all your soul".  As I hit the water, I realized, it's not that bad. I jumped in, got wet, and felt great.

So remember - get it done, nothing bad is going to happen. Resistance is a debilitating disease you must fight with all your soul - Happy New Year!

ps. Thank you Tori for coming even when you didn't feel well. It means a lot to me to have you and Zach present for this most important life lesson.

link.title: Happy jump in the lake day 2014

entry.title: My name is Dr. Bug
entry.content: Zach wants everyone to call him Dr. Bug, as he loves to control robots. We shouldn't encourage this behavior, but I have trouble helping my self:

entry.title: Week 191AZ: Today is the best day of my life
entry.content:
Gripping the walker for dear life, desperately trying to stay vertical, Zach pawed furiously at the ice with his skates. Two inches from the skating rink entrance, for the thirty seconds since we got on the ice, I hold the walker and tell Zach to relax and lean forward. It's pointless though, Zach's first time on the ice is a failure, and we both know it. I help Zach take the two steps off the ice, and escort him to Tori, who on account of Sprocket not wanting to be squished, has decided to stay off the ice. Tori, Zach and I are at the skating rink as Julia, one of Zach's best friends, wanted to go skating.

With Zach on the sidelines I head back to the ice determined to show Zach that skating is fun. In front of me, Julia, a determined four year old girl, has her walker in one hand and her wobbly mother in the other and is pulling them both towards the ice. Noel, Julia's Mom, was eyeing the ice apprehensively so I offered to take Julia onto the rink. Noel, concerned but grateful, helped me put Julia and walker on the ice.

Julia took two unsteady steps with a huge smile, and then nailed her balance. Within a minute we skated her first lap, and Julia was beaming. On our fourth lap, Julia noticed her unsteady Mom's distress and said "Igor, I'm good, can you help my Mom skate?". Noel declined the offer, and demanded I keep my full attention on Julia. My attention was not needed though as Julia in skates is like a fish in water. Julia did several laps with me a fair distance back. The best thing about Julia was every few laps she would come to the glass Zach was sitting behind, wave at him, and demand he come on the ice. Zach, like Julia's mother, was done with the ice and refused.

Small world that it is, our next adventure, several hours later, was skating with families from work. Given our earlier skating adventure, I didn't expect Zach to go on the ice, but at least he'd see his Dad enjoy skating. To my amazement, after watching me skate for a few minutes, Zach wanted on the ice. We rented him skates, and this time he got the hang of it! It took several ice excursions to build up confidence, but within the hour Zach was skating all by himself, even better then Julia had.

As we were leaving the ice to go home, I asked "Zach, how did you like Skating?", and he beamed back "Today is the best day of my life!"

In Other News

This is cookie week, the week that Tori makes the Christmas cookies we hand out to our friends and neighbors. As you can imagine, Tori is in charge of production, and Zachary is in charge of distribution. In years past my contribution has centered on quality control, and sub-par product disposal, but this year I'm on a strict diet, so no biscuit for me.
Unrelated to cookie production, Zach woke up on Friday to a blanket of snow. At first Zach was confused, but then was thrilled to go outside and throw snowballs, make miniature snowmen and frolic whimsically. 

Best of all, Friday was our Christmas train ride (different from the santa train from last week), and we got to see the train and terrain covered in snow. As it was snowing in Seattle the roads were treacherous, but luckily Tori was wise enough to buy an all wheel drive SUV, and we made the train with minutes to spare.

Finally, we've been using our Microsoft benefit of highly subsided baby sitters and Zach loves it! Tori and I like it too because we can get out of the house knowing Zach is in good hands.

Conversations with Zach

Zach is learning about trickery, for example after we finished swimming at 9pm:
Z: Dada, I've got lots of energy I can go home and watch cartoons.
I: I'm thrilled you have lots of energy, let's go to the grocery store 
Z: Oh, I can't go to the grocery store, I'm ahh, grounded

Zach's also learning misdirection. When Tori Zach and I were in the car, and Zach, who is not wearing headphones, was kicking the back of Tori's seat:
T: Stop kicking my chair!
Z: What? I can't hear you - I've got my head phones on. 
Z: OK, I've got them off now. What did you say?

Speaking of cars, I was warming up the car waiting for Tori and Zach. Suddenly Zach rips open the back passenger seat door and says like a bank robber:
Z: Let's hit the expressway.

Zach's also learning how to control a situation, after i discovered Zach had just pored him milk on the floor Zach said: 
Z: Dada - don't panic!

In another control situation, Zach responded to Tori and I arguing first thing in the morning. 
Z: Mama, why are you and dada mad?
T: Well, sometimes Mom wakes up and her brain doesn't work yet, and daddy asks lots of questions.
Z: Daddy, when mommy's brain isn't quite right, you shouldn't talk to her.

Have a great week and remember Those who can, do. Those who can't wish they did - ZiT

link.title: Week 191AZ: Today is the best day of my life

entry.title: Week 190AZ: Choosing Santa Trains
entry.content:
I'm experimenting with different formats for the blog. If you have preferences, favorites or requests holler.  Zach and Sprocket -  I realize you won't be able to give your input till it's too late, but you should apply your input to the blogs you write for your families. 

"I love you too" I whispered to Zach as I turned off his bedroom  light, and took a moment to reflect on my day as a father.....

The day started with me half asleep, searching for my instant coffee. "We've got circus school, and then the Santa train" Tori briefed me, as she sipped her own coffee and continued, "I'll be coming to circus school so we can get to the Santa train on time, it's a two hour drive".   "Yup" I nodded, trying to keep a positive look on my face.

In my head, I wondered if I'd actually agreed to this train ride. I hate long car rides, and a four hour round trip drive to see Santa on an antique train  isn't my thing. Then I remembered, I was originally going to skip the train, but realized I'm not a sixteen year old kid, but a husband and father, and making your wife and child happy are part of the deal.

As I turned off the car in the circus school parking lot I remembered today was demo day. Demo day is the last day of circus class, when parents can come and watch what their children have learned.   Even though I'd forgotten to tell Tori it was demo day, serendipity, better known as a long drive to a train , had her at my side.

I was thrilled Tori was with me to experience Zach's pleasure on tightwire, trampoline and trapeze . With  Demo day complete we hopped into the car and headed to the train.

I was grumpy for the two hour ride to the train, ruminating on all the fun things I could be doing instead of sitting in the car, and grumpier still when I realized we were early and needed to wait another 30 minutes before boarding.

As we lined up for the train, a set of grandparents with their grand kids lined up behind us, and I decided it was time for some fun.  I started hopping around like a bunny rabbit, and before long Zach, the boy  in line behind us, and various kids in line started chasing me.  With so much hopping I starting to enjoy the day, and before I knew it we were on the train.

The train, a hundred year old steamer,  was great. We wandered around the cars, talked with other friendly folks and imagined the slower pace of life in years gone by.  The train had  a stop over at the maintenance train depot, and it was really interesting to see the tools used by industry of yesteryear. Zach got to meet Santa on the train, and a good time was had by all.

After the train ride, we ate at a spiffy restaurant that was in two side by side cut open train  cars. I really enjoyed my meal, talking to Zach and Tori, and reflecting on how lucky I am.

On the two hour ride home, we were all in great spirits, we saw a family of deer, enjoyed the drive, and even  sang made up Christmas carols.   By the way, if you never heard Tori sing before, I strongly recommend you encourage her to sing, it's angelic.

The morals of the story are two fold:
1) Thank Tori, she makes our family awesome
2) Father and partner are  large chunks of my life, I can choose to think of these tasks as responsibilities or rewards.  Whatever I choose, will be true, so choose wisely.




In Other News
Tori and Zach walked down to the corner store and picked up our christmas tree. Also, Tori made Zach a bunny suit (which I'm jealous of). The home remodel is moving slowly, Tori's driving hard, but contractors are a bugger to track down. I think we'll pay a premium for responsive contractors.  In health news, I lost 5lbs in November and thus didn't have to pay a 1000$. I've re-bet in December, and hope to keep losing 5lb per month instead of 1000 per month. My cheapness is very motivating.

Enough of the opening acts, it's time for ....

Conversations with Zach:

Zach's training to be a mini Zen master
Z: Boring is called waiting

Like his father, Zach's interested in junk food and health. Some of our discussions:

Z:Get me any bubble juice you want except for the one I don't like.
I: What one don't you like?
Z: All the one that taste like water.

Z: I’m hungry again?
I: What?
Z: I'm hungry for McDonalds
Z: Find a McDonalds with a play space.

Z: I need healthy food like chips
I: Chips are not healthy
Z: They're healthy for me
I: Trust me, they're not healthy.
Z: If they were not healthy, I'd throw up


Zach is learning to use synonyms which is awesome:

Z: I'm sbf
I: Huh? I don't understand?
Z: I'm sbif?
I: Huh, I don't understand, can you use a different word that's like that word, maybe I'll understand that
Z: crying.
I: Oh, you're sad - I get it, good job!


Zach's also learning my behaviors, and our relationship:

Z: Write in your book!
I: When are you going to start writing in my book?
Z: When I turn into you
I: When will that be?
Z: When I grow up!

Zach's also learning family relationships:

I: Let me talk to my sister.
Z: You talk to your sister, I"ll talk to aunt yelena.

And baby sitter relationships (he's talking ot the baby sitter):

Z: You should come back, can I get your number
Z: Don't tell anyone else your number it's secret between you and me

Have a great week and remember - Family on the Santa train, kid eating a candy cane- ZiT

entry.title: Week 188AZ: Digging Ditches
entry.content:
"Daddy, is it morning yet?", whispered Zach as we laid in bed watching the sun rise.  "Not yet", I answered hoping to squeeze a few extra minutes of sleep out of the morning. "But Dada, the bobcat has lots of chores it needs to finish".

This week is American Thanksgiving and we made our annual pilgrimage to Maureen and Brian's ranch. Instead of our normal "leave at midnight, and fall asleep when we get there" travel arrangement, we monopolized on the fact that I'm a crazy early morning person and left at 4am. Leaving at 4am is perfect as we skip traffic and arrive at a reasonable time in the afternoon feeling refreshed. Beyond leaving at a sane time, I didn't speed at all, which let Tori have a relaxing journey.

Getting to pretend we are farm hands is one of our favorite parts the trip. This year Zach got in on the action and helped us feed cows, rip out a stump and dig a big hole with a back hoe, and drive the stump around .   Zach also took a stab at being a dog's best friend. Zach and Cochise spent many hours playing catch. It was extraordinarily cute and helped me understand why dogs and little boys go together better than peanut butter and jelly.

Once we get back from Maureen and Brian's it'll be back to work and this time it will be different. See I recently switched jobs, leaving John's team and joining Sean's Team.  While happy for the change, I'll miss my old team greatly. Zach being a problem solver, had a clever solution:

Z: Did you tell me how was your day?
I: Nope
Z: Tell me
I: It was a hard day because I can't work with my friends anymore.
Z:  Why is that hard?
I: Well imagine you used to have friends at school and now you don't get to be in their class anymore.
Z: Why can't you stay in their class.
I: Well, imagine I used to be in Teacher John's class, and now I have to go to Teacher Sean's class. I'll miss my friends in Teacher John's class.
Z: Um, I know, I'll make a Seaninator which turn John into Sean and then you don't have to change classes.



On the homestead, we're trying to get a bathroom and office built in the basement. Tori's been corralling contractors but they're a wiley bunch and they keep getting away.  With luck, we'll have the first basement project  done before Sprocket arrives.   On the remodeling topic I installed a fancy thermostat which can turn off when it figures out we're not home. I did the electrical installation and Tori did everything else. It's a pleasure to watch her work. While I'd be taking hours, doing it over several times,  dropping everything on the ground and putting it in crooked, Tori just grabs her tools, uses her fingers like the legs of an octopus and gets the job done in minutes.

Of late, we've had a renewed interest in health. Tori's been cooking healthier food, and going to pilates. I made a bet that I would lose 5lbs by December 1st, or pay a $1000.   This bet was one of the best thing I've done in a long time, as I can pit my desire to be cheap against my desire to eat junk food and not exercise. So far the cheapness is winning, we'll be testing my weight shortly.  If you talk to me, remind me to redo this bet every month as it's excellent for me!

Finally, my favorite part of the show - Conversations with Zach:

Trying to put off something useful, I was sitting on the couch staring off into space when Zach said in a frantic voice:

Z: A Dragon is coming, we need to lock the door
I: Uh, why don't you give me a hug
Z: Dad, how will a hug help?
I: I don't know we'll feel better.
Z: Oh, you should hug the dragon if he comes.

Z:  I'm talking to the dragon on the phone now
I: Um, can you get me a coffee from the dragon
Z: Huh?
I: Well he can use his fire to boil water.
Z: Wait, the dragon only makes cocoa
I: OK, I'll have cocoa
Z: Hum the dragon doesn't speak English like I do
I: What does he speak
Z: Japanese
I: Oh, no cocoa for me I guess.

As I walked in from getting groceries, Tori had her hands on her hips, and her lips pursed:

Tori: Zach wants his juicer back
I: Well, you can't have the juicer I gave it to uncle Ammon.
Z: I'll destroy uncle Ammon then.
I: Um, but will that get you your juicer back
Z: Doesn't matter.

In my office I keep a big jar of fortune cookies. Zach can't read yet, be he is already understanding the importance of a good omen:

Z: Can I have a cookie?
I: Sure, here you go.
Z: This cookie says - Zach you should eat me.

Zach's not always cute. He's getting very excited about being evil and making traps.  Zach put out my acupressure mat (a rug with poking things on it), and tried to get me to step on the trap. Zach tripped and landed on the mat:

Z: Crying
I: Zach do you need a knife to cut off your feet.
Z: No, I don't want to cut off my feet.
I: OK do you want a hug?
Z: No, I don't want a hug
I: Well, that's the problem with traps.
Z: I wanted to make a trap to distract you.
I: Well, did that feel nice to be in a trap
Z: I didn't want to be distracted; I wanted you to be caught in the trap..
I: Well, was that nice?

Zach's still getting used to the idea of babies, and Sprocket in general. As we were reading a story about big brothers, we had this discussion:

Z: You play with baby, and then you'll have to stop playing with me.
I: No, we'll still love you, but need to play with baby too.
Z: I'll have to make a baby-inator
I: What?
Z: It'll just be a toy baby-inator it won't hurt any one.
Z: Baby's can't talk. Baby Kathy can't talk, not till she gets bigger.
Z: Babies eat baby food, we eat people food. We'll need a lawn mower to turn people food into baby food.
I: Huh, do we have a lawn mower? Z: A lawn mower is a blender. A blender does what a lawn mower does.


To record these conversations I need to write them in my book, Zach observed me doing this and said:
Z: What are you doing?
I: I'm writing this down so I can remember it.
Z: But you're doing what I do!
I: Huh?
Z: You're not writing letters, you're just writing scribbles

Zach came down and kept poking me.
I'm like huh?
And he points down.
I look down and he's wearing his bee slippers.


Have a great week and remember. Hands on at a farm, works like a charm, to keep your mind out of harm - ZiT

entry.title: Week 184AZ: Three and a half year old independence
entry.content:
"Zach what do you need to do before crossing the road?" I asked as I scanned the road for cars.  Since Zach didn't answer I turned my head and saw Zach with pants around his ankles and urine arching onto the grass.
"What are you doing?" I asked with some concern.
"I'm peeing on the grass" replied Zach joyfully.
"What? No, you pee on bushes or trees" I said uneasily
"Dada,  I don't do things like you do" smirked Zach as he pulled up his pants
"No you can't pee where people can see your penis" I stated firmly. At the same time I was filling with pride at Zach's independence and ability to pee without getting his pants wet.
"Don't kid me, sometimes I pee off the porch" answered Zach authoritatively.
That's not the only thing Zach does differently. When Zach gets people to pose for pictures he says "Say Stupid!"
Also, every week Zach's imagination grows. How's this for imaginative:
  
Z: A dragon is coming we need to lock the door
I: Uh, why don't you give me a hug
Z: Dad, how will a hug help?
I: I don't know, we'll feel better.
Z: Oh, then you should hug the dragon if he comes.
Z:  I'm talking to the dragon on the phone now
I: Um, can you ask the dragon to get me a cup of coffee?
Z: Huh?
I: Well he can use his fire to boil water.
Z: Wait, the dragon only makes cocoa!
I: OK, I'll have cocoa.
Z: Hym, the dragon doesn't speak English like I do
I: What does he speak?
Z: Japanese
I: Oh, no cocoa for me I guess.
This was a tough week for the family, Igor's work had a lot going on, and Zach, Tori and Igor had rivers of green escaping from their noses most days.  We're not healthy yet, but we're on the mend.
Saturday, Tori went to her final escort training session and I went to Burlesque.  Burlesque was awesome, but escort training did not consist of feathers and lipstick.  Tori needs 196 hours of volunteering to get more points for her nursing school application;  escorting people in wheelchairs is her volunteer activity. After this weekend only 192 hours to go.
Sunday Tori was out escorting and I was running Zach around the park. Watching Zach is hard. I was out cold by the time Tori got home, I don't know how she can watch Zach all day - she's a super mom!

Have a great week and remember -  To much time peeing in the grass, and someone big might kick your ass - ZiT

link.title: Week 184AZ: Three and a half year old independence

entry.title: Halloween 2013: Zach's Turn
entry.content:
This year, Zach didn't want to go out for Halloween, but wanted to give out candy instead.

Some funny moments during Halloween

When someone asked for a lollipop:
Z: I don't want to hand out lollipops, but I'll give one to the next kids.

When a teenager came to the door
Z: I won't give out people with masks, take it off.

After dropping a candy
Z: It's not easy with these short arms

I recorded a few of the encounters as Zach gave out candies - enjoy!

entry.title: Week 179AZ: Love Potions and other select snippets from Zach's week.
entry.content:
"Bear and Bear Bear are in love because they drank love potion" said Zach.

Remember I can't call you because I only a pretend phone

I only control people with love potion

You're kidding me I also like garfield and johnny test and sonic the hedgehog

What that (turnip?)
It'sa  point radish

I work at daddy's work, I used to be athe old janitor, but now I"m a vacuum cleaner, but the people there told me to see love potion.  But I hated it so I went home.

WHar are you looking for?
Cauliflower


We went to see the sheep.

Zach and I went on an adventure to buy my buddy Sean a tee-shirt.

I: Let's get Sean a tee-shirt
Z: Sean?
I: Yup Sean.
Z: Sean the sheep?
I: No, Sean from work
Z: Oh - Ok


Have a great week and remember - Rain in spain, lick some sugar cane- ZiT

entry.title: Week 183AZ: When a leaf falls in the forest
entry.content:
Breathe in, breathe out, breathe in breathe out, I'm brought back to awareness as I hear the crinkling of footsteps over leaves.  I keep my eyes closed, letting he footsteps get closer before I acknowledge them.

A knotted old pine trunk juts into my back. The purple and gold leaves I sit cross legged on are damping, making my bum wet and cold.  In my lap, Zach sits peacefully, embraced in my bear like hug, resting after a long hike in search of a swamp monster. I feel Zach's warmth in my lap and become curious about the hikers who got no closer.

My eyes flutter open, I'm enthralled by the serenity of the trees.  Green, yellow, purple and red, a rainbow of leaves of all shades are on the trees and forest floor. I scan, but see no one to make footsteps. Then I understand the source of the rustling, it's leaves falling from the trees hitting  the lower branches on their path to rest on the golden forest floor.

I hug Zach tighter, and take a few minutes to breath, and enjoy the scene.  This weekend Zach and I went to the forest, and we loved it.

Here are some fun conversations we had this week:

Zach and I were at the grocery store, and Zach was in charge of the shopping cart: 
I: Steady, Steady
I: Careful, don't run into her
Z: Daddy, it's OK, I drive just like mommy does.

Zach and I still go to the bar - this time Zach was staring off into space while we ate: 
I: Zach, what are you thinking?
Z: I'm thinking don't steal my fries!

Attempts to distract Zach from the cemetery line of reasoning are not working well:
Z: If you sleep, and I yell cook-a-doodle-do in your ear, what happens?
I: I wake up.
Z: OK, If you're sleeping in the cemetery I can scream cock-a-doodle-do in your ear.
I: Uhh, what did you enjoy most today?
Z: Going to cemeteries.
I: Look - a train!

We were going to our neighbors birthday party, where Zach saw a pirate outside, and Zach said: 
Z: I'm bad
Pirate: Um, are you as bad as captain hook?
Z: I'm not as bad as captain hook, I'm as bad as Doofenshmitz.
I: Let's go inside
Z: No I'm thinking I need 7 more minutes.
I: What are you thinking?
Z: I'm thinking of trapping perry the platypus.
I: Let's go inside.
Z: Daddy, minutes are slower than that, there are still lots of minutes.

Hugs can be hard to come by in my house, for example: 
I: Can I get a hug?
Z: Sorry Dad, I'm actually just starting a cartoon.

As the days get shorter, it's time for bell season. As Zach says: 
Z: Can I get a bell - I haven't gotten a bell in years.

Finally, I'm perplexed where Zach picks things up, for example:
Z: Dad, you've gotta stop cold turkey, no more balls, more juggling, no more work, no more circus school, or you're fired.

In other news Zach is enjoying pre-school, and Tori is getting ready to volunteer to get more points for nursing school. Igor is wondering when he lost all his weight, and cat wonders why there are so few people to sleep on.

Have a good week and remember - Sitting on my knees, leaves falling from the trees, I'm happy and free - ZiT

link.title: Week 183AZ: When a leaf falls in the forest

entry.title: Voicemail from a three year old

link.title: Voicemail from a three year old

entry.title: Week 182AZ:Sprocket
entry.content:
I: I wish I could go to circus school with you, but they don't let grown ups in.
Z: It's ok, I know what we can do.
I: What's that?
Z: I invented a turnbackinator.
I: Huh, what's a turnbackinator?
Z: It makes grownups into little kids
I: That's a great idea, how do we make that?
Z: I don't remember; Mom can make it.

It's been a busy few weeks. Work's been crazy. I went to Canada, and oh yeah, we're having a kid at the end of April, nicknamed Sprocket.  Like people of yesteryear, we won't know if it’s a boy or girl till it appears in our living room.

The trip to Canada was a riot, jam packed with work, friends, family and almost missing a plane.  While exhausting, it was a great opportunity to practice being  effective, being calm, and enjoying whatever downtime I can get.

Work will be crazy for a bit, I'll give an update when it calms down.

Zach is an absolute riot. He's growing up, and reminding me of my childhood.   For example, just the other day Zach was kicked out of the library. I felt bad but told the librarian if his father was any indication, this will be a frequent occurrence.

Tuesday's we go swimming at the local pool, where Zach tends to run around with goop on his face, and swimming trunks that don't quite cover his bottom. Other moms are often concerned by Zach's bit of bare booty, and offer their assistance in pulling up his shorts. Being a Dad is awesome.

As a little man, Zach's starting to appreciate music, and share's my taste:
Z: Can we watch Macklemore? I love macklemore!
I: Sure, which song?
Z: The song with the little girl shopping
I: That's thrift shop.

Zach interest also extends to my hair arrangement
Z: Dad - why did you take off your mustache
I: I like change
Z: Why don't you have hair on your head?
I: Well I'm bald, one day you'll be bald
Z: No I won't - it looks silly
I: Oh, you'd be surprised, me and my Dad had this conversation.

Being a dad isn't all fun and games, the other day Zach brought me to tears:
Z: Do people get buried in a Cemetery?
I: Yes
Z: Um, but how do you leave?
I: You don't leave you're dead.
Me getting teary eyed
Z: But how do you go home if you're dead.
I: Remember when Ash the cat went to sleep and never woke up.
At this point I had to distract him with a train, the thought of either us being dead would have put me to tears. I'll leave these hard conversations to mom.

Lightening the load, Zach's also exploring the limits of his power and imagination.
Z: Dad, did you know I control the weather?
I: Nope, can you make it sunny? 
Z: Nah, not today.

To my great appreciation, Zach's starting to understand money.  After locking me out of his room:
I: Hey, can I come in.
Z: Nope you have to pay.
I: Here, I have a ticket.
Z: Nope, we don't take tickets, just dollars.
I: Hey, no way.
Z: Yup, see, here's the sign.
I: Ug!

Finally, there's nothing like getting a text from your wife, about your child:
T: Who taught your kid to poop off the front porch?
I: Uggg!

Have a great week, and remember  - One Kid - Fun, Two Kids Done - ZiT

entry.title: Week 178AZ: Don't Look
entry.content:
"Don't Look" screeched Zach as his urine formed a golden waterfall off the side of our front porch.  Thirty seconds earlier I was trying to find what Zach was doing outside. Thirty seconds earlier I told Zach his kindle would need to take a break if he refused to pee.

Tori has taken to sending Kindie (Zach's Kindle) to Gromit Island (Zach's pronunciation of Guemes Island) when Zach refuses to tell us when he's pooed or pees inside of the house outside the potty.  After Kindie's last vacation I asked zach what was going on. He replied " Um, good news and bad news. The bad news is Kindie is going to Gromit island".

On our post circus school adventures we had some interesting conversation:

I: Zach sit in your seat.
Z: Space makes you float away, gravity keeps you down.
I: That's why you need gravity.

Traffic was bad, so we listened to some Rap.

Z: Who is singing.
I: Macklemore.
Z: Is he your friend?
I: Well, I don't really know him.
Z: Well, he's my friend. He likes to watch TV all day long, just like me.

After sitting in traffic for ahn hour, we stopped at the grocery store to get some blending supplies. We parked across the street, and Zach demanded we hurry.

Z: Daddy we gotta run across the street
I: Why?
Z: Because otherwise Mom say's we'll be car pizza.

On our way home a strange discovery:
Z: Um I like junk Food
I: Why?
Z: Because it's filled with onions and onions are tasty.

At home I found Zach's broken foam sword:

I: Who broke your sword
Z: It broke when I wasn't home.
I: Where were you?
Z: I was out buying chips, someone came from the the bottom of the ocean to break it.


Have a great week and remember - the key to happiness is pretending - ZiT

entry.title: Week 177AZ: Stop I've got to poo!
entry.content:
Swerving into the parking lot of a downtown gas station, I bolted from my seat to get Zach out of the car. I intended to succeed this first time Zach asked to poo while driving.  I hurried Zach to the door of the 7/11 but Zach dug in his heels preventing me from pulling him into the gas station. "I want to poo on a tree" Zach declared. I froze in my tracks, temporarily confused.  My eyes darted around looking for a secluded tree, but being down town, there are none to be found.  I returned to my senses and negotiated with Zach. A few minutes laters, Zach flushed the toilet, washed his hands, and I nodded approval to my reflection in the gas station's bathroom mirror.

We've been busy these last few weeks. Maureen and Brian came to visit (escaping without a group photo), we went to the fair, a circus show, and I started a blending health kick including 5am wakeups.

In other news, Zach's growing up fast. He's started Co-Op preschool this week, and starts Waldorf preschool next week. This investment in education is paying off,  as Zach is always trying to increase his knowledge:

I: Zach do you want some Cashews?
Z: Huh? What kind of shoes do cats wear?

With education, comes creativity:
I: Zach do you need to poo:
Z:We're all out of telling Dad we need to poo's but I've got a few Mom we need to poos left

With creativity comes a desire to share knowledge:
Z: We live on the bottom floor of space, it's called earth.

With knowledge sharing comes independence:
I: Zach, did you poo?
Z: Dad, I've got it under control.

With independence comes identity:
I: Zach, say hello to the nice lady
NiceLady: Hello Zach
Z: Uh, you can call me boss, or sometimes you can call me train conductor.

With identity comes self awareness:
I: Share please
Z: I'm not sharing because I'm not good at that.


With self awareness comes a desire to increase your impact:
I: What do you want to do today?
Z: We need to save the world so lets make traps for bad guys.

This weekend will be busy. The Greek Festival is going on, our friends are having a bbq, we have a pre-preschool playdate, and pirate are going to one of our favorite malls.

Have a good week, and remember - What's the difference between having a boy or a girl? Caring about one penis, or caring about lots of penises -  ZiT

link.title: Week 177AZ: Stop I've got to poo!

entry.title: Week 174AZ: Sammie, Yelena And Justin
entry.content:
"It's ok, we'll call them on Skype", said Zach as Yelena, my sister, and I were wiping away our parting tears. Aunt Yelena, Uncle Justin and Cousin Sammy, better known as the Potts', were visiting us from their home in Hamilton, Ontario, Canada.

Justin, Yelena and I normally talk about an hour a week, and being in our 30's, we look the same as we did the last time we saw each other in person five years ago. So for us, it feels like we saw each other a few days ago.

Sammy and Zach on the other hand, grow like weeds - changing as fast as the skin on an octopus. To be able to touch Sam and Zach is a real treat for us grownups. This is the first time Yelena's brood has ever touched Zach and after this reunion we’ll have more such events in our future.

We took Yelena's family on a few tourist outings but the highlight of the trip for all of us was seeing our families play together.  Justin explaining to Zach the value of sharing. Me showing Samantha how to juggle. Yelena holding Zach’s hand. Sammy putting Zach to bed. Tori getting the full Dvorkin-Potts experience.

When I visualize my childhood, I always see a picture of my older sister holding my hand at about 3 years old, and when I see an older sister with a 3 year old brother I often get misty eyed.   Watching Sam play with Zach invokes a similar emotion. Hearing the excitement in Zach's voice as he waits for Cousin Sammy; Observing Sam guiding Zach just as Yelena did me; Overhearing Sam reading a bedtime story to Zach - Priceless.

Before he left, Justin, my brother in law said "Thank you for being such a good host and showing us around Seattle". I was a bit taken aback, for my entire life my sister and brother in law held my hand, just as Sammy held Zach's hand. They guided me, protected me, encouraged me, and nurtured me. It is my greatest pleasure to be able to return a fragment of their love and hospitality.


Have a good week, and remember - Family together, lots to remember; Don't ever forget, there's more to enjoy yet- ZiT

entry.title: Re-speaking: Speak to us of children
entry.content:
Today we have a re-run of this post, sadly my original recording was lost.
--

I originally recorded this five months before I had Zach, and I still need to remember this poem.

entry.title: Week 173AZ: Ramblings of a father
entry.content:
Zach is growing up. He's getting a little too big to fit into ride on cars, he's starting to negotiate, and his intelligence is starting to blossom.

Some early examples of his intelligence

As I read Zach a story,  he saw a bird sticking out of the mouth of the crocodile...

Z: Hey, the crocodile should have asked ...
I: Should have asked what?
Z: If the bird wants to be eaten
I: What do you think the bird would have said?
Z: No!
Z: But it's important to ask before the bird is in the tummy, because you can't hear from the tummy.

The other day Tori hurt her knee ..
T: Get your doctor's bag, I hurt my knee. 
Z: Um, I'm not a real doctor silly. 

I was sleepy so I laid down in Zach's bed
I: Zach, I'm tired, I want to do some sleeping. 
Zach got his broom and started sweeping me.
Z: Laughing And giggling

While talking about the future
Z: When I grow up I want to be a train conductor
I: I see, what does Daddy do Zach? 
Z: Huh? 
I: You know you want to be a train conductor, what does Daddy do? 
Z:  He's a Daddy silly. 

Zach's still fine tuning his excuses: 
On our way to the Y:
I: Let's go to the YMCA
Z: No, I don't want to.
I: Why? 
Z: Because there's a boy there that eats other boys. 

When Zach was very Sad at the YMCA play space:
I: Hey buddy, what's wrong, are you OK? 
Z: Yeah, I just didn't get enough sleep.

When I got home from work
I: Zach, I need my hugs, they make me happy. 
Z: No. Sometimes I'm just giving out hellos, goodbyes, and thank yous. 


And his negotiation skills: 
On our way to the corner Store
Z: I want chips
I: Chips are bad for you ...
Z: Chips will make me grow big.
I: No they don't.
Z: Chips make my tummy happy. 
I: Chips are bad for you.
Z: If you don't give me chips I'll hit. 

When Zach needed to go to the potty:
Z: I don't want to go to the potty. Don't tell me what I want. 
I: I'm not telling you what you want, I'm telling you what you need. 
Z: Grumpy Voice, Don't tell me what I need, I'll do what I need.                            

When Zach doesn't want to share
Z: I don't want to share because she's evil and stupid. 

Zach want's to make rules, so we let him.
I: What should our new house rule be? 
Z: Um, um, the new house rule is we don't put caps on markers.

Our morning routine
Z: I want a mustard sammy.
Z: No wait, a mayo sammy.
I:  
Z: Hey, I don't hear any sammy making. 

When thirsty
Z: Is there water in the car? 
I: Yes, are you thirsty?
Z: My tummy says give me something to drink. 

But even with excuses and negotiating, Zach's still sweet: 
Z: Can we have a peach? 
Z: I want to share it with you.
Zach then shared every other bite. 

Any whoo ...

This weekend my sister and her family flew into Vancouver, before spending a week with us in Seattle. I took the train up to Vancouver to get a few extra days with her. Coming into Vancouver I was amazed at how my brain has changed. On the train, I sat across from a couple with a 6 month old. Six years ago, the last time I was on a train, an infant in front of me would have irritated me. This time, I was really grateful to play with a baby and even did some tickling. The parents were on vacation from Holland, and happened to live in Berlin and speak to their child in Russian. Hearing parents cooing at their kid in Russian brings back warm memories of my childhood - I loved it. 

Coming into Vancouver, I got a bit of harassment from the Canadian border guard, which is very unusual.  It started with...

I: Hey Boss
Border Guard: Where you going?
I: Vancouver to pick up my sister.
Border Guard: Have you ever been in prison anywhere in the world? 
I: Um - nope
Border Guard: Grinning
Border Guard: Are you sure? 
Igor: Uh, yup. 
Border Guard: You started by saying Hey Boss, I've only heard that in prison. Be sure not to say that on your way back into to America. 
Igor: Thanks for the tip. 

Being back in Canada, I recalled how nice it is to help people. My first act of kindness was helping a homeless man push his shopping cart up over a curb.  Sure the vagrant didn't have many teeth, but you don't need teeth to say thank you, and he did wholeheartedly. 

Vancouver was awesome, as is time with my sister. We were lucky enough to have a hotel on the beach, and went for a walk just before a giant zombie mob congregated.  The zombies had amazing costumes, although Sammie, my niece, was less than thrilled, especially when one of them lunged at her. 

On our way out of Vancouver, waiting for our rental car, I saw a young couple becoming very stressed as they couldn't get the car seat into their rental car.  Two kids crying, an exhausted wife, and a husband going ballistic trying to install the car seat - not a pretty scene. I offered to install their car seat and two minutes later the infant was strapped into the car seat. I think the husband was ready to hug me.  I do love Canada. 


Next week we'll have Yelena, Justin, and Sam joining us in Seattle, it will be awesome

Have a good week and remember -With Sam I am, good times are a slam! - ZiT

entry.title: Week 172AZ: Like Father Like Son
entry.content:
Zach and I are sitting on the red futon in the basement enjoying our Saturday Evening Cartoons.  I get up to pee, and on the way back I grab a giant radish to snack on. Seeing me chewing, Zach says;

Z: What's that?
I: A radish.
Z: Where's the box?
I: Didn't bring the box, you can have this one.

Zach takes the radish.
Z: Get the box, then we can share.
I: Nah, it's OK you can eat the radish yourself.

Two minutes later
Z: I need milk
I: You can get milk when the cartoon is over and we go to bed.
Z: I need milk now, the radish is spicy.

Even though it shouldn't surprise me, I'm constantly surprised by Zach and my similarities. Just today, I noticed Zach is a bus riding,  radish eating,  power pedaling , multi-screen computer using,  game playing, gym going, order giving, Tori loving, bossy human, just like myself.

Other exciting happenings this week include:

Clogged Toilet -   I clogged the toilet and I decided I'd not flush for a few hours letting it clear on its own. Sadly, I forgot to send Zach the memo. When he went into the bathroom and noticed it was "stinky" he concluded the problem was no one had flushed, and flushed until the poop was all over the floor. Next time we have a clog we'll have to unhook the flushing mechanism.

After a lot of clean up, Tori took Zach to the hardware store and got a toilet auger to clear the clog. The new tool was taller than Zach, so he had to stand on the bathroom counter to help Tori use it.

Fender Bender - I got in a fender bender, no one hurt, no damage to Mouse (Tori's truck).  For a while I was thinking to go out of pocket, but the insurance agent confirmed Tori was right, I was better off using insurance.

Day off – Zach is realizing how to ask for down time. For example, he had enough of being at the YMCA so he said, oh I don’t want to be here, and I’m too tired (a lie if I’ve ever heard one).   Zach wants entire days off as well, just the other day he was telling me “I get two days off”, I was a bit surprised when Tori chimed in with “No, not two days off - you get Tuesday’s off!”

Shooting Stars - Tonight we will be watching shooting stars.  Tori booked us a yurt in the middle of nowhere, so it should be easy to see the Perseid meteor shower.

Have a good week and remember - What's the difference between Fathers and Sons? Not a tonne - ZiT

entry.title: Week 171AZ: When I grow up I'll stop saying stupid.
entry.content:
I expect when Zach grows up, he'll say much worse.  Zach has some interesting idea's about what it means to be grown up, for example:

I: You're a big boy
Z: No I'm Small
Z: When I'm big I can do lots of stuff
I: Like what?
Z: Drive
Z: Not make messes
Z: Wash dishes at night while people are sleeping.
Z: Carry heavy things

Part of being young is not believing you'll turn into your parents, for example:

Z: How come you don't have any hair?
I: When You grow up sometimes your hair falls out
Z: No, not me, my hair won't fall out.
Part of being a dad is not knowing how fast your kids grow up, for example:

 Zach pours his own milk
I: When did you grow up?
Z: I'm not grown up, I'm just a kid pouring milk, and I'm I know how to pour apple juice too. 

Part of being a kid is not being sure if you need help or not: 
While climbing a ladder
Z: I might fall, 
Half way up
Z: Oh wait I don't need you any more!

Part of being a kid is re-assuring your father: 
Tori can change Zach while he's standing, instead of on a changing table. Tori calls these field changes and I’ve never been able to do them. While camping Zach made a big poo so I decided to try a field change.  I was quite successful, and Zach said:
Z: I told you you could do it. 


Speaking of growing up Zach has started taking his own pictures, he seems to shares a few tastes with his father, which is to be expected. 

Actually, Zach really likes saying actually. For example:

Zach trips and falls off his bike
I:  Zach, get back on the horse
Z: Actually, that's a bike, but sometimes we call it a train.

This weekend we went to the renaissance fair, which is always enjoyed by our family. Zach especially liked running around with a sword looking for other pirates. Amazingly, when we ran into a big pirate who was ready to do some sword fighting with Zach, Zach backed down quickly saying well, the pirate is too big, I only want to fight with pirates my size.

Have a great week, and remember: Maybe I'm fat, but I saw a girl with a rat, and she was all that  -ZiT

link.title: Week 171AZ: When I grow up I'll stop saying stupid.

entry.title: Week 170AZ: Live and learn
entry.content:
We were on vacation this week and it was awesome.

As usual, Tori did all the leg work, for which our small  family is eternally grateful. Our week included a cabin on guemes island from which we went crabbing, and kayaking to an island. Back in Seattle, Daddy got a giant tricycle.

Crabbing is  documented in it's own post you should read the adventure.

Taking Zach and Tori on a 2 mile kayak trip in the ocean seemed like a great idea when we started, but when we were coming back in choppy waters and Zach was freaking out it was a little less appealing.  Also, not putting sunburn on our legs, resulted in tori looking like a cooked lobster. Live and learn.

This week at value village there was a giant adult sized tricycle (there was also an awesome world war II fighter pilot cap  which I couldn't resist) for 40 dollars. Normally I'd be too cheap to buy this but we happened to have a 30% of coupon, so Tori treated me to a new toy. The trike is super fun to ride, but Zach won't let me ride it in peace. Everytime I want to take the trike for a spin Zach demands that he should be allowed to ride it, but his feet don't reach the pedals yet so it's a no go. The compromise is that Zach get's to ride on my leg, which results in zach bobbing up and down like a sewing machine needle, and my right leg getting a solid workout. Live and learn.

When Zach was younger, and didn't want to do something,  we'd often have this conversation:

I: Let's go
Z: But I want to watch TV.
I: I don't care

Now it turns out kids learn from their parents, and Zach now replies to my fiats in similar fashion:

I: Let's go
Z: Why?
I: We need to get to circus school
Z: I don't Care.

This happens in lots of situations, for example our new timeout dance:

Zach does something wrong 
I: You're in timeout
Z: No
I: Go to your room now, you're in timeout.
Z: No, you're in timeout - you go to your room.
If Zach is very upset he'll sometimes add the following. 
Z: I hate you, you are stupid.

At first it was painful to hear that, but now I've learned Zach's brain hasn't developed and he doesn't understand what he says. Atleast that's what I say to feel good about my parenting.

Tori a roll model as well. Turn's out one of Tori's endearing qualities is she growls when I annoy here.    Zach's picked up on that too:

Zach's watching TV, and I need some attention so I sneak up on him and ruffle his hair. 
I: Hey buddy, give me a hug
Z: Grrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrr!

Zach also copies most of Tori's behaviors, as you can see in the videos.

Live and Learn.

Now, Zach doesn't want to be left out in this teaching, so he likes to chime in when he can:

In circus school you go barefoot so when we arrive at circus school we need to take our shoes off.
I: Take off your shoes
Z: Actually they are sandals.
I: Fine, take off your sandals.

Live and Learn.

And, best learning of all Zach's learning to potty train. In the house he doesn't wear panties, and for the first time ever on Sunday Zach dropped his pants and took a piss on a tree.

Live and Learn Kid - Live and Learn.

Have a good week and remember - Live and Learn, Dream and Yearn. Without sunscreen you'll get a burn - ZiT

entry.title: Stop throwing your toothpicks in the urinals, the crabs are learning to pole vault..
entry.content:
Zach, while you think your dad is a stick in the mud, believe it or not I was fun too

... read the graffiti on the urinal wall on our way to Geumes Island.  Geumes is a secret island in the San Juanes known only to crab fishers, beach combers and retired KGB agents.

This year, our annual Guemes trip landed during crabbing season, and Tori was resolute we'd be catching crab.  While I was busy gathering sun screen and lawn chairs, Tori invested in crab pots, floats, and raw chicken drumsticks. As Tori described the crabbing processes, my imagination flip flopped between the worlds deadliest catch and a geriatric bingo game played on rowboats.

If you're wondering about the raw chicken, in America there is a brand of tuna called chicken of the sea. This has nothing to do with our story, except when crab fishing you need bait, and we used the raw chicken drumsticks. The drumsticks make great bait as the crabs can't get the big bone out of the trap - who knew.

Finally the of day crabbing came, Zach,Tori, Chiyako, Me, and our chicken drumstick baited crab pots loaded onto a large aluminum row boat, and I rowed, rowed, rowed our boat till I found a good spot.  Crab pot heaved over the side, I row, row, rowed my boat back to shore.

On shore, I was pretty sure this crabbing thing would be a dud, but I didn't want to spoil the excitement everyone else was having, so I kept my mouth shut.  Zach and I played water guns and dutch doors as we waited for the supposedly snared shellfish.

As Zach hung upside giggling from a super duper tickle monster attack, the oven alarm went off and Tori commanded me to  get my life jacket -  we had some rowing to do.  Once again we all piled into the boat, this time with the only crab transporting to shore vessel we had - Zach's neon accordion ikea toy bag.  It was a bit tricky to row back to the place we dropped our pots but the current was light, so we landed it quickly and Tori began pulling up our pots. I have to confess, even as Tori was pulling up the crab pot, I was still thinking "well this is a waste", but  I kept my mouth shut. Suddenly, the crab pot broke through the water, and we had a huge bounty. Seven crabs in the pot, and even a bonus crab hanging on to the outside of the trap, trying to get at our chicken drumsticks.

Crabbing in Washington state is chivalrous, so we had to throw back the little males and all the female crabs, in the end we still caught two big males, and rowed back to shore.

On shore, a seven year old boy explained to Tori how to kill and cook the crabs. You crack the live crabs open on their bellies, pull out their viscera and then boil them in a pot of sea water. The pot boils a top a a propane powered gas burner found on the  guemes resort beach.

In the past I was never a fan of fishing or sea food, but on this day, with my wife on my left, my child on my lap and a big pile of fresh crab shells in front of me, I'm a crab fisherman for life.

In the spirit of full disclosure,  our next outing was a bit urm, crabbier.  First the currents were up, so trying to stop the rowboat in the middle of an ocean within  a foot of our buoy is a challenge. While the analogy isn't quite accurate, imagine trying to parallel park on the highway, with your child screaming in the background and your wife providing helpful directions.  After five near misses and two "really what were you thinking" misses, which Tori was amazingly disciplined to remain calm over, Tori finally came up with a strategy for buoy landing which aligned well to my driving skill. "Just run the buoy over" suggested Tori, which I did effortlessly on my next try. We then pulled up our catch. This time, instead of seven succulent shellfish, we caught one one starfish, and something that  looked surprisingly like a large tooth pick.

Enjoy your crabs and remember - If it's a crab, it won't stab.  It'll probably pinch, and then you'll wince - ZiT

link.title: Stop throwing your toothpicks in the urinals, the crabs are learning to pole vault..

entry.title: Week 169AZ: Glamping Tales
entry.content:
Marching Band
I'm encased in a cacophony of laughing, giggling, and squeals of joy.  I'm walking the loop of the campsite like a conductor in a marching band. Instead of waving a baton, I'm balancing a ball on the back of my hand, and instead of a brass section, I'm followed by a gaggle of preschoolers on an assortment of bikes, trikes and scooters.

This isn't a dream, it's the last day of our camping adventure at Kanasat Palmer state park.  Before I continue,  Zach and I are  grateful for the amount of work Tori does to make these trips happen - without Tori's hard work we'd be surfing on our couch watching TV.

Now, before I had the dream job of preschool conductor, I had to learn an important lesson.  For the first two nights of camping, Zach and I did the camping loop alone. Zach had his bicycle, I had my juggling clubs, but both of us looked longingly at the campsites with other kids, wishing they'd join us as adventure are better together.  I suspect Zach secretly wished I'd ask the other kids to join us, and I wished Zach would do the honors. In the end, a nice Mom asked  if she could join our parade, and we gratefully said YES.  With an example set by someone braver, I asked the other parents on the camping loop if their kids wanted to join us, and every parent gave a grateful yes.

There is a lesson here which I need to remember. Everyone is lonely and seeks connection, but someone needs to be brave enough to make contact. Mom's are bravest of all, so find one, and they'll do the hard work!

Sponges
While I was leading the band of pre-schoolers, Zach showed off some of his parent's behaviors.  At one point in the bike parade we went through a throng of older kids, and the older kids cheered, encouraging the kids to keep going. Zach wanted none of this and said: 

Scowling at the older kids
Z: Hey! Stop all that noise! You're giving me a headache. 

Later, as I continued my loops one of the mothers decided to join me, and Zach was very excited, he instantly went up to her and said: 

With his best smile:
Z: Um, we have lots of chocolate and wood and marshmallows, you should come to our campsite and make smores.
Random Mom: Um, well, I don't know.
Z: No no, we have lots of chairs, it'll be fun your boys will love it.


Morning Routine
At the yurt, I was trying to get Zach out of bed: 

Referring to the kids riding around in the loop
I: Zach wake up, you there's a road rally 
Z: Wait, they can't go without the boss
T: What does the boss do?
