Z: He tells them when they can come and go, and makes sure they are safe. 

Finally Zach gets up, and issues some orders:

Z: Give me pants, and then I want juice, but no socks.
T: Well it's cold out
Z: OK, then I want socks.

Finally on our way outside, as I open the door. 

Z: Hey, everyone needs to wait for the boss.

The water cycle of life
This weekend I really remembered my dad, and I marvel as the circle of life continues.  My dad loved water, he was always swimming, and canoeing.  

On Saturday, we we went to a park with a lake. At first I didn't want to go swimming, and then I thought "Hey, I don't want Zach to hesitate to do things" so I stripped down to my shorts and ran into the lake.  Just like when I was a small boy, Zach also refused to go into the lake after his dad. 

On Sunday, we went canoeing, and Zach was a champ, he sat in the front seat of the canoe while I took him out for a few minutes. Then we picked up mom and she sat in the middle of the canoe. For the first time ever I got to be the only one paddling, and it was splendid.

When we got to shore, Tori and I pulled the canoe out of the water and started putting it on it's rack when we hear "SPLASH, WAHHAAA".  We turned to see Zach in  two feet of water screaming in starfish position (a position that makes kids float). Tori fished Zach out of the water and praised him for doing such a good starfish.  This moment was especially poignant for me, as I'm pretty clumsy, and I'm certain my dad fished me out of many a lake on many occasions.

Serendipity, Tractors and Helicopters

Usually camp sites are in the middle of nowhere and this campsite was no exception. Tori and I were desperate for something to do, so we decide to drive west. We came into a town of 500 people, and thought well, they must at least have a coffee shop.  Being lucky folks, it turns out the fair was in town, so we  headed on in. The fair was perfect for Zach, they had an antique tractor exhibit and Zach spent two hours running between 30 tractors built between 1910 and 1960.  The coolest tractor even had steel wheels. Turns out before rubber wheels, tractors had steel wheels, I'm sure that made for an uncomfortable ride.

When even Zach was bored with the tractors we were off to the rides section of the fair. I personally am petrified of rides, but Zach at 3 was already taking a helicopter ride which went up down and around, I was totally impressed, at 35 I would be too afraid to do that. 

Glamping in a yurt
In my head I'm a poor potato farmer who doesn't own a car, I  bicycle to the mine where I work, and I rough it outdoors.  Objective reality is a little different.  But I'm told fantasies are important for survival.

When I showed a neighbor in a tent our yurt she snickered  "So this is glamping".  Like a dog hearing a high pitched sound, I cocked my head  "Glamping?" I asked.  "Yeah, you know, Yurts and other ritzy camping experiences" she said.  I was a little taken aback by her judgment, but like Zach I loved the yurt which had a porch with an outside light. Here are some of our Yurt experiences.

Standing outside, and pointing to the Yurt
Z: Do you want to come to the firestation?
Z: When the light turns on it's an emergency
Zach runs into the yurt and turns on the front porch light
Z: Hey there's the emergency light now, we need to come to the fire station.

During lunch, Zach really wanted us to go into the yurt so he took another stab with more imagination.
Z: The porch is leaving, everyone needs to get on the porch before it leaves.
I: But I'm eating my snack.
Z: But the porch will leave, if we miss it we'll have to wait a long time.

Tori needs Zach to eat so he won't be hungry later: 
T: Zach you need to come back before someone eats your Sammy.
Z: Who's eating my sammy?
T: The mommy and daddy chipmunks
Z: Hey, that's not cool.

Finally Zach sits down and eats lunch
Z: I need milk
T: You can have this
Z: Hey, you know what this tastes like?  You know what this tastes like?
I: What?
Z: It tastes like coffee!

Now, glamping isn't all glamour, as I was reading Zach his bedtime story, I heard Tori curse.

A grumpy tori walks into the yurt
T:  Damn it, a racoon just ran off with our sugar.
I: I think that was god telling us we need to be on a diet.
T: No, I think it was a racoon eating my sugar.

Have a good week, and remember, Glamping and Camping, it's far better then cramping  - ZiT

entry.title: Week 166AZ: Zach's First Camping Trip
entry.content:
I know I missed a few weeks, and yes I also know we didn't actually bring a camera camping. but as we say in computing - details, details, details.

The mountains glow orange from the setting sun. I wiggle to get  comfortable  on the rock beach, while  plants himself on my lap. We both throw big handfuls of rocks into the Puget Sound, screaming with delight

"BBBBBBBBBrrrrrrrrrrrrrbbbbbBBBBBBB!" I jump as the horn of the ferry jolts me from my day dreaming.  I'm on the sundeck of a ferry returning to  Seattle from our first camping trip with Zach.  The trip couldn't have been better and for your entertainment I'll make this post a set of very short stories. 

Juice

I'm becoming rounder than I'd like, so I decide to start juicing. Deciding to juice is often like an earthquake. It comes out of the blue and can be jarring for those near the epicenter. This time we had a 7.0 on the juicer scale as Tori was finishing loading the car to go camping. I warned Tori I'd need room for vegetables and my juicer in the car.

T: What? Can't you start juicing when we get back?
I: This is important to me, I want you to support me.
T: I'm happy to support you, but we're going camping for 3 days. You haven't juiced for 3 months, there is no power, and it's crazy hot. You can wait, your vegetables will rot, you have nowhere to plugin your juicer. 
One of the traits that ZiT share is a strong case of the stubborns
I:  No time like the present and no problem. I'll bring my giant battery, plugin it into the car, carrots take a few days to rot.
T: Is your battery charged? 
I: No I'll charge it off the car on the way to the campsite. 

The first night at the campsite, with s'mores, chips, and sausages, I'm forgetting my earlier objections to being round, and the juicequake it induced . As I stuff a giant s'more into my mouth I hear: 

T: What? You can't bring your juicer and eat s'mores - spit it out. 

The second night at the campsite I decide to fire up the juicer. Having charged the battery during the 2 hour drive I assume I've got at least 30 minutes of juicer time. In reality the battery is still completely dead. Luckily I have a car inverter, which I plugin into the car. I start the car, start the juicer, and the juicer won't spin - not enough power.  With 30 lbs of near rotting vegetables, a very smug looking girl friend and lots of failed electricity solutions, I need to brainstorm. I close my eyes and head to the bathroom where I do much of my best problem solving. As I sit on the throne and ponder my problems I see a power receptacle. 

It's easy to think of the disadvantages of juicing in the campsite toilet, but lets focus on the advantages instead: 
  • You can stop and pee any time you want
  • There's a sink in case you need to rinse anything off
  • There's a drain at the bottom of a sloping floor so it's an easy clean situation. 
  • There's 15Amp, 120V power plugs!
Science tells us the harder you work to produce food, the better it tastes, and this toilet forged juice was my favorite to date. 

Survivorman

Tori and I get along best when I give her room to work in peace, so when we got to the campsite, I took Zach on a reconnaissance mission.  As we explore the camp, I see Paul's minivan. Paul, parent to Ben and Sam has already arrived and we headed down to the beach to say hello.  At the beach, I see Paul, Sandra, Ben and Sam.  Sandra has to work, so she's heading back in a few hours and Paul will be running his camp solo. As I approach Paul, I observer a 1 foot weapon strapped to his outer thigh.  

I: Dude, that's quite the machete. 

Always a stickler for safety, Paul "Survivor Man" Rambo, unlatches the safety from his knife holster so he can draw his foot long survival knife

P: This Igor, is not a knife. It's a survivor tool.  To prove his point, Paul blows into the knife handle producing a large screech. The he draws the fire starting flint and makes some sparks for me. As  I look skeptical, Paul breaks into a grin and says:  "Most importantly you can use it to skin bears, and fight off seals stuck to the fish you've reeled in."

I grin and make a mental note to ask Tori if I can get a giant knife

Paul's boys Ben and Sam have formed a small gang with Zach and race through the campground, at one point I hear the following conversation:

Ben:  Sam and I have multi tools and I just learned knife safety. Does Zach have a knife? 
Tori:  Well Zach has a butter knife.

A few hour later it's dinner, and I wander over to Paul's site to see if there is anything tasty to nibble on. Paul has an elaborate setup: tasty food, multi tools, camp stoves, appliances and a roaring fire.  I smack my lips eager to enjoy some some tasty beans and I realize something curious - no utensils.   

I head back to my camp to scavenge some forks, and face Paul with my find:
I: I brought you some forks. 

Paul looks down his nose at me: 
P: Igor we're men. If we need utensils we can use our knives and our bean cans. If you lack those core skill and insist you need a spoon, you can head to the beach and get some empty shells to scoop with. 

Rangers

To excite Zach about camping, we used Smokey the Bear as bait: 

T: Smokey the Bear is a forest ranger at the camp site that puts out fires. 
Z: Oh, that sounds fun. 

When we got the campsite, Zach wanted to find Smokey the Bear and was very excited. We saw a forest ranger, and said hello.

I: Hi there, we're looking for Smokey the Bear.
Z:  Yeah, we're looking for Smokey
Forest Ranger: Well we're a state park, only national parks have Smokey the Bear

Zach was disappointed, but not deterred
Z: Oh, well, we'll look for Smokey. 

Later as we were chilling by our tent, the forest ranger came to our site and brought us a sticker. 

Forest Ranger: Here's a sticker for your son.
Forest Ranger: We don't have have Smokey the Bear, but we have a beaver
Zach: What's its name? 
Forest Ranger: Eager.

The idea that there was no Smokey the Bear, didn't really click for Zach and we went looking for Smokey at least every few hours. 

The forest ranger left a strong impression. After we got home from camping we went to the park:

Z:  Let's be forest rangers. 
I: OK
Z: You can be ranger Daddy, and I'll be ranger Zach. 
I: Sounds good, what to do forest rangers do? 
Z: They find people in trouble and give them stickers.

Juggling Clubs
When you start learning something it's super fun, as a small amount of effort results in a lot of growth. That's where I'm at with club juggling, and I bring my clubs everywhere so I can put in a few more throws.  

While Zach's playing on the slides or climbing the monkey bars, I'm  a few feet away juggling. Often kids will come up to me and want to hold my clubs - I always oblige.  Within 15 seconds Zach, whose normally ignoring me, runs over gets a huge puss face and says: 
Z: You can't have those. Those are my daddy's clubs. 

Another time I was walking with my clubs and Zach asked to hold one - as usual I obliged.  As we walk,  Zach sticks a club on his head:

I: What are you doing? 
Z: Put clubs on your head. 
Seems like a good idea to me, so I oblige
I: OK, what are we doing? 
Z: We're reindeer!

Good Parenting
Tori and I have very different parenting styles, I'm dictatorial and Tori's much more inclusive. When Tori's encouraging Zach to do something he doesn't want to do, it's very foreign to me, and during camping I saw an amazing episode. 

Tori and I decided we were going to do a small hike at the park, and Zach would have none of it. He was whining and crying and demanding to be carried.  Tori and I really wanted to go for a walk though so we decided to push through: 

Z:  But I want to stay at the playground 
T: It will only be 15 minutes and you'll like it.
Much crying and whining, no actual walking.
T: Zach, I'm fed up, there are two of us that want to do something, and usually we do what you want, now you need to do what we want, and I'm leaving. 
At this point, Tori crossed the street and Zach is very upset, so I kneel down and talked to him. 
I: Hey buddy, how you doing? 
Z:  I guess there are two of you, and we can do what you want.  

Amazing! It worked. We had a wonderful hike, and Zach spent much of it looking for Smokey the Bear. 

Rules
For a while I thought Zach would be a police man as he was always telling other kids what they couldn't do. Now, Zach has taken up advocacy and a close examination of the law. I suspect policeman is out, and lawyer may be the new profession. 

It was hot on the camping trip, and Zach needed some water: 
T: Go fill up your sippy cup with water across the road.
I:  You know the rules, you need to hold my hand to cross the road.
Z: The other rule is two hands on the sippy cup, that rule is more important. 

The kids were playing in the car, and Zach kept honking - I stuck my head into the car:
Z: I need to press the horn button when cars are coming. 
I:  If you press the horn you're done in the car.
Z:  But grown ups press it when cars are coming.

As we leave the campsite:
Z: Ben and Sam are coming to our house, because I told them that's the rule

Post camping, I'm sitting on the couch enjoying a popsicle.
Z: I want a popsicle
I:  Zach, you can have a popsicle, but not when you're on the couch
Z:  But you're having a popsicle on the couch

Interpreting the law may have been a stepping stone,  as Zach's just starting to try to pass new laws 
I: Hey, don't stick the shovel on my head
Z: It's a very important idea
Z: Otherwise your head will get dirty and sticky
Z: My head likes shovels. 

It's all about the Kids
For all my jesting, life is really about the kids. Last time we were at a campground we saw parents  burned out, as their kids raced around the campsite, screaming with joy. This time, we are the parents, and now I understand that although the parents are burnt out, they are completely high with pride and pleasure.  My two favorite moments were throwing rocks into the surf while Zach sat on my lap at sunset, and seeing Zach running towards me at full speed following Sam and Ben. It's amazing watching him grow up. 

Have a good week and remember -  When you get to the park, and it's already dark.  If you have to really pee, make sure you do it on a tree, as opposed to all over me. - ZiT

entry.title: Week 161AZ: Girlfriends and reflections on parenting
entry.content:
I often tell new parents and non-parents that kids are like hard drugs, the lows are brutal but the highs are to die for.  When you are with your kid, and they're not listening,  telling you "Hey you can't put me in timeout" or  "you made up house rules, I'll make up my own house rules", those can be draining. But when you come home, and the first time your kid sees you his face lights up with a huge ear to ear smile, the high you get for that minute is off the chart.

Other highs for me are:

For the first time Zach told me about his dream:

Z: I had a dream, that disappeared.
Z: Maybe I had a spell cast.

Zach is also building situational awareness:

Z: More milk I'm thirsty
I: I can't hear hear you - what do you have to say
Z: I dunno - accusingly
I: Please?
Z: Mommy needs the please word, but daddy doesn't.

Sometimes Zach just has something he needs to get off his chest:

Z: Can I tell you I like beans?
Z: I want to tell you I like beans
Z: Can I tell you that I like spicy beans

Zach also spends a fair bit of time on the phone.

Z: Gotta Call Stacy
I: Who's Stacy?
Z: My Girlfriend
Pick up phone
Z: Hi Stacy
Z: I can't see you Thursday because I have a date at the Y.
Z: Stacey I can come tomorrow after I'm done with circus school
Z: GoodBye
30 seconds pass
Z: Now it's curious George calling.
Z: Can't see you Friday since I have swimming lessons
Z: Bye Curious George

Z: I was gonna setup a date with Curious George
30 seconds pass, pick up phone
Z: Now I'm calling Julia
Z: What are you doing I want you to come here and to do something right now.

Sadly Zach's also pickup up some bad words

I: Let's go home around the block.
Z: That's way is stupid.

Zach is also being curious:

Z: Hey what's in your nose
I: What's in your nose?
Z: Boogers
I: Well do I have boogers in my nose
Z: No, your nose is stinky shoelaces
Z: Your nose is smelly
< Rubbing my head> 
Z: Your head is scratchy
Z: Your nose is smelly
Z: Your cheek is cheeky

Zach is willing to share roles too

Z: you can be captain daddy and I'll be pirate Zach

Beyond dialogue Zach's also learning physical skills. For example  Zach can open the power windows with his shoes. Tori tells me if Zach is bare foot, he can even make the window close.

In other news, our retaining wall is dug out, and rocks are purchased. Tori's quality bar is higher than mine and she thinks the wall is not level enough and will re-level it - lots of progress though.

In Igor news, after not wanting to learn to juggle clubs for years, I've concluded clubs are the coolest looking thing in juggling and am now learning them. My hands are all bruised up, and I'll probably get the odd black eye, but once I nail this, and learn to pass, I think I'll be happy.

Tori's heading off to California next week. Zach's commentary on the trip is: A family has 3 people, next time we should go to Grammies as a family.

Have a good week, and remember If you can't join them, beat them -ZiT

link.title: Week 161AZ: Girlfriends and reflections on parenting

entry.title: Magicians making housecalls
entry.content:
When your sink leaks, a plumber makes a house call. When your fridge is empty and your stomach growls like the neurotic pacing lion at the zoo, a pizza boy makes a house call.  When you're face is green, and fluids escape from your orifices like a river overflowing,  a doctor makes a house call.  Why then, isn't there someone to make a house call when you can't smile.

We've all been there, slumped on the couch, the coffee table a junk yard of half eaten take out, empty ice cream pints, and 1/2 finished boxes of oreo's. Maybe you boyfriends dumped you, maybe you're stressed from work,  maybe you 12th grade nightmare of not wearing pants to work actually happened. Whatever the cause, the symptom is the same, you haven't' smiled in days and you're trapped in your own head, not experiencing pleasure,  stuck in the rut of sadness and depression.

The answer my friend is a profitable new business opportunity called Magicians making house calls!

Imagine it, instead of a doctor, you'll hear the ding of a horn as a three year old pedals up in their big wheeler. Instead of a doctors bag, the three year old has a slightly too large magicians hat.  Instead of a  stetascope,  a magic wand, and instead of the normal doctor's entrance you'd hear a  knock on the door, you'd open it, look down and the 3 year old magician would say "Tada". Then they'd smile at you!

Worried about the effectiveness of these magicians?  Certainly if you have kids yourself you understand that a kids smile is like a shot of cocaine to a shaking drug addict - Instant overwhelming dopamine infusion. If you don't have kids of your own, go to a playground, and you'll quickly realize the smiles on a kids face are more contagious then pubic lice

Running such a business is easy.  There is, at this very moment, a glut of 3 years, and, even as these 3 years olds naturally turn into 4 year olds, a new batch of 2 year olds are becoming 3 to replace them. Wages are low, most magicians happy to work for a lollipop, and an occasional trip to the zoo.

To invest in the magicians making house calls franchise, please email invest@magiciansmakinghousecalls.com

entry.title: Week 160AZ: Wonderful Weekends.
entry.content:
Tori has been pushing us out on the weekends, and as a result we've been having a wonderful time.  Last weekend was one of my favorites and it started with  Zach and I letting Tori get some well-deserved morning shut eye.  With Tori snoozing Zach set the tone by asking if he could sit in my lap and read a book (Zach, if you can read my thoughts, sit in my lap more often, it always puts a smile on my face)

After lap sitting and book reading, Zach and I played  several pretend games which involved hiding under the covers, then popping up to yell Peek-A-Boo.   In a silent movie, all the games we played were the same but add sound, and you could hear we spent an hour riding our rocket ship to the moon, hiding from scary monsters, and exploring a cave - super fun.

Zach and I had such a good time pretending we continued pretending as we got into a real rocketship (the car) and flew to outer space (the YMCA).  When we were done our spacewalk (Igor running, Zach playing), we took our rocketship (the car) back to earth (our home).  Pretending is awesome, and a great example of the difference between subjective and objective reality.

As I marveled at phycology, Tori wanted to join us and we drove off to a great park in Fremont.  The sun was shining, and the Fremont park already had  five buccaneering toddlers climbing ladders, swinging on swings, and sliding on the slides, so we sat down, and Zach chased another little girl up a slide.  As I usually do when in good spirits, I practiced my juggling and handed out bells to the kids.  Bell in hands, the kids all ran to show their confused parents who tried to return the bells. I insisted the kids keep the bell, and the park transformed into a Christmas carol.  After enjoying the park, we wandered around Fremont, and found a cool Russian dumpling restaurant.  Not only did the restaurant have dumplings, but it also had carrot and cabbage salad, and an old fashioned record player.   With dumplings digested and records played, we found an ice cream store for a sweet treat. To work off some calorie, we then went to the crazy Fremont steps and Zach ran up and down while Tori and I expressed gratitude for the awesome day as we watched the boats on the river.

A Perfect Day - Thanks Tori for making it happen!

Other recent wonderful weekend activities included going to the zoo, where we made elephant poo paper. Touch-a-truck, where Zach got  play in an ambulance, bus, and tractor trailer.  And, Science Saturday, where uses chemistry to make Zach elephant toothpaste slime, and many other mysteries of the natural world.

There's more to our world then just weekend wonders, we've also restarted the retaining wall and got a food dehydrator. Tori is back to working on the retaining wall, she thinks it's only a few weekends left, but from my experience on the right (pun intended), it's more work than we expect.  In the dehydrating world  we bought a fancy pants dehydrator and I'm happy to report dried cauliflower leaves something to be desired while dried apples and kiwi fruit are as tasty as you'd expect.

Zach is now a master marble monster - we now have two marble runs, and when we go to visit our friends', Ben and Sam, Zach only wants to play with their marble run.  Yesterday, as we were playing marbles, Zach kept talking about her, and how she could walk and talk. When I asked Zach what he was talking about he said it's my baby marble.  Imaginations are great.


Have a good week and remember - Strawberries and Blueberries, Absinth and Green Ferries- ZiT.

entry.title: It's not science, it's an experiment!
entry.content: A picture, 1000 words. a video, a few less. Tori's science experiments - priceless.

link.title: It's not science, it's an experiment!

entry.title: Week 158/159AZ: Selected Vignettes from a 3 year old.
entry.content:
Composing coherent blog posts is hard. Instead I'll share some of my favorite vignettes and experiences on select topics.

Flat Sammy and troll food.
This week we got a flat version of Zach's cousin Samantha in the mail. We're taking her on a tour of Seattle and our first stop was the Fremont troll. This troll lives under a bridge and can be seen eating a car.   Now, I tried to tell Zach that this troll happens to eat humans, but Zach corrected me.

Igor Taking a bite out of Zach's leg
I: I'm a troll eating Zach!
Z:Trolls don't eat humans, trolls eat troll food
I: What's troll food
Z: You know rocks and grass with Ketchup, and Sammies that their mommies make.

Smarty Pants
The other day, after Zach was being very grumpy and bossy, I gave Zach a huge hug and we had this exchange:

Igor giving Zach a huge hug
I: Why do I love you?
Z: Because I'm the greatest.

Now you may wonder how Zach learns such things, on a separate occasion I asked:

I: Zach, why are you so smart?
Z: I go to smart school


Timeouts
The current en-vogue disciplining method is timeouts, which we also use.  That doesn't mean Zach enjoys it or that we see any useful results.

After Zach threw something
I: You're in timeout
3 minutes later
I: All done
Z: (matter of fact, angry voice) I'm done being in timeout.
Z: Every time there is a timeout I get grumpy.

Possessions
Mine, gifts, sharing are all concepts to be mastered. For example.

Zach's buddy Jonah is coming over:
I: Zach, get up, your buddy is coming over.
Z: I don't want to play with Jonah.
Z: We should hide my toys
Z: Jonah might break them.

At Zach's birthday, children arrive bearing gifts.
Stranger: Here's a gift for you.
Z: It's OK, I already got a present!


The Tori and Igor Incident
This week Zach discovered he can use our names, Igor and Tori, instead of calling us Mom and Dad.  I didn't think much of this but it really bothered Tori so we took a united front and in a true demonstration of unified parenting we said that it is unacceptable. Zach has now reverted to Mom and Dad with the occasional slip .

Bed Time Routines
Every night before bed I read Zach a story. Recently he's decide that to listen to a story he has to sit in my lap, which I really enjoy (I don't know where he learned this but I love it). After our story, I get my hug turn off the lights and Zach says:

After our good night snuggle.
Z: Send in the booboos.

Deaf as a door mat
Zach's not the only one with funny stories. Just this week I was deaf in my left ear. Being an allergy sufferer, I chalked this up to allergies and went on with my week. By Friday I couldn't hear squat and was really hoping my allergies would clear up. I mentioned my hearing loss to my coworker who asked "have you been the to doctor?". "No", I replied. My friend then gave me a lecture on going to the doctor.  The next day in the doctor's office the doctor was saying - "Um, wow that's a lot of ear wax, completely blocked".   Twenty minutes of water-picking my ear later - I could hear again.  Moral of the story, when you can't hear, go to the doctor!

link.title: Week 158/159AZ: Selected Vignettes from a 3 year old.

entry.title: Week 156/157AZ: Children in the attic
entry.content:
Like walking and talking Zach's imagination skill is starting to develop. It's a blast to experience and enjoy.

For example, Zach is now pretending our chicken coop is an egg time machine. I'm not sure  how an egg relates to a time machine, but that's what imagination is all about. Zach also likes to take imaginative pretend "pee's on the potty."  Pretend pee's don't sound like much, but assure you me, getting his butt on the potty is an improvement. And to start the day, Tori's favorite, when Zach wakes up when it's still dark he runs down stairs opens the front door and says "Mom, wake up - it's sunny!"

My favorite example of imagination happened when we went up to our bedroom (which has a door into the attic), and Zach said "There are kids in the attic. We shouldn't bother them, if we ask them too many questions they'll get bored of us".

While imagination is fun to watch develop, grumpiness, bossiness, and general pain in the butted-ness comes with growing up as well.

Zach is experimenting with being grumpy and a pain in the butt.  For example, the other day Tori was trying to take a bath and Zach started banging on the door. Tori said - "Zach, can I have some privacy". At which point Zach ran off and become silent. I was impressed. Then I heard Tori exclaim "Zach, privacy means no playing with the light switch" (our light switch is outside the bathroom door).

Zach's grumpy at me a lot. Saturday, I came downstairs to see all my pens dissected  I said, Zach why are dad's pens pulled apart. Zach replied "Hey, why are you asking so many questions?".  After that episode, Zach tried to pull me closer to him which made me smile, as I got close enough for a hug, Zach's face turned to a grimace and he pushed me away saying "Go AWAY, go sit on the couch".  Not wanting to be bullied, I told Zach I'm not going anywhere, and he ran off.  A few moments later, wearing a shirt and no pants, and yielding a ladle and a spatula he declared "If you don't go, I'll hit you with a spatula".

Most mornings I get a hug from Zach, this morning as I was giving Zach a hug he proclaimed - "No Squashing!"

Have a good week and remember - Bacon and Eggs make good long legs -ZiT

entry.title: Week 155AZ: Kid-O-Palooza at Zach's!
entry.content:
The highlight of this week was Zach's third birthday party hosted at our place.  As usual, Tori pulled out all the stops and the party was a one of a kind screaming success!  Zach had a riot at our six hour party, and was disappointed every time he realized someone else had left.  

Beyond having double the food required to feed the 40 people who came, we also had 50 handmade cupcakes in three flavors topped with sour rainbows, 3 gallons of lemonade, iced tea, and raspberry lemon punch.

Not content with having the funnest food, Tori also setup some awesome activities.  For a base, we started with our standby activities: ride-on toys around the block, foam sword, volcanoes,  bubble machines, and our backyard play-set which got an upgrade to include a rope ladder. To that Tori added bubble wands which make four foot wide bubbles, Mentos in coke cans (video TBD), and a heap of dirt filled with buried treasure complete with kids shovels.

To finish the event Tori sent everyone home with a gift basket, which included cool cat sun glasses, kid measuring tapes, and handmade play dough with sparkles.

I'm not sure If I should be bragging about this, but one of Zach's circus friends had so many yummy cupcakes, she actually puked.

Since these are our memories, I want to add some Igor commentary - First, As usual I was a tad confused, and thought the party was on Sunday not on Saturday - Thank god Tori is patient.  Second, I realize I'm sending mixed messages to Tori when I tell her not to kill herself to make a party, but then praise her when the party the awesome. Need to think about that :)

In the front yard, Tori made me get rid of my broken stove, and broken BBQ.  Even though I claimed broken appliances in the front yard are a more effective theft deterrent then cameras, Tori still made me haul them out (thanks Paul).   With the party done, and appliances gone Tori is starting to dig out the second half of the front yard to put in a wall and garden. Tori thinks she'll need a pickaxe to complete the dig and  I'm trying to convince her she's not 20 anymore, and we should instead rent a machine to do the digging.   

In the back yard, our friends Shayna and Alison gifted us a chicken coop, and we're now plumbed for 8 chickens.  Hold your clucking though, we’ve got too many projects right now, and as I like to say, chickens will be a atleast 9 months in the future.    The chicken coop was crazy heavy - maybe 300 pounds, and moving was an adventure in shipping and receiving :)

To load the coop into the truck we got lucky as a landscaper and his crew were at the load site, and they demonstrated how professionals lift heavy things. The landscaper used tricks like using a two by four to get the coop off the ground so he could get straps under it, and then used the straps to allow 4 people to carry the coop like  Paul bearers and did an excellent job explaining directions to his crew.

To unload the coop, there were no landscapers available and Tori took charge. Her plan was to load the coop onto our cart and wheel it into the backyard. Luckily at the start our neighbor tom was around to give us a hand.    As soon as the coop got onto the cart, all the wheels went flat. I thought we'd popped our wheels, but Tom thought the weight was just flattening them, so with coop on cart, Tom inflated the wheels, and we were good to go. We started pushing, and then Tom's wife came out and gave us a push in slippers. Then our other neighbor and his son came out to also give us a hand. With 5 helping hands, we were able to place the coop in our back yard landscaper and injury free.

Finally, on the topic of circus school, for the first time ever Zach did the entire class, including warm up, without me being present. To celebrate we gave the circus school instructors cupcakes.

Have a good week and remember - If you need to move a chicken coop, find a 2x4 - ZiT

entry.title: Seattle Poetry Slam Finals 2013
entry.content: You can listen to the recording @ http://m.ustream.tv/channel/theseattlepoetryslam. The competition starts at 1h11 minutes. It's cool hearing many of the poets and poems that crushed me at  the poetry slam. I've got a year to practice before the next finals .

entry.title: Adventures in Relationships: The basketball hoop incident
entry.content:
Zach's friend Malcolm was over last night, and Tori was talking to Malcolm's parents John and Misty.  I was working in the basement, when I heard John yell "ZACH, that is not OK". Some commotion followed, and Zach was whisked off to bed. I was paged to read  Zach's bedtime story, and I asked Zach what happened:

I: Why was Mommy mad?
Z: I wanted to give Malcolm an owiee.
I: What, why did you do that?
Z: Because I don't like Malcolm.
I: That's not true.
I: How would you like it if Malcolm gave you an owieee?
Z: I'd put malcolm in time out.

As it's hard to interrogate Zach I put him to bed. The next morning before Zach woke up I asked Tori what happened.  Tori told me Zach tried to push our basketball hoop over onto malcolm (*)

When Zach woke up I decided the basketball hoop incident was serious so we'd have a father son chat.

I: Zach what did you do wrong yesterday?
Z: Nothing.
I: Let's talk about trying to hurt Malcolm.
Z: Ohhh, I was frustrated. Sometimes Mommy's frustrated, sometimes you're frustrated, sometimes I'm frustrated.
I: What can you do next time you're frustrated.
Z: I have an idea!
Z: Maybe I can put malcolm in a box.
I: No!

Such incidents remind me parenting is hard.

Notes:
*) There was a heavy rock keeping the basketball hoop from being knocked over. Zach understood he had  to remove the rock to be able to push over the hoop, which he did methodically

link.title: Adventures in Relationships: The basketball hoop incident

entry.title: Week 154AZ: Happy 3rd Birthday
entry.content:
This post is pretty much a brain dump, Tori didn't even get to see it before it was posted. I'll do better next week.

This week was Zach's birthday, and we got lots of videos, I'll post some.  His party will be next week. My mom (babba) was making fun of me, as I never wanted to have birthday parties for Zach, but she's right  you don't get a choice in such affairs.


Anyway, Zach activities ...

Zach was "teacher zach" today and put me to bed, when I asked him to read me a story he climbed into bed, started and then said, wait I can't read - why don't you read this.

Zach likes to say,  you can have some but not all of the junk food.  If you eat all the junk food there won't be any left and we'll need to go to the store to get more.

Zach has also taken to running around with a juggling club saying this is my remote control incase we see a scary monster!

Zach watches  too much tv, so we've decided to cut back his TV time, and give him access to video games. I figure if he's playing video games he might learn how to read. Although since Zach has the screen rotated, I suspect Zach might end up not knowing which orientation the letters have. 

Zach also likes to say hello to our 90 year old neighbor. He's always running over and ringing her bell. She always say's he's cute, but now that Zach tries to say hello hourly I think our neighbor has had enough, and is asking Tori to limit the Zach visits to once a day

On parenting ….

It's funny how Zach responds differently with Tori and I. Food's a great example, with Tori zach gets to pick what he eats, with me, Zach etas what I’m eating. Who's watching who is another example.   With Tori, Mom watches to make sure Zach doesn't run off, with Dad, Zach watches to make sure dad doesn't run off.

A night I've started setting a timer, and say when the timer goes off, you need to turn off the TV. Zach responds really well to the timer, in fact sometimes I"ll set it for 3 seconds and then Zach will be like, Oh timer has rung, TV time is up. It's pretty cool.

Have a good week and remember - 100 watt light bulbs are bright - ZiT

entry.title: There are no scraps of men
entry.content:
Awesome story about doing the right thing, leadership and dignity. From TED:



Alberto Cairo's clinics in Afghanistan used to close down during active fighting. Now, they stay open. In this powerful talk, Cairo tells the moving story of why -- and how he found humanity and dignity in the midst of war.

link.title: There are no scraps of men

entry.title: Week 153AZ: Daddy, can you read me a story and put me to bed.
entry.content:
The title is odd, because Zach never wants me to read him a story when Tori is around, and even odder since Zach has never wanted to go to bed of his own free will.  Not being one to look a gift horse in the mouth, I said, sure and then crawled into bed and said:

Z: Next time I promise not to hit Mommy in the head. 
I: Oh, I see
Z: Yea, maybe when mommy's done being grumpy, she'll give me booboos.
I: Inside my head voice - Yeah, that's what I've been thinking for years.

Other entertaining conversations this week: 

Later, Zach and I went to the children's museum - where Zach and I had this gem of a conversation:
Z: Where do babies come from?
I: Mommy Bellies

Z: I see, what do babies do?
I: Oh not much, they sleep and grow, sometimes they kick.

Z: I don't think so.
I: What do you think they do?

Z: They're like and fight bad guys.
I: Oh

Getting ready to go to the YMCA Zach pulled off his pants, and I said:
I: Zach you're a super star!
Z: Don't call me a firestar (that's a character from spider man),  I’m a Zach.

I: You're a super Zach
Z: Don't call me a super Zach

I:What should I call you?
Z: Uhm, Super Duper, Coo Coo Zach

I: OK - you're a super duper coo coo Zach!

When Zach wouldn't put his shoes on:

I: Well if you can't put your shoes on, you can't watch TV.
Z: Maybe when I get bigger I can put shoes on, but not as big as you guys, because you guys are no fun.

But enough of conversations.  As I write this, I'm watching Zach from the window of the YMCA daycare.   I just watched Zach run  to put his bowl and cup in the garbage.   It is really cool watching and realizing that Tori and I have crafted a human being and helped him develop.  It's an amazing feeling. Thank you Tori and Zach! 

Have a good week and remember - YOLO - ZiT !

link.title: Week 153AZ: Daddy, can you read me a story and put me to bed.

entry.title: Roach Motel
entry.content: Long ago, I posted about the house I wanted to live in, now it's Tori's turn. Tori wants to build an insect hotel. They come in lots of cool designs, and you can see a whole catalog of them,here.  Knowing Tori, insect hotel construction is already on the drafting table. I'll send a picture in a few years when ours is open for Beesness :) .

entry.title: Start your day
entry.content:
This story starts at 5 o'clock
With screaming from an alarm clock

Eyes shut,  lying warm in bed
Need to get up, need to clear your head.

Now upright, turn on the light
Today's a new day, spend it right

Down the stairs, smell the coffee
Focus on goals, think thoughts lofty

Breathe deeply,  find pen and journal
Be quiet, transcribe  your mind internal

Sip your java, warm your hands
Decide who'll get your commands

entry.title: Zach upside down in the silk
entry.content: Look closely (and set the resolution to high if you're a computer person)  Zach's in the middle silk (the red thing)  flipping upside down. This is the kind of stuff he does at circus school. The view is crappy since I'm behind a window in the far away observation tower.

link.title: Zach upside down in the silk

entry.title: Double Passing
entry.content: What's more fun then passing? Double passing (stealing is fun too).

entry.title: Week 152AZ: Daddy, are we clowns?
entry.content:
This post isn't great and it covers two weeks of excitement. You can complain to management, I know I do.

This morning, Zach asked me if we were clowns. I thought about it, and proudly said, why yes Zach we are. We then had a long conversation focused on the important role that smiles have making people laugh, and why it is  integral to the fabric of our society.
Of course, Zach asks deeps questions about everything. On our way to a Passover party Zach asked me what it meant to be Jewish. Of course, I didn't have a clue - and said so.

Zach's normal interrogation  protocol works like this:
Z: Why does blah blah blah?
I: Because blah blah blah?
Z: Why?
I: blah, blah blah…
Z: Why?
I: blah, blah, blah.
Z: Oh! I didn't know.

Some other Zach stories I captured:

Early one day , Dad sprained his ankle
I: Daddy hurt his ankle
Z: Oh!
Later that day:
I: Let's get in the boat
Z: Where's the ankle on the boat?
I: Boat's don't have ankles
Z: But what makes the boat go under water?
I: The propeller
Z: Oh, I didn't know that

When Zach couldn't get something open:
Z: Oh, I think it's glued together with tape.

On our way home from swimming:
Z: I want McDonalds
I: No, McDonald's is yucky
Z: But I like McDonalds
…
When we get home and Zach finds Mom.
Z: Daddy says McDonalds is Yucky, but I like McDonalds.

Zach tries to negotiate, but I’m not so bad at it myself.
I: Can I have a hug? 
Z: No.…Maybe Later
I: OK, How about now?
Z: OK - Huggs

While Giving Zach a Hug:
I: Zach, you give the best hugs
Tori: Check Zach's Panties
Z: No, my panties are fine!

The standard fighting words:
Z: Use your words not your fists
Z: Use your nice voice, not your mean voice.

After consuming some junk food:
Z: You ate all the chips?
I: Yup
Z: Oh man, we need to go back to the grocery store.

On a cold day:
I: Don't go outside it's cold.
Zach goes out anyways, Dad follow him out
Z: Dad don't come out, it's cold out.

Last Sunday we had an awesome all afternoon BBQ. We started at 1pm, and it kept going all the way till 9.  It was wonderful to see old friends, and make new ones. Best of all, at any given time we didn't have too many people so it was always just the right number of people.

This weekend, Tori went nuts on the Garden, in two short days we got a rock wall finished and half a yard put in. Tori keeps drawing pictures of her garden art, but I can't imagine it till it's built. I try to remind Tori I almost failed drafting but she refuses to hear me.

While Tori was gardening Saturday Zach got to fly RC planes.   A friend of mine  ( thanks Gaurav) was kind enough to show us his RC planes  and best of all he had a spare remote control. Zach got to "take turns flying', which he really enjoyed. Zach's voice commands were matched almost perfectly by the airplane.
While Tori was gardening Sunday Zach did his most independent work out at circus school ever. After warm up I went to the upstairs observation deck, and Zach ignored me till the class was done. Great Job Zach - I'm totally proud of you.

In health news, I think I'll Join the YMCA and Tori and I will start going to the gym together. That's going to be wonderful. At the same time, I'm taking another stab at juicing, because well my pants are too tight.
Have a good week and remember - Tea is for drinking Pee is for flushing - ZiT

entry.title: Poetry Slam #1: Last Place
entry.content:
Last night I went to a poetry slam. First the poem I read (audio): 

Wham, Bam, Thank you Slam
To nail this piece, I had to Cram

Fresh meat I am, just a slam virgin
My heart is poundin' my blood's a surgin'

Trembling me, on rebar's stage
Come on brain, don't disengage

Don't want to look,  don't want to touch
At the same time, need to connect much

That chick there with the glowing red hair,
I want to show that girl some flair

And That dude with the funky beard
I tell you what, I bet he's damn weird

And me, how the hell did I get here?
Any why, why aren't I paralyzed with fear?

Because I looked up, I woke up,
What else could I do, I spoke up

See the world's fucked up
There are just too many suck ups

And I'm here to push back
I'm here to give the cattle a smack.

See there are some people that do what they love
There are some people who aren't afraid to shove

Some people will get on the stage
And those people will stand here and rage.

I want to be a person like that
I'm sick of being a beurocrat

My words needs to be set free
My soul need to scream yippee

So here I am with my heart on my sleeve
So everyone else can go home and believe

That what ever you want, whatever you dream
It's there, as long as you have,  the self esteem


Rewind a few days, here's how I ended up being on stage :) 

Thursday: Someone mentions I might like poetry Slam.
Friday: I check it out, and figure I'll go on Tuesday as an observer
Saturday: Hym, why be an observer, I can read something at he open mike.
Sunday: Screw that, I can compete, I write a 3 minute poem.
Monday: Double check rules, Grr- I need 3 pieces (for each round that I might win), cobble together 2 other poems from previous poems I've written.
Tuesday: Trying to practice poems and decide if I should open with my strongest poem, and close with my weakest, or start with my weakest poem, and close the finals with my stronger poem.

Tuesday @ 8pm: Arrive at poetry slam, and realize the place is cash only and I can't get in on account of not having cash, and not having an ATM card for the last 10 years.

Tuesday @ 8:10: Call everyone I know begging them to deliver me 5$ so I can compete, begging god they'll arrive before the 8:30 cut off to enter the slam.

Tuesday @ 8:27: Greg arrives with 5$, and I enter the slam with 3 minutes to spare.

Tuesday @ 8:30: Listening to MC and realizing, shit everyone has their works memorized, and they're good.

Tuesday @ 10:05 Deliver my poem and rank dead last.

The good news: 
  1) Being last means you can only improve from here.
  2) I opened with my weaker poem, so I saved my best for another week.

Things I learned: 
  1) F#$ the resistance - go for it.  What's the worst that happens?
  2) It doesn't matter what you want, it matters what the audience needs
  3) I should carry cash.
  4) I love poetry slams.

entry.title: Week 150AZ: Pee in the potty
entry.content:
Only parents can understand how awesome it is when your kid starts using  the potty, and we are experiencing that awesomeness this week.

Sure it comes at a cost. We trade TV time for time on the potty. Zach's been watching loads of TV while sitting on the potty, but as they say in war, a small price to pay.

Zach's has also been picking up some very funny phrases. For example:

When I went to wake Zach the other day:
Z: I want mommy
I: It's mom's birthday so she gets the morning off.
Z: Um, ok you can turn on the TV while Mommy makes my sammy (sandwich)

Zach doesn't do the warm up at circus school, so I often tickle him.
Z: Daddy that's not funny.

Zach loves other kids but he still working on his interpersonal skills. He will sometimes grab another kid by the cheeks so he can speak an inch from their face and declare his opinion.  He is much better with adults. He never pushes his opinion. Instead he starts off with "maybe" so it sounds like his plan is their decision.

When Greg (a grown up) was sitting on our couch - with open hands:
Z: Maybe you want to go to the backyard with me Greg.

While watching TV the other day:
Z: What are we going to do today Daddy?

At circus school, with the exception of warm up, Zach has become fully  independent. Frankly, other than him teasing me at warm up, I don't get to really participate any more.  Already I’m realizing the mixed blessing of independence.

On the house front, Tori has ripped apart some the front yard and has replaced a retaining wall. As an uneducated observer the process reminded me of the Flinstones: lots of rock bashing with chisels and sledge hammers. But hey, the retaining wall looks fantastic.

In juggling news Igor is becoming fond of contact juggling. Acrylic balls (think crystal balls) are cool until you drop them.  Then they either break your toe, break your floor, or break themselves. I suspect I'll be sticking to plastic balls for a while.

On the health front, Tori's out ahead. She's been going the gym three times a week while I'm struggling just to get my outside running back again.  It's inspirational having her at the gym and maybe we will get a family Y membership just like I had when I was a kid.

Spring is coming to Seattle. The tree's have flowers and leaf buds and the daffodils are coming up. One of the nicest things about getting old is you start to appreciate the seasons and spring is becoming my favorite.

Have a good week and remember - "If you want a BBQ, we'll be having one Sunday, show up" - ZIT

entry.title: When the color blue was born - My Favorites
entry.content:
When the color blue was born is a generative writing class I really enjoyed.   Here are my favorite creations during the class. 

See Red, You're Dead
Knife Gripping
Life Slipping
Blood Dripping

From <http://ig66.blogspot.com/2013/01/when-color-blue-was-born-poetry-class.html>

Tomorrow smiling at me.

Tomorrow you'll be chasing tail,
Just like every teenage male.

Tomorrow you'll likely have no time
It's OK our journey was sublime

Tomorrow you'll think I'm wrong
Heck you'll probably sing it in a song.

Then one day you'll be really sad,
because you won't know your dad

I hope that day I'm still alive
So we can make our friendship jive

But if I'm not, that's OK too,
Because I left this blog for you.

From <http://ig66.blogspot.com/2013/02/when-color-blue-was-born-week-3-green.html>


Seeing Being Blue
Blue is lack of color, lack of joy, lack of pleasure
Blue is being present in body, but lost in spirit
Blue is insignificant ego swimming in a sea of self doubt
Blue is fear of failure, fear of judgment, fear of worthlessness
Blue is my favorite color, but being blue sucks. 

From <http://ig66.blogspot.com/2013/03/when-color-blue-was-born-week-4.html>


The Martian 
Oil green skin, like a slug
Even martians need a hug

Giant silver gun, set to stun
Makes the earth men want to run.

Black Shoes, on feet seven
Red mittens on hands eleven

Yellow eyes like daffodills
Stare at you and steal your will

Pink under wear,
Please, he forgot his pants don't stair.

Two Translucents Talking

Ooops I guess I'm dead
Yeah that's what the last one said

Do you think we feel emotions?
I think so, I'm feeling commotion.

Do you think we need glass to see?
Nope, we need 'em to look jolly!

Can you see the wind on your cheek?
Um, when I'm a the park carceek.

Hey not only are we translucent,
But we're also sans-a-sent

From <http://ig66.blogspot.com/2013/03/when-color-blue-was-born-week-5-black.html>

Dreamless Nights

Sleeping dreams I don't remember
So I'll use  day dreams from November

My daydreams are void of color
Frankly they're mostly void of wonder

Even when I think of  fine green foam,
My dreams are still in Monochrome

So what's the deal? Am I just broken?
Who cares, in my dreams I'm built and smokin'

Alive
Power, leap, stride
Jump, run, collide

Think Clearly, Think Freely
Ride your bike, poppa wheely

Live Your life, rejoice
Sing In your loudest voice

Kids hop, and should inspire
Never entertain black ire

Now this poem comes to an end
Get on the bus and make a friend.

Obese 
Fat, round, cow, whale
Over size in each detail.

Stair climbing , Fast walking out of breath
Diabetes, Heat Attack close  to death.

Family warns you out of fear
Makes you stop and have a tear

Crunch, Crunch, snack, snack
Wolfing  food down like it's crack.

Stuffing your face, show no grace
Jam it down, ignore the taste

Afraid to step upon the scale
Afraid to be called a whale

What to do, how to fix
Diet, exercise, no quick fix. 

When props talk

Thou single wheel calls out to me
Thou body sets my transport free
                                                          I roll, I turn I jump
                                                          I really wish you were less plump
Upon they pedals I make a stand
Upon thine perch I feel grand
                                                           I feel bad when people stair,
                                                           I feel sad when people compare 
Upon you I am one with thee
Upon you I juggle balls three
                                                          I am not just for the fool, 
                                                          Frankly I'm a rather tool 

From <http://ig66.blogspot.com/2013/03/when-color-blue-was-born-rainbow.html>

link.title: When the color blue was born - My Favorites

entry.title: When the color blue was born: Week 6 - Rainbow
entry.content:
Homework - Make something colorful to release into the world. 










Homework - Send a color into a another time
(I took the bus to class, holding my project and noone could even look at me) 

Yesterday's tomorrow is today
In the city people see grey

They listen and look, but see no color
They're like boats with a rudder

There eyes look down, afraid to speak
Perhaps they guess others speak Greek

So to the future I send yellows
So others will be jolly fellows

Enjoy the yellow, think of the sun
Look around and have lots of fun


Homework - Write about colors in your dreams
(I don't remember my dreams, so I had to improvise)


Sleeping dreams I don't remember
So I'll use  day dreams from November

My daydreams are void of color
Frankly they're mostly void of wonder

Even when I think of  fine green foam,
My dreams are still in Monochrome

So what's the deal? Am I just broken?
Who cares, in my dreams I'm built and smokin'

At class early - I was just sitting around writing: 
Power, leap, stride
Jump, run, collide

Think Clearly, Think Freely
Ride your bike, poppa wheely

Live Your life, rejoice
Sing In your loudest voice

Kids hop, and should inspire
Never entertain black ire

Now this poem comes to an end
Get on the bus and make a friend.

At class early - I was just sitting around writing: 

Fat, round, cow, whale
Over size in each detail.

Stair climbing , Fast walking out of breath
Diabetes, Heat Attack close  to death.

Family warns you out of fear
Makes you stop and have a tear

Crunch, Crunch, snack, snack
Wolfing  food down like it's crack.

Stuffing your face, show no grace
Jam it down, ignore the taste

Afraid to step upon the scale
Afraid to be called a whale

What to do, how to fix
Diet, exercise, no quick fix. 

Exercise: Pick an object, and write in different persons, including though

This is re-organized and edited from what I had in class, I prefer it this way.

Thou single wheel calls out to me
Thou body sets my transport free

                                                          I roll, I turn I jump
                                                          I really wish you were less plump

Upon they pedals I make a stand
Upon thine perch I feel grand

                                                           I feel bad when people stair,
                                                           I feel sad when people compare 
Upon you I am one with thee
Upon you I juggle balls three

                                                          I am not just for the fool, 
                                                          In fact I am a useful tool 

Exercise: Take everyones fact and write a line from each
Everyone wrote their line down, and we wrote them on the board, and then wrote out a poem.

Press on my eye ball, 
I can't see, now I fall!

Not blue, not green, make the name fit
Whatever you do differentiate it!

Born long ago,  my walls are blue
And I agree my friends love you

For every letter x
x is read x is sex

Finnish line, golden ticket, forget your knowing
This will allow your awareness to be flowing

Data lets us observe gaily
Only with faithful persistence daily

Throw it the hell away
tat pot of gold I say
My aunt painted room black as inside of a sack
Now no matter what she can't turn back

Do you believe in Sappir Worf theory
If so you'd find the wold dreary

Pink for the girls toys
Also used by little boys

Th shrimps sees sound as light
imagine how then make our world bright

Green provides s our life no dramas
unlike bright brought by our mammas

Lepricons are evil sneaks 
Don't be fooled if they are meek

Keep your mind like a young fawn
I really mean keep the light on

link.title: When the color blue was born: Week 6 - Rainbow

entry.title: When the color blue was born Week 5: Black And White
entry.content:
This class I wasn't doing a good job paying attention. So I did a bit of choose your own assignments. When this happens I feel a lot of empathy with Zach not following instructions

I'm not sure what the assignment was, but I put on very dark glasses, and couldn't really see without using a flashlight directly on the page. This was an interesting experience. Without vision my hearing increased significantly. 

Shadowy Figures every where
Can see clearly nowhere

A small circle illuminated
Thus writing emancipated

Hearing becomes Doominatnt
Living like a savant

The of rulling pages
Surrounded by sound sstages

Now pens on pagper grating
Not seeing actually illuminating

Whight sight what I witness
The better question is my focus


Focus sharp like a know knife
To learn the good things in life

The assignment was write a biography, the instructor often makes a witty comment at the end of someone reading a poem - for mine it was Autobiography? 

The Martian 
Oil green skin, like a slug
Even martians need a hug

Giant silver gun, set to stun
Makes the earth men want to run.

Black Shoes, on feet seven
Red mittens on hands eleven

Yellow eyes like daffodills
Stare at you and steal your will

Pink under wear,
Please, he forgot his pants don't stair.

Write about translucent objects - the interesting twist was we read it backwards instead of forwards
Two Translucents Talking

Ooops I guess I'm dead
Yeah that's what the last one said

Do you think we feel emotions?
I think so, I'm feeling commotion.

Do you think we need glass to see?
Nope, we need 'em to look jolly!

Can you see the wind on your cheek?
Um, when I'm a the park carceek.

Hey not only are we translucent,
But we're also sans-a-sent

link.title: When the color blue was born Week 5: Black And White

entry.title: Week 148AZ: I Don't Care.
entry.content:
I didn't take any notes about this week other than Zach starting to say "I don't care." Zach surprisingly doesn't care about lots of things: diaper changes, bed time, getting out of mud puddles, putting his toys away and so on. 

Thus instead of the usual weekly highlights real,  I am writing up our Monday adventure. 

Monday nights Tori goes to the gym and Zach and I have a father son adventure. Here's the blow by blow.

It was time to plan a Monday night adventure, so I said..
I: Do you want to go downtown?
Z: Yeah, I want to go downtown. It's the best. It's great.
Z: We need to take the bus since it's far away. It's in Seattle, where mommy and Grammy live.
(Actually, Grammy lives in San Francisco - but not bad) 

On the bus, I try making small talk. 
I: Zach, Why do we need to take the bus downtown?
Z: Because it's far away
I: How far away?
Z: Years away. 

On our way downtown, Zach sees a picture of a man screaming.
Z: Why is that man yelling?
I: Maybe his little boy made him mad.
Z: Yeah, maybe his little boy didn't listen to Mommy. 

I like making Zach give away bells. While riding the bus, I tell him to give bells to someone.
I: Zach can you give someone bells.
Z: It's your job to give all the bells. It's my job to give some of the bells. That's how we work like a team. 

Once downtown, we headed to the mall with escalators in it. On our way to the mall Zach and I sang the Spiderman tune, but instead of Spiderman we used the word "escalator." It was awesome. 

In the mall, Zach jumped on the escalator without me. (Interestingly, one of my few memories of high school was my dad and I going to the mall and me heading back home without telling him. I recall my dad being really angry about this, and me not understanding - now I get it) 

I: Did you forget something?
Z: Yeah, I forgot Daddy 

Next up on our trip we hopped on the subway. On the train I was playing with my new juggling ball, and Zach decide it should be his new juggling ball.

Z: I want that.
I: That's for Daddy's
Z: I want to share.
I: That's for Daddy's I don't need to share.
Z: I f I want something, I say I want to share, if you don't share I put you in the timeout box. 

Still on the subway, Zach looked out into the train tunnel.
Z: It's dark in the tunnel. I forgot my flashlight 

I decided our trip grand finale would be a stop at the grocery store for an apple. On the way out of the grocery store Zach saw some pipes.
Z: What are those?
I: Pipes
Z: What comes out of those?
I: What comes out of pipes at home?
Z: Water. What comes out of those pipes?
I: What do you think? 
Z: Water
I: That's induction!
Z: Induction?
I: Yeah, when you see stuff and generalize.
Silence
I: There's also deduction
Z: What's dduction?
I: It's when you say everyone named Sally is a girl, and when you meet another Sally  you then knew it's a girl
Z: Um, why'd she say that? 
I'm confused at this point?
I: Who said what?
Z: Why did Sally say she's a girl? 

Our subway ride home  was without incident. On the bus home Zach notices reading lights above the seat.
Z: Can you turn them on?
I: I can try - hym, they don't turn on.
Z: Can I try?
I: Sure
Zach tries but they don't turn on.
Z: Maybe they're out of batteries 

Earlier in the night I put a bell in Zach's pocket saying he could give it to someone on the bus. Zach agreed at the time, and was very excited to have a bell in his pockets like his dad. But, when it was time to give out the bell on the bus Zach had a different idea.

I: Zach, give a bell to someone.
Z: OK, You!
I: No, you need to pick someone else
Z: OK, you pick! 

Back home after our adventure, we see our neighbors and chat for a bit. Zach tells them all about the bus, the train, the grocery store and the apple. As we were getting ready to go, 
Z: Good Bye!
Neighbors: Good Bye!
(remember it's Monday nigh)
Z: Have a good weekend. 

Back at our house Zach gets me to make him a Sammy (Sandwich).
I: Zach, do you need some milk?
Z: I was thinking root beer
Z: Root beers my best! 

In bed, I was reading Zach a poem about a mosquito.
Z: What's a mosquito?
I: It's a bug that bites you and sucks your blood
Z: Oh, it takes your blood and you go to the hospital.
I: No it's just a bug eating.
Z: Oh I like bugs.  I'll get my butterfly net, and catch a butterfly.
I: OK, Good Night. 

Zach's learning to negotiate.
Z: Um, can you go to bed with me.
I: OK, let me get my book, but first you need to go to bed.
Z:Um, can you leave the light on.
I: No, you need to wait in bed with the lights off.
Z: OK, I'll wait for you.
I turn the light off.
Z:OK, I'm waiting for you.
I return with my tablet and with me back Zach falls asleep in 30s.

Have a good week and remember - "If you feel odd, check your underwear" - ZIT

entry.title: When the Color Blue Was Born - Week 4 Indigo/Purple
entry.content:
Homework: Seeing through blue
I like to be metorphorical when I'm talking about Blue

Seeing Being Blue
Blue is lack of color, lack of joy, lack of pleasure
Blue is being present in body, but lost in spirit
Blue is insignificant ego swimming in a sea of self doubt
Blue is fear of failure, fear of judgment, fear of worthlessness
Blue is my favorite color, but being blue sucks.

Homework: A Poem about Violet and Indigo

Violet + Indigo? Dude I'm male yo!

I only name colors primary
at a stretch maybe tertiary

Have I named purple - maybe?
but only to impress some lady

Now If we want to be precise
We'd measure these with a device

And conclude, Indigo is a superset
of violet, please - don't be upset

But if we want to be rather poetic
we'd say these are colors energetic

In Class -  We did Haiku's by writing a line and passing.
Here were two I liked

Blue Boys, Green Girls, Violet Virgins
Inappropriate
To undress the spectrum with
Purple Glasses Strip

The Sad Harmonica
Mouth Piece held too tight
White Knuckles About to split
Art is suffering


The next exercise was write 10 lines with facts taken from other class members. I decided to make a haiku sandwich (tm).

Untitled

Cosmic Beige Latte
Outside universe seeing
Professor GlazeBrooke

Free of count, free of meter
What fine soul brought in the heater

And now back to our haikus
Before the cattle start their moos

Perceive the color
Depends heavily on context
Do you see it now?

Next we listened to a song from our neighbor - I got  Green Rocky Road. Write a poem about how it tastes and feels 

Questions For Dead White Mean

Where have all the tees gone, when driving to Rainier
Clean cut, only stumps, have a beer.

Not lepricons, but wet forest says my nose
And it feels like the hips of a black woman's pose

Taste on my tongue, simmered beans
Texture on my tongue, smooth greens

And to answer you, Ecstasy
Or maybe the answer, fantasy.

link.title: When the Color Blue Was Born - Week 4 Indigo/Purple

entry.title: Week 147AZ:Tales of the Zach
entry.content:
Zach likes to drive cars. To indulge this, we often sit with him in the car in our driveway. Today as we sat in the car and Zach "drove" me around we had the following conversation:

I: Villains?
Z: Yeah, Villains, bad guys?
I: What do bad buys do?
Z: Bad stuff
Z: Like Germs, Germs make you sick.
I: What happens when you're sick?
Z: Stuff comes out your mouth

For those of you wondering about where some of these concepts comes from or why Zach uses words like "villains," the answer is cartoons and Mom. Zach has started watching Spiderman cartoons and Mom has been trying to explain about bad guys versus good guys. Snidely Whiplash fan that she is, Mom taught Zach about villains, which is a much cooler word than 'bad guys.' Mom is also trying to convince Zach to cover his mouth and nose when sneezing and to wash his hands, hence the germ discussion. Mom is also a little paranoid about the annual family flu that seems to strike around Zach's birthday and might have told Zach a few times too often that we are not doing the flu this year

Back at your friendly neighborhood car

I: What do you do with Money?
Z: Give it to the train, the train always wants money
Z: No train tickets

Mom trades rides on a train for Zach sitting still for a haircut. Zach got his hair cut this weekend but couldn't ride the train. Mom forgot to bring cash for the tickets and Zach was more than a little bent out of shape about missing his regular treat.

Zach opens the door and claims the car needs gas

Z: I'm going to fill the car with gas, do you want music?
I: Yeah
Z: Which one?
I: Thomas the train
Z: OK

Zach goes outside to fill the car with gas, when he comes back

Z: I have got to put the groceries in the back, then I'll come right back.

"I have to do blank and then I will come right back" is something that Mom tells Zach all too often.

Friday we went to Ikea so I asked Zach about where we were
I: What's at Ikea?
Z: Ikea has a place where you need to sit on the potty to play.
I: What else does Ikea have
Z: Ice cream
I: What else?
Z: A place to eat.

Ikea has a play space for kids three and over so that parents can shop in peace. Kids have to be potty trained to use the play space. We have been trying to convince Zach that play spaces are worth the bother of potty training. He doesn't seem to believe this however. Our Ikea also has a restaurant and a place that sells ice cream. Since we were there near Zach's dinner time he got both dinner and an ice cream, which really made everyone much happier.

At this point Zach wants to switch to driving the truck, (Zach's teddy bear is called Bear Bear, and Tori's truck is called Mouse)
Z: Mouse likes Bear Bear

After we're done with the car, we come back into the house:

I:  Can you put Bear Bear to sleep?
Z: No he has energy to stay awake and ride the train.

Bunny (Zach's newest stuffed animal), Bear, and Bear Bear all have a ridiculous amount of energy and never need naps, unlike Zach's parents. Zach fell asleep sitting in a chair at the kitchen table the other night mid sentence. He wisely did not fall out of his chair, but did wake up about an hour later to finish his sentence from his bed.

Potty training is going very slowly. Zach  feel the need to address the issue when he has servants (aka parents) to address his needs. Chocolate, while tempting is not a worthwhile motivator, nor are toys or trips to the children's museums or cool play spaces. Being about the get out of his seat at a restaurant is about the best thing we have found so far to motivate Zach to want to go to the bathroom, but it is a hard and expensive thing to replicate.

Operation bedroom has begun. So far the ceiling has been painted and two colors have been picked for the walls. The recent trip to Ikea has resulted in some furniture and there is hope on the horizon that constant house painting phase will soon be suspended until further notice.

entry.title: Week 146AZ: Bear, Bear Bear and Learning about Money
entry.content:
I'm very fond of naming things; I'd say it's one of my defining skills. The apple doesn't fall far from the tree and Zach has my naming knack. You see Zach's got a teddy bear and he calls it Bear. When Zach got a second bear he called it Bear Bear. I'm proud. I couldn't have done better myself.

We had a few interesting discussions about money this week. The first one was about a beggar:

Looking at a beggar on the street
Z: Why is that man holding a sign?
I: Well he's working.
Z: Why does he work? 
I: So he can get money.
Z: Why do people stop for him?
I: So they can feel happiness by giving.

Later, when driving past a very cool vacuum repair shop that has robots outside: 
Z: Buy me a robot.
I: But we don't have money.
Z: How do we get money?
I: We have to go to work.
Z: Why?
I: So we can have money, we trade our work for money. 
Z: Buy me a robot.

Lastly, we had a very ironic conversation at Cash and Carry.  Cash and Carry is like Cost Co, but it targets smalls business owners, not consumers. Cash and Carry has a  large produce section with sliding doors, so Zach calls it "the store with doors inside".   Any whoo, we're at Cash and Carry with our giant shopping cart and Zach says:

Z: We're like garbage men.
Z: We're filling up the truck with garbage.
Z: It's garbage man Zach and garbage man Daddy. 

Our big secret this week was a couples massage. I lined up a baby sitter (thank you Chiyako!), a couples massage, and a post massage trip to the best French bakery in Seattle. Sadly, my best laid plans were foiled by Tori getting a stomach bug, which started Friday night, and continued through most of the weekend. 

The weekend was jam packed with eating. Friday we went out with the Paul and Sandra clan for our first BBQ of the season. Saturday night, the Nathan clan came to visit and we feasted on felafel, gefilte fish, and fried chicken. I do love my fusion meals. There was so much eating I need to get back in the gym. I'm writing this at 6am, after a 5am gym visit.

Zach is becoming more independent. Last Wednesday Tori went to personal training and left Zach in the gym daycare - awesome work!  Sunday at circus school, for the first time ever, Zach did some of the activities on his own, without me being present. Great Job buddy. We're proud of you - I'm sure we'll miss you being dependent and pray for the day you become interdependent again. 

Have a good week and remember - Scotching Before Watching, Running  before drumming - ZIT

link.title: Week 146AZ: Bear, Bear Bear and Learning about Money

entry.title: When The Color Blue Was Born: Week 3 - Green + Blue
entry.content:
The homework: 
Name your own color palette: 
I really need to drink more water yellow
One tequila too many green
I shouldn't have made him angry black and blue.

5 observations about green: 
Seaweed, Kale, Broccoli
Arugula, Cilantro, Parsely

5 observations about blue: 
Blue Mood, don't Intrude
Blue Berries, make us merry
Blue Cheese, yes please
Blue Eyes, see the skies
Blue KoolAid, needs accolades.

2 Facts about vision and the eyes
We smell less and see more by evolution
Thus we need a clever solution

For when we fall we should not wack it
thus we have an eye sock-it

---
(Hey I'm jewish this is OK :) 
Notice that to our nose we are blind
Odd, when it's bigger then our behind.
--

For the class itself: 

Part 1: Write a poem based on your green homework (5 min) 

Green is sick, but blue is sad,
While we're at it, red is mad.

Back to green the salad bar,
and the shades of a rock star.

Green as well is kermit the frog
Did you know he's allergic to smog.

Green is the ocean floor
You know I love the sushi store.

Green as well the sea turtle,
Fungal Feet make me milk curdle.


Part 2: Write about an experience you had today (5 min) 

Waddle in data said my boss,
Huh? I'm truly at a loss

How the heck should I do that?
Staired into space while In my chair sat.

Then I remembered I work for money
And suddenly it was very funny

So once again a grin wear I
Because I am feeling oh so sly.


Part 3: Merge them (5 min) 

The data has been green all day
I feel my mind is filled with hay.

Is it lunch time yet?
I think a salad I will get?

Day dream some more
Hey, now it's four!

Done am I - I again wish,
Now I think of raw fish

What is that nasty smell?
In my head goes off a bell.

From my job I am now free,
Since I work for moneee.

At this, point many people shared some deep emotional poems, so I was feeling time to man up - the next tasks was to write about a picture you brought in. I brought  a picture of my son smiling.

Poem about a picture of my son smiling at me.

Tomorrow smiling at me.

Tomorrow you'll be chasing tail,
Just like every teenage male.

Tomorrow you'll likely have no time
It's OKour journey was sublime

Tomorrow you'll think I'm wrong
Heck you'll probably sing it in a song.

One day you'll be really sad,
because you won't know your dad

I hope that day I'm still alive
So we can make our friendship jive

But if I'm not that's OK too,
Because I left this blog for you.

link.title: When The Color Blue Was Born: Week 3 - Green + Blue

entry.title: Week 145AZ: I love you too daddy
entry.content:
There's lots of awesome things about being a dad. Listening to your
kid talking to himself  before he falls asleep certainly ranks highly.
Last night I don't remember most of the conversation, but I at least
recall:

Zach: 4,5,6,7,8,9,1,2,3.
Long Pause
Igor: (in whisper) I love you Zach
Zach: (in whisper) I love you too daddy

The alternate title for this week was your "Poo Stinks Too."  This
came about because Zach's now all about 'WHY'.  We were at the grocery
store and I had to pee urgently, so I picked Zach up and ran to take a piss.

Zach bouncing up and down because we're jugging at a decent gate, looks at me and says...
Zach: Why are we running?
Igor: To go to potty
Zach: Why do you  to go to the potty?
Igor: Because I don't wear panties
Zach: Why don't you wear potties?
Igor: Because they get sticky, and icky, and stinky.
Zach: My panties don't get stinky
Igor: Oh, life lesson here - your poo stinks too!

As you can see, Zach's nailed conversation, and I'll share some more of my favorites:

Out of the blue
Zach: What's up dude?

At dinner friday night
Zach: How was your day?
Igor: Long, grumble, moan.
Zach; OK - ask me about my day now.

Tori is now armed with a decent camera phone, and is doing an amazing job recording Zach's many adventures. It was a real challenge picking out this weeks photos, so I highly recommend checking out flickr.


In other news:

I'm getting fat; it's time to start going to the gym and juicing again.  Zach's going to love the juicing.  He especially  likes going to Cash and Carry, which he calls the store with doors inside,  for fruits and veggies and helping work the juicer.    In other health news Tori has started personal training and can be found in the gym several nights a week. One of those nights, Tori and Zach are doing swimming lessons at the Y and Zach is overcoming his fear of putting his face in the water. He still won't get in a shower though.


Tori's finished the missing trim around the doors, WOOHOO!   Tori got Zach got a conductor's hat and he wears it pretty non stop. Tori is also working on a chef's hat and a cape, so we can go into dress up high gear.


I'm going to start calling daycare/pre-schools "castles."  We found a "castle" I really like around the corner from our house and Zach loves it. It is called the Cottage School and I can't wait till they have openings in September.  Zach still likes his co-op preschool class and has started to admit there are other kids with names in his class. He loves to ride on the zip line and hold on to Teacher Connie's and Teacher Anna's hands.

There is only a small amount of progress on the potty training front. Zach is being rewarded with a combination of visits to the kid's museum and TV. Slow but steady wins the race though so there is hope. Zach especially likes the Everett kid's museum which has a rooftop playground, a plane and a bus as well as tons of other stuff. He is also willing to take a ferry to the Bainbridge kid's museum and might even head down to the one in Tacoma one of these days. 

We have a big Saturday surprise planned for next week - please ask Tori what it's all about.

link.title: Week 145AZ: I love you too daddy

entry.title: Passing
entry.content:
One of the funnest parts of juggling is passing. Here's what it looks like:

Balls flying through the air
Kids laughing without care

Four Count,  Fast Start, Three Count, Slow Start
Juggling Techno Babble,  this is my art.

Smile, Laugh,   Lose your Ego
Enjoy yourself  my dear amigo

Patterns spanning people two
We're here to entertain you

So when you see us doing that,
Stick a dollar in our hat!

entry.title: When the color blue was born - poetry class week 2 - orange and yellow
entry.content:
Useful things I learned:
  • Poets look down on my desire to rhyme and use couplets. 
  • I tend to classify "poems" that don't use rhyme as  bad prose.
  • Prose writers are called Prosers. 
  • Orange and Red are often misnamed:. Fire Trucks are red, fires are not. Red heads are orange. 
  • In nature, orange is often transition: Fire, Sunset, Leaves in the fall. 
  • My work is so focused on the rhyme you miss the story. Need to fix that. 

 Today's exercises were fun:

First, from a peer get a question that Orange might ask of you and answer it: 


How does it feel to be so open to interpretation?
Frankly this is causing serious perspiration.
