Many shade but words few,
I can only think of two

Amber and orange is all I see
Do you disagree with me?

Now amber alert is kind of odd
It makes me really doubt my god

Amber is name of a girl gone
A girl who'll never see the dawn

Let's lighten up w/vitamn C
Who picked an orange label - not me!

Did you notice orange doesn't rhyme
I know, it truly is a crime


Second,  from a peer, get an observation about yellow, and a quote from a yellow poem. Then write down a secret and put it in your shoe. Poetize it:
Lemons on the kitchen counter. Describe the ...

Lemons on the kitchen counter
I hear a secret - I counter

Describe the shade of carpet - sir
Really? I need to rhyme that - grr!

Let's return to secrets now,
Will I disclose - if so how?

You see someone may get hurt
Always a problem if you blurt

Is it someone in the room?
Perhaps it was was with the groom!

Or maybe it happened with the the teacher?
Or perhaps back there, behind the bleacher?

Perhaps names we can disguise?
Yes indeed, so very wise!

I'll say it now, I'll even YELL
Are you crazy? I'll never tell.

Third, copy down some writing from someone else in the class:

Red ink of mismanaged burdens -- grammar, spelling, exhausted leaps of over heated logic, sentences lain still, wounded, and discouraged by topic, dripping the red of failed hope.

link.title: When the color blue was born - poetry class week 2 - orange and yellow

entry.title: Week 145AZ: Canollies, Canollies, Canollies.
entry.content:
Zach, like his father, likes to be the center of attention - It's kind of a problem.  When other people are talking Zach will start to scream. Today,  while Chiyako was trying to have a conversation with Tori, Zach screamed Canollies, Canollies, Canollies,  By the way that picture of Chiyako was taken by Zach - he's got the artist's eye :)

Friday Night, Amy and Sarah came over, which was wild as Sarah brought over her Sitar. I do enjoy having  jugglers and musicians over for dinner.

Funny things Zach said this week:

After serving Chiyako one sliver of carrot:
Z: If you eat too much you get a tummy ache.
Z:  You can have some , and then you can have some more.

While Amy And Sarah sat at our dinner table:
I: Zach, how were you looking for at the grocery store.
Zach smiles at Sarah and Amy and says:
Z: You guys.

While Watching TV - turns to me and says:
Z: Go Sit  on the couch, I'll just finish watching TV.

Out of the blue:
Z: Is it tomorrow yet?

Tori and Zach have been working on potty training. Still a slow process, but Tori explained to me  Zach's bottom is named Rudy. I wanted to post a picture, but Tori forbade it (you're lucky to have such a great Mom Zach).

Sunday, Tori got some serious work done on the french doors, while Zach and I had a super adventure.  Zach and I did Circus school, Pizza with the Doties and Nachos with the Rambos.


Have a good week and remember - Rhyming is Timing - ZIT.

entry.title: Thank you for adopting us ...
entry.content:
Thank you for adopting us
Sure you'll say you made no fuss.

But when we lounge upon your couch
and when our kid is such a grouch

When something silly I have said
and Tori's eyes roll in her head

That's when your kindness is stretched longest,
That's when your our gratitude is strongest.

Time with you is time with family. 
Time with you is time spent happily. 

When Paul and Sandra make their soup
and I see the pride in their troupe!

When Ben's independence is on fire 
and respect for Sam is growing higher.

When everyone loves each other
And there's enough love to smother

That's when I say thank you
For adopting us out of the blue!

entry.title: The Doties
entry.content:
John and Misty you make me feel good,
Add in Malcolm and you're my familyhood

Your kid is cute, your kid is smart
He is so awesome he stands apart.

At circus school or playing chase
He's full of energy and sets the pace.

To your wedding we failed to go.
But that was really long ago

With your chickens we play when you're not home
Fear not, that's just a bad rhyme for testosterone.

When Zach was born you brought us salad
Which proved to us our friendship valid

Zach and Malcolm will be like brothers
And jealous will be all the others.

Tori helped you put in your dishwasher,
And she's almost the wife of the author.

By the way, if I'm at your house all happy and gay
Never be afraid to say:   "GO AWAY"

entry.title: A Party For Sam
entry.content:
Boys and Girls, dear Moms and Dad
When having a party you'll never be sad.

Birthday, christmas, graduation, barmitzvah
Strawberry, chocolate, and vanilzvah

Hats, balloons,  clowns and snakes
Just don't forget the party cakes!

Sam you are my favorite niece
Enjoy this poem, my masterpiece!

entry.title: When the color blue was born - poetry class week 1 - red
entry.content:
Unless you've got a crush on Igor, are evaluating his sanity, or are fond of amateur poetry you probably want to skip this post.

This year I’m on a lucky streak. For example, the poetry class I wanted to take on Wed Night was cancelled, and I didn't find out till Tuesday at 3pm.  Instead of being sad, I asked the messenger if she had other class recommendations, and she mentioned I take When the color blue was born which started that night. Tori was kind enough to grant me permission and off I went to my first writing class – 35 years into life.

When I arrived I saw the following on the whiteboard:

The opening line of a poem is like finding a fruit on the ground, a piece of fallen fruit. Fruit you have never seen before, and the poet’s task is to create the tree from which such a fruit would fall.

The students and the instructor in the class are  awesome, all of them can write, and even more awesome they can all read spoken word at a professional grade. It was like listening to This American Life. Best, each student had different reading and writing voices, and it was a riot going around the room hearing everyone read someone else’s poems, or hearing them read their own writing.

We did two writing exercises, the first was write a line, pass left – 30s per person. Here’s the output:

Red Dress; Red Folder

A new way to fold, to fall out of
And into, and onto and blindly

Like the scales of a lizard,
That was beyond origami

A folded crimson sun
That set each evening between the couch and the chair

The lizard on his rock, feels the wind changing,
He slides against the back of satin sheet

And the dust from the desert swept life up
and descended it again

I love the dress and hate the folder,
Chaos today; tomorrow order.

The next exercise was on small pieces of paper write 5 red words and  5 non red words, put everyone’s papers in a pile, shuffle piles, draw 10 words, write poem – here’s what I wrote:

Act 1:  10 parts         
Cucumber Soup - Deceive!
My arms against your, peaceful, acne
Ashen, bellowing, frigid, pale
Rose

Act 2:  Filling
Acne on my nose,
Red Rose!
Peaceful, frigid, pale
Yes, a red whale.
Swimming in cucumber soup,
Dreaming, glouroius red soup.
My arms against your ashen lips,
Bellowing, deceiving, I miss your hips.

We had a bonus exercise, of using red without color – here was mine ...
Act III: Black and white
Knife Gripping
Life Slipping
Blood Dripping

link.title: When the color blue was born - poetry class week 1 - red

entry.title: Week 144AZ: Home Alone
entry.content:
Now that I'm caught up expect good posts starting next week. 

Most of this week Tori and Zach were in California spending time with Grammy (Tori's mom) and Zach's four month old cousin Kathy, so this post will be mostly about my adventures.

It is weird that every day for the last 3 years I've wished for peace and quiet. "Just a few more minutes" I have begged for myself day in and day out.  This week, with Tori and Zach out of town, my wish was granted. Man was I lonely. The highlight of my day was the picture Tori would send, or a call on Skype with my family. Thank you Tori for sending me pictures daily, and Skyping even when you were exhausted.

I squandered much of my free time, but I did start reading Shel Silverstien, who is my poetic inspiration. Next week I start my poetry class and I'm curious if I'll enjoy it.  I also started juggling class a few weeks back and it is awesome. I found a juggling partner who has me passing, and more importantly practicing. She’s cool  and that's her, her fiancé and Zach sporting fine china.

I got a chance to play squash with some younger folks this week and it was a riot seeing how I've grown wiser, shifting my game from tactics to strategy. It's amazing that even an old man making a crappy shot can win if the opponent is always in the wrong spot. 

Whenever I clean the house, and the car, and get flowers, Tori thinks I am having an affair. She figured it must have been a dozy while she was gone as the house was spotless.  Speaking of getting back from vacation, there is no better feeling than your kid spotting you in the airport and then running into your arms to give you a huge hug - Fatherhood rocks.

Have a good week and remember: There's an O in horse - ZIT

entry.title: Week 142/143AZ: I want to be like you when I grow up
entry.content:
Zach's out of town this week so I'm finally catching up - I'll merge Week 142 and 143 and we'll start back on weekly posts for week 144.

 As I mentioned last week, Zach's a person now, here's a few things the little man  said:

When I was randomly sitting on the couch (induced tears):
Z: I want to be like you when I grow up.

When I got home from work:
Z: I want a Zach sized police car.

When I stopped to fill the car with gas:
Z: leave the radio on

When we went past Zach's favorite play spot:
 Z: Why not stopping at Benna (the play spot is Ravenna which Zach pronounced Benna).

Of course, more than Zach talking, we measure Zach by what he does at the circus class. Zach is now in the 3 year old class at circus, which means he gets to learn new skills like forward rolls, hanging upside down on the trapeze, and walking on a tight rope. The tight rope (a metal cable) , is the first device which has made Zach declare he's actually cold.  Yes, the blame of Zach's coldness was bad fathering, I forgot to bring Zach socks.

As a person, Zach's starting to rebel against his nap, and starting to explore using the potty. These events conspire to indicate Zach's getting ready for daycare.   I'm very hopeful we can get into the cottage school, which is a daycare about 8 blocks from our house.  There open house is early February, cross your fingers.

On the house front, Tori's been making slow buy steady progress. Thanks to the arrival of her nailer and router bits, trim is magically appearing around our doorframes.

On the Igor front, I finally got around to installing a car stereo and TV in the RAV4. I should have done that long ago. I'm also very close to discovering my personal mission statement and have started in juggling class.  Juggling class is very fun, and I've now found someone to pass with - Wooohooo!

Have a good week and remember: The one who laughs last, laughs longest - ZIT

link.title: Week 142/143AZ: I want to be like you when I grow up

entry.title: First Flush
entry.content: If you're not a parent, seeing your kids first flush doesn't make a lot of sense. The first time they do though, you want something like this:

entry.title: Week 141AZ: I live with a little human being
entry.content:
Arg, I'm getting behind on these -  I'm  going to bang some posts out so I don't lose my memories :) 


This was the week where I finally figured out that I live with a small human being! Joy, Pleasure, Awesomeness!  Here is how I came to this realization...

I've been  on vacation for three weeks, so I've been waking up at 5 am and working on my computer projects in the basement. 
 Zach has figured out I am  in the basement, and so every day when he wakes up around 8 am, he goes down into the basement to see what I'm upto.  On the day of my great realization, I was talking to my sister on Skype, and Zach came down and said what's that scary noise? That was the exact moment I realized Zach's just a little human. 



Tuesday, New Year's Day is jump in the lake day, and I had a blast as usual. Sadly Zach and Tori were sick and couldn't come, but I'm looking forward to them joining me in the lake next year.




Thursday we went to the tree at REI and Zach was doing a small show with his hat. As you can see it shouldn't be long before Zach becomes an honest to goodness busker.


On Friday, we went to our new friend Nathan's house, where I failed to get pictures, but had a wonderful time with Nathan's family.


On Saturday, we chilled with our buddies Teman and Aiden. Aiden has the awesomest hair!



Sunday, I got into Zach's finger paints, and that was super fun.  After painting up my head, Zach and I hit up a Quebecois square dance. 

Now one of the key properties of being human, is awesome conversations, here are some I wrote down.


On Silliness:
  Z: Dad your're silly?
  I: What? Why?
 Z: You do silly things
  I: Smile
 Z: I'm silly too
  I: Huge Smile.



On going for adventures:
 I: Let's go for an adventure
 Z: NO

 I: Let's go for an adventure
 Z: NO

  I: Let's go to the tree at REI:
 Z: NOOOOYES
 Z: OK
 Z: Let's GO


Have a good week and remember: Blue paint is not for those who tend to feint.
-ZIT

link.title: Week 141AZ: I live with a little human being

entry.title: My first going out to dinner with Zach
entry.content:
Today, for the first time in his life, I took Zach out for dinner with me, where Zach was my date. Sure I've taken him in the past, but in those cases Zach was a possession, not a human companion. Here are some of our conversations:

Zach: I'm a smart boy
Igor: What? Who taught you that?
Zach: I taught me that

And also:

Zach:  Um, what did you do at work today.
Igor: Shock, Aww, Pride

link.title: My first going out to dinner with Zach

entry.title: I've been living my life and it's been working

link.title: I've been living my life and it's been working

entry.title: First time at an open mike - achievement unlocked
entry.content:
My public debut at beacon bards:

Two wheels full of grace
Snot dripping down my face

Legs pumping full of might
Yellow jacket super bright

No noise, no yukky, no gray
No animals to scare away

Sure it will take you twice as long
But you'll look better in a thong

And parking, well that is a joke
Relax, smile at the womanfolk.

Breath in the air, and be alive
To be present,  for that we strive

Thank you my dear bicycle
For solving problems societal

In case you're thinking I'm fearless -  I started shaking after I got off the stage, but it was totally worth it!


---
I later made this into a song here.

link.title: First time at an open mike - achievement unlocked

entry.title: Week 140AZ: Mad and Sad
entry.content:
(Sorry folks with time off my posts are getting long. I blame the eggnog. Compressed unreadable posts will be returning shortly)



On Monday we  lucked out and had Christmas day dinner at our friends Paul, Sandra, Ben, and Sam's house. They had invited grandparents, aunts and several neighbors with kids of various ages there so it was quite the party. Zach headed straight to the playroom and ignored the grown ups and other kids for most of the night. He came down occasionally for food in between chasing his four year old friend Ben with a Nerf gun and playing trains. He was finally carried out crying and saying vehemently that he wanted to stay. We bribed him with some of Sandra's smashed potatoes and he finally decided that maybe he would go to bed at home.



Of course, such an event can not be drama free, and this was no exception.  An unnamed perpetrator locked Zach in the closet for 10 minutes.  Upon release Zach declared with great emotion - "I'm mad and sad".  Zach was so mad and sad, he continued telling this story for days. I'm very pleased Tori has done such a good job teaching Zach to express his emotions.



On Tuesday, running an hour late, we raced to a play date at  Liam, Jen and Jim's three week old daughter's house.  Jogging up the stairs, something seemed odd when  a sign on the door said "don't ring the bell baby sleeping". Slightly puzzled I knocked on the door, and Jim appeared in his underwear.  I don't know Jim well, but my respect for him went through the roof, and I invited myself in. Like his father, Zach is able to feel comfortable anywhere so I flopped down on Jim's couch, and Zach proceeded to play with Liam's toys. I asked Jim where everyone else was, and he said the party was tomorrow  I guess I wasn't an hour late, I was just 23 hours early.



On Wednesday and Thursday we forgot to remember what we were up to



On Friday Tori felt terrible so we had a solid day of manly bonding. A few highlights for the memory box.

First - Zach came down to my office and we had this conversation:
Z: I broke Mommy's feelings
I: How?
Z: I did something on purpose
I: Hym?
Z: I was doing my timeout and wanted to play trains.
I: I see.

Second - A few hours later upstairs:

Z: Can you get my kindle (his tablet) so I can not watch TV. I'll just wait for an email from my friend Mr. Jonah.
I: No, you're just going to watch TV.
Z: Dad, go to your office and listen to music so I can watch TV.

To finish our wonderful man day we hit the  bar, where we got this awesome video. The video demonstrates the  perfect yin and yang of breeding a Tori with an Igor. While at the bar, we also had this hallmark moment:

I am at the bar, enjoying my wine.   Zach emerges from the kid pit holding a toy train, and scurries onto the bar seat beside me. He pauses for a few moments and says:

Z: Daddy, do you want some train juice?
I: Sure

Zach then tilts his train into my cup  until I make the stop poring signal, and we sit and enjoyed our beverages.

And, we ended our fine man date would with  intra bar and inter bar bike rides.


On Saturday I wanted to wear my bathrobe all day, but settled for wearing it  to the gym and our family hood - before I succumbed to Tori's demand that I apply pants.  After the pants were applied we spent a dandy evening with Shayna, Allison, and Jonah. We ate tasty stew and watched the kids battle for who would be in the band.



On Sunday we started our day sorting coins with Ben and Sam. Initially, Zach didn't want to go to Ben and Sam's but we said maybe he'd be able to lock one of them in the closet, and then he decided he would come.  After visiting with Ben and Sam, we watched String - which was some kind of performance art. Well technically Zach and Tori watched String with a group of Mom/ kid friends, while the tech for the performance space patiently escorted me out of the audience. I am claiming this as a no-fault event. After String, we hit up Melissa's favorite cocktail spot, where I had two too many Tequilas.


Have a good week, and remember: Just because you've changed doesn't mean anyone else has - ZIT

entry.title: Happy jump in the lake day 2013
entry.content:
Cold, Freezing, Wet, Brr
Too long, and you'll start to slur

People screaming at the shore
Souls ready for their soar

Four, three, two, one
Run in and have your fun

Feet, Knees, Nuts, Neck
Are you crazy what the heck?

Can no longer feel your feet?
Turn back before you feel conceit

Now you stand upon the grass
Find something to warm your ass

Sadly, Zach and Tori were sick and couldn't join me this year, but I hope they'll participate next year.  The most moving part of the event happened as I was getting into my car to leave.  A  mother ran up as I was getting into my car and said:

My Son has been walking behind you and loves your hat, can he take a picture with you?

Of course I replied, and  lofted the kid onto my shoulders.

Merry Jump in the Lake Day!

link.title: Happy jump in the lake day 2013

entry.title: Week 138/139AZ: Snow and Snuggles
entry.content:
This post covers weeks 138 and 139 when I was distracted from posting by so much going on.  


It's Christmas time in the Pacific North West and Zach thinks he's Santa Clause. Zach acquired this notion after giving out the tasty cookies he and Tori made for our neighbors. Next year we'll have to make more cookies and deliver them to more neighbors. I wish I had made videos. There is nothing cuter than a neighbor opening their door and Zach handing them a gift bag saying "here you go" before walking away while humming 'Jingle Bells'. Zach, like his dad,  knows two holidays songs - Rudolph the Red Nosed Reindeer and Jingle Bells -  and sings them or hums them constantly most days. 

Christmas morning Zach got up and watched cartoons while he ate breakfast. We reminded him that he could open his presents and it took quite a bit of coaxing before he decided to give it a try. Between the wrapping paper and regular packaging Zach lost some interest in his presents and decided to just devote himself to making sure all the paper was off of everything. So Tori and I did most of the actual opening and then Zach caught on that there was really something in all of the boxes instead of just the nice picture on the outside of the box. 

Unrelated and amazingly, Zach's hatred of bike helmets was localized to the yellow helmet I had bought him. Tori let Zach choose an identical blue helmet at the consignment store (kuddo's  for saving money) and Zach loves wearing it. I think there's a management lesson to be learned here, but I'm going to ignore it for now. With Zach's new blue helmet we can bike up to the school and bike around their play ground. There's something very fatherlike about standing around  watching your kid on a bicycle. And if there's any confusion it feels awesome.

Tori is working her inner artisan to paint, build, and install baseboards and door trim. Zach is getting introduced to the noise and mess of routing and sawing. His aunt gave him his own tool set for the holidays and he stopped humming long enough to say "this is just what I needed!!" Zach will make a fine young tradesman. Our main floor is almost finished and as soon as  the doors are trimmed out and the last wall painted we'll  start designing the remodel. It's funny on the artisan thing, Tori has come to terms with the fact that I can't tell a difference more subtle then purple or green, and I'm coming to terms with the pride Tori takes in the work she does.

In basement news, Tori encouraged me to check out University of Washington (UW) surplus, where I found an awesome office desk for $10, and Tori found a brand new in the box overhead projector for $50. I suspect we will become regulars at UW surplus. Thank god our house is small, which limits our maximum junk ownership.  I'm itching to build two walls for my office and hang an actual door with a Zach proof lock. If you have any construction skills I'm looking for conscripts.

We took our friends Chris, Melinda and their two year old Logan to the snow where we all got to put on layers of snow gear and watch Logan and Zach's first attempts at snow walking.  I especially like the contrast between my and Tori's teaching methods for showing the boys how not to constantly fall over. 

As I am typing this from my office, Zach is sitting beside me spinning in his office chair watching a Caillou cartoon on his Kindle. This is the good life. 


Have a good week and remember - Carrots and Peas, Peas and Carrots, Watch your mouth, kids are parrots.
ZiT

entry.title: Planning the upstairs
entry.content: We've started our big remodel planning. Here's one of the first drafts of the upstairs. If you're interested I can send you the plans they're drawn in SweetHome3D.

entry.title: To eleven more!
entry.content:
Tori, you are my love,
Tori, you are my dove.

You make me laugh, you make me cry.
When I'm with you I feel so sly.

You are the best Mom I know,
I wish to say that in stereo

My love for you is hard to measure,
like yours for  Zach - a giant treasure.

It's time to make our friendship re-ignite,
I want us to be like dynamite.

Hear my words, and hear my rhyme
To make this right I'll work overtime.

Sometimes my efforts are hard to see
But when you notice yell yippee.

And when I see you being great,
My praise for you will percolate.

And with this effort all will see,
The two of us are full of glee.

Together we've been for years seven,
Now lets renew for another eleven!

entry.title: Zach's First Solo Show
entry.content:
Oh the highs of fatherhood - here is Zach's first Solo Performance!

A few things you probably didn't notice:
1) The red blanket on the floor was going to be the curtain.
2) Zach starts by saying "Thank you for coming everyone"
3) Frog has a broken arm

entry.title: Week 137AZ: Best Weekend Ever
entry.content:
(I know sometimes art doesn't work, but you have to embrace the suck to suck less so here goes something novel)

We did a bunch this week but I had so much fun this weekend that it is all I want to talk about. Usually I lack the stamina and Tori lacks the trust to let me have Zach for most of the weekend, but this weekend the magic happened, so I'll give you the blow by blow:

Saturday:
Zach and I slept in - ahh
Then Tori ran off to gather leaves and play with Bunny
Zach and I went to Malcolm's where I chilled with John and Misty as Zach and Malcolm went crazy
After which Tori rejoined us just in time to…
Enjoy the youth show at Zach’s circus school where Zach was a little disappointed he couldn't clap continuously.
Play with the owners at Shodai Teriyaki while eating yummy japanese food.
Walk around Greenlake with Ammon and enjoy the hundreds of candles and musical/ choral groups celebrating the Pathway of Lights.
Come home and crash.

Sunday:
Zach, Tori and I all slept in - ahh
We all  went to Circus School where Zach did a super star work out and I signed up for magic class.
Zach and Tori went to REI to play in their tree while I caught a shower at the gym
Then Tori ran off to put her new table saw together and make some baseboard
Zach and I went to Paul and Sandra's house where we played with the magical Ben and Sam and helped them decorate their Christmas tree and return books to the library.
After which Tori  was sick of installing baseboard so we picked up her up and brought her to Paul and Sandra’s just in time to .. 
Savor a scrumptious dinner with Paul, Sandra, Ben, Sam and their friends. 


Ahhhhhhhhhh

Have a good week, and remember:
Shut up and hug -ZiT

entry.title: Week 136AZ: O Christmas Tree
entry.content:
This was a great week. Zach has made some real progress, Tori's finished painting the living room, and Dad's feeling great from the above and stuff going well at work.

Zach started by saying some very cute stuff this week:
  • It won't work it's plugged out (not plugged in)
  • Dad - Did you poo? Zach - No I only farted (lying through his teeth)

But he also had some major break achievements:
  • Let Tori leave him at the daycare at the gym while she worked out
  • Peed in the potty

Not to be outdone, Tori finished painting the living room, dotted the living room with spots,  and orchestrated a Christmas tree tradition.

Feeling competitive Igor went on a spending spree (don't ask), and feels like a champ since his family kicks ass and his job is going well.  Unfortunately my pants are shrinking again so it's time to go back to the gym.

While the week was great the  weekend was greater. We started Saturday by hiking through the woods to find an x-mas tree with Sam and Ben (pictured). Of course, the dad's didn't have a map so we just wandered aimlessly in the woods till the mom's made us give up and buy trees at a tree farm. The kids didn't know better and were having a blast holding hands and throwing snow balls.

For Sunday we hit the Santa train, which while cold and wet, makes Zach happy and lets us hang with our pals MG,CG and Logan.  Chris and Igor ate cherry pie from twin peaks, and Zach and Logan made goatee's from the chocolate in their cookies (hopefully we can get a photo from the Gray's).


Have a good week and remember - Mustache For Movember; Dandilions for December - ZIT

entry.title: Words from the Zach:Daddy will bring us muscles
entry.content:
Where does he get this stuff ...

Mom - we need to go to the gym
Zach - no lets stay home
Mom - How will we get big muscles?
Zach - Daddy will give us muscles and we'll stay home.

link.title: Words from the Zach:Daddy will bring us muscles

entry.title: Week 135AZ: Flooding, Trenching and the Family Ranch
entry.content:
When they say owning is better than renting they fail to take into consideration things like leaking roofs and flooding basements. Thanks to our Mason's quick action the roof is now patched, and we now own our own shop vac which Zach and Tori used to dry out the basement. We've got some ideas as to what caused our basement troubles and are working on necessary repairs. We just need to buckle down and wait for the next storm to see if the repairs have worked.


It was American Thanksgiving so we went down to Maureen and Brian's ranch where we were put to work trenching. Driving a Bobcat is very fun and we got to help put in 40 feet of trench for the future micro hydro electric plant.  There is something very wholesome and mentally healing about working with heavy machinery.  

Like his folks, Zach loves it at at the ranch. It is a shame it's so far away, otherwise we'd be there even more often then we are.  It is hard to say what Zach's favorite part of the trip was, but watching him fight for dominance with the alpha dog and then play with the beta dogs was very pleasant.

Our methodology for getting to the ranch is worth a mention: we drive through the night often leaving at 8 or 9pm and arriving around 5am.  This works great since Zach sleeps for most of the drive and the roads are fairly empty. In case you have not had the chance to drive in a car with Zach, he back seat drives, sings, screams, and mostly recently throws things at your head from his car seat; not really what you want to deal with for eight hours straight.  On the trip home from the ranch (where we left at 8pm) I got a great 6 hour stretch of using my cruise control.  This was my first time ever using cruise control (Brian taught me how to turn it on the last time he was up), and it was extremely helpful. It allowed me to hold an even pace while being the lead car, and made sure I wasn't speeding while going through the various cities.

As usual, Zach has been learning more new phrases. Some of my favorite this week are:

  • Zach's job is to do what Zachy wants to do 
  • Mom give Dad a smoochie whoochie so I can watch TV.
  • Mommy turn on the blue light again (referring to the dashboard light for cruise control)
Have a good week and remember - you can put a man in a bobcat but you can't make him trench a strait line - ZIT.

link.title: Week 135AZ: Flooding, Trenching and the Family Ranch

entry.title: Week 134AZ: Zach Painting
entry.content:
Short post this week, I'll post more at thanksgiving.

I've been waiting for the living room to appear painted for about a year now, and it finally happened. It turns out the magic is letting Zach paint. Any hoo, 3 more walls painted this week, and at this point we've just got to complete the accent walls.

Next week we're heading up to the farm for our annual thanksgiving pilgrimage. As per tradition we'll drive through the night so Zach sleeps and mom and dad can practice their coffee drinking.

entry.title: The Name Game
entry.content:
Zach -What's Dad's name?
   Igor
Zach - What's Mom's Name?
  Tori
Zach - what's your name?
  I dunno

entry.title: Blogging from Zach's Bed
entry.content:
I'm sure this will result in me branded a bad parent, but you know it happens to the best of us. Zach convinced me it's less effort to sit in his bed till he falls asleep than to listen to him scream - so here I am. Zach never wore this dragon suite which is a shame as it was awesome, but we somehow conned him into wearing the dragon head.

Happy day!

entry.title: Week 133AZ: Super Sunday
entry.content:
Wow, what  a great day:
  • Tori painted a strip of the living room (I don't think we'll keep it, but it's progress after a long hiatus)
  • Zach did everything at circus school and even volunteered to go first
  • Dad read Zach a nap time story (even though Zach never actually went down for a nap) 
  • Tori dragged Zach and Dad to the park where we stomped around in the rain and watched the salmon swim upstream 
  • We went to Fu Man Dumpling house where Zach chomped down on his dumpling and house special chow mein - (Zach using chopsticks)
  • We found a new fruit stand pretty close to our place (the peach pit) 
  • We came home and made Juice w/Zach
Of course the main attraction is Zach, some of my favorite things he said this week were: 
  •    At mom - you need to give dad a smoochy whoochy
  •    At mom - no going to the store is a daddy job, you can't do it
  •    At dad - no mommy doesn't need to go to work, that's a daddy job
  •    At mom - (crying) dad said no to me, it made me sad
  •    At dad - (after dad said we'd make juice tomorrow, and dad tried to play with RC Car) dad you can play with my toys tomorrow.
  •    At mom - (Zach's preschool teacher is teacher connie) I'm the teacher connie zach
Have a good week and remember - faith is the bird who starts singing before the sun comes up - ZIT

entry.title: Week 132AZ: Canadian Turkey Day
entry.content:
Every year we celebrate Canadian thanksgiving by picking a random day in November and declaring it Canadian thanksgiving. Then we invite all our friends (all of whom are Canadian, married to a Canadian, or otherwise good people) to a cabin in the woods, put one of them in charge of cooking a turkey, and feast for the weekend!
This year thanksgiving had some interesting statistics:

1 1 year old
2 2 year olds
3 pregnant women
4 Canadians
5 bedrooms
6 lbs of sweet potatoes
7 glasses of mulled wine

Since we had lots of kids we setup a bubble machine and had bubble dance party which all the little kids (and many of the big kids) enjoyed greatly. Many pictures to be posted.

In more mundane news, I'm super impressed by Tori who got her and Zach memberships at the YMCA!  Their first night there I picked them up, and it was weird for me to go the YCMA as I'd been a member from the age of 6 through 24, and my dad even spent a few years working for the YMCA.

We were bad circus parents and skipped circus school the last few weeks. This weeks excuse was we needed to pick up Mouse so we could pick up mulch so we could build top soil in our back yard.

I've decided it's time to get disciplined again, and have recovered the juicer from the porch. With Tori going to the Y, we'll have to race to see who can get healthier faster.

Finally, it's now Movemeber, and thus I'm sporting a Mo' for the month. It looks peculiar, but that makes me happy.

Have a good week and remember: "You don't need to be a Bro to wear a Mo" -ZIT

entry.title: When Zach took the keys off Tori's computer
entry.content:
(This picture has nothing to do with the post, but it's adorable, so I'll use it) 
This dialogue doesn't do this conversation justice, but it'll remind us of what it was like when Zach was 2.

Tori discovers Zach has one again ripped all the keys off the computer .

Tori: Zach, you made mommy very sad. Go into time out
Zach: (Crying) .. I don't want to (runs to couch with me)
Tori: You broke it
Zach: You can fix it
Tori: I don't think I can fix it.
Zach: I can fix it.
Tori: You can't fix it
Zach: Daddy can fix it
Tori: Daddy can't fix it.
Zach: runs off for 20 minute
Zach: (Coming back w/Guitar)  - I just came back
Tori: Hello
Zach: I brought guitar, he'll make you not sad
Tori: How will guitar help?
Zach: Guitar will fix computer.
Tori: You should say Sorry
Zach: Sorry

link.title: When Zach took the keys off Tori's computer

entry.title: Happy Halloween - the musical cow
entry.content:
For the first time since we've lived in Seattle, we've had lots of kids for Halloween   We had so many kids we ran out of candy, which is a good thing since if the kids don't eat the candy, we will.

Another first occurred today - Zach put on his Halloween costume. Check out the awesome musical cow videos here.

As usual this wonderful day was brought to you by the Amazing Tori - her awesomeness includes:

1) Putting up a giant spider exhibit on our front porch
2) Making Zach's cow costume
3) Making Zach's dragon suit - which we have yet to get Zach to Wear

Happy Halloween - ZIT

entry.title: Week 131AZ: The leaves they are a changing
entry.content:
Today is a sunny Sunday and we can see the glorious  leaves changing colors as they fall (pun intended). We had to skip circus school this week as we had a double party schedule- first the kids from our birth group and second our neighbors birthday party.

Halloween is almost upon us, and Zach will not put on his costume . We've still got a few days left so there's  hope. Tori made Zach the most cute dragon costume, which Tori and I wear in hopes of making Zach jealous. As I write this I wonder if we should make the neighbor's kid wear the costume in the hopes that will inspire Zach.

In health news, I'm pushing to get to gym, I made 3x3 mile runs last week, and I've got a 6am gym date scheduled (thanks Ammon).  Also, Tori got her and Zach a membership at the YMCA. They had some scheduling snafu's but we've got hope that this week Tori will get to the gym and Zach will go into kiddy corner.

Zach's super skill by  is monologuing. Hell just go up to people and start telling them things, the people usually listen politely for a minute or 2, and are eventually  flabbergassed when they realize Zach won't stop talking.  It's adorable - I wonder if I did that when I was a kid.

Have a good week, and remember - "A drunk person can only be trusted to say they're drunk not that they are sober" - ZIT

link.title: Week 131AZ: The leaves they are a changing

entry.title: Best friend is a hard post to hold
entry.content:
Monday night Zach and I went to REI to play on their tree. There were a bunch of 7 year olds there, and Zach was playing tag and hide an seek with them. While Zach played I heard a little girl, Sally, describe Zach to her Dad:

"There's a little boy in the tree and he's saying stuff I don't understand and then he's pulling out a muska tool, just like on TV"

After we headed home, I asked what his favorite part of Monday's adventure was and he said

"My best friend - Sally"

Seems best friend is a rotating post, and an hour or so of tag and hide and seek is enough to win it.

link.title: Best friend is a hard post to hold

entry.title: Week 130AZ: Mommy is my best friend
entry.content:
When I asked Zach who his best friend is he said "Mommy".  Speaking of cute, Zach and I are on the couch as I write this, he's licking his popsicle leaning on my chest in the crook of my right arm which is wrapped around him and I'm typing. It's a pretty charming photo of the modern family. Luckily Zach has heard about napkins, and he's now asking his mom for one while his popsicle drips on me.


In health news I've pulled my juicer off the porch and I've started to add veggie juice to my diet this weekend. I forgot the many fine gases of juicing - lucky Tori.  I've been running twice this week, next week I'll push up to three, which is exactly what the Igor  ordered.

This weekend was pretty busy, even though circus school was cancelled we still:
  • Bounced at Seattle Gymnastics Academey
  • Ate bacon wrapped dates at Paul's pumpkin carving
  • Picked string beans at Julia's birthday party.
  • Supported civil liberties at a charity pumpkin carving.
The days are getting shorter and the the trees are changing colors.  It's finally getting chilly, and I've bought a fancy new back blinker in hopes of sparking the winter riding bug.

Tori has been burning the midnight oil working on Zach's monster costume, pictures will be provided at Halloween!

On the house front, Tori has finally granted me permission to compost, which really excites me - I'm looking forward to a giant pile of vegetable mulch!

Have a good week and remember - "I don't have to run faster then the bear, just faster then you" -  ZIT.

link.title: Week 130AZ: Mommy is my best friend

entry.title: Week 129AZ: Stealing the coffee cup
entry.content:
I tend to steal Tori's coffee cup, it's a problem I have. You'd reason  it's a problem Tori has - since taking the coffee cup doesn't bother me. But  reason harder-  if Tori has a problem I have a problem, so it's my problem after all.

On Sunday, Zach did a great job at circus school, adding most of the warm up and the silk cocoon to his list of accomplishments. Great job buddy - you don't realize how transitive your success is! After circus school our Neighbor Malcolm came over the play on the swing and eat bratwurst, yummy!

On Saturday we went to an apple pressing at a local co-housing community. This co-housing community is a spiffy  group of 11 families who live in a bunch of town houses and share meals 5 times a week. I think Tori and I might enjoy living in such a community, but we're not ready to sell the house yet.  Anyhoo, we went over for apple cider, but ended up  picking apples, chopping apples, and running an apple press. There is something wonderful feeling about using manual tools, turning the apple press filled me with joy and made me ecstatic to be a live.

On Wednesday night Zach was vomiting through the night, not very fun at all.  When I woke up Tori was talking to the poison control center asking if this could be caused by the AJAX cleaner Zach used as a topping for his dinner. The nice people at poison control explained the small amount Zach might have gotten plus his symptoms meant this was correlation not causation.

On Tuesday, Tori hosted parents night, and my job was to take Zach out and show him a good time till the parents all left at 9:30.  It's hard to find places to take your 2.5 year old on a Tuesday at 9pm, but we made it through successfully.  The last 30 minutes was accomplished with junk food and chocolate milk alone.

On Monday, Zach tried to convince us  his bike helmet no longer fit and that he should ride without a helmet. I figured out what was going on though and said No, your bike helmet is fine, you're fine, and if you want to ride anything you'll need a helmet!

On the health front, I have been sleeping in in the morning, I'm really missing my wake up at 5 am shtick, and need to get it going again. Will try again Monday.

On the house front, Tori has been engaged on our spider themed Halloween decorations,  we've got lights and webs and rumor has it there will even be black lighting when the day comes.

Have a jolly week, and remember - "Ashes to Ashes we all fall down" ZIT

entry.title: Week 128AZ: Sun and Bikes
entry.content:
Zach took his bike to the corner store,  picked up an apple, a bottle of wine and headed home. On the way he stopped to eat his apple and I took this  photo. I have to say, between the bike, the apple, and the wine - that's my kid no doubt about it.

Zach came up with a clever trick for his bike helmet. He started putting on an imaginary bike helmet, instead of a real one. Luckily I'm kind of clever myself and told Zach he can only wear his imaginary bike helmet on his imaginary bike!

Weather in Seattle has been awesome this week (heck this whole year). Today, like the whole week, was sunny and in the 70s.

Today Zach's circus school performance was his best ever!  Not only did Zach do the trapeze and the tumble track, but he didn't even put up a fight during warm up, and during his only trouble spot, the trampoline, he quietly just said he wouldn't do it.

 Zach has been getting back into routine, and that puts him he's in much better spirits, which results in  fewer tantrums.  This is awesome for Tori and me, and I have to agree with Tori routine makes a huge difference.

In house news, the play structure continues to grow. It now has has its mini-climbing wall and cross beams. The only thing left is the awning and clean up work.  The play structure picture shows Tori, Zach, Julia and Noel. Julia and Zach were taking turns pushing the lawn mower down the slide.

Have a good week and remember:  A Bit of Bitter Butter is Bitter, But add some Better Butter and the Butter's Better - ZIT

entry.title: First Bike Ride w/Zach
entry.content: It was pitch black, but fun anyways! Zack has now learned the power of pedaling.

entry.title: Week 127AZ: Rest and Relaxation
entry.content:
This week was all about decompressing, I've been on vacation and taking it easy.  Baba left for home on Wednesday, and Tori and I have been chilling for the last four days.   As usual, we try to keep Zach entertained, so we hit the harvest festival, went to the zoo, saw Mel, tackled circus school, and spent lots of time playing in the backyard.

Since Baba came to visit on an airplane Zach thinks all airplanes go to Baba's house. For example, we were driving home and Zach said "Look - an airplane to Baba's house".

Zach is getting very good at talking these days, and is rather fond of lying to advance his desires.  Some cute examples:

On going to the library when Zach doesn't want to:

Dad: Lets go the Library
Zach: No, It's closed

On getting fruit at the fruit stand when Mom is with us:

Dad: Lets go to the fruit stand.
Zach: Dad buy fruit, mom and zach stay in the car

On going to bed:
Dad: Lets go to beds.
Zach: No, it' scary, I want yogurt, I pooped,etc. 

Everyone say Awwwwwww ....

On the house front, our furnace wouldn't fire up, and the nice folks from the furnace company came out and fixed it. Also, our deck is  rather lacking in support, so Tori has bought some nice 2x4s to keep our deck from falling down.

Next week is back to work, and I'm looking forward to getting back into a nice routine, I suspect Tori feels the same way.


Have a  good week and remember Igor's second rule of women: Shut up and hug - ZIT

entry.title: Why yes, that is a park in my backyard
entry.content:
It's always nice to be wrong, especially when I'm wrong, Tori's right, and Zach's happy as a two year old at a park.

For a while, Tori has wanted to fill our back yard with a giant play set.  Even though she asked me if I was interested, and I said I was, I secretly expected this would be an albatross - filling our backyard, and completely ignored.

The play set is up now, and Zach loves it! He constantly begs to be swung, and loves pushing his lawn mower down the slide (so we're bad parents).   Heck I'll be honest, I love it too, you can even find me on the upper deck meditating, because its' rather peaceful in among the tree trunks.

Awesome foresight and construction Tori, you are truly amazing.

Ps - not only do we have a park in our backyard, but Tori got most of it  for free on FreeCycle!

link.title: Why yes, that is a park in my backyard

entry.title: Week 126AZ: BABA!
entry.content:
This week Baba came to visit and it's awesome to watch her interact with Zach! Zach loves telling Baba stories, and Baba loves hearing them. Zach also loves to boss Baba around, and Baba doesn't seem to mind at all.

Baba's had a chance to experience a day in the life of Zach, going to circus school and pre-school and even going to the toy store (Value Village).  Baba's also gotten to see some of the stuff Zach really looks forward to: the Children's museum, the  Geek festival, the historic train ride, and the model sail boat races.

Zach has been super cute this week. My two highlights are Zach demanding to have Baba pull him around in his red wagon, and making us all hold hands in a circle and dance and sing.  The circle dance is even cuter because after every song zach runs into the hall and presses one of the drawer knobs, and runs back and says "OK, now sing X", where X is one of the five songs he knows.

Tori has been busy as a bee keeping my Mom's trip running smoothly, and building our outside playground (picture next week). A few weeks from now we'll have a park in our back yard, pretty frickin' cool.

On the health front, I'm back in the gym, I lost some ground since August, but I'm dragging my butt to the gym and re-enforcing the habits.

Have a good week, and remember - "It's more fun with a Baba" ZITwB (Zach, Igor,Tori with Baba).

entry.title: Week 125AZ: Potty Training Begins
entry.content:
We've decided it's time to teach Zach to use a potty. We ordered special "get wet" panties, that let Zach know when he's wet himself, and we've got a bag of cheerios on the bathroom sink. So far, Zach just pee's through his "get wet" panties and eats the cheerios, but we suspect progress is imminent.

Zach's Baba comes up this week, and  in anticipation we've upgraded to a new futon. This new futon was quite the adventure, including multiple futon stores, and two trips to Ikea (we forgot to actually measure our futon).

Saturday, the whole family went down to Pirate day, a fun adventure at the mall with stores giving away toys and a scavenger hunt. I'm not sure if Zach understood what was going on, but he liked getting the toys and candy from the merchants. More fun than pirates, Zach got to go on a train ride (sorry I didn't get a picture), which Zach absoloutly loves. Zach may grow up to be a professionsal train passenger. 

Tori believes Zach is addicted to TV, so she brought the TV to the basement, which means that Zach is now super nice to me in the hopes that I'll turn on a Mickey Mouse for him. Tori has an awesome idea of giving Zach a "Popsicle stick currency" for TV shows which he can earn. I love the idea.  Right now Zach is trying to find a stick :) 

Zach started another year of preschools, and caught a cold the first day. His co-op pre-school class has 3 sets of twins, which helps us remember to be grateful. As Zach's now in the 2/3 class he gets to bring his lunch to school, and walk across the street to play on the playground - pretty frickin cool.

Tori has been working on Zach's cow suit for halloween. She's not thrilled with it, but maybe we'll be matching cows this year. The Greek Festival comes up this weekend, as does ciesel the diesel, which means my mom is visiting in time for lots of cool stuff!

Igor's been slacking on his health lately, and really needs to get that going again. So far 2 days in a row in the gym, but diet is still crappy.

Have a good week and remember: No stick,  No TV - ZIT

entry.title: Have a good trip Ash!
entry.content: Here is a short  photo blog of Ash, you'll be missed buddy.

entry.title: Week 124AZ: Memorizing all the books
entry.content:
Every night before bed, I read Zach bed time stories, it's an interactive experience where I ask Zach questions and he gets them right.  Lately I started pausing and letting him fill in words like an intense No - he had no troubles. Then, I wondered just how well he knew the stories, and I let him fill in a random word per sentence. Turns out, he can do that too. Looks like Zach is basically memorizing all of his bed time stories - pretty frickin cool.

This week we had a block party, which is fun since that lets the oodles of neighborhood girls drool all over Zach.  During the block party, instead of looking for Zach I just looked for a herd of girls, and Zach was almost always in the middle.   At one point, I could find neither girls nor Zach and got a bit worried. Luckily Zach had just brought the girls inside for a home tour. Turns out Zach was telling the girls all about our colorful staircase and wonderful basement.

Zach had a busy week, he rode the train, went to the science center, explored the children's museum, tried drop in daycare, went to gymnastics, and even went to a zoo - who'd have thought my kid would have such a busy schedule.

On the house, Tori's getting the basement ready for Mom. Lots of junk moved out, new futon mattress being hunted for.  We also got an oak dining room table to replace my plastic Walmart folding table. I'm surprised how much I like having a wood table - who'd have thunk it.

Speaking of Tori, she also completed her co-op preschool duties of loading the equipment into the preschool. If you're looking for good jobs in the co-op preschool circuit- load in seems like one of the easiest.

Finally, today was the last day of Zach's circus school (we're signed up again for fall quarter).  Zach started the class with "I can't do that/I'm too busy" for most of the activities, but he had his strongest finish ever, sitting in the cocoon of aerial silk, and bouncing like a professional gymnast down the tumble track! Zach  - when you're reading this, we're super proud of you and if you think you can't do something, you probably just need to try again.

Enjoy your week and remember: "Tomorrow's battle is won during today's practice." - ZIT

entry.title: Week 123AZ:Squawk
entry.content:
This was a long week (heck, long month), and I've  been really busy at work.  As such, I  haven't been getting my Tori and Zach hours in. Thankfully, this weekend, we've been spending lots of time together, which really makes my day.

We put down our little grey cat Ash on Monday. Zach was there and sang Ash to sleep with "Puff the magic dragon".  Ash has been sick for a while, and he was starting to suffer last Sunday so it was time.  Ash was a wonderful cat  always sitting on us, often sitting on Zach's head. You'll be missed little buddy.

On Thursday a fledgling crow show'd up begging for food, and we've named him Squawk.  Let me elaborate, begging for food means flying a few feet near  you and squawking continuously. If you ignore Squawk he'll hop up closer, or even land on your shoulder and squawk in your ear. We tried putting out bowls of cat food and crackers and nuts, and pretty much everything we thought he'd eat, but Squawk didn't seem to know how to eat it.  By Saturday Squawk's begging was getting really aggressive. He'd land directly on  us, and I gave in and started hand feeding him cat food. Hand feeding means dropping food down Squawk's throat, with Squawk's  beak closing on my finger. After I got a few pellets of cat food in, Squawk stopped squawking  and just hung out on our porch. By Sunday, Squawk was getting thinner and looking worse so we took him to the animal rescue people, hopefully Squawk can be rehabilitated and sent back to the wild.

In non-animal news Zach went to the fair this week where he got to ride his first roller coaster, and spend oodles of time on tractors.

This weekend, Zach has been a rather moody two year old. Our first trip to the zoo was aborted as Zach just wanted to play in the playground. Our second trip to the zoo was more successful, with us running madly around the zoo chasing Zach. We got Zach Zach to the elephant show 10 minutes early so Zach used this time to take "fake" tickets from people.  Everyone including us thought it was adorable, until Zach fell off the bleachers and bled a little.  Luckily Zach was OKand we got to watch the rest of the elephant show.

In Igor's world - work has been busy, but I realize working more hours does not make things better. I need to work smarter, and that means keeping my hours under control, being realistic about what I can accomplish, and spending time re-charging  with my family.  I've also been very slack on diet exercise and need to get back on that horse.

In Tori land,  Tori took Zach to a drop in daycare, which she didn't super enjoy, but she'll give it another try. In another month Zach will be 2 and a half which means a bunch of new care options open up, which will be great for all of us.

In home improvement land,  Tori is sanding like a bunny on her new wall. It's her first drywall project, and I think it looks great.  Not to be accused of single tasking, Tori is also painting our basement blue in preparation for project "Baba Visiting".

Anywhoo - Have a good week and remember: "Manage your energy not your time" - ZIT

entry.title: Week 122AZ: The Maureen and Brian come to Town
entry.content:
(Short post for this week - I'll update with pictures, and do something better this weekend) 

Maureen and Brian of Ranch fame came to town with their dogs Lilly and Cochise. They're camping out in our backyard and it's almost as much fun to have them here as it is to go to their place. Since they were here we used the third row seats in the RAV4 and were able to ram 4 adults, 2 dogs and 1 Zach into our car for our many journeys! I can't articulate why stuffing many people into a car makes me happy, maybe it's my circus tendencies, but it does!

Brian and Maureen are a great influence, they installed our dryer vent, reminded us to eat salad for dinner, and even taught me how to get the cruise control to work in the car.

On the funny side,  Maureen and Brian were playing with Zach's playdo and a few hours later their dog started pooping blue.

Anyhoo - have a good week and remember: Behind every great man is a great woman - ZIT

link.title: Week 122AZ: The Maureen and Brian come to Town

entry.title: Week 121AZ: Awesome Circus School and Street Canoing
entry.content:
Zach has been going to circus school for 8 weeks now, and this week was the first time he did the entire class without calling out he wanted to go home or be picked up! This is huge progress, usually Zach wants to leave right away, or cries to be picked up as soon as we start doing any exercises! Great Job Zach we're totally proud of you.


Saturday we went blueberry picking and went for a nice family walk. In both cases Zach was a bit grumpy until we found other kids, and then he was a pleasure.

Sunday we went for our first family canoe ride.  Even though from looking at this weeks picture you may conclude we were simply sailing the street, we did get into the water, where I'm pleased to say Zach stayed happily in the boat for 45 minutes. Better Zach sat could sit quietly in the middle of the boat when Tori wanted some breathing room in the front.

On the house front,  Tori got the back yard cleared out  (surprising and picture worthy), started painting walls in the basement (we had a spot of mildew) and has put up her first drywall wall (looking fine).  It's pretty handy being pseudo-married to a women more useful than a general contractor.

On the Igor's work front, things started good last week, but kind of went crazy at the end - this will be a very busy week for me.

On the cat front, Ash, the little grey cat, is having some health troubles, he has been losing weight, and we've got him on a special non-chicken diet (which is surprisingly hard given cat food always contains chicken).  Even though we think Ash is a bit sick, he is still out catching rats, so far the rat toll is two in the last two days.

On the Zach front, Zach went to his first drop in daycare, but sadly they were actually full that day so Tori and Zach just played there for a bit as Zach acclimatized to the space. In other Zach news, Tori has started explaining consequences to Zach - currently the TV is in time out. Finally - I'm rather proud I've started reading Zach bed time stories, this week I'm 6 for 7 nights of bed time stories.

Enjoy your week, and reflect: 
Anxiety is just practice worrying - ZIT

link.title: Week 121AZ: Awesome Circus School and Street Canoing

entry.title: My favorite time of year and the funniest thing Zach said to me
entry.content:
I was telling Tori how much I enjoy my 30's as I'm starting to understand what I like - for example early august is my favorite time of year. It's hot out, and the days are long enough but not too long. While I was rather proud of my new found discovery, Tori assures me I've been saying this every year around this time:)  Any who - Zach and I were out Kayaking yesterday and we had the following conversation:

Igor - "Zach, look at the baby ducks"
Zach - "No Way Jose"
Igor - "Zach look at the ducks, they are super cute"
Zach  - "I'm busy" 
Igor - "Zach, just look at ducks"
Zach - "I'm busy working on the house"
Igor - "Sigh"

link.title: My favorite time of year and the funniest thing Zach said to me

entry.title: Week 120AZ: Camel Rides
entry.content:
(maybe I'll re-write this week's post to flow better as well - but probably not)

This weekend we went to renaissance fair, and Zach got to ride a camel - not only did Zach enjoy riding the camel, but he enjoyed feeding the camel too - who would have guessed!  In case you're wondering, we didn't come in costume, but we'll plan better for next year.

Thanks to the wonder of babysitting, Tori and I had our first date in a very long time. We were a bit out of practice, but I look forward to more opportunities to hone my craft. I'll have to re-remember my hard fought skills,  for example the emergency joke.

Sadly, our nanny has retired, so we're looking for a new care solution - if you're local feel free to suggest some. Tori's checking out a nice daycare 2 miles from our house on Monday - fingers crossed!

Now for the reason everyone reads these lets talk about Zach:

Zach's personality is really emerging, he loves talking to people, often telling them about the purple people in the purple rocket.  While Zach enjoy's intellecualizing, he's not really into " taking action", this is a state I can get into, which I need to be careful to avoid.

Last week I told you about Zach's desire to kiss things better, this week Zach's been using his other medical skill - the hammer. He has several hammers and he often bangs on things while saying "Fix It".

Zach has added some brilliance to this vocabulary like:
1) Mommy Daddy Stop Singing
2) Daddy get out of Zach's bed, I want to sleep
3) No way Jose
4) I'm too busy for a car ride.

On the cute and amazing side, I've started reading Zach bedtime stories every night, and I was flabergassed when Zach had already memorized the words to the book I still fumbled while reading.

Remember “Aerodynamically, the bumble bee shouldn't be able to fly, but the bumble bee doesn't know it so it goes on flying anyway.”  - ZIT

entry.title: Week 119AZ: Zach and Jonah
entry.content:
We finished the week with an amazing joy, we got to watch our good friend . This was our first 5 hours with 2 2 year old  experience, and it was a riot. Zach and Jonah were  playing together, having a blast, and hopefully learning from each other. We'll do this again.


My favorite moments of the Jonah adventure were:

  1. Jonah playing air guitar on a broom 
  2. When Jonah stubbed his toe, Zach demanded to, and then proceeded to kiss it better. I don't know how Zach's kiss ranks against the ranks of Mom's everywhere but Jonah and Zach were happy. 
  3. A conversation at the park with another dad who just finished screaming "Gentle with the little ones" after their son was running fast around Zach. "It's OK, I believe in survival of the fittest" I said, but then thinking twice I added "but then again, my kid is bleeding from the back of the head". Nothing to be worried about, Zach just bashed his head when he fell backward, not much blood, just a big goose egg. 

On the weather front, for the first time in 2 years, it has crossed 90 degrees (30C) in Seattle. I remember as a kid my parents sleeping downstairs when it was hot, and me not caring. Well last night I slept on the basement floor, and Zach was fine in his room - the great circle of life continues.


Speaking of basement floors, I've found a cheap source of foam tile (thank you K-Mart) and covered a quarter of the basement floor with them. Tori isn't a huge fan, but it's cheap per square foot, and keeps a layer of insulation between me and the floor.

This week at  circus school, Zach was his bravest yet - he was doing airplanes and trapeze, and pushing balls. Tori is doing an awesome job making him enjoy circus school.

Saturday Zach and I went kayaking through the arboretum - it was great in that I was able to solo load him, and we stayed out for almost 15 minutes. Now that I can solo load, I think we'll also try kayaking greenlake. Next, I have to convince my friends to get their own (preferably inflatable) watercraft so we can make this a group activity.

On Friday Zach and Julia went to play in the wading pools, Tori tells me Julia almost taught Zach to swim, but sadly this was not recorded on video.

Earlier in the week is a bit of blur, but we started the week on Guamez Island.

Enjoy your week and remember:
Little strokes fell great oaks - ZIT

entry.title: Week 118AZ: Hello From Guemes!
entry.content:
This long weekend (Saturday - Tuesday) we took a vacation at Guemes Island Resort. Guemes is a crabbing resort,  but we didn't have the desire to catch crabs so we went kayaking, beach walking and saunaing instead.

A cool thing about this resort is that many families come back year after year, which means every conversation at the communal fire pit starts with "So how many years have you been coming here",  it makes you want to book your return trip, but we haven't yet.

Guemes is a cool underdeveloped island, it has exactly 2 stores and access is by unmarked ferry terminal. If someone hasn't told you about the Guemes Ferry you can't find it, as it's at the end of a residential street.

During our trip, Zach learned a few things - for example boat safety. If you ask Zach what you need to go kayaking he'll say - "Life Jacket", which Tori and I are rather proud of.

Zach also learned that you should cook cilantro. I'm not sure who he learned this from, but he constantly was taking the cilantro out of the fridge and putting it into the oven. Luckily Zach hasn't learned to turn the oven on yet.

Zach's final learning was when someone scores at fooseball you should scream at the top of your lungs, I'm not sure where he learned this from, but it's awfully cute, and as usual in such situation I say awwwwwww.

Before we left Tori got some work done around the house, we now have door knobs on our french doors, and some day cares scoped out - I can't wait till we land the daycare!

On the Igor side, work's been busy with a big project landing shortly.  The project was going out of control for a bit, but last week the project had some breakthroughs so I'm feeling much less stressed - we'll see how it looks post vacation :)

By the way - Zach is currently very fond of trains and is  running around the  house with his magnetic trains going chacka-chacka-choo-choo. And, Zach is just now learning about breaking things and consequences. Zach just said:

Uh-oh ... broken ... Zach timeout. 

Before I discover what that's about, let me leave you with this valuable nugget of wisdom:

Giant 90 calorie marshmallows should not be bought as trying to eat them will make you sick from sugar overload - don't buy them, and if you do buy them give them away.

Happy Week - ZIT

entry.title: Week 117AZ: Hello from the rainbow staircase
entry.content:
Tori has completed her rainbow stair case vision, and Zach and I love it.  The only thing cooler than that art installation that inspires you, is having that art installation be your home.   The stairs are even cooler then they look in the photo as the upstairs landing has another 4 colored walls, and a hanging chair.  To top off the exhibit, when the sun sets several of the walls in the landing actually glow in the sunset. AWESOME JOB TORI!

As well as finishing the stairs, Tori transferred 750lbs of trash to the dump. I have no idea what that 750lbs of trash was, but I can now see most of the shed floor, and the basement is starting to take shape as a large open  space. 

On top of  being adorable, Zach has picked up some new skills this week including:


  • Realizing things are scary.
  • Putting on his own shirt.
  • Requesting specific episodes of curious George.
  • Sleeping in his own bedroom.

Work is getting busy for Igor, luckily he's already aware of the importance of sustainable balance, and has been practicing habits to keep his work and home life in said balance.

I should mention I'm typing this from the parents pit at circus at school. Zach and Tori are in the training tent, but Zach is rather shy and not quite into the activities. 

Enjoy your week and remember: “My friend, love is a verb. Love -- the feeling -- is a fruit of love -- the verb. So love her. Sacrifice. Listen to her. Empathize. Appreciate. Affirm her. Are you willing to do that?” - Stephen Covey

link.title: Week 117AZ: Hello from the rainbow staircase

entry.title: Week 116AZ: Tori shows how it's done
entry.content:
This week saw the french doors properly hung and the storage unit emptied. On top of that, Zach's got a bed in his room, and even spent the night in it on Friday!  Take a bow my dear partner Tori you deserve it! 

Tori took Zach to see Thomas the train, which he very much enjoyed - as I got home Zach spent all night telling me how he's going back to see Thomas at Halloween - I'm looking forward to it.


Zach is becoming so comprehensible it's like talking to a person.  Most people can now understand him about as well as I can,  which is really cool.   When you're kid is younger you can't imagine talking to them, but now I totally can! I often give Zach alternatives like:

  •    Would you rather daddy take you out of the car, or stay in the car while daddy goes shopping. 
  •    Would you like to lie in your bed and get a chocolate, or not get a chocolate (don't tell Tori).

Tori is has started a diet, and I'll join her on this health kick.  You know what they say: the family that health kicks together, avoids heart disease together, and that's awfully important, once you've spawned.

Zach says happy week from the home depot rental digger!

link.title: Week 116AZ: Tori shows how it's done

entry.title: Summer Nights 1: Ben/Sam/Ice Cream/Head Gash
entry.content:
You get a new enjoyment of summer when you have kids. Zach and I hung out with Paul and his kids (the famous Ben and Sam)  and we all had a riot.  Sure it was fun and games till Zach bashed his head in a water fountain, but I was nearby, and ice cream fixed it.

The real pleasure is captured in the movies. My favorites include Sam's I'm too sexy dance, and the touch down with Ben video.   Nothing is sweater then Ben and Sam being really gentle and inclusive with Zach, it's real testament to their parents - nice work guys.

The accordion in the background is some dude practicing ( maybe he was busking, but no one paid),  it really set the mood for the evening.

entry.title: Zach's First Kayak Ride
entry.content:
Today Zach went on his first Kayak ride. It was short, and went quite well. Initially, Zach was pretty scared so he was still as a mouse, but then  he got his courage and decided he should be in charge of paddling. This was a bit of a problem, but luckily I still weigh  6 times as much as Zach and can over power him in a pinch.

After the ride we played in the montlake community center, watching a family shoot a model rocket in the air. That was super cool, until the rocket got stuck in a tree. Lost rockets make Zach  very sad.

For the rest of the day Zach would run around telling everyone that would listen to him that he went for a Kayak Ride, and then the purple rocket went in the air and got stuck in a tree. Most people thought they didn't understand him properly - but I dutifylly explained "nope, you got it, we just had a big fun day".

Zach is strong, that cart we used to lug the kayak is heavy, you can see a video of him pulling it here and here.

I know there really isn't enough content to justify two pictures but I've got a cute kid and I'm proud of it. If you want to see the rest of the pictures from our adventure they are here.

entry.title: Week 115AZ: Summer is here
entry.content:
Summer has arrived in Seattle.  For the 4th of July we got a chance to see some backyard  fireworks, where Zach spent the entire event in my lap (Tori's rules) screaming "Mo, FiWook".  Zach is turning into a commentator - he loves sitting on the sideline calling the shots (it''s possibly he's giving orders, we'll know in a few weeks no doubt)


With summer here Zach's back into the water parks, and we both love it.  You can see Zach walking in one of our local parks, and doing is super cute "Vroom Vroom" here. 

This week's first picture shows Zach crashed out after a hard day of partying - It reminds me of my days of drunken stupers.  The week's second picture shows Zach usurping my ice cream (video).

Zach has also started drumming on pretty much everything. Like everything else he does it's crazy cute, and while it happens we just stand around gawking "Awww".

On the house front, hallway rainbow is complete (video to be inserted here). Re-re-re-hanging the french doors, is Tori's next task - we now own an 8 foot level,  which Tori swears (in both senses of the word) is the problem. 

Sadly, Tori has the allergies - they're clogging up her ears and making her head explode. Tori says she's now interested in juicing, maybe the juice fairy will take her allergies away, just like the juice fairy took my allergies away.

As you enjoy your week remember "Time flies like an arrow, but fruit flies like bananas"

entry.title: Week 114AZ: Choocka Chooka Choo Choo
entry.content:
Tori and I are  blessed to watch Zach grow developmentally. This week we were thrilled to watch  Zach driving trains while saying Chaka Chaka Choo Choo  and to watch Zach stopping and sit everywhere (like the sidewalk in the middle of downtown) and turn an imaginary steering wheel while yelling "Vroom" "Vroom".


Last weekend after we wrote the Zach post, we borrowed  a friend's hiking pack and took Zach and frog on a neighborhood hike (lower picture). This was a grand adventure as we finally met the other neighborhood orange cat (not mooch - details pending if interested).


This week we got a lot of family time in the evenings, I enjoyed immensely. One night we went to Alki in west seattle  (upper picture) and one night we stayed home and played trains.

This weekend we were supposed to go camping, but bailed as we thought the weather wasn't good enough for Zach's virgin camping trip. Instead, Saturday Zach and I went on bus adventures while Tori was painting. Sunday,  we'll go off to Circus school, and then we'll  ride Bike Sunday, where the street will be closed off for our journey to Seward park, which Zach will enjoy muchly. 

On the child care front our baby sitters have vanished and our nanny is fading into non-existence, while the nanny still comes 2 or 3 days a week, it feels like the family photo from back to the future, where every time you look it's more faded.  Tori is investigating alternatives.

On the house front, Tori has started "Hallway Rainbow" which is going slower then expected as our painter didn't actually prime everything we thought he had. Pictures will be provided once the rainbow appears.

May your journey leave a smile on your face and a sweet memory in your sunset years.

entry.title: Jump Jump Jump
entry.content:
Jump Jump Jump, a photo by idvorkin on Flickr.

Sometimes Dad's can still teach the kids how to play!

entry.title: Week 113AZ: Birthday Season Pride
entry.content:
Every week seems to be a birthday party and I love it. I'm  using a picture from last week's birthday party in which Zach is taking  Tori for a drive in a car that hasn't moved for a while (Seattle Play Garden for the locals   ).

After this weeks birthday party we went to the Seattle gymnastics academy where Zach and I got to do some serious jumping.  In the spirit of gymnastics Tori signed Zach up for Circus school,  which starts tomorrow. I always wanted to go to clown college, now I can do it vicariously through Zach.

In case I never mentioned it Zach's middle name,Marshall, came from  Justice Marshall, which I constantly confuse with the other Justice Marshall who has a local school named after him.

Tori will be striking (aka:tearing down) her play till the wee hours of the night tonight - so wish her well and dream happy coffee thoughts. To give Tori a break, I took Zach out of the house and it turns out he wasn't wearing pants. As magic would have it we ended up in the middle of capitol hill in pride weekend, where being happy and scantily clad was the way to go!  Sadly, I didn't bring my camera else we'd have great pictures of Zach among the chapless. 


In good news, our MIA Nanny (some adventure with her family) is coming back on Monday - which we're all looking forward too.  On the house front, all our interior doors are now hung and door knobbed. Tori tells me trim is coming next and then paint and then a dining room table - can you say baby-party-o-rama?

entry.title: Week 112AZ: Zach's first Solstice Parade
entry.content:
I'm a huge fan of the fremont solstice parade  (life goal: put a float into the parade). This week Zach and I partook, and after sitting on the sidelines as spectators - I decided we should participate by being run over by the giant beach ball ( a 10 ft diameter beach ball which is continuously flattening the crowds).  Sadly when I lied down in the street with the beach ball approaching Zach was not pleased and would have none of it.   Once I'd tasted participation, I couldn't help myself and Zach and I walked in the parade!  It was awesome, I have circus monkey in the blood, and I need to encourage the same gene in Zach.

As we were busing home from the solstice parade, Zach was being extremely independent. Zach demanded that I not sit beside him on the bus.   This is normally reasonable, except Zach was so tired his eyes were drooping and he was completely falling over on the bench- just before he fell out of his seat, I was able to snuggle up beside him, and have him sleep on me - talk about a fatherhood high!

From this blog, you'd think Zach only gets to do cool things with Dad, but Mom does far cooler stuff. For example,  Tori took Zach to a cool farm that had trains and electric cars for the kids to ride. Zach and his pal Julia had to work together to drive the electric car - Zach turning the wheel while Julia pushed the pedals.  Sadly  no awesome videos were produced since the support crew of  Tori and Noel (Julia's mom) were frantically chasing the electric car ensuring no innocent people would get damaged.

Week over week, Zach continues to develop. His words are getting easier to understand, and his  reasoning is getting stronger, I got home on Thursday, and we had the following conversation


Have a good week!

entry.title: Week 111AZ: Kiss it better
entry.content:
This week we'll start with three funnies:

One) While we were downtown Zach was swinging a stick like a Kung Fu master, I said
   "Zach! Stop before you hurt someone"
Zach replied
  "It's OK -  I'll kiss it better".

Two) I said Zach, lets go to the bar, and Zach's eyes lit um and he said "Yeah! Uncle Dave". Sorry Dave, we need to spend more time in the park ;)

Three) Zach has a large scab under his bangs which I noticed and was poking at. Zach looked at me and said "It's OK mommy kissed it better".

When I'm in suburbs marveling at peoples larger houses or wooded lots I ask myself why in the heck do I live in the city?  This weekend  I remembered, and I'm writing it down so I don't forget again:

1) Public Transportation and Friendly  People On Friday, Zach and I did our normal bus to downtown, train to airport routine.   We got to downtown early so I thought we would wander into pike place market. As we wandered, Zach was irate since he wanted a train ride, but I tried to convince him Pike Place Market would be cooler.  As we walked some nice people were trying to convince Zach that he'd enjoy the market, and were asking me where I was from and where we were going to go on the train. "We live in Seattle", I replied, we just take the light rail to the airport  instead of going to a movie I answered.

2) Urban Bike Paths On Saturday, we did a 5 hour ride through the city.
