If you haven't ridden in Seattle for a while, there is now  a decent connection between Fremont and Magnolia via the ship canal trail -  (Yippeeee!).  During our ride we had a few cool adventures, first we ran into some friends (Hi Logan and Melinda) walking down the Burke, Zach was too shy to play but nothing makes me happier than running into people I know while being out and about.

3) Fun Stuff To do  After seeing our friends, we kept biking till  it was time for lunch. At lunch we grabbed some apples at the Pike place market and ate them sitting at the cool art installation infused benches downtown. It's fun watching the tourists interact with the blue trees and the metallic people. After lunch we headed to the space noodle (That's what Zach calls the space needle) for a quick loop, and then for the grand finally we hit up the center for wooden boats for pond sailing races.  Sailing races are done with model sail boats (great idea Tori) and Zach loved it.

4) Friends in Hands Reach Tuesday night Tori and I walked around the block to chill with our friends Malcolm, Misty and John who have chickens living in their basement. What could be cooler?

entry.title: Week 110AZ: Life's a beach
entry.content:
In theater there is a saying: Every Play Opens and Every Play Closes.

Tori's play opened, and Igor got through a 4 day x 12 hour work  week too.   Now we're back to our regularly scheduled programming and very much looking forward to it.

Earlier this week Tori took Zach to his new pre-school - Fox in the Forrest. It's a cool forest based pre-school run by a lady named Ms. Fox.  Zach when you grow up name a  a business  Zach in the Zarengeti or Dvorkin in the Dumpster.  On second thought, you better be in charge of picking your own business name. Ah heck, I'l be glad if you read this before you're 25.

Sunday we took Zach to golden gardens, a nice sand beach, and as I sat there listening to the waves crash, and making mud paddies with Zach I thought - huh I'm a dad now, whaddya know (I can hear Tori  rolling her  eyes, but it's true - that what I felt).

We just got back from the park were Zach was almost interacting with some twin girls his age. It was really cute, after a few unsuccessful hellos one of the girls was petting Zach, a few minutes later all 3 of them were doing loops down the slide.

Living Lucky Lives
ZIT

entry.title: Week 109AZ: Did he really read that?
entry.content:
This weekend Tori's play is in Tech (aka: Crazy Busy High Stress Time)  so she is slammed. The whole family (Tori included) look forward to Tori getting sleep and time to her self now that the play is wrapped up.

This weekend was also Folk life, a large fun hippy festival at the Seattle Center. Zach and I went and I found it very energizing. While Zach enjoyed himself,  he had the most fun when we left the festival and went up and down an escalator for half an hour (possibly the whole hour).

The coolest moment of folk life for me came on the bus ride home. The bus had an LCD sign showing the next stop. When the next stop became BELL Zach called out B-E-L-L.  I'm not sure if I made it up, or prompted Zach, or it was a random coincidence,  but I'll call that moment Zach's first reading! Great Job Zach - I knew the hours watching Super Why! would pay off.

Three random cute stories from this weekend:

First,  I was sitting around watching TV and Zach kept saying "Pickle Pickle". I ignored Zach so Zach ran to the fridge and get outs a jar of wickles, and brought them to me, again saying "Pickle, Pickle" until I opened the jar and gave him some Pickes.

Second, and significantly later Zach  was sitting around watching his tv show on his picnic table.  Zach realized his picnic table was too close to the TV so Zach  dragged his picnic table back saying " beep beep beep" the whole time he was backing up.

Third, and not involving watching TV, Zach Tori and I were walking in the arboretum.  Suddenly Zach grabbed a stick and started running up to lots of different plants. I was a bit confused, but Tori realized what was going on - Zach was watering all the plants in the arboretum.

Finally, let me leave you with a sound of fatherhood. This is the sound of me putting Zach down for a Nap.

link.title: Week 109AZ: Did he really read that?

entry.title: Week 108AZ: Birthday; Nap; Party; Sleep; Park; Birthday; Nap; Play; Sleep
entry.content:
I dunno how Tori gets through the week, just the weekend can over exert me. This weekend we had a busier than most weekend which I'll use as my excuse for a crappy blog post

Saturday:
  Birthday
  Nap
  Party
  Sleep
Sunday:
  Park (aka Tree at REI)
  Birthday
  Nap
  Play
  Sleep

To top it off, Tori is trying to get an essay done for English, and trying to get a play done which is about to get super busy. At the same time  I'm trying to get done some big papers at work and get ready for review season.

Tori complains I never cut the grass, but I think I've got proof to the contrary!  In this week's photo you see Zach cutting the grass,. While Zach may have seen someone other than Igor cutting grass,  I highly doubt he saw someone other than Igor cutting grass without pants. Good "Monkey See Monkey Do" Zach - teach your kid the same and we'll keep the Dvorkin male line a going!


Happy week and remember not to feed the mind monsters.

link.title: Week 108AZ: Birthday; Nap; Party; Sleep; Park; Birthday; Nap; Play; Sleep

entry.title: What I want to do when I'm old
entry.content: I'd be OK pulling Tori too :)

link.title: What I want to do when I'm old

entry.title: Zach and the harmonica
entry.content:
Zach and the harmonica a video by idvorkin on Flickr.

Few people find this video as entertaining as I do. I'm super proud and happy to see my boy playing harmonica and talking. When you read this Zach (even if your Daddy never learned how) play an instrument, it will bring you great happiness and joy.

entry.title: Week 107AZ: Teaching
entry.content:
(This weeks picture shows Zach going for a drive at the grocery store.  Like many morning commuters he likes to pick up a bagel for the journey)


Zach goes to a co-op preschool where parents attend along with their kids. All the parents got to provide a one sentence description about all the other  kids. Here is the  description of Zach the preschool teacher assembled from the other parent's description:

Zach is hands on, playful and full of energy … he equals fun and is always on a mission … .Zach is our highest jumper .. He covers more ground in class than any other kid. You can tell he's happy to be at school … He has such big hugs and so much love in him …  … he just knows if he worked a little harder he could actually get into teachers Connie's cabiniet.  One day in class kids were taking turns playing with a box full of  blocks and toys in the room. When Zach came up, he picked up the box and turned the entire box over and smiled triumphantly!  Similarly, the other kids who were watching were delighted at his action and the resulting loud noise … The way Zach gives out hugs to others is so indicative of this sweet heart .. Good natured, friendly, fun … Our budding chef … He may seem like a tough little guy at times, but I have seen him give the biggest hugs…  He is bound for greatness and will lead the masses in some new realm … ( Like his father in his being first to wear the individual toe booty shoes)

Tori taught Zach how to count to 10,  and it was really cute I was walking him somewhere counting to 10 myself when Zach cried out "Daddy Counting!" I was totally proud!

Speaking of teaching, you'd imagine the fact t that every  few  minutes I run off to pee (on just about anything anywhere) would be sufficient  potty training for Zach, but it turns out Tori doesn't think so.
A few days ago I got home from work, and poked my head into the bathroom to see:  Zach, stark naked, standing on a stool  facing the toilet. Tori and Gena (our Nanny) were huddled around Zach with big smiles and encouraging words - trying  to get Zach to pee.  I saw this, shook my head, and kept going.

In hind sight I should have said everyone but Zach out, and given a live demonstration - I'll know better next time.  A few days after this,  Zach went to Toys'r'us to buy his own potty.  So far the only person to use this new fancy dancy 3 in 1 super duper talking  potty is Polar Bear, but you need to start somewhere I guess.

Not to be outdone by our teaching, Zach is teaching himself independence. Two days ago, I tried to put Zack to bed while Tori was at home downstairs. I  put Zach in bed, and lied down, closing my eyes to set a good example. One minute later  Zach shouted BYE! and jumped out of bed and went back downstairs to find Tori -  Smart Cookie.

Zach is also teaching himself  creativity.  This morning Zach was running around with a paper towel roll yelling "Trunk".  I was a bit confused until I realized that Zach was being an elephant, and the paper towel roll was his trunk!

In case you think we're making this teaching stuff up, here's a video of me teaching Zach to pedal, and a video of Tori teaching Zach how to throw a temper tantrum.

entry.title: Week 106AZ: No Daddy No
entry.content:
Public service announcement: This blog is a story about us, which is a story about you.  Add your part of the story! Every time I read Baltasar's comments milk shoots out my nose and I laugh hysterically.   Join  the story,add comments  ...  and now back to our scheduled programming. 

 "No Daddy No" is starting to feel like Zach's favorite word. For example, Zach loves diggers, and when we went to the park, he was playing with the one in the picture.   Zach isn't big enough to sit in the seat and operate the digger arms, so I tried to help him. Instead of taking my help,  Zach screamed "No Daddy No", pushed me off, and stopped playing with it.

At this same  playground Zach scared the poop out of me when he climbed a ladder (second try video here). At first I was freaked out and then I realized that Zach is going to do this, I need to encourage him,  support him, and help kiss his booboo's when he falls so he gets up and tries again.

Fatherhood isn't all bad and scary. Zach and I were playing catch ( Zach doesn't have twitch reflexes yet, so if you throw a ball at him it just hits him but that's another blog post), he really digged it as did I. Who'd have thunk I'd look forward to playing catch with my son.

On the talking and memory front, Zach now easily names our friends "Uncle Dave" and "Ammon", and after 6 months of Dave saying "Booger", Zach will finally say it as well! Zach has also decide he loves, and thus often requests, car rides, bus rides, bike rides and sitting in his car seat.  



Namaste!

entry.title: Week 105AZ: Daddy Tea; Mommy Coffee; Zachy Coco
entry.content:
Daddy Tea,  Mommy Coffee,  Zachy Coco - said Zach as our family enjoyed our morning beverages.  On another morning Zach ran to Mom, got a hard boiled egg,  then ran to the couch, and yelled at me to turn on Pocoyo (a kids TV show).  Next, Zach sat on the floor, leaning back against the couch. Then, while watching TV, Zach cracked open his hard boiled egg on the floor, and had breakfast watching TV.

A big shout out to Ammon and Elise for making Zach the awesome school bus cake. You guys are great friends - thanks! Funny story on the cake, the cake came in the evening, and Zach got a piece before bed. That night, Tori told me I needed to take the cake to work otherwise we'd just end up eating it.  I took the cake to work before Zach woke up and apparently Zach was very angry that the cake was gone in the morning.

Zach's new favorite phrase is "No Daddy", which I normally respond to with some in appropriate tickling.  Zach's other favorite word is Mamma Digger, Baby Digger, which refers to the tractors which are doing construction at the park near our house.  Zach loves tractors, sometimes we go to Home Depot just play on their rental tractors. 

For those  that like metrics Zach saw the doc, and is now 32" by 29lbs - yippy!

Tori's play is shaping up and that's a mask she  made for it in the picture.  Zach got to see his first play rehearsal and got his first trip to the leather store.  

Dad's  been doing some work on his  bike, after 3 years of procrastination I finally got a seat post that was long enough for me. It took about 30 minutes (including walking to the bike shop, stopping at the library with Zach, and finding a mallet (don't ask) ).


Happy Week!

entry.title: Thanks for all the Cake
entry.content:
IMG_3172, a photo by idvorkin on Flickr.

Uncle Ammon and Aunt Elise made Zach a big yellow school bus chocolate cake. For which Mr. Dvorkin and Master Dvorkin are most grateful. Thanks for the all the cake!

entry.title: Week 104AZ: Wickles
entry.content:
This week I give up on paragraphs and use questions with lists for answers instead.  We'll see if it lasts.

What did I discover Zach interacting with this week?

  1. Wickles  - Wickles are the greatest hot sweet pickle known to man.  Zach loves them, and even though his face wrinkles a bit when he eats (they are spicy) he still demands more.
  2. The word "more" - Zach has now mastered the word more, in both adjective and adverb form.
    1. More Pickles
    2. More Milk
    3. More Park (really he means more playing at the park - so it's an adverb)
  3. Compound Thought -   I had the following conversation yesterday:
    • Daddy
      •   - Lets go to work to get Daddy's Bike
    • Zach - Daddy's work
    • Daddy - What's at Daddy's work?
    • Zach - Daddy's Blue Bike.

What am I most grateful for since we've had Zach?
  1. Unlocking children - Before Zach, I just ignored children, now I can speak "parent" and take infinite pleasure even from watching kids being upset. (Zach, this won't make sense till you have Kids).
  1. Real Change -  After 30 years, my life was pretty much in a rut. Nothing new, maybe I'd be on some silly bender like trying every coffee or wine in the city.  Now that I have Zach, every day there is something new, and that makes life thrilling.
  1. Zach's relentless Happiness -  "So/So" isn't in Zach's vocabulary,  he's either 100% happy or 100% sad, and it's  happy 95% of the time (at least in my memories).
  2. Smiling in Contagious -  Because of Zach's happiness, any time I'm around Zach I'm just ecstatically happy, because everything  makes him happy, it makes me happy too.
  3. Watching Development - I don't know if you can read it in my blog posts, but being able to see Zach's development is both extremely interesting and also fills me with an undeserved sense of pride.

Did Zach get a party?
No, Tori an I aren't real big into birthdays. We'll see if we revise this opinion now that we have Zach. We want everyday to be a special day for Zach, birthdays are not special.

Anything new with the house?

Heck yes!  Two more walls turned orange, and the basement filled with the stuff from our now 1/2 empty storage unit, and blackberries and sunflowers went into the ground!
entry.georss:featurename: 905 E Pike St, Seattle, WA 98122, USA

entry.title: Sunday's Hobo Blogging - Capital Hill (10th and Pike)
entry.content:
Sunday mornings we have a baby sitter so Tori and I normally walk over to the local coffee shop where Tori does school work, and I do work work, or blog work. The last few Sunday's Tori has been on site for her play, and I've been dropping her off since it makes me feel manly.   While I wait for Tori to finish work, I rent some space and an internet connection from a local coffee shop.

Last week I got see Lower Queen Anne, this week it's Capital Hill.  I can report these hip neighborhood don't have much action at 9am,  which is probably a good thing as I need to focus to write.

By the way, I used to think capitol hill would be in appropriate as I got older, but I just saw  a 55 year old man walk by in a pink dress,  maybe cap hill would be fun in my next few decades too.

entry.title: Week 103AZ: Daddy Work Go Bye Bye
entry.content:
Tori and Zach picked me up from work on Tuesday, and as we pulled out of the parking lot Zach exclaimed:

Daddy Work Go Bye Bye

It blew my mind, just a few short weeks ago Zach could barely say Dada and Mamma, and now he's coming up with abstract concepts.

Everyone says family traditions are important, and we're building them!  For Zach's second birthday, (just like his first) we all took a few days to vomit up our meals. While I'm all for shared family experiences, I look forward to retiring this tradition and replacing it with something more fun like biking or swimming.

Tori continues to write article reviews for English 101, and make goofy masks for her play ( no, I don't know the name of the play, nor the theater in which it plays). On top of that, Tori has started to attack the front yard. Saturday saw the removal of a few more shrubs, and the insertion of sunflower seeds, I can't wait till we get next years crop of sun flowers.

Dad still needs to finish his taxes, and find a good goofy health kick to blog about.

Saturday was Sunny and Warm and  Zach and I did the friend tour (Tori was engaged terrorized our "old person front yard", and building props).    The friend tour started with breakfast and play time with the Doty's, followed by a 5 hour ride with Zach, Paul and Ben.  The ride was great,  we got to see the new section of the  Burke Gilman (wonderful!!) and play at Matthews beach and log boom park.  On the way home as Dad was slowing down from being in bad shape, and Zach was getting grumpy and tired, we stopped at the market and got apples and donuts which re-charged Daddy's leg muscles, and Zach's happiness muscle, resulting in happiness all around.

This weeks picture shows Zach and mom walking through the arboretum by our house.  For a cute video, check out Zach bed time routine taken by Zach.

Happy Week Folks!

link.title: Week 103AZ: Daddy Work Go Bye Bye

entry.title: Week 102AZ: One Bus; Two Buses
entry.content:
(The crappy posts will stop when Zach and I get a week of not being sick - I promise) 

Yesterday Zach actually said one bus, two buses. Where does he come up with this grammar stuff?

Last week was tough, Zach had a fever, and was sick, and I've had a fever and then a soar throat, and I'm finally feeling better. Me and Zach being sick is brutal hard on Tori, since she takes up the slack. Zach and I are grateful - let me say that again, Zach and I are grateful for all you do for us.

Tori is convincing Zach that he no longer sleeps in our bed, and it's working! Right now, I'm lying in my bed, and Zach is in his crib talking to himself softly as I write this. I can hear Zach saying: "Up and Down" ;  "Ben and Sam" ; "Mommy Working", "no, no,no,no"; "Knock; Knock", and even humming the odd tune.

It's so fun watching the words come in, far more fun then watching the teeth come in. Someone should have told me to record a sound bite every week, I'll know for next time :)

Tonight we played with our friends who have a 3 and 5 year old boy named Ben and Sam. Zach loves these guys and will run around demanding to see "Ben and Sam". Adorable videos here.

Outside of the sick-o-sphere, and the cute-o-sphere, Tori is working on English 101, and  making props for a play. Igor is confusing Tori through a random of assortment of hair brained health kick schemes, and running down the clock on finishing his taxes.  Seattle finally has shorts weather, and we're grateful!

Have a good week!

entry.title: Week 101: Little Boy
entry.content:
I needed to come up with something clever to say and I failed.

Monday (Today) Zach was a little bear, he has a fever so he's mean as molasses (is that a real simile?) . When Zach's in a bad mood it's contagious and Mommy and Daddy claw at each other.

In the few cute moments between Zach going bats (and consequently mom and dad too) Zach did some awfully fine stuff like blow bubbles and lock the car with the keys. Even cuter he tried to open the car door with keys (not realizing there is no key hole in the back door).

Zach is getting better and better with words.  I pulled Zach outside, away from Tori, so Tori could get a well deserved break, and outside  Zach screamed: Back Home, Back Home, Back Home, until he started screaming dog, which was odd, but sure enough there was a dog tied up in the bushes.  Then we walked a bit more and  Zach screamed  two doggie, and sure enough there were two dogs, next  Zach yelled woof woof, which was fitting, before returning to his original wail of  Back Home until I returned Zach  to his booboos.

I guess the morale of the story is don't take a feverish man from his booboos.  On the bright side, I've really been enjoying tasty things, I think I need to get back on the juice train :)

Namaste - and thank you tori for watching over our grumpy, feverish, biting, clever child!

entry.title: Week 100AZ: Seattle Sun Shining
entry.content:
Spring, which I define as sun and warm days,  came to Seattle this weekend.  The timing is perfect as Tori has completed her exams and Zach has picked up a plethora of new tricks:

Zach now says happy and sad. When he gets an owie he's sad. When we play with other kids he's happy.

Zach has also  taken a shining to dolls. His favorite is froggy, which you'll note is wearing shoes and likes to go swinging.

Zach is also starting to master grammar. He's now onto 3 word sentences like:
"Daddy Blue Hat"
"Mommy Two Boobs"

We maximized our sunshine by packing our weekend with fun activities.  For Saturday daddy day care, we hit the sculpture park, the  pike place market, where Zach enjoyed the free samples, and a rocking bus ride home. After nap,  we hung out with our friend Gracie at steward park, and then had her family over for Teriyaki and Ice Cream.

Sunday, we had breakfast with Uncle Dave - it was very yummy. Then we went to greenlake where we ran into Uncle Ammon (whom I failed to capture in a photograph).

After all this adventure Zach is out like a light.

Namaste!

entry.title: Week 99AZ: It's a marathon not a sprint
entry.content:
(Lack of spelling and grammar error courtesy of my divine partner 's editing - You rock Tori!)


First, I'm writing this while Tori and Zach are out watching a basketball tournament for 8 year olds. Who knew our community center rocks on Friday nights, and that Zach is a B-Ball Fan? He watched the whole game without super wiggling, trying to steal the ball, or anyone's legos.

This was a tough week: lots of stuff went wrong at work,  Tori's writing exams, and we've got crappy, cold, rainy weather to boot :) This has me reverting to some bad habits, including drinking instead of exercising, sleeping in, and french fries. Thankfully by week's end,  I have recalled how much I prefer the "new" Igor, who'd rather drink green tea than coffee and booze, and who'd rather wake up at 5 am instead of going to bed at midnight.

As I meditate over this, I recall what I wrote on my door a few weeks ago, "It's a sprint not a marathon".    Zach when you read this, remember that. It's hard to know in your 20's but it's what will keep you alive into your 70's. Anywoo - enough about me.

Zach is getting very good at talking, just the other day he got Tori to call me and then said "Hello Daddy!". I was floored.  Zach also took a stab at peeing in his potty, it was out of the blue and hasn't happened since, but I'll take it! He will now drag his step stool over to the front of the toilet and stand on it naked, pretending to pee standing up, just like Daddy. Aim is not the priority though and this weekend we are off to have Zach pick out his own personal potty chair.

The local community center is in the process of replacing their playing field with artificial turf and Zach loves to go and play on the diggers, tractors, and other machinery. Our community center is set on the edge of Lake Washington and tends to flood quite a bit so not only does Zach get to crawl all over big machinery, but he can splash in puddles up to his eyeballs doing it. Spring is around the corner; the hoards of robins, crocuses, and daffodils remind us of this everyday.

link.title: Week 99AZ: It's a marathon not a sprint

Zach has discovered that pockets are meant to hold things - like soggy pine cones and rocks. The washing machine is not amused.

He is also becoming very talented at saying please and thank you, and plugging in our small coffee maker that we use when we have company. I came out of the bathroom the other day to the word "hot" only to find that Zach had indeed plugged it in and turned it on. No more solo pees for me.

entry.title: Week 96AZ: It's working!
entry.content:
The Nanny works!

The Baby sitter works!

The sink works!

Tori made the studying work - and her midterm score is: 94%!

This week Zach and  I went on a Rumspringa,  Drinking, eating burgers, watching TV, fries, coffee,  ice cream, chips even a Root Beer Sunday! I traded my daily habit of weighing myself for drinking and eating junk food. I tell you I didn't  enjoy it much,  and it certainly wasn't worth the decrease in energy, and the mood swings.

After the adventure in badness,  I re-baptize myself in my faithful mantra "I'd rather be skinny than drunk".

It feels like Zach is spitting out some new words daily. Our nanny said to Zach "Little Man" and Zach said back, "lia ma" - which I think is little man :)  Even cuter when Zach wants my phone, or my camera or generally anything he's not allowed to have he says "My Turn", in the hope that we'll let him play with it. It's a hard road, on one hand, he has to share all his stuff with others, but on the other hand,  parents stuff he can't have even if he says the magic incantation.

Tough World little man!  Speaking of  ... Today as Tori and I left Zach with the baby sitter Zach didn't cry, or frankly care, that Tori and I were leaving. Instead,  Zach just wanted to play with the teenage girls.  I guess he's just practicing his adolescent behaviors.

Another thing  Zach is now a super mimic: I like to hop like a bunny when I'm with Zach. I'm not sure why, it just makes me happy and it will be rather useful when my purpose in life becomes embarrassing Zach :)  When I hop, Zach usually smiles and runs along side me. Today though, when a little girl came to the park, Zach started hopping just like his Dad does- it made me proud.  Tori recounted a similar story earlier this week: When Zach was downstairs he took the lid off the cat box, and started scooping around for cat poop.

It's a good life people - if you're reading this find someone to kiss and plant a smooch on 'em!

entry.title: How Igor Met Tori: The Genesis Story
entry.content:
As I get older my fading memory takes steps to rewrite history.  Some days are more important then others, and the day I met Tori is one of my most important days-period. I'm sure Tori will think this is corny (and wish I could spell), but sometimes you just need to suck it up and be glad there are people in the world that love you more than you know.

Tori and I met on a dark and stormy night, it was pouring and we walked around green lake in the pitch black in a down pour.

For the hour it took us to go around the lake, I could not understand anything Tori said - I knew the words and the grammar, but the sentences were nonsense, utter gibberish.  It's not clear to me why I found that so attractive, or why Tori would consider that an effective courting tactic, but 7 years later -I can confirm it worked.

Of all the things I didn't understand that night, there is one I remember the most - several times through the evening Tori kept talking about her mouse. This mouse that she brought with her, and then left at Greenlake.  She mentioned this several times,  and I worried she might be a little too "batty". Alas,  I should have asked what she meant (a mistake I continue to make) as mouse is Tori's truck.

Back then, Tori she had two prized possessions: Mouse, and the cats. Unlike mouse, the cats were real, and they wanted to make sure I was good enough for Tori! SeaBass, the oldest cat, tried to claw out my eyes - while I, being on a first date and trying to make a good impression,  petted him gently and kept saying good kitty.  The other cats Ash and Mooch,  were in on it too, and put their wet catfood dish on my path to the bathroom.   You know how ackward that first date can be. Imagine how much harder it it to be  "cool" when your feet are covered in wet cat food.

Maybe Tori will do a guest post on her memories of that day - I love you Tori!

link.title: How Igor Met Tori: The Genesis Story

entry.title: Week 95: New Skills
entry.content:
(Aside:  I forgot the misery which was teething (although  it's much easier than last time).   It's a return to  grumpy, clingy, poor sleeping Zach's - come on teeth, come on through)

Zach has lots of new  skills this week in random order:

Two syllable words -  on a good day I've been upgraded from DaDa to DadDy which is pretty frickin' cool.
Skipping - which looks more like limping during a seizure, but you have to start somewhere.
20 Questions -  But unlike before, yes means yes, no means no, and we all end happy.
Dressing - Shoes and shirts, although for shirts left/right front/back are still a work in progress
Zoo - Not only does Zach ask to go to the Zoo, but he also realizes it's full of animals.

Mom and dad aren't slouches either our new skills include:

Mommy Skill - Nanny - Even though it's been scary for Tori, she's had a new nanny out.  Zach loves it, and Mom is starting to acclimatize.
Daddy Skill - Wake up early -  I've been up before 7 everyday,  my best day I was up by 5.
Daddy Skill - Sink Breaking - The sink repair hasn't gone as smooth as I'd hoped, but when it's bathroom remodel time I"ll be ready.

Happy week!

entry.title: Week 93AZ: I am Zach
entry.content:
This was the week - as I scraped poo off Zach's Tush, Zach pointed at himself and said I Zaaaak. No one was as impressed with moment as I was, but that's ok, I write this for me and Zach, and Zach that was a huge moment!

Seattle had amazing weather this weekend so instead of the kids museum we walked through the arboretum (and bar) with Chris Logan,  Paul, Sam and Ben.  Paul is the newest addition to our troupe and we're glad to have him. Paul  lives about a mile away and with an oldest kid whose 7, he's probably 5 years a head of us. It's great having him out.

I had a cold this week,and somehow I completely forgot my sisters witch doctor medicine of Oregano Oil. I now reek of oregano, but I'll tell you I don't have much of a cold so a welcome trade. Ps - if you're interested in oregano, check I talk about it in my health blog (tbd).

Tori and I had some wonderful baby sitters come out and Zach loved chilling with them. Unfortunately getting time with them  baby sitters is really tough as they're booked booked booked. It might be easier to get a mason then to get a contractor (sorry bad remodel joke).

I can't remember much else about this week as my brain is a little fried from the cold, and the sunshine.

Oh I should mention my neighbor. My neighbor is awesome, for the last 10 years he's been working on a 60 year old car, and he's finally got it outside, you can see a picture to the left. Not only has Tom restored this antique car, but he did it in a very zany way. Instead of using pullies to lower the engine into the car, he raised the engine up using 100's of tire inner tubes. Slowly but surely every time he added an inner tube the engine lifted up. Then Tom rolled the car under the engine, and started removing inner tubes  till the force excerted by each tube couldn't no longer lift the engine and engine fell into place.  Tom explained to me how this method had a nice failure mode :)

entry.title: Week 92AZ: It's always cuter when they hold hands
entry.content:
First, I skipped Week 91, during which Seattle had a total SnowMagaddon. To make up for it, we have a bonus picture of Tori taking Zach out sledding - yes that really is Seattle!


Now, this week I had the quintessential fatherhood experience:

Dad - Ready to head out the door to work
Dad - Stops to hug Child
Child  - Pukes all over Dad
Dad - Changes and rushes to work (now late)
Dad - At work - smells like Puke.

As usual, Tori's quintessential motherhood experience is much worse: comfort the baby all day and all night while he pukes all over you.  Then, exhausted, go write an exam you need to get a 100% on.

If you haven't had these experiences yet, it's much less unpleasant that you'd expect. There is just something about kids that is wonderful and softens all of life's "blows".

On the bright side, Zach is feeling much better, and unlike last time Tori and I didn't have to puke this -although Tori and I were both rather constipated  (I'm happy to report things are moving freely again!)

This weeks picture shows Zach and Malcolm waiting for a bus and holding hands. I gotta say kids holding hands are really sweet.

For skills,  I was amazed to hear Zach bending notes on the harmonica, maybe when he gets a touch older Zach and I will sign up for some harmonica lessons, and we'll be able to duet "happy birthday to you".   Zach is  getting more and more talkative - the other day he said Daddy Glasses while poking me in the eye. Today Tori is pretty sure she heard Zach say please! It's amazing how worried we were that Zach couldn't talk and now he's got non-stop babbling down.

link.title: Week 92AZ: It's always cuter when they hold hands

entry.title: Operational Costs For Different Forced Air Heating Systems
entry.content:
(Yeah I'm not sure where I should post this essay, but I could not find this calculation clearly on the internet so I'm publishing it now)


This page allows you to compare the operating costs for the different heating systems:  oil, electric, gas, or heat pump.  You'll find this page useful if you are evaluating  heating systems and are interested in comparing the operating costs.  After the summary I'll  include the math if you want to understand how these values are computed. Finally I'll discuss how the efficiency of heat pumps is reported which you're welcome to ignore if it seems too technical.

The table below is populated with the efficiency and utility cost values for my area (Seattle), however you can change the values for fuel costs and efficiency to match your circumstances.

The table below compares systems via dollars per Million BTU's ($/MBTU). This measure can be computed for all heating systems to provide apples to apples price comparisons.  My house took  10 MBTU to heat in December 2011 -  your house will be different.


Figure 1: Operating Costs of Various Heating Systems

Computing $/MBTU for your self:
You'll need to know:
1) Unit of Purchase:
2) BTUs / Unit of Purchased Energy
3) Efficiency of Heating System
4) Cost  $ per Unit Purchased Energy.
Apply formula: 1M BTU/ (BTU / Unit * Efficiency) * Cost

Understanding the quoted efficiency of heat pumps:
Heat pumps move (aka pump) heat, as a result they can produce more heat energy by pumping than by using the electricity to make heat. The efficiency of such system is measured by the Coefficient of Performance (COP) aka Heat Produced By Heat Pump / Heat Produced by Electric Heating.  So if you have a COP of 2, you are 200% as efficient as regular electric heat.

The COP for a heat pump is function of the the outside air temperature and the target inside temperature.  Therefore you need to use a seasonal COP (the integral of the COP over the entire heating season).   This requires you to specify outside and inside temperatures. ANSI standard 210/240 specifies a season and it's temperature and defines a term called HSPF.   HSPF is the unit the heat pump manufactures quote, and can be converted to a seasonal COP by multiplying by .293.

The most expensive heat pump we looked at had an HSPF of 9.5 which is  COP = 2.8. However, recall the COP is  a function of temperature, so in your climate you may have a very different COP.

link.title: Operational Costs For Different Forced Air Heating Systems

entry.title: Week 90AZ: Let is Snow
entry.content:
It's pretty rare to get snow in Seattle, but who am I to complain. Zach enjoyed getting out in the snow but was a little confused by the cold hands.

Zach, I and Tori (ZIT) are getting back into the swing of things now that work and school are back to normal.  Now that we've got heat, a bed, and paint on the walls the house is getting more like a home.

Zach is  learning 2 words a day, and it's tricky for us because there are so many words it's hard to know what he's talking about.  Zach is also picking up grammar - with such adorable sentences as "Dada Shoe".

I'm trying to get back into the super health kick I had going in the summer. It's slow going but every day of healthy is far better than a day of unhealthy.  Reflecting, I think the biggest deterrent to health is happy juice. Which is a shame since I now brew my own Vodka Sencha Tea - it's wonderful stop by and I'll share my flask.

Tori is looking at Zach care choices, next week she's checking out drop in care, and interviewing a Nanny.  We'll both be delighted when we have options so Tori can  get some Zach free time.

entry.title: Like Father Like Son
entry.content:
Zach and I are both proud Canadian citizens.   Not ungrateful, we're also proud to live in America, and to have Russian blood flowing through our veins.

Turns out Zach and I look rather similar when you see the baby pictures, I guess my family hasn't been lying after all :)

entry.title: WEEK 89AZ: It's a wonderful life.
entry.content:
I've got it good. I've got an awesome pseudo-wife, an amazing kid, and a collection of pretty cool hats.   

Zach is really developing, just last night I'm like Zach, lets go to the bar, and Zach was like "Bar", "Bar', and proceeded to get his shoes. At the bar, Zach was playing with the older kids the whole night long.   A few nights earlier we took Zach to our friends house and Zach spent the night playing with their kid.   Playing with other kids is a new behavior we've never seen before  Having kids play with each other is awesome!  Parents can sit back and relax. The only parental duty is to be sober enough to dial  9-1-1 in the event of an emergency.

Zach and Dad's new Saturday morning  hangout is the Seattle Children's Museum, which is where the really cute kids sized village pictures come from (see movie where Zach is in charge of Taco Delivery).

Now, being a parent isn't just fun and games. Zach has decided he likes to knock other children over (See second  movie).  We've started sticking Zach into time out but it's unclear how effective that is. Disciplining  a kid is hard.
Zach and Tori have started school again. A&P II here we come. Everyone asks why I use we when I say Tori's back in school. Sorry dear, it's just a problem I have :) 

On the house front Tori is a rock star. Zach's room is painted (Blue and Green), as is the bathroom  hallway (Yellow).  More impressive, while Zach and I were doing our shots at the bar, Tori was busy installing the insulation in our attic (which I'm happy to report is complete!).

entry.title: Polar Bear Swim - That's the way to start the year
entry.content:
Kudo's to Dave for taking me out for the polar bear dip!  When Dave suggested we go, I originally  said no!  Thankfully I was reading Flinch, and this gave me the kick in the pants I required to go.  I'm ecstatic  I changed my mind.  The swim was a super fun event, which Zach, Tori and I really enjoyed.

  My father would have loved this event.  In fact, I'm pretty sure he swam in just about any body of water he ever saw. It took me 33 years to realize how alive you are when you just do it.  Zach, when you're reading this and thinking me a fool, take your time, but remember the faster you realizing you're  better off being cold and alive than warm and enslaved the better your life will be!

 You can see all the pictures here.

link.title: Polar Bear Swim - That's the way to start the year

entry.title: Learn From a 2 year old: Either be alive or be asleep.
entry.content: I've got to remember Zach is here to teach me, just as I'm here to teach him. Lesson 1:  Either do something or be sleeping, don't be asleep  with your eyes open.

entry.title: Cool shoes dad!
entry.content: If you want to know what the heck these are are you can check out my health blog.  Otherwise marvel at what a cute kid I've got and  what a strange man I must be.

entry.title: My Home Town
entry.content: Too Funny, this is my home town, I recognize every landmark in this video. You can see the Harvey's where I started my career at the 21s mark!

entry.title: Week 87AZ: BUS,BUS,BUS,BUS
entry.content:
Happy holidays thank you all for the gifts, cards and well wishes, we are grateful to have such friends and family!

Now to business,  Zach loves to say BUS.  While driving around he constantly screems bus when he sees a bus, in fact at home he yells BUS, BUS, BUS and wants us to show him a picture of buses. Tori got him a stuffed BUS, and that's the only toy we've ever seen Zach carry around with him.

In an attempt to teach Zach other words we took the bus to the train to the airport and watched planes, but Zach refused to learn and called every mode of transport a bus. The airport was pretty fun as a tourist though, you should try going to your airport for fun, it's way less stressful when it's a field trip!
For Christmas we took Zach to the Zoo. We almost didn't make it to the zoo because I wasn't saying what I was thinking,  luckily Tori asked why I was being poo-headed about going to the Zoo. I told Tori I thought it would be really crowded. So Tori  made me a deal if the parking lot was a Zoo (excuse the pun), we'd go elsewhere. Turns out at 9am on Christmas Eve, the zoo is empty. We got to spend our time at the Zoo almost by ourselves - great job for Tori communicating, if we both learn to do this we'll be an unstoppable couple.

Any hoo at the zoo a strange thing happened, Zach saw the statue of the male gorilla and started saying DaDa, DaDa, I'm not sure why but Zach associates me with a silverback gorilla.  Tori was kind enough to pose with the gorilla, to remind me to be good or she'll find herself a new silverback.

As you know we've now got heat so we need new household projects!  Tori has re caulked the sink and is now painting Zach's room.  I'm pondering covering our basement floor with primary colored foam tiles.  I'm not sure if that's brilliant or not so I'll start by doing a few pathways through the basement before standardizing on which foam tiles to get.

entry.title: The evolution of HOT
entry.content:
A cool thing about having kids is you get to see how they evolve and develop. For non-computer weenies you get to watch them grow up :)

In the beginning when Zach couldn't talk we used the word HOT to indicate that food was too hot for Zach and he'd have to wait before he could have some.  Zach understood this, so then we started using the word HOT to mean something wasn't safe. For example we say the furnace is HOT (actually - it's cool to the touch).  Zach even started to use HOT for dangerous, when Zach was afraid of the shower he'd scream HOT if ever I tried to take him near a shower, even if I showed him the water was luke warm.

Lately, Zach's use of HOT has evolved, when Zach wants my tea, he points at the cup and says HOT, and I know what he means and give him some tea.

Last night, Tori and I were out doing errands (Woohoo for getting through our entire list) and Zach started saying HOT, HOT, HOT.  Tori said to Zach  "shh, Daddy shouldn't know about hot". I figured Tori was grabbing lattes and she was letting Zach have a little bit.   When I asked Tori what hot meant she said a little sheepishly that "hot" meant French fries.

After we went through the drive through Zach went beserk saying HOT, HOT, HOT.. It was pretty cute, we gave in and gave Zach the whole bag (it was a small bag), after eating the fries Zach was content, and went right to sleep.

entry.title: Week 85AZ: Cold Be Gone!
entry.content: After four months of the most frigid seattle winter we've had in years without a furnace, we have cast a spell of natural gas, large sums of money and competent workers and presto WE HAVE HEAT. In general Zach is indifferent to our largest appliance, with the exception that he's bummed he can no longer drop cat food down the holes that were our vents. While the delays we had were avoidable, there is some silver lining to this experience - which my dear son I want you to burn into the back of your head when you read this :). First always listen to your wife, she's right. Second, don't take for granted the things you have. Simple things life a roof over your head and heat coming out your vents bring you great pleasure. When you think things are truly crappy, you have lost perspective. Backup and see all the wonderful things you do have, a loving family, friends, your health, maybe even some heat if you're lucky.

entry.title: Newbie Parent Mistake: Where did you find a diaper
entry.content:
I have to admit that this was a little embarrassing. I changed Zach and then a few minutes later I was rather confused when Zach was holding a diaper in his hand. I said "Zach - where were you hiding that Diaper?" Clever kid I thought, has a stash of diapers hidden through out the house.


A few minutes later I realized Zach had just taken his diaper off on was waving it around.

Ahh, newbie parent mistake.

entry.title: Today at Zach's bed time
entry.content: I took Zach to bed and I wanted to read my book as Zach was falling asleep so I left the light on. Zach made quite the fuss and kept pointing at the light. I turned out the light (thus becoming unable to read) and Zach fell asleep in 2 minutes. My book light is in the mail.

entry.title: Week 83AZ: Happy American T-Day!
entry.content:
(This post has lots of links, click the links to see pictures - you can even leave comments on the flickr pages if you're feeling talkative - Zach will get to read  these comments after we're all long dead) 


For T'Day this year Tori and I decide to make a night pilgrimage to the sleepy hollow ranch .  We left at midnight and arrived at 9am, with the theory being that Zach would sleep while we drove, and traffic would be dandy. This theory worked OK in practice, but worked better on the way home when we left at 5pm and got home at 2am.

Anywhoo, back to our story. For T-Day we went to Maureen and Bryan's Ranch and had a blast. They took great care of us and  let us play with their dogs, cows, chickens and even let us start a fire. Most importantly, Zach had an absolute riot.   The pictures and videos on Flickr say it all.

On the Zach skills front - Zach is a total sponge. After watching me floss, Zach decided he needed to try it.

On the house front, it's still freezin in Seattle (I have to type this  in hobo gloves). Gas should arrive in 2 more weeks. Our electrical bills are ridiculous as space heaters are expensive to run, and the house isn't even warm. I'm not sure what I'll write about once our house has heat - maybe our home  improvements.
entry.georss:featurename: Nat for Dev Road 2060, Ashland, OR 97520, USA

entry.title: Week 82AZ: Oollia
entry.content:
The other night I came home and Tori said watch this - she picked up a picture book  and asked Zach what things were.  Zach recognized and said Dog, Cat, Banana and Car. I was amazed, Zach hasn't really "gotten" books before - but now he's a pro.

More impressively, I've always teased Tori when she said Zach was saying Julia.  Sure enough we ran into Julia and Zach says Oolia right in front of me. I guess just one more example of Tori is always right. This weeks picture has Zach and Julia sitting together at mighty mites. They've known each other for at several months now, and  Tori and Julia's mom going to the park every Thursday.

Zach is also developing personality. I yelled at Zach since he was doing something unsafe, and he became very sad, looking down at the floor and then hiding behind Mom.  A few minutes later I tried to comfort him by picking him up and he was mad at me, wouldn't let me pick him up or play with him. I guess that's fatherhood in a nutshell for you :)

Zach went swimming twice this week and he loved it - he would even jump off the edge into my arms (recall this is only second time in the pool).  Unfortunately, Zach still screams like a banshee when we go to shower off.

Zach is funny - he likes women far more then men.  We were at the pool and Zach ignored the life gaurd. Out of the blue Zach kept trying to get attention from the life gaurd. I looked up and realized  what was going on - the lifegaurd went from a boy to a pretty girl :)

For thanksgiving we'll be burning the midnight oil for a trip down to Oregon, I'm looking forward to seeing Maureen and Brian and their small band of chickens, cows, bees, bears and deer (apologies for the species I left out).

Oh yeah, when people ask how I'm doing I like to say I'm chillin' - which is apt since seattle is having a nasty cold spell and we're heating our house with space heaters.  This is likely the coldest year we've had in my 9 years in seattle. On the bright side I'm now typing in those fingerless gloves like the homeless wear :)

entry.title: Swimming like the fishes
entry.content:
IMG_1780, a photo by idvorkin on Flickr.

Today I took Zach swimming and he loved it. I was worried after he freaked out at the showers - but when we got into the warm pool he was ecstatic. He especially enjoyed it when I stuck my head in the water and blew bubbles. We swam for an hour before wandering through the gym looking for good stairs to climb. The gym was a superb success!

entry.title: Week 81AZ: Talking is hard to get right.
entry.content:
Since Zach is already a master of movement, he's now focusing on talking. New words abound - Uh Oh, Juice, Car and my person favorite - Aieeeeeee!  in case you've forgotten your childhood vocabulary Aieeeeee! is the word you say when someone is chasing you screaming Aieeee!

Let me give you an example of how cool talking is with the simple word "Uh Oh". If Zach drops something, he says Uh Oh! If I drop something Zach says "Uh Oh". If I'm looking around for something on the floor Zach says Uh Oh!  Now the oddest, when I kicked a ball in the air the first time Zach saw this he  said Uh Oh, but I explained it's not the right time, and he doesn't do it  anymore.  It's hard work figuring out when a word should be used when.

This week we got our first 2 nights of baby sitting (almost 4 hours), unfortunately, Tori couldn't get a break in either of those slots as she had class one night and parents night another. There is hope though!

Today, we got out and played in the arboretum, I haven't done this all fall, and it's a shame since it's very pretty with the changing leaves. This weeks video shows Zach playing in the leaves.

Funny story on the heating, remember we went on a long journey to try to avoid paying an extra 5000? Turns out we finally got the bill (although gas will be another 4-6 weeks) and it's only 1500$. Sheeesh - I really wish we got this done in July.

link.title: Week 81AZ: Talking is hard to get right.

entry.title: Zach says Juice
entry.content:
Usually kids learn words like Dada, Mama, Cat, and No. 

Thanks to my juice based health Kicks one of Zach's first 20 words is Juice.  When I say "Juice" Zach also says Juice and  runs to his observation tower to gaze at the juicing operation.

Once juice is prepared Zach then runs to the  table demanding to share my concoctions.

Juice On!

entry.title: Week 80AZ: Uh Oh
entry.content:
Zach enjoying the first juice from the Juicer, while daddy wears his turtle hat!
Thankfully Zach learned what to say when he drops things from his Mom (not his Dad).  After dropping something on the floor Zach now says Uh Oh! This is a well timed word as Zach can now open Zip Lock bags, dumps their contents on the floor and says Uh Oh!  As well as Uh Oh, Zach also say "at" which means cat, and will walk up to people (including strangers) and have full babbling conversations with them.  The strangers, like us have no idea what Zach is saying, but Zach definitely has the flavor for sentences, he's just missing words :)

Igor finally got his replacement juicer part, and as a result "Health Kick - I'm not juice fasting - Take 2" has begun! You can see updates on my health Blog if you're interested in that sort of thing.

Tori hasn't been feeling well, her sore belly and sore brain are most inconvenient as the house is freezing and she has another exam on Monday, almost there dear!

Seattle has had a real cold snap, getting down to 32 (0 for the Canadian readers), which is brutal as we still don't have a furnace.  Nothing like an icicle  on your nose to open your wallet, and let me tell you our wallet is now wide open and draining :) We've decided to pay the 5000 to get the street repaired so we get can get Gas to the house. Lesson for those looking to screw with their heating systems - do it in the summer! To be clear, Tori wanted this done by July but I was seeking out alternate heating systems like Fairies, and Hamster wheels, and now we're doing what we thought we would do in July. Lesson 2: Listen to your wife, she's right!

entry.title: Trick Or Treat
entry.content:
Apologies for my desire to haiku, it's a problem I have which you'll have to suffer through

Halloween Bee Suit
Hello Neighbor Trick Or Treat
No Candy; Too Sweet

Zach and I did some trick-o-treating while Tori was at school. As usual, everyone loved Tori's costumes, the bees might have been her greatest piece yet. I can't count the number of times people told us we were the best costumes they'd seen this year.  Surprisingly I heard a "new one" while we were out. A fellow asked:

Did you guys just write a test? 
Because I see a B plus

This was extra funny since I was holding Zach who could be considered the plus.  On the less corny but extremely adorable side, Zach loved pressing everyone's door bell and then hiding his head into my bee suit!

entry.title: Week 79AZ: Gobble Gobble, Eh!
entry.content:
Sorry it's been a while since I wrote - I'll do better and I'll have lots of content in this post.

This weekend we celebrated Canadian Thanksgiving (yes, I realize this isn't actually the weekend of thanksgiving, but no one in America knows that). To celebrate we took over a cabin in pretty Bellingham, and had our friends come out for a few deep fried turkeys, and various other fixin's.  The cabin was nice, but Zach got the hacking coughs, and that had him in a rather foul mood for the weekend.

Speaking of foul moods, Tori is busy as a bee starting to study for her next exam, which she'll write next Monday. Good luck!

Speaking of bees, that is our Halloween costume, I'll make sure we get some pictures to share!

The last few weekends we got to see lots of farms, and farm animals. In my photos, you'll see pictures of pigs,  lamas, and goats.  You'll also see some videos that look like Zach being at a rave. What's going on is Zach decide he hated baths. Tori being a SuperMom(tm) came up with the solution- she bought waterproof  lights we put in the bath which makes Zach now love splashing about in the the baths.

Zach learned new skills over the past month, most importantly mastering the art of pulling the parent. When Zach wants something he now pulls you. For example, he was done being at a friends party so Zach pulled me to the door. In another instance, we were at the bar, and Zach wanted some 6 year old girls to play with him, so he walked over and pulled them to the play area.   It's not words, but it's certainly effective communication. The other skill which Zach has been heavily investing in this month is climbing. You can see Zach up on the table, a feat he accomplished by pushing the chair to the table, and then climbing up.

On the house front, it's getting mighty cold without a furnace.  We've now eliminated heat pumps and boilers and are waiting to get gas to the house so we can get the new furnace installed.

Finally, Igor had a chance to do some of Zach's pre-school activities, man they are tiring! Tori is a SuperMom(tm) for being able to pull this off.

entry.title: The best mom in the world
entry.content:
IMG_1438, a photo by idvorkin on Flickr.
OK, maybe tied for best with mine.

link.title: The best mom in the world

entry.title: Week 76AZ: Zach's age measured in 1/2 years
entry.content:
I can no longer stand quoting age in days, weeks, or months. I've  decided Zach is 1.5 years old and will be for the next 1/2 year.

After last week's video, Tori was petrified to discover Zach looking for sticks with which to whack other children at pre-school.  While Tori is concerned, I have a more pragmatic approach - we need to borrower a bigger kid with a bigger stick, and the problem should take care of itself.

This weeks videos shows Zach enjoying some sorbet in bed, I notice that like Zach's fathers father, and Zach's father, Zach doesn't much care about food on his face.

Instead of the normal state of the ZachIgorTori union, I'm going to tell you about my evening watching Zach while Tori was in school:

First, I came home to grab Zach and take him to the bar, while we were leaving Zach said ByeBye to Tori.  I couldn't believe it, I'd never seen him say that before! Often when I hear Zach talk for the first time, I question if I'm just making things up, but this was a clear as day ByeBye

At the bar I was feeding Zach some steak and he'd have none of it. Zach then pointed  at the ketchup, demanding his favorite condiment, which I dutifully provided.  Smothered in ketchup,  steak consumption occurred dutifully. After a few bites of steak, other kids came strolling into the kid pit at the bar. Zach quickly  decided he was done eating and needed to play. This was the first time I've seen Zach interacting with other children. It was great to watch, although he only plays with older kids, the kids his age he mostly  ignores.

After a while, that first round of kids ran off, and a new round of kids appeared, two 8 year old girls. Zach was all over them, the 8 year old girls were enjoying him as well, calling him "random baby" and playing with him.

Thankfully the girls were old enough to dodge the blocks Zach was lobbing at their heads (we'll have to explain to Zach that even though Mommy does it to Daddy, it's not a generally accepted sign of affection).  After a while the girls had to do homework, so they want back to their table.  To my amazement, Zach followed them and started poking them. At this point the 8 year old girl said to Zach:

You don't know what homework is yet, but soon you will, it's not fun


Namaste!

link.title: Week 76AZ: Zach's age measured in 1/2 years

entry.title: Week 75AZ: Emergency One - Locked in the bathroom.
entry.content:
I suspect every parent with an old house and small child has had this experience. Kid playing in bathroom, kid locks door, kids starts screaming, kid realizes problem and screams continuously.  Meanwhile parents figure out kid is locked in bathroom and then run around like chickens with heads chopped off trying to calm and rescue  child.

Luckily Tori and I were both around when this happened to Zach. We only had one false start which was trying to remove the door knob. The rest of the rescue involved a ladder, a mallot and a window.  Good thing I've been juicing or I might not have made it through the window.

On the more fun side we took Zach to the pumpkin patch with the Scott family. We ate grapes and apples  and blackberries right from the vine/tree/bush!  Tori reminds me this is stealing, but I claim I was simply following Zach's lead.  I also note for the many nasty looks I got from my companions, they all enjoyed our illegal bounty.  After snack time Zach also met some pigs, a video of which I'll share next time.

This weeks video shows Zach fencing with Dave. I'm not sure what Dave's questioning look is, I thought the whole exchange was extraordinarily  cute.

Tori is officially back in night school, and I officially need to re-start my health kick.  Mouch the Cat has returned from his great quest, and Ash the Cat is becoming comfortable with Zach pulling him by the tail and electric heaters are keeping us warm

Namaste !

link.title: Week 75AZ: Emergency One - Locked in the bathroom.

entry.title: Week 74AZ: So he eats ketchup with a spoon - are you perfect?
entry.content:
Zach racked up a lot first this week, in no particular order:

  • Feeding of bunnies, chickens, goats (Waldorf School) 
  • Corn Maze (Heck, I'd go even if I didn't have kids) 
  • Crashing of an Art Class (that was one of my chick meeting strategies from college) 
  • Hugging people (and cats, which starts cute but ends when Zach relocates the cat by the tail
Zach also put in his 15th tooth (yippeee!). On the not so great side, Zach with his farm hand like build, and lets push things around personality is becoming a bully. He knocked Logan over twice tonight - not good.   With luck, we'll  find some big kids to push Zach back.

Next Monday, Tori starts night school, which is pretty exciting since it's her second last pre-requisite before she can start nursing school.  I'm trying to decide what to  do with me and Z,  my current thinking is a swim at the pool.

This weeks video shows Zach eating ketchup,  which I find most entertaining, it's worth a click.

On the house front, we're closing in on a heat pump, hopefully before winter closes in on us.

link.title: Week 74AZ: So he eats ketchup with a spoon - are you perfect?

entry.title: Week 73AZ: 14 Teeth Editition
entry.content:
You likely don't recall but Zach started putting in molars back in June. The teeth have been antagonizing Zach ever since, breaking the skin, and then retracting.  This sucked for Tori and I, just as much as for Zach. Today I'm happy to announce we finally have 14 teeth (that's 6 more if you're counting) - Woohoo!

We're very excited Mighty Mites has started again after the summer break. Two weeks in a row Zach and Igor have hopped on the bus and popped over to the community center. This week's video is at the community center where Zach is learning how hard it it to deal with women. Such lessons will serve him well through life.

Tori has started Zach's academic career with weekly classes at a Co-Op Preschool and a Waldorf school. I'm not sure what he's learning, but rumor is they have rabbits and chickens (not for lunch, this is Seattle).

Speaking of new Zach skills, I suspect Zach was mad at me because I wouldn't pick him up. I can't be certain, but it looked like he was sulking.  Can't wait till Zach can say what he means, he should have lots of good vocabulary from his parents.   Zach is becoming a play dough master, in fact he's often gets the play dough container and demands you open it.

The Halloween costume factory is in full production, usually from midnight to 4am. If you peak at the photos you'll see some rather cute costumes. This years order must be completed before Tori's schools starts in one more week.

Zach is almost ready to tackle walking down stairs by himself. Unfortunately, Tori's heart can't take it, so Zach will have to wait a few more weeks before free stairs can be done.

entry.title: Dogs allowed on Seattle buses, so long as they pay fare!
entry.content:
From the seattle bus web site:
  • All dogs that are not service animals must be on leash.
  • Dogs are not allowed to occupy seats; they must remain either on the floor or sit on their owners lap.
  • Small dogs who remain on their owner's lap ride for free. All other dogs pay the same fare as their owner
I hope this wasn't Seattle's master plan to increase public transit revenue.

link.title: Dogs allowed on Seattle buses, so long as they pay fare!

entry.title: Ha! In seattle, large dogs pay the same fare as their owner
entry.content:
From Seattle's but
  • Service animals for persons with disabilities: Free
  • Dogs that fit in owners' laps and other small pets: Free
  • Large dogs: Pay the same fare as their owner

entry.title: Week 72AZ: Better at Everything
entry.content:
Sorry Zachster, it's been a long while since the last update  - I'll try to do better.  On the bright side, we've made lots of pictures and movies.

What really amazes me about Zach is how he's getting better at everything. A trivial example is how Zach walks down the stairs. A few weeks ago Zach would simply step down, and he wouldn't care where his weight bearing leg was (resulting in falls). Now Zach knows better, and makes sure his weight bearing leg is as close possible to edge before stepping down.  It's cool to watch the development.  Zach's learning to play with balls and it's super fun to watch. He'll pick up a ball, go to throw it forward, and then be confused when it flies backwards.  I'm sure a few more weeks and he'll be throwing the ball farther than I can fetch it.

Tori got Zach a tricycle, and an observation tower, both of which he adores. Tori gets bonus points because I thought those toys where silly.

Zach's going to start school next week; he doing Waldorf and Co-op preschool. Tori's spending a tonne of time to make these work and we're grateful for it.

This week's picture shows me taking Zach for walk at Greenlake. If you think this picture is obscene, I recommend a therapist and an ice cream cone.

Zach's  getting strong physically.  He often tries to pull off my toes (reason unknown), or will try to roll Tori  over to get access to the boobs.   It's pretty cool.

My health is going swimmingly, you can track my health (and kicks) at IgHealth.

Like Zach, the house is developing (but way slower), the bottom cabinet doors are 1/2 painted and the dining room is starting to be usable, and the living room now has bookshelves. They say a house is all about the neighborhood, and we just had a block party with our neighbors. It was super fun, and lucky for Zach, most of our neighbors have girls.

If you're looking for a movie check out "a man named pearl", quite touching.

entry.title: Week 68/69: First Blood, First Art, First Fireball
entry.content:
IMG_0921, a photo by idvorkin on Flickr.

Let's start with blood: We put Zach on a really big slide, which he was very excited to go down. For an unknown reason 1/2 way down the slide Zach decided to stand up. Gravity was against Zach though and he came crashing down the rest of the slide head first. I nabbed him at the bottom and luckily I saw that he bit the inside of his cheek. Within seconds we were all covered in what looked like blood, as Zach's blood mixed with his spit and our white shirts became streaked with red. It looked gruesome but within a few minutes Zach was giggling again.

Tori kicked off Zach's artistic career with some tempura hand prints, pretty shnazzi in lots of colors. Be lucky, and one might show up in your Christmas stockings.

Zach's been growing, as evidenced by his shoes no longer fitting and a desire to bite people big and small. Tori is learning to use her "No" voice to put end an to the nibbling terrorist. Zach also has a desire to put things (cords, headphones, sheets, cats) around his neck, we'll likely have to start discouraging this.

This weeks picture shows Zach and Logan at St. Edwards park, which is a wonderful park up in Kenmore. It's got a huge infant play area, a huger toddler play area and a really hugest lake which you can walk to. Chris and Melinda joined us there this week, while John, Misty and Malcolm took us last week. If you got kids, go to St. Edwards - it's awesome.


On the health front, due to the swarm of fruit flies Tori has allowed my juicer back in the kitchen. This makes juicing much easier, to the point that I've been solid juicing all week. Some people make fun of me for juicing, but really it's the most effective health strategy I've had short of chasing Tori.

From previous weeks you know Mooch can go from the new house to the old house, but this week we discovered Mooch also knows the opposite direction, Mooch re-appeared at the cat food bowl after 2 days of mystery.

On the appliance front, the oven has decided that fireballs are the way to go, luckily the fireballs take enough power to blow out our circuit breaker. Also, we're trying to decide if a heat pump makes more sense for us than a gas furnace. Gas is super expensive for us since we have to replace the street.

link.title: Week 68/69: First Blood, First Art, First Fireball

entry.title: Week 67: More Painting, More Splashing, More Missing Mouch
entry.content:
This week felt a lot like last week, except I’m back at work, which I suspect Tori prefers.


Zach learned to ride his blue dog this week, and had his first date with Noelle and Julia. Zach still isn’t talking but he’s becoming an expert at the "point my finger than shake my head till you figure out what I want" trick. It’s not efficient, but you’ve got to start somewhere.

This week’s picture shows Zach and Jonah taking leaves from Jonah’s Mom Allison.

On the house front, the kitchen is getting close, most of the painting is done, and we are waiting for our cabinet doors to come back so we can paint and re-attach them. With a completed kitchen, dinner parties can be had for all.

On the cooking front, I’ve discovered a powerful tool called the meat thermometer, using this gizmo I can get my steaks to the perfect temperature - quite the improvement over my previous methodology of either over or under cooking my steaks.

On the cat front, Mooch continues to run away. For now Tori is sealing him into the Miller house. I guess this is good practice for when Zach discovers girls as a teenager.
On the donkey front, Tori says I am one, but she still loves me.

link.title: Week 67: More Painting, More Splashing, More Missing Mouch

entry.title: Week 66AZ: Splash, Splash, and more Splash
entry.content:
(Week 65? Zach went to San Francisco and spent time with the Stephens/Joplin clan. To his credit Zach did an amazing job flying and Tori was a super Air Mom.   Zach stayed in contact with Daddy via Skype, which worked well due to Zach’s baba’s frequent video calls )
Igor was on vacation on Week 66, which meant Igor got a lot of playground time with Zach while Tori was painting the kitchen. The kitchen will be yellow, green and blue shortly.  We'll post pictures once we've stripped our drawers. 
This week's big discovery is Zach LOVES to splash in water. This is rather surprising as Zach is afraid of fountains (can you blame him?) and often doesn't like to get his feet wet in the bath tub. We took Zach to fountains, wading pools, and finally tide pools, which he absolutely adored. If you're from Seattle, be sure to check out "Jetty Island" in Everett, it's worth the drive.
Mooch continues to run away to the old house on a somewhat regular basis. The new tenants of the Calhoun house did not know what they were getting as a home coming present with the house. Hopefully we'll get some crappy weather to encourage him to come home and stay home.
On the juice front, I'm taking a juice vacation till we've got more of the kitchen done, I can’t wait.
After several weeks of misery, and even more bottles of baby Advil, Zach’s first molar has finally popped through – Yippee!
Oh yah, Zach got his own Adirondack chair, so we can sit on the porch together watching our neighbor tend his chickens or work on his old car.

link.title: Week 66AZ: Splash, Splash, and more Splash

entry.title: Back In My Pants: About Juice Fasting
entry.content:
Juice Fasting is eating (technically drinking) nothing but fruit and vegetable juice, water and tea.

The internet is full of juice fasting stories, most of them written by laymen, or as I like to say "Quacks and Hippies".  The quacks and hippies make it hard for someone to determine what components of juicing are beneficial. For example, is not digesting food the key? Or is it the fact you're getting severe calorie reduction?
Being a bit of a hippie/quack myself I'll add my story :)

I am not juice fasting, but I am consuming a lot of vegetable juice (2 - 4 liters / day), and other than that I'm also eating vegetables, fruit,  yogurt, meat and tea.

In the 20 days I've been "juicing", I've felt phenomenal.  Here is my quack story (explanation free):
  • I've lost 8 lbs
  • I've been to the gym 3-5 times a week (from 0)
  • I pace myself at the gym so I don't get injured.
  • I'm full of energy, and have stopped drinking coffee, pop and black tea.
  • I'm drinking green tea, but may need to go to decaf as I'm still too energetic.
  • I'm pretty sure my memory and cognitive function has improved (hard to measure)
What amazes me is after rhyming off all the benefits of my new fad,  I still catch myself dreaming of having a cookie, or a bag of chips, or maybe a baguette, or even a 1 pound steak.  I really need to remind myself of the benefits I'm achieving, and how important it is I set a role model for Zach.

link.title: Back In My Pants: About Juice Fasting

entry.title: Week 64AZ: The cat came back the very next day
entry.content:
Zach is adorable as usual, but we shouldn't forget our previous adorable dependents Ash and Mooch. Pictured is Zach taking a nap with returned from the lost cat, Mooch. Zach went out to his first story time, a library reading program at the center for wooden boats, and also went on tour with lots of Tori's friends: Natalie, Bunny and Loren to name a few.

Zach also did his first ice cream ferry ride, not to be confused with the ice cream fairy, a gay man who sells ice cream in capitol hill. Zach enjoyed his orange float with returned lost roommate Ryan, who we sorely miss - visit more often.

On the not so cute side Zach has decided bathtubs are for pooing, no happy ending here, just lots of washing of bath toys.

On the home front, Tori has painted the nook a sunny yellow, and I have begun a juicing odyssey. Tori says the house now smells like a horse stable, and I smell like a vegetable. This strikes me as a small price to pay for health.

Tori is about to head off for Cali-forn-i-a, it'll be the first time I've been without Zach - I'll sorely miss Zach and Tori.

link.title: Week 64AZ: The cat came back the very next day

entry.title: Back in My Pants: Fat Sick and Nearly Dead
entry.content:
On July 7th, 2011 I got an email from a friend:

    Watch the movie "Fat Sick And Nearly Dead" then discuss.

To give some context, I've been extremely unhealthy of late, my weight has reached an out of control 230lbs, and I've been ignoring diet and exercise.  The next day I watched the movie, and started on a health kick like no other I've  been on.

If you've lost track of your toes, can't fit into your pants, or feel crappy, go watch the movie.   I'll summarize it for you below:

  • Joe, a really fat guy, buys a juicer and drinks only juice for sixty days.
  • Sixty days pass.
  • Joe, now a healthy dude, is healthy and happy.

Always loving kitchen appliances, I've purchased a juicer, and am experimenting with drinking lots of vegetable juice (this is called juicing). More posts to follow. 

I have a question to my readers, would you like to see my health kick stories on this blog, or on igfood.blogspot.com - I can't decide what is best.

link.title: Back in My Pants: Fat Sick and Nearly Dead
