entry.title: Week 63AZ: The Fun Ones
entry.content:
Everyone talks about the terrible twos, but right now we're smak in the middle of the fun ones, and it is awesome.

Not content with feeding himself Zach is taking a stab at feeding us in this week's photo.  Zach also loves flying through the air, belly laughing, giggling and going for walks.  Zach's starting to learn that walking on the road isn't safe, and Mommy and Daddy are learning to catch Zach before he goes on the road. Zach painted with pudding for his first art project and hit his first set of sprinklers. He has become quite the sandbox athlete and is starting to "cook." He babbles and sings his way through the day and has just discovered the joys of shorts.

We had a bit of a cat scare last week, you see Mooch the Cat disappeared. Tori and I were very worried, we thought the big fat racoon ate Mooch. Thankfully, after posting to our friendly community mailing list, our friendly neighbors told us Mooch was lounging about at our old house. Five quick trips to the old house later and Mooch has been returned to his "new" home.

On the house front, Tori has all the doors up and is threatening to begin painting.

Since my last post I bought a bbq, a juicer, a hot water maker, and an inflatable kayak. Tori claims it's a midlife crisis, I contend it's just me trying to stock up before the new budget takes effect.

ps - If you're keeping Track, Zach's teeth still haven't popped out, and if you're curious, yeah that makes him grumpy.

pss - Don't judge the fat, that racoon ended up having kittens.

psss - Yeah, kittens are what you call baby racoons.

entry.title: Preparing for old age - do stuff that you can do when you're old.
entry.content:
IMG_3130, a photo by idvorkin on Flickr.
I was chatting with a good friend. What can you do to enjoy old age we asked?

We concluded you need to do things that you can do with limited physical and mental capacity, Ideally requiring few others. Chess, solitaire and domino's seemed to be good ideas, as was having a family to remember. Then I realized I'm already doing something that meets all these criteria - blogging! For people that just look at the pictures here's another favorite.

link.title: Preparing for old age - do stuff that you can do when you're old.

entry.title: Week 61AZ: Zach using a spoon.
entry.content:
I'm not kidding when I say I was worried that Zach wouldn't learn to use utensils. You see, I really like eating with my hands, and without a fatherly figuring using a fork, how could Zach learn this societal skill?

The other day I was eating yogurt, and since I'm all about pragmatism, I was using a spoon (as is my habit for liquid like things in tubes).  Now it just so happens that Zach loves yogurt, so I was spooning out some yogurt for Zach. Before I knew it Zach had stolen my spoon and my yogurt and was feeding himself. Clearly necessity is the greatest teacher.

In the world of language, after Zach learned Mama and Dada (which no one believes but me) I'm teaching Zach banananana, which while not technically English, is an extremely fun word to say, and a rather fun fruit to eat.

This weeks video shows Zach playing with our friend Chiyako. You'll note even though Chiyako claims she is not a toy, Zach is not convinced. 

On the house front, we just bought a washer a dryer and double utility sink.  Igor will be preparing his plumber's crack for another sink installation.   At the same time, Tori is grinding through our doors. She has hung 2 framed doors, 1 naked door, and is hanging our French doors as we speak. Once all these doors are hung I'll have to plead my value or Tori will hang me.

entry.title: Week 60AZ - Where are those teeth?
entry.content:
Zach's mythical teeth poked through and then retreated. This caused a chain reaction: grumpy zachy, grumpy mummy and grumpy dadda. 
Speaking of Dada I'm convinced Zach says Dada when he wants my attention and Mama when he wants Tori.  Others tell me this is all a fantasy in my head, which is fine, as even fantasy thoughts makes me happy.
For firsts, Zach tried frisbee, which I would say he enjoyed playing more than watching. Zach played the slide whistle, which Tori says he's been doing for a while. And for a grand finale , Zach started crying when I leave the room (something he's always done for Tori but never for me) - I think this a bad thing, but it is touching. 
On the health side, Tori is investigating south beach cookbooks and I am now wearing a pedometer.  Perhaps we should install lots of mirrors to remind us why we should cook from the cookbook and make sure we take enough steps.
For Fathers day we had pancakes at Castle Von Doty (a short jaunt from TorZachIgor farms). After breakfast we took a walk to the park, which is the subject of this weeks photo.

entry.title: Week 59AZ: Little Boy Cutting Teeth edition.
entry.content:
(Sorry for  crappy post, it's been a busy week)

I was playing with Zach the other day and realized he's no longer a baby, instead he's a little boy. Everyday we (well mostly Tori) needs to get the energy drained out of Zach or he'll be a monster when it comes to sleepy time.  We'll take him to the park to swing, slide, or play in the dirt, sometimes Zach will just run up and down stairs, or ladders if we're not paying attention.

I was amazed to see how Zach copies behavior. I watched Zach rip the tab of a pop can, just like I do - amazing. And then at the bar, Zach watched an older kid shimmy backwards to get downstairs, and Zach flat out copied him - good skills when he gets to college.

Zach has been quite grumpy this week as teeth 22 and 21 coming in, but despite the grumpies  Tori managed to get Zach to sleep in his crib for the first time.  Great Job Tori!

I'll do better post for Week 60 - promise :)

link.title: Week 59AZ: Little Boy Cutting Teeth edition.

entry.title: Week 58AZ: Blueberry poop
entry.content:
Zach eating the blueberries
Students say "What goes up most go down", while parents say "What goes in, must come out, and when it's fruit, it comes out lots".  This week's video shows Zach enjoying blueberries.
We're now officially living in our new home. As expected, progress is slow, but certainly steady. Much has been unpacked, the bathroom sink now functions, and the toilet is ready to acquire fishes.
Tori has been gallivanting around the city with Zach, they've been to many a mighty mites and hardware store.
If you're curious what happens at daddy day care check out exhibit A and exhibit B.

entry.title: Our First Zach Freak Out
entry.content:
Less than 24 hours after Zach was born, Zach's breathing was crazy fast - more than 60 breaths per second (medical jargon: Respiratory Distress). We just had a home birth, and had no desire to go to the hospital, where we expected hospital staff would run oodles of tests on Zach and not let us have him back. As we were trying to decide if we needed to go to the hospital, I was counting Zach's breathing every few minutes. I recall thinking that keeping track of Zach's fast breathing was causing me my own respistory distress.

Eventually (at 9pm by these notes) we decided not to go the hospital, which was double handy as we didn't yet own a car.

We'll have lots more Zach freak outs, but this was the first.

entry.title: Week 57AZ: We're in!
entry.content:
After much, much, much moving, we're now living in the new house! Sure our kitchen isn't usable, and either is our bathroom sink, actually I'll stop the enumeration now as it's rather overwhelming, but let me re-iterate, we're in!

To mark the occasion Zach has become a masterful walker, which we exhibit in this weeks video.  Zach also took his first trip to day care, a 15 minute episode which he didn't object to, so long as someone would carry him.

Tori is ecstatic to be out of the old rental house, although technically she's over there now rescuing our award winning raspberries, strawberries and possibly even rhubarb.

Even though it's clear as day, I'd like to remind everyone how amazing Tori is. Not only is she raising Zach, getting our new home move in ready and clearing out the old home, but she still manages to smile and not murder me. Thank you Tori, you are the best thing that ever happened to me.

entry.title: Week 56AZ: Progress, and the many things you might find in a toilet bowl.
entry.content:
This isn't usually in here, a photo by idvorkin on Flickr.
With walker, Zach has taken Tori and I for a walk or two around the block. It's amazing, truly a milestone in parenthood - we've had Zach literally walk us around the block. Zach does a great job on the walk until he sees stairs, then he drops to his knees and goes crawling up the stairs, leaving us scurrying up to a strangers front door to rescue Zach (who can't getdown stairs), such is parenthood.

Zach is probably surpassing the cats for curiosity now, in this week's picture, you can see the cat and Zach both bemused by the ball Zach has stuck down the toilet. Balls down the toilet are cute, but when Zach flushed Tori's cell phone down the toilet it  was downright annoying.

In sad news, we set the tent trailer free this weekend.  We sold it to a nice young couple that reminded me of Tori and myself. And I quote:

Young Husband (to wife): What do you think?
Young Wife (to husband): Why are you asking me? You'll make up your own decision, and it doesn't matter what I say.

And like Tori and I, the wife was just as happy to get the tent trailer as the husband.

Saturday morning brought out my old roommate Julian, and his son, 3 year old Kyle. It's kind of surprising, we've yet to see a single daughter in the Saturday morning nerd crew.

On the house front, we have a new motto: "Ready or not, here we come". This weekend we moved tonnes of stuff, Trees, Tig Welders, even Zach's and my crib. Huge thanks to Mel, Danial and Ryan for the moving help - without you we'd still be sitting in a pile of boxes yelling at each other!

link.title: Week 56AZ: Progress, and the many things you might find in a toilet bowl.

entry.title: Week 55AZ: Let the moving begin
entry.content:
I declare Zach walking, since when he's not paying attention he happily takes a step or three. Summer has finally arrived in Seattle and this weeks picture is framed on the family walk in the arboretum - yippiee!
For firsts Zach got his first dentist appointment, his first sandbox and even his first dip in a water fountain
Above and beyond Tori's normal duties she was able to acquire a compound miter saw (I have no idea what that is) and she has been packing like a squirrel.
Saturday morning was a screaming success, weather was amazing, and with the minor exception of forgetting to apply sunscreen, it was perfect!
On the house front, the floors are drying and the great move has begun! Thank you Uncle Ryan for helping us lug some of big stuff into the basement, and thank you for your friendship.  You've been there for us whenever we've needed you - you're a true friend for life.

entry.title: Holy House - Fantastic Floors - Terrific Tori
entry.content:
When we got the house, everyone was raving about how good our floors would look once they were refinished. I'm pleased to say everyone was right! The re-finished floors look so good I think I should get a facial.

On a serious note, I need to reiterate how amazing Tori is. With a baby in one hand, and a crowbar in the other Tori is able to coordinate contractors, get the work done, and not rip my head off. I'm totally grateful Tori, thank you!

link.title: Holy House - Fantastic Floors - Terrific Tori

entry.title: Week 54AZ: Zach goes on Tour
entry.content:
Zach is doing all sorts of activities, he went biking with his Dad when we had a sunny day. On the trip we saw turtles and sword fighters and we even heard some bongo drums. With his Mom, Zach went to the Zoo and the Aquarium.  At the aquarium Zach got to touch star fish. I'm told Zach likes ice cream, but I know Tori and I don't eat ice cream so I don't know who is giving this mythical ice cream to Zach.
Saturday morning is turning into a full blown baby carriage club. With membership on the rise we might need to form an east side charter, or maybe even patch over an existing club.
On the house front, the walls are primed, and floors (being done as I write this) look awesome. Tori is stocking up on power tools and we're getting ready for move in.  At the same time we're trying to figure out what we can live with and what we can live without, windows are the current topic of discussion. 
    
Tori informs me Grandma Stephens is coming up soon, we can't wait, it'll be awesome to have a hand as we start moving in and unpacking.

entry.title: Simple pleasures
entry.content: What will i get?

entry.title: Week 53AZ: Almost there
entry.content:
Zach can almost walk, the walls are almost done, the summer is almost here, and Tori almost killed Igor.
I think killing Igor makes Tori feel better, so that's a good thing.  Zach is experimenting with balancing as he watches me type this report - I will not be surprised if he's riding a unicycle in a year.
Tori joined the Mom's of Mayhem at the Zoo this Friday - fun was had by all. Like Zach, Tori stopped puking and that makes all of us happy!
Igor got to take 1000lbs of garbage to the dump - that was fun. Igor has also been eating better, and after Daddy Day Care the Sons Of Nerds Baby Carriage Club went on a multi hour walk. 
On the house front, drywall is in place, french doors are in the mail, and painting starts on Tuesday. Holler if you have a router table, as we need to make some molding.

entry.title: Week 52AZ: PukeFest at the big 1.0
entry.content:
Sorry to be graphic, but that's the way it went.  To celebrate Zach's birthday, Zach discovered food poisoning. A few days later so did Tori and Igor.  This was made more exciting by the fact that we were at a remote cabin with no running water.  Yummmy.


With that out of our bellies, Zach has started his first year as a star.  Not content to be pushed around, Zach has decided it's high time to push his own stroller around. Actually, Zach seems to think it's time to push everything around. Zach isn't walking quite yet but he loves pushing things around, chairs, boxes, strollers… you name it.

Igor's adventures with the contents of his stomach will hopefully be the inspiration he needs to start exercising and eating better.  

On the house front, Tori's perseverance and hammer have discovered a secret passage between our living room and front bedroom.  Add some French doors and we'll have lots of light in our living room and a really cool den.   The house is coming together

entry.title: Week 51AZ: Follow me; Interact with me; Pay attention to me: I can jump barriers.
entry.content:
This week Zach acquired spontaneous interaction.  Zach will now bang to get my attention and try to get me to chase him (by crawling).  This brain development has its problems though. While I was literally on the $hitter, Zach jumped a makeshift barrier and fell down some stairs.   On the bright side, make shift barriers have now been replaced with honest to goodness baby gates.
Saturday activity was supposed to be a trip to see the tulips, but we pooled all our testosterone and concluded Daddy Day care would be more fun. At Daddy Day Care a sweet little boy kept running up to Zach and gently kissing him on the head. Who needs tulips when you have cute stuff like that.  Post Daddy Day Care (and baby naps), Tori and I took a walk on Alki Beach. Seeing the sunset over the water was awesome, but the biting cold winds turned a romantic gesture into a wind chilled foray into foolishness.
Igor's "get to work at 7am" plan worked on Monday, but fell apart shortly there after. I'll try again next week.
Tori's been pushing hard on the house. The electric rough in is complete, and we now have some lights with out the risk of fire.   Tori tell me there is now going to be a complex dance of contractor dominoes required to complete the work so we can move in on time.  I'm grateful Tori's taking care of the details - I wouldn't be able to do it without her.
See you next week, when we'll be hitting Zach's big 1.0

link.title: Week 51AZ: Follow me; Interact with me; Pay attention to me: I can jump barriers.

entry.title: Week 50AZ: Bah bah bah bah bah.
entry.content:
This week Zach has been practicing his monosyllabic rants. It's fun, but like most rants gets old quickly.   Zach's prolonged exposure to the cats has resulted in a bizarre behavior - petting other children. Luckily Zach's gentle so other parents don't complain.
For Saturday activity - Chris and Igor went for a big walk followed by some quality time at Daddy Daycare – yummy,
As predicted Igor's work was busy. As expected, Igor getting to work by 7am failed to materialize. Igor will try the 7am game again this week.
Tori is doing a fine job of contractor herding.  Our wallpaper is now stripped and our electricians have started.  We're in the lots of choices phase: White or Rainbow? Daycare or Nanny?  Re-Plaster or Dry wall?   In other news, Tori has also begun a new therapy to deal with her acute Igoritiss.  It's call Wood panel removal therapy, I'm not sure the exact details but it involves a sledge hammer, a  crowbar and a 100 year old house.
See you next week.

link.title: Week 50AZ: Bah bah bah bah bah.

entry.title: Week 49AZ: Home owner Edition.
entry.content:
This week we closed on our house. There were quite a few last minute snafus with grumpy TorIgor and last minute running to the bank. Thankfully that's over now, and we can focus on contractor herding.
This week, Zach got to Might Mites a la Tori, and Igor needs to find a new Saturday morning activity.
Igor's work has been getting busy. Igor needs to force himself up and to work by 7 so he can leave work by 4:30.  On the bright side, Igor did get a squash game in this week.  Although Igor won, he was limping for 3 days after his victory.
Tori is the General Contractor on the miller house, and  it turns out herding sub contractors and putting together a budget and schedule is in her blood. Recall, Tori’s being the GC, while still juggling a Zach, and feeding an Igor – impressive. Oh yeah, if you buy a fixer read the following: Budget? What Budget

entry.title: Week 48AZ: Over the hump
entry.content:
Zach's teeth are in and Tori's exams are done as is all the house stuff we need to do.  The winter is retreating, replaced by sunshine, tree blooms, and daffodils.
With Zach's teeth in, Zach is in better spirits, but now he's acquiring advanced personality traits like "I want that and you won't let me have it".   A useful life lesson I suppose. Firsts this week include:
    • Zach took a short bike ride with Daddy.
      • Zach rode a teeter totter.
      • Zach got pushed around in cars.
      • Zach wore his shoes in the park and backyard
      • Daddy flipped the chariot while practicing (don’t work Zach has a bike helmet, and a five point safety harness, not to mention he wasn’t in the chariot at the time)
    This week's Saturday adventure was Mighty Mites (video). Chris (a fellow fearless father, with Saturday baby duty) thought I was taking us all to a soup kitchen .  Sadly Mighty Mites will no longer run on Saturday mornings and we'll need to find a new adventure.   After Might Mites, Greg (a fellow fearless father, with Saturday baby duty) joined us at our favorite Daddy Day Care  Montlake Ale House.
    On the house front, we're so close  we can taste the mortgage payments.  Some paperwork snafu's and some not awesome real estate people pushed our close out to Monday. Thank you Tori for being so patient as it's painful having to reschedule all the contractors and parties.

entry.title: Sunny in Seattle
entry.content:
Zach’s first teeter totter.

What a pretty day - the sun is shining.  As Tori wrote her exam, Zach and I went to the park where we were descended upon by a small band of toddlers from a neighborhood daycare. It was amazingly sweet, from silence emerged shrieks and giggles and jumping and singing. It was wonderful - really. It was too much for Zach though, so we had to wait till the hurricane of toddlers disappeared, which they did as quickly as they came. Then back in our own world, where Zach and I did our first ever teeter totter.

 

For those of you not yet in Spring, it’s almost here!

entry.title: Week 47AZ: Exams; Teeth and Back to Work
entry.content:
This was a hard week, tough on us, and tough on our relationship. Tori is writing finals, I'm back at work, and Zach is cutting teeth. 

After much grumbling and poor sleep Tori and I can finally see the tips of Tooth 26 and Tooth 23.  Due to mouth pain, or possibly due to his meat eating father, Zach is very fond of shearing huge hunks of meat with his front teeth. This works well as Daddy is too lazy to make small pieces of meat for Zach to eat.

This week's Saturday adventure was a trip to the zoo. While Zach is still too small to hang out with the animals, we had a great chance to hang with the Scott's,  the Gray's and Daniel (Mel was leaving on a Jet Plane).  Zach got his first taste of ketchup which he enjoyed. The delivery system, French fries, might not to be restricted in the future.

On the house front, everything looks great, we're gathering bids to figure out which work we can afford to have the big girls do.  If you’re in Seattle,  and you didn’t get an invite to the ‘before’ party; pong me and we’ll hook you up.

link.title: Week 47AZ: Exams; Teeth and Back to Work

entry.title: Week 46 AZ: The days are long but the years are short....
entry.content:
ZachLearningToWalk a video by idvorkin on Flickr.
A lady said this to Tori and I as we were pushing Zach in a swing. How true it is! Every day can be exhausting, but at the same time Zach's first year flew past, I can barely remember it. As such I'll try to write a weekly report, our friends do this and I think it's brilliant.

This week we celebrated Tori turning the big 3-0, for Tori's birthday present, Zach and I will spend Saturday mornings together away from Mom, letting Mom get some much deserved rest. This first week we went to the Miller community center and chilled in the toddler room. The toddler room had lots of other kids there so it was fun for Zach and tiring. Zach came home and has been sleeping for the last 3 hours.

For new skills this week Zach is pushing around a walker, or anything that looks like a walker. When Zach's not paying attention he can stand, but as soon as Zach realizes he is standing on his own, he falls down. Zach is also now a wicked fast crawler, and we have to keep our eye on him or he'll go outside on his own. Zach also really enjoys watching me pee, and if I'm desperate to make Zach happy we'll go to the toilet and spend some time flushing.

On the house front, everything is now ontrack for a 3/25 close, if we're lucky we'll get a float down on our loan as the mortgage rates came down a bit this week.

Finally on the work front, my one month parental leave comes to an end an I'm back to work on Monday. It was great spending the month full time with Zach and Tori, it's certainly one of the best benefits Microsoft has for new parents.

link.title: Week 46 AZ: The days are long but the years are short....

entry.title: Don't freak out
entry.content:
IMG_2451 a photo by idvorkin on Flickr.
Today I was walking Zach and we got in a bit of a tight spot, I squeezed Zach and his stroller into a pathway that we couldn't get out of. Luckily I didn't freak out and just popped the wheels off the stroller, and continued forward. Good lesson for life.

entry.title: Zach eating Breakfast
entry.content:
My Movie a video by idvorkin on Flickr.
Parenthood, is a great lesson in "life is what happens" enjoy it! Here's Zach eating breakfast. I'm sure the parents out there will love this, while those without kids will be rolling their eyes.

entry.title: Which way is up?
entry.content:
IMG_2464
Originally uploaded by idvorkin
This photo is in the correct orientation - these are hanging shelves, hung with coat hangers built from a door. I'm not sure why the previous owner was so fond of building things out of doors, but it's annoying as I'd take an interior door over a hanging shelf any day. There are some delays on the house, hopefully nothing deal breaking, but we'll keep you posted.

entry.title: Gentle, GENTLE!
entry.content: One of the challenges of being a parent is constantly screaming gentle as your child explores the personal space of others.

entry.title: Zachariah CodFish
entry.content:
Zachariah CodFish
Originally uploaded by idvorkin
The whole time we were at Grandma's she insisted on calling my son Zachariah CodFish. While Zachary Marshall is a fine name, I've got to say Zachariah CodFish is better '.'

entry.title: It's not allergies, but my miner's lung seems fixed.
entry.content:
IMG_1457
Originally uploaded by idvorkin
For the last few years I'd go through spells of coughing like a smoker. These past few months I've been much worse, people often asking me if I was OK after I'd hack up a small organ. With Tori's firm support (go or I'll kill you), I set off to the allergist. I had high hopes for relief; as I'd self diagnosed myself with allergies after one of the first spells.

The allergist was old which I like in my doctors. He inspected my snot, and poked my arms full of all manner of allergens. After a few minutes, no welts appeared on my arms, and no bogies were found in my boogers. Whelp said the doctor, it's clear you don't have allergies. He gave me some nasal sprays and sent me home. I was pretty disappointed, Tori was going to kill me I thought as I coughed up a fur ball.

I looked up the nasal spray's the doc gave me, both for allergies. I took them anyways, curious why the doc would give them to me since I clearly didn't have allergies.

Anywho, next day I didn't cough much at all. Seems the cure for my non-allergies are prescription allergy meds. What ever the reason Tori and Zach will be much happier.

link.title: It's not allergies, but my miner's lung seems fixed.

entry.title: Justifying a Bad Job
entry.content:
In my previous post on doing a bad job I realized sometimes I'm going to do a bad job, and that I need to get on with it. Something feels dirty about the way I explained that though. In Seth's blog post, he frames a  "diminishing returns"  style argument as follows:
There are three phases of doing a job:
    "Beginners phase" where everything you do,  you get a lot of value .
    "Novice phase" where what you do  gives you only a bit of value.
    "Expert phase" where what you do brings even less value, but you've achieved near perfection

Seth argues the expert phase is extremely valuable, but requires a tonne more work than novice.  He also argues where you are in the novice phase is irrelevant - it's not distinguishable. His conclusion is if you're not going to be in the expert phase, and trust me you probably aren't, it's not worth "wasting time" in the novice phase. Stop as soon as you hit dimminishing returns at the end of the beginnners phase.  So that's the justification for doing a bad job. If you're not going to do an amazing job, no one really cares about the different kinds of mediocre jobs, so stop as soon as you cross the line into mediocre.

I've got to add, it's not trivial to determine you've made it into the novice range.

entry.title: The two minute Sencha problem.
entry.content:
IMG_1122
Originally uploaded by idvorkin
(Gratuitous picture of Zach for those not interested in my forgetfulness)

Sencha is a green tea that is wonderful when prepared correctly but awful if not brewed properly. To make a good cup of sencha you must have water at the right temperature and you must steep for 2 minutes. Steep Sencha too long and it is bitter and nasty. Temperature is easy for me, but not over brewing is a huge pain. Two minutes is too long for me to do nothing, so I start doing the 'next thing' and forget about my tea. As I ponder my ruined tea dilemma it occurs to me the answer to my problem might be a 2 minute breathing exercise between prepare and drink. As I ponder more, it seems I'll have the same problem - perhaps I'll go out and buy an egg timer instead

entry.title: Home on the range
entry.content:
IMG_1217
Originally uploaded by idvorkin
Tori has family that live on a ranch in southern Oregon whom we love to visit. The ranch is about 500 miles away, which is a long drive for a 5 month old Zach. Even though Zach was a champ we still needed some emergency pull off the highway NOW stops.

Emergency stop number one led us to a full size Lebanese grocery store that I would be grateful to live beside. The store made its own baklava and sold fresh shish taouk I even saw them making tabooli in the back - Yummy. Emergency stop number two took us to an Oregon prison - luckily no prisoners escaped during breast feeding.

This was our first long trip with Sparky, our red v6 rav4. Sparky did a great job climbing through the twisty mountain roads, much more fun then driving my old v4.

Grandma, the real reason for our trip was great to see, there's something magical about those 4 generations pictures.

The ranch, which is off the grid has beautiful cows - one of whom was kind enough to pose with Zach.

Big thanks Brian and Maureen for having us at the ranch it's a real pleasure being there and visiting you guys. Next time we'll even try to be useful and dig ditches or cut grass or feed cows or something :)

entry.title: Don’t Wait to do a bad job – Combating Procrastination
entry.content:
My most expensive type of procrastination is I have to do something I don’t want to do – for example writing my review at work.

Because I don’t want to write my review, I don’t.

But, since I’m not writing my review, I feel guilty and can’t do other work things that would be very valuable but aren’t as urgent as writing my review.

I’ll continue in this state, of not writing my review, and not accomplishing any non-urgent tasks until just before the deadline for my review. With deadline looming I write up a crappy review, blame the crappiness on the time pressure, and move on.    With deadline and task completed I then proceed to do my non urgent work which has now piled up since I burned so much time in the state of “paralyzed guilty”.

After I fell into this procrastination trap for the zillionth time I decide to give myself permission to do a crappy job even before there is a deadline looming. This is great for a few reasons. First,  if I want to make the work less crappy in the future, I have lots of time to do that.  Second, if I decide the crappy work is good enough, I’m done early.  Best of all, no time is wasted moaning about how I need to get something done!

link.title: Don’t Wait to do a bad job – Combating Procrastination

entry.title: Cleanliness is next to godliness.
entry.content:
IMG_0601
Originally uploaded by idvorkin
Today we went to our friend's briss. As a youth, I understood the negative side of religion, a force designed to control and repress the masses. As I get older I appreciate the warmer side of religion. Religion is a tribe, a place to go where the voices of generations sing together and understand what needs to be done, both big and little.

The big things - introducing the newborn the tribe, let all witness and bond. The old re-live their memories, the young see a glimpse of their future.

The little things - the sabbath. A time to unplug and focus on your family. Defend yourself from becoming overwhelmed by the pointless things that crowd your attention.

If you think this post is mushy, you should have seen me crying in the back row.

And no, of course we didn't circumcise Zach in the Sink.

entry.title: You only have one brain
entry.content:
IMG_0558
Originally uploaded by idvorkin
That's the trick to drunk driving. That brain that keeps you from driving drunk is drunk so can't make the right decisions.

My problem ain't drinking - it's being jacked up on caffeine, rushing around and ignoring my priorities. Instead, I need to be prioritizing the things in my life. I need to slow down, reflect more, and do what matters most. Going slow might be the best thing for my little brain to be doing

These things matter when you've got things you love.

entry.title: Tales from the birth - The we're pregnant speech
entry.content:
IMG_0403
Originally uploaded by idvorkin
I'm not much of a drunk, I just don't have that kind of dedication. Having too many is rare for me, and when it happens, I want nothing more than to pee and go to sleep. At the same time Tori's not much for holding in big news till the time is right.

With that, it was a hot summer day in July 2009. For some reason lost to history I had a few too many brews before stumbling home. Upon my arrival, I was devoid of emotions other than the normal drunk ones: pee, sleep, pee. Tori, on the other hand had big news - my state of sobriety was not relevant. As soon as I sat down she said:

We're pregnant! look here's the stick.
No, don't hold it from that end - that's where I peed.

Luckily, although Tori won't admit it, we were trying to have a kid, and so it was great news! Double lucky, since I was already sloshed I didn't need a drink to celebrate.

ps - If you're considering placing a bun in the oven, recall a woman needs to "eat for two", but its partner who had to pick up the slack by "drinking for three".

link.title: Tales from the birth - The we're pregnant speech

entry.title: Tales from the birth - Meeting the midwives
entry.content:
Zach in a monkey suit
Originally uploaded by idvorkin
(I plan to write several posts about the birth and pregnancy, once I've written them all maybe I'll even resequence them so they make some sense. So you get the right impression I'll give you the spoiler - I couldn't have been happier with our birth team. I liked them so much I'd rather call them our birth family.)

From the start of the pregnancy, Tori wanted a home birth, but I was very negative on the home birth idea. At the time, the only only home birth experience I had to draw on was the 'Baby Jesus' manger, and I had visions of my child being born on hay with goats bleating in the living room. Making things worse my friends and colleagues were assaulting me with stories of pregnancies gone wrong - and I was stupidly relaying these terrible exaggerated stories on to Tori who was not enjoying them.

My ignorance was compounded by the fact I'd never met the midwives -Tori's medical care providers for the pregnancy. After having missing several midwife appointments, the midwife took matters into her own hands and sent Tori home with a brochure entitled - "Having a baby without a Partner". It worked, and I was at the next midwife appointment.

This midwife appointment, like the rest of the appointments, was quite different from a "normal" doctor visit. The appointment was about an hour long. The medical stuff took a few minutes, and we spent the rest of the time talking about the pregnancy, how we'd function after the pregnancy, what support system we'd have in place, what classes we should take, what worked for us and what didn't. At the time it felt like we were just having a casual conversation about birth.

Honestly, after my first visit I still wasn't thrilled with the idea of a home birth, or midwife care, but I was confident the birth would be safe since the midwife seemed to know what she was doing, and would only perform births that were safe for a midwife to perform.

I should point out, after a few more midwife appointments, those hour long chats started to feel like we were chatting with a close friend or an experienced family member, I'd even use the midwife to convince Tori that was should consider doing some things.

link.title: Tales from the birth - Meeting the midwives

entry.title: Working from home take 2
entry.content:
Working from home take 2

Long time readers of my blog are often scared off by my original working from home picture. Oh well, their loss. Here's me and Zach in "newborn work from home" position.

entry.title: Small things - confused woodpeckers.

Originally uploaded by Tomi Tapio
I'm walking to bus stop the other day, and I hear a very strange rapid metallic banging sound. I stop - look around, but the sound has stopped. Repeat a few times and I figure it out - it's a woodpecker on top of a steel street light pounding on the light.

I'm not sure why, but it made my day.

entry.title: It's a small world when you have a webcam.
entry.content:
I've started doing a lot of video calls and they are wonderful. I talk to my family and friends 1/2 an ocean away and it feels like we're in the same room. Finally video calling has arrived!

If you haven't tried a video call in the last year or so, give it another try, the technology is finally good enough for mass use. If you don't have a webcam yet, get one that has 2 megapixels. For video software I've been using skype and I'm very happy with it.

entry.title: Are winter days really shorter in Seattle?
entry.content:
I wasn’t sure so I looked it up. Turns out they really are shorter in the winter, and longer in the summer.

Day Seattle Toronto LA
Dec 24 8h26 8h56 9h53
June 24 15h59 15h26 14h26

You can figure this out yourself if you go here.  I recall when I was in Helsinki in June, I talked to a local and said how awesome it is to have so much daylight. The local explained to me how it’s just a loan they pay back in the winter.

link.title: Are winter days really shorter in Seattle?

entry.title: Things that make you happy: Little details.
entry.content:
I was on my bike yesterday and discovered this great park 1/2 a mile beside my house, which I have never noticed before. It was wonderful, and it got me thinking, happiness doesn't come from giant things, those are achievements - happiness comes from the little things - the little details that put a smile on your face.

A few examples of little things that make me happy - you should list your own, it'll probably put a smile on your face:
  • A smile from a child.
  • That artfully placed garnish on the top of your dinner.
  • The perfect drop shot after a long rally in squash.
  • A tree cut down by a beaver.

link.title: Things that make you happy: Little details.

entry.title: Things that can improve your life: The Mangroomer
entry.content:
I guess we're all looking for ways to improve our lives, men with hairy backs have a simple solution - the mangroomer. The mangroomer is a do it yourself back shaver you can admire here. Verbatim from the ad - ways the mangroomer can improve your life:

* Look and Feel Clean and Manicured -- Eliminating unsightly back hair presents a more refined, clean image to others.
* Confidence -- Increase your confidence knowing that you are "back hair free" and no one will be staring or snickering at you, or get turned off by unsightly back hair.
* Romance -- Start up that spark in your relationship or marriage by surprising your partner with a smooth, sexy back.
* Muscle Definition -- Shaving the hair off your back shows your muscle definition in much greater detail. You'll simply look in better shape after using the Mangroomer.
* Sweat -- Keep your back shaved clean and help keep your back dry with less sweat and less chance for body odor.
* First Impressions -- As the saying goes, you only get one chance to make a first impression. Don't let back hair ruin the image you are trying to project.
* Summer Essentials -- When your shirt is off this summer, no back hair is a big plus. Whether you're at the beach or a pool party, use the Mangroomer to avoid embarrassing, hairy-back jokes.
* Avoid Embarrassing Public Treatment Options -- With the Mangroomer you can shave your back privately, easily, quickly, painlessly, and inexpensively by yourself, in the comfort of your own home.

Here's to the happiness of Hairy men!

link.title: Things that can improve your life: The Mangroomer

entry.title: The sound of my voice - Speak to us of children
entry.content:
Update - I lost the  original mp3. I re-record here. Interestingly I originally recorded this five months before I had Zach.

I've always been fond of both sound of my voice, and of powerful words, so today I'll merge these joys into a short reading I've stolen from the prophet about parenting:

Your children are not your children. 
They are the sons and daughters of Life’s longing for itself. 

They come through you but not from you, 
And though they are with you yet they belong not to you. 

You may give them your love but not your thoughts, 
For they have their own thoughts. 

You may house their bodies but not their souls, 
For their souls dwell in the house of tomorrow, which you cannot visit, not even in your dreams. 

You may strive to be like them, but seek not to make them like you. 
For life goes not backward nor tarries with yesterday. 

You are the bows from which your children as living arrows are sent forth.  
The archer sees the mark upon the path of the infinite, and He bends you with His might that His arrows may go swift and far. 

Let your bending in the archer’s hand be for gladness; 
For even as He loves the arrow that flies, so He loves also the bow that is stable.

link.title: The sound of my voice - Speak to us of children

entry.title: The sound of my voice - On Children
entry.content: I've always been fond of both sound of my voice, and of powerful speeches, so today I'll combine these joys into a short reading I've stolen from the Prophet about parenting.

entry.title: A great story of white collar crime
Kind gestures, and the responses they produce are overwhelming.
entry.content:
I watched an interesting documentary about a death row chaplin called At Death's door. My favorite memory from the movie:

A convict that was going to die in a few hours kept telling the chaplin how he loved cigars. So the chaplin went to the 7/11 and brought the convict a cigar, and put the cigar in the convicts pocket just before they put the convict in the gurney to be killed. The chaplin described: The convict kept looking at his pocket and smiling. I'll never forget the smile on the convicts face, and the happiness that moment brought both of us.

Small things make all the difference

link.title: Kind gestures, and the responses they produce are overwhelming.

entry.title: The goal of religion is to find divinity everywhere you look.
entry.content:
That great nugget came from a documentary that really moved me it's called Hiding and Seeking. I didn't think I enjoyed the documentary, but it moved me to write this, and there are still tears streaming down my cheeks - I guess I did enjoy it. Some other deep thoughts this documentary brought me:

Families and children are happiness.
There is beauty is in youth, and just as the seasons change youth and beauty erode.
With youth comes stupidity, and arrogance.
When you get caught up in the rules, you miss the point.
In all people there is basic goodness, and in some that goodness is strong.

link.title: The goal of religion is to find divinity everywhere you look.

entry.title: Here she blows and crawling on your belly.
entry.content:
If you're old enough you likely recall a volcano blowing up in the eighties. That Volcano is Mount St. Helens and Tori and I took a trip to see her a week ago. At 9,000 feet, shes about 1/2 the height of the Mighty Rainer, but Mt. St Helens is worthy in her own right:

  • St. Helens has deciduous forrest; we don't see it much in our travels, and I miss it.
  • St. Helens is covered in ash, which gives her a grey hue, resulting in a gostlike appearance.
  • St. Helens blew up and created pristine lakes, which you can't take gas motors into.
  • Coolest of all, St Helens has a pitch dark, freezing cold cave you can explore.


    • From the ape cave web site:
    The 1½-mile (2100m), upper portion of the cave takes about 2½ hours to complete. Cavers must climb over approximately 27 boulder piles and scale an 8-foot (2.5m) high lava fall.

    The boulder piles, called breakdown, formed after the eruption subsided and the fluid lava drained from the tube. As the lava tube cooled, it began to shrink and crack. These cracks weakened the ceiling and walls causing parts of them to collapse. The entrances to Ape Cave formed in this way.

link.title: Here she blows and crawling on your belly.

entry.title: My programming blog
entry.content: If you program check out my programming blog. http://ig2600.blogspot.com

entry.title: Haven't I heard that before?
entry.content:
Someone already thought through this and did a fine write up

One of the excuses that prevents me from writing is knowing that someone else has already written what I want to write, but better. You know: Wikipedia; some learned journal; even a full blown book. But - I've decided I'll no longer use that excuse and here's why:

  • I'm writing to learn to write, so the fact that someone else has written it is irrelevant.
  • The odds that anything anyone writes is original or the best, is very close to zero.
  • If I only talk about things that I bring unique insight to, I'd have almost nothing to say.


Maybe my writing will even add something to the picture.

entry.title: Fire in the hole
entry.content:
Tori and I spent the last few days at Mount Rainier -- as usual an awesome vacation! This camping trip we had a new recipe - jalapeño poppers. The basic recipe:

  • Cut top off and remove innards from jalapeño pepper.

  • Stuff pepper with bacon bits and cream cheese.

  • Cook on Fire.


    • As presiding jalapeño popper chef, I was in charge of cooking the jalapeño poppers -- an uneventful experience. Next up I needed to pee -- off to the woods I went. On my return, as I sat by the fire I noticed a strange tingling in my nether region followed by a sudden burning desire to step away from the fire.

    I spent some time in silent painful contemplation, pondering what to do next: A dip in the freezing river? Some cool milk? Luckily before I engaged in a bizarre act involving something cold and my genitals, the burning ceased.

    Ryan later told me his brother recommended not peeing while working with jalapeños.

entry.title: White Water, Serendipitous Sun, and Happy Holidays
entry.content:
Tori and I don't usually brave the freeways on long weekends, but this memorial day we took the risk and went white water rafting.

To quote the River Guide:

There are only 4 days with the perfect combination of Sun and Water each season, and today is one of them.


For lodging we camped at Rachel's folks cabin. Calling it a cabin doesn't do it justice. Built with Rachel's Dads bare hands, the cabin is a beautiful structure with huge wooden beams and lots of windows. While sitting in the wood fired hot tub most of the boys where thinking they needed to buy a plot of land and build their own cabin.


Awesome weekend! Big thanks Rachel's Folks!

link.title: White Water, Serendipitous Sun, and Happy Holidays

entry.title: Deserts, wild flowers, and cows.
entry.content:
In the spring of 2009, Tori got wild flowers on the brain. Tori went to the oracle, and the oracle spoke of a Beasely hill in the desert, covered in flowers. So we attached the tent trailer, and went off to desert.

We headed east, past the mountain range, past the end of trees, to the desert.
Awesome is the desert, but flowers were few -- so we continued.

A soapy lake we found, but wild flowers this is not -- so we continued.

A giant dam we found, but wild flowers this is not -- so we continued.

Much swearing, much cursing, much stairing at maps, yet no hill.
But flowers were on the brain -- so we continued.

We crossed paths with a dog with a man, and the man knew of our hill -- so we continued.

Thanks to our man, we found the Beasley hill, and we started the great climb. But as we climbed, we discovered cows, lots of angry cows. Angry at us cows, and we got scared. So we backed away, backed away slowly, to lessen the cows anger.

Somehow the cows freed Tori of her desire for wild flowers and we lived happily ever after.

entry.title: Hiccup - Connecting with your inner tadpole.
entry.content:
I just read Your Inner Fish and loved it. It's a story of our evolution, and presents some interesting ideas in a easy to read, entertaining fashion.

My favorite part of the book is the explanation of hiccups. Hiccups the author explains , are how tadpoles use their gills without flooding their lungs. If you're feeling nerdy check out:A phylogenetic hypothesis for the origin of hiccough.

entry.title: Igor And Tori Take 3
entry.content:
Tori says it's been three years since our first date. She complains March 6th can't be our anniversary though, since I still had some dates with other people to finish up. To me, that is just not good sharing. For reasons which I will unfairly attribute to our anniversary, we had a soiree.

The first act was the Circus. Laughing and singing, we had a blast! Cooler still, some of the circus props where built by Tori and lived in our family room before becoming one with the show.

13 Coins was the second act. Open 24 hours, 13 coins was packed at 11pm when we arrived for dinner. While waiting for our table we chilled in the trendy lounge sipping a beer while enjoying the live Jazz band.

entry.title: Ungratefulness, Mind Monsters and Tom
entry.content:
I was chatting with an old friend who was having a bad case of mind monsters. Standard story: His girl left him, lost his job and someone shot his dog (alright he doesn't have a dog). Being a friend of mine he is naturally wise, and he said something very smart:

"I am suffering from the common malady of ungratefulness"

This got me thinking, how often do I freak out of the little stuff? Really I should focus on being grateful for all the awesome stuff I have.

When I was discussing this with Ryan, Ryan said:

"Imagine how great your life is in comparison to Tom"

Tom, short for peeping tom, is an alpha who lives in our toilet bowl.

entry.title: It's not about being able to answer questions. It's about knowing the questions to ask.
entry.content:
The internet isn't smart, but it's great at answering questions. You name the question, and the internet probably knows the answer. What the internet can't tell you is if you are asking the wrong question.

There is an analog here with technology shifts. For example, instead of asking how to make a better telegraph, ask how to replace it - and you may get a telephone.

I have a sports analog too. For weeks I've been focusing on how to win squash games, and I kept losing squash matches. Now I'm focusing on how to win squash matches, and I'm on the verge of winning squash matches.

link.title: It's not about being able to answer questions. It's about knowing the questions to ask.

entry.title: Dating for Dummies: The Emergency Joke
entry.content:
It happens to the best of us - you're having a great date, everything is spiffy, you're both relaxed, and then out of the blue you say something stupid. She pulls back, her guard goes up. What to do? You pull out your emergency joke.

What's an emergency joke? It's a joke I use to switch up the conversation. Hopefully it will grab my dates full attention and get her laughing and relaxed again.


A few thoughts for your emergency joke:
  • Keep it Simple
  • Use lots of facial animations and sound effects. Grab her full attention.
  • Know the joke well you're probably nervous or you wouldn't be using an emergency joke.

link.title: Dating for Dummies: The Emergency Joke

entry.title: Dating For Dummies: The Acid Test
entry.content:
IMG_1361
Originally uploaded by AngryDave
A few of my friends have recently started internet dating. Today I'm happily virtually married, but back in the Pre Tori Era, I used to do lots of dating.

For the benefit of my mate/date hunting single friends I'll spend a few blog posts describing some internet dating tactics and strategies.

One of my favorite tactics was the acid test question. This single question told me with a high degree of confidence if a girl would be compatible with me.

My acid test was: Would you rather have a prehensile tail or a belly button?

People that won't like me tend to say things like:

People with tails are freaks! How could I find pants at Macies?

People that enjoy my company tend to answer with things like:

A prehensile tail would come in handy so often that I'll have to pick that
choice, but a belly button is just generally fun. And it's the sign that we are
human, isn't it? Wasn't there some movie where the aliens were known by whether
they had belly buttons or not? Hard decision.

Remember like any good interview question, there isn't a right or wrong answer. It is the thought the process, the evaluations, and the values that are expressed that matter far more then the actual answer.

Did you have an acid test question?

link.title: Dating For Dummies: The Acid Test

entry.title: Snow in seattle
entry.content:
Seattle is having a multi day snowstorm -- this is a rare event and I love it. Driving is not an option since:

  • Seattle doesn't usually get snow thus:
    • Seattle has 24 snow plows.
    • By contrast, Toronto has 600 snow plows.
    • But it takes more than just snow plows (here for more details).
  • Seattle also has lots of steep hills on major streets:
    • Imagine a steep ski hill.
    • Now imagine it being a sheet of ice.
    • Finally imagine your car sliding backwards down the hill.

As a result, it's a great time to take your bike out for a spin. Some people say I'm cooky but it's the way to travel:

  • When you fall, you tend to slide as you're on ice.
  • There are few cars out, so you get most of the road to yourself.
  • You can feel when you are about to lose traction, this makes you appreciate snow driving more.


Happy Biking!

entry.title: The rainbow fruit - Cauliflower
entry.content:
Today I went to the store and was amazed. Boring white cauliflower now comes in green, orange and purple. At first I was shocked - do we really need different colors of cauliflower?

After thinking more on the topic I concluded apples and melons come in different colors so it's only fair that cauliflowers can be rainbow colored too.

How do you decide what color of cauliflower you need? This page goes into the details.

entry.title: Back in my pants: December goal settings.
entry.content:
Bikini Diet? Pop? Booze? Running? Many an idea was tried, and many a belt buckle was loosened. Today , very dehydrated, I weighed in at 200.2 lbs. If I was hydrated that probably equals 203 lbs - about where I was in September. So lets try October's goals again:

Goal: Lose 5 lbs by January 1st 2009.
Success Metric: I will weight 198 on or about January 1st.

This month I'll try a more general strategy and we'll see where that gets me:

* Eat less.
* Exercise more.
* Motivate myself by telling the world.
* Spend time writing about weight management strategies.

Interestingly of the many ideas that I've tried and given up on - one strategy I've been very aggressive on is not drinking diet soda. I haven't had a diet soda in over 5 months - success.

link.title: Back in my pants: December goal settings.

entry.title: For every minute you are stressed you lose 60 seconds of happiness
entry.content:
This weekend is thanksgiving and Tori and I have colds. On top of that I'm stressed over a decision I need to make at work. Between stress and our colds I had an odd experience - I didn't really sleep Thursday night. Instead I tossed, turned, coughed, and had irrational thoughts about my decision. That made me an absolute mess on Friday. I spent Friday exhausted with my mind racing. Luckily by the end of Friday my mind was calmer and I slept through the night like a baby.

Today is Saturday and I've got my head again. As I surfed the internet I found and greatly appreciated the quote I made the title of the article.

This picture is brought to you by the turkey carvers of Canadian thanksgiving local 33.

link.title: For every minute you are stressed you lose 60 seconds of happiness

entry.title: The best and the worst.
entry.content:
The best part of the holidays is leaning over and giving that special someone a nice juicy kiss.

The worst part of the holidays is having too much happy juice and vomiting.

The best part about getting old is you've learned to get the best things in life without tripping on the worst things.

The worst part about getting old is your memory fails you.

Happy Holidays!

entry.title: Getting back in my pants: Would I rather be skinny or drunk
entry.content:
The bikini diet prohibits beer but has no restrictions against alcohol in general. This resulted in me adding a fair bit of booze to my diet since:
  • A glass of wine is a pleasant social activity while others are eating.
  • Happy Juice adds variety to the often monotonous bikini diet.
This pro alcohol stance is bad since:
  • Alcohol has 162 calories per ounce 100% alcohol.
  • Drinking alcohol makes me more likely to skip exercise and double down on dessert.
  • Alcohol supposedly reduces fat burning capabilities.
The other day I thought: What's more important being healthy or having a shot of vodka? In that context it's an easy decision. I'll now try to cut my alcohol to only special occasions

link.title: Getting back in my pants: Would I rather be skinny or drunk

entry.title: Kid Immersion
entry.content:
In school I did French immersion -- speak French every day, end of the week you understand a bit of French.

This week I went to Canada and it felt like kid immersion. In Seattle no one I know has kids yet, in Toronto everyone I know already has kids. Examples:

  • Stacy's kid is 0.2
  • Dennis's kid is 2.
  • Losha's kid is 3
  • Sammy, my niece, is 4.5

At the start of the week I was pretty petrified, but by the end I was getting the swing of it. Things I learned:
  • You can take your 3 year old to piano lessons.
  • Those fancy running strollers are pretty fun to jog with.
  • Children can be used for weight lifting - they seem to enjoy it.
  • When pushing a baby stroller - everyone tells you how much the baby looks like you, even if it isn't yours

entry.title: The sound of music: Goal Setting
entry.content:
If goal setting can help me lose weight, it can help me play harmonica better too. My first harmonica goal is:

Make a music video of Frosty the Snowman by December 31 2008.

Sub Goal:
Practice Harmonica 5 days a week.
Memorize Notes to Frosty by November 15th.

entry.title: Getting back in my pants: September Summary and Story Time.
entry.content:
I did not meet my fitness goals for September. On the bright side I hit my exercise goals for several weeks in September. I'll reset my goals when I get back from Canada.

Instead of going into gory details, I'll tell my story of trying to run 9 miles a week:

The first week, I jogged 3 miles on Monday ,Wednesday and Friday. The next week, I ran 3 miles on Wednesday, then nothing till Sunday. That Sunday I had to run a brutal long a 6 miles. From that I learned. Now I run 4 miles on my first run so I only need to run 5 miles on my second run.

link.title: Getting back in my pants: September Summary and Story Time.

entry.title: Getting back in my pants: Closed, Please Come Again.
entry.content:
Last week was a failure: 0 games of squash, 0 miles run, 1 carton of ice cream and 2 pieces of baklava.

I have no excuses to give, nor personalities to forgive.

I'll do better this week. So far: 1 game of squash, 4 miles run and no junk food.

link.title: Getting back in my pants: Closed, Please Come Again.

entry.title: Getting back in my pants: Death to Diet Soda.
entry.content:
[Background: Before starting the bikini diet I drank oodles of diet soda. We're talking over 12 cans on some days. The bikini diet prohibits diet soda.]

Why ? Isn't diet soda 0 calories?

Two reasons:

1) Diet soda is so sweet, it dulls my tastes buds and prevents me from tasting healthy food. Try this experiment:

  • Eat a carrot.
  • Drink diet coke.
  • Eat another baby carrot.
  • Did you enjoy the first or second carrot more?

2) Abstaining from diet coke is like push ups for my will power. I end up doing will power push ups every time I get thirsty or walk past a vending machine. It's a good thing too, as I need all the will power I can get to keep me from cheating the bikini diet.

link.title: Getting back in my pants: Death to Diet Soda.

entry.title: Getting back in my pants: Out of the closet and initial goal setting
entry.content:
On a scary day this fine summer, I realized a large roll of fat prevented me from doing a side stretch. A rapid weight-in gave quantitative values to that qualitative restriction. I'd reached an all time weight record of 217 lbs. Something needed to be done, and I began my patent worthy bikini diet (more on this later). Today I weighted in at 203, but the diet is faltering. To keep the weight off, I've decided I'll set and publish my weight loss goals monthly, I'll then discuss my plans, successes and failures.

Goal: Lose 5 lbs by October 1st 2008.
Success Metric: I will weight 198 on or about October 1st.

Strategy:
  • Continue bikini diet, although possibly in less aggressive form.
  • Run 9 miles a week.
  • Motivate myself by telling the world.
  • Spend time writing about weight management strategies.

link.title: Getting back in my pants: Out of the closet and initial goal setting

entry.title: Kvetching and Grinning
entry.content:
Igor And Tori
Originally uploaded by idvorkin
A few months ago, a cute kid came by, and we ended up with a few magazine subscriptions to magazines we didn't need or want. As you can imagine, this left me kvetching every time these magazines arrived. From the moment I emptied the mailbox, to the moment Tori mercifully thew them to the abyss of the recycling bin.

Today, a pair of 20 somethings came over trying to sell some over priced magazines to Tori based on a sad tale from America's ghetto. As our money seeking visitors tell their long well practiced and professional tale of woe, I kvetch to myself, imagining another worthless set of magazines cluttering our mailbox and coffee table. To my shock and pleasure I hear Tori saying
"No, I don't believe in giving money - I volunteer and that's how I make a difference"
The twenty somethings, possibly tipped off by the cute kids that recently sold us those magazines, were not so easily disposed of. They pushed hard, even showed Tori a knife scar from the ghettos of Detroit. But Tori would not budge.

Not only do we not have a new magazine subscription, but now I sport a big happy grin.

entry.title: The year of living biblically
entry.content:
Is a very funny book about a fellow that decides to live the bible for a year. This appeals to me since it's a goofy idea. But it appeals to me more as the author goes into the value of religion.

When I was younger, I thought religion was silly. Many things associated with religion I concluded were silly by association.

Take thanking god or saying grace. I thought what a waste - how could an all powerful being need to be told that he's great? But the value isn't in making god feel better, it's in appreciating the moment, and realizing how good we have it.

The year of living biblically goes into lots of things like the above, which I very much enjoy.

entry.title: Perspective - it's your choice
entry.content:
I recalling overhearing this:

Everyday I wait for the bus with this old man. He's always smiling and happy. I could never understand it, rain or shine, good or bad, he is always smiling.

One miserable day, extra cold and wet, and the bus must have been 30 minutes late, this old man is sitting there smiling, so I ask the old man

Why are you smiling, it's a miserable day?

he smiles at me and says

Every day I wake up and choose - will I be happy or will I be sad.

and he pauses, looks me in the eye and says

Why would I choose sad?

entry.title: Grasshopper, do you believe in Luck?
entry.content:
"Ummm, No." I said without much thought. Later, I thought about it. What is luck? The dictionary says: The chance happening of fortunate or adverse events. Fortunate Event? Having unexpected good fortune; lucky. Lets re-phrase this in words that feel good to me:

Luck is a random event that leaves you better off. Lets break it down.

Random Event? From my perspective things are random. Another Blog post will dig into if things really are random when we switch perspectives. I don't want to go into this today, but you can imagine if I pour water on an ant, to the ant the water falling from the sky is random, but from my perspective it is not.

Leaves you better off? Here comes the deep part. How do we determine if something leaves us better off? Externally you can't. The only way to tell if something leaves you better off, is by asking your self. You see, you decide if you are better off, and so you decide if you're lucky.

To answer the question, I believe in luck, and moreover I believe I choose my own luck.

(Those are my good friends Raman and Supraja playing in the snow)

link.title: Grasshopper, do you believe in Luck?

entry.title: An explorer, like an army crawls on its belly.
entry.content:
With out local support , and being cheap, we´ve ended up eating many not so tasty meals. A shame. Like failed conquerors we´ll stick our tail between our legs and return to germany where we can enjoy nice cheap beer.

Today was grey, and this worked well as we spent most of the day in museums. Most paintings don´t interest me, but the spanish national art gallery did have a section called erotic art. It was funny - basically a collection of penii and vaginii that could be found on many American bathroom stalls.

We also saw a castle, it was big , but we were hungry so we gave up and hunted for food.

I´ve been doing some deep thinking , along with tooting you are my sunshine on the harmonica, and i´ve concluded my natural vacation is:

spend euro --------------- walk ---------------- repeat

i guess there is some sleep involved but it complicates the picture.

link.title: An explorer, like an army crawls on its belly.

entry.title: A 34 Euro Lesson.
entry.content:
Weakened by hunger, our defenses were down. We looked at a menu and a beautiful woman
accosted slobodan, suggesting we should come inside it´s only 9 euros.


Before we had a chance to look at the menu, they had us order drinks. Drinks ordered, I looked at the menu and it sucked. We could leave now, but we´d ordered drinks. I thought we could just have our drinks and split, but we were famished. Oh well atleast it was only 9 euros.

When ordering Slobodan asked for a recommendation. The waiter said he didn´t really know, as he didn´t eat here, he just worked here.


The meal wasn´t disgusting, but I could imagine slobodan cooking tastier. The bestest part was to come in the finalle, the check. Our drinks were 7 euros each.






Ah well, a 34 euro lesson. If someone tries to get you into a restaurant - don´t go. On the bright side they had had an excellent picture for the mens bathroom.

entry.title: Things to remember before going somewhere
entry.content:
Print out the address to your hotel. Me - I didn´t think that would be necessary and spent my first 2 hours in barcelona hunting for my hotel. The random spiral theory is not optimal for this sort of thing.

slobodan_pictures 197
Originally uploaded by idvorkin

Don´t pack suspiciously. I set off a full blown bomb threat, when my spiral notebook ( antenna coil on an xray) and my ipod connector ( bomb connector on an xray) where packed at right angles closely in my bag. On seeing this on the xray machine my security line was shutdown, the police were summoned, and I was sent for chemical investigation. All clear in time to catch my flight though - yippy!

Barcelona is nice! It´s warmer than eastern europe and it has a very pretty beach complete with chinup bar!

link.title: Things to remember before going somewhere

entry.title: Travel Poetry
entry.content:
Grey and cold in berlin - but no snow so sad.
Wish Tori was here - would that be so bad?

Now hope and I wait, and dream of a cake
but we can go nowhere till Slobodans awake

Tis not quite the truth since he's in the shower
It takes a while to clean him, he's a delicate flower.

I can not complain since I'm slow as molassis
and spend much of my time sitting on my assis

A great day will we have , it will end in barcelona
All of these thoughts excite my seretona

Slobodan my thanks, for bringing me to berlin
In this last 2 weeks I've had so many a grin

From sausage to cabbage to pickled herring
Thank you dear chefs, for all of your caring

But now my great epic must come to an end
Smile and be happy, and I'll just click send.

entry.title: World Cafeteria Tour Berlin
entry.content:
Planned as world museum tour Berlin, we had a full schedule. To ensure a good start, we started with some hearty sausage and cabbage, and followed up with some rum balls. With our bellies full, we headed to the museum. My poor planning failed to notice that the museum was closed on Mondays, so we were sad. Mulled wine with rum (something we'll have to investigate for our next party) took the edge off as we searched for the next museum. We got distracted by a search for Frank Gehry's whale and then a epic journey to find the remains of the Berlin wall drained our resources. We needed to re-charge and a meat sandwich hit the spot. Next we quested for the German parliament and lego land. A few shots with me and a giraffe later, and it was time for coffee and apple strudel. I'm told for apple strudel in Berlin there is only one choice - Einsteins, and I have to agree.


Content, even though museumless - we returned home, but not without a stop for some Christmas market fried mushrooms. Yummy!

We'll try again for the museum tomorrow.

entry.title: Learning from our elders.
entry.content:
slobodan_pictures 063
Originally uploaded by idvorkin
Here I am in prague, kicking back my beer at a local drinking establishment. With no english on the menu, I had no choice but to order the first thing on the menu, and another beer. As I revel in my survival skills this 80 year old woman walks in and sits down beside us. She orders a 0.5 L beer and whips out a book and starts reading. Over the next few hours as I watch a hockey game and my octoganarian friend reads her book, I think she drank us under the table.

For the curious, Prices in Prague:
Beer - 1 Euro
Great Meal 2 Euros.
Overpriced tourist expensive restaurant with duck confit goose and deer - 10 Euros.
Museum admission 10 Euros

entry.title: Art - it makes you think.
entry.content:
I don't like art. Sorry, I just tend not to get it. Today, I had someone explaining some art to me and it was brilliant. First, on the sight of a big book burning, they have this empty library room with shelves but no books, and a light that's always on. This symbolizes that the books can be destroyed but the ideas can not.

Next the Berlin memorial to dead Jews. This is a very strange concrete maze, it starts off as a very easy to see comfortable thing, but then as you get into it becomes scary, you can't see what's going on, where you are going , who is behind you, etc. I guess it needs to be experienced to be understood.

It's funny when I got to this memorial, I was hopping up and down on these concrete blocks. Then I figured maybe this was some kind of memorial. When the tour guide, fabian of all names, started talking he mentioned that the artist who created this sculpture wanted people to play on the monuments, but the government decided this was not cool. I guess I'm more an artist than politician.

An interesting story about this monument is that it has a special coating to prevent spray paint from sticking. This is important in Berlin as everything is covered in spray paint. Anyways, after that monument was built and the blocks are covered with their anti spray paint coat, it's discovered that the company who makes this magic coat had a Jew murdering connection. Everyone goes nuts, the monument must be destroyed, the coating removed etc. The artist who created the monument says: look this company that made the coat also made the fillings in my teeth and I'm not going to pull the fillings out of my teeth, and lets not fret over the monument. And then everything was OK.

entry.title: The Pope's revenge.
entry.content:
Like the CN tower in Toronto, and the Space needle in Seattle, Berlin has a big phallic symbol for its city. It's called the TV tower - think CN Tower with a disco ball. Built by the communists after the war to prove communist superiority it comes with a few funny stories. First it was the second largest building in Europe when it was built. Who would build a second largest tower you ask? Well, it turns out the tallest tower was the Moscow TV tower,and communist pride wouldn't allow you to build a tower bigger than the one in the mother land. To understand the second funny thing about the tower you need to understand that Russia doesn't believe in religion, so it is constantly tearing down religious artifacts like crosses. Well it turns out when the sun reflects on the disco ball in the TV tower, it forms a giant cross made of reflecting sunlight - this is what Berliners call the Pope's revenge :)


The Pope's revenge, the Fernsehturm in Berlin
Originally uploaded by crossey

entry.title: If you are what you eat I'm German
entry.content:
500 centimeter sausages, 5 cm sausages, all lengths of sausages in between. Roasted chestnuts, cheap donairs, pickles wrapped with pickled herring. Wheat beer, which would be cheaper than water except a law passed to prevent it. Rye bread with seeds. Warm red wine with spices served in a real mug from street vendors. Baklava cafes with 20 kinds of baklava sold by the kilo. Pork tongue for dinner. Yummy!

German prices are funny. For lunch I had a donair for 2.50 and a coke for 1.00. A burger fries pop combo at burger king is 6.00. A coffee is 2.00,but you can find them for .60 cents and a tube of toothpaste is 3.00.

Clutch - Berlin re-unites and they want to get rid of all the communist stuff. Turns out there is one exception. The little men in the traffic signs. You know the little man that tells you its safe to walk across the street. The communist Berlin 'walk' sign has a much cooler man. Now all of Berlin will be converted to use the ex-east Berlin walk sign.

link.title: If you are what you eat I'm German

entry.title: And what do you think?
entry.content:
Tori's kin got a chance to see our Flickr photos, and they provided a funny review. We haven't had a chance to meet them yet but hopefully this fall. Their witty response below:
OK Victoria, Brian and I went to the picture site and looked at quite a few photos. We were especially impressed by the window display of the carved wooden dicks. Christmas shopping? If so, I'll pass, but I think they'd be perfect for the rest of the family. Especially Kathy. I know she doesn't already have one. I have a lovely tin you can pack it in. We also liked the shot of Igor au naturale with his keyboard in his lap. Very few can get away with a shot like that. And since none of the rest of us have men without raging inhibitions it makes for a nice change. Want me to print it out and show it to your Grandmother? Maybe it will start a trend. Perhaps Ed will consider posing with a circular saw or Scott will vogue with a stick of dynamite. Very carefully placed. As for the house...it would have been more interesting to see the house rather than your collection of college-era furniture. You might want to consider going to the dump...Nonetheless, the house looks way better than many of the places we lived, and the neighborhood does indeed appear to be respectable. Hopefully the three of you won't spoil that. Life on the Ranch hasn't changed much. The new calf is well and I just bought a highland heifer from Yakima, WA who should be arriving next month I think. Her name is Lass, and she is bred, so her calf is expected next March. She's pedigreed up the wazoo, so the ranch is going upscale. Either that or I'm just pissing away money. Depends on whether you're talking to me or Brian.

entry.title: There are great movies, they're just not playing in theaters.
entry.content:
Recently, I bought a TV and a blockbuster total access subscription. As a result, I've seen slews of movies. At first, I was worried that this would be a waste of time as I don't really enjoy most movies in theaters, but to my surprise I've seen slews of good movies. In case anyone else reads this, here are some that I enjoyed that you likely won't find on your own:


  • Price of Milk - my favorite romantic flick
  • Cache - Weird, French, and very realistic emotions.
  • Man Of the Year (Rio version) - It's violent, but it has stuff to say about crime, values, social commentary , and there's even a pig.
  • Roger Dodger - Sexist and crude, but it's hard to argue with the main characters points.
  • Every Stewardess Goes to Heaven - A cute story, I especially liked the fellow stealing air plane parts

entry.title: Why should selfish people do good?
entry.content:
I saw two good movies last night, Memories of a Geisha and Cache, both of which have the following in common: Both movies have a trivial gesture by another person early in life, which has huge consequences later in life.

One of my mentors told me:
" It's not an act, but our own interpretation of that act that causes the majority of the act's consequence."

For example, I was recently in a car accident where my car was totaled.

The tow truck driver said to me:
"Wow, you must be pissed"
I laughed and replied:
"I'm thrilled, it could have been my neck that was totaled not my car"
My next postulate is that we believe others act as we do. If we act only out of good, we can't imagine or understand that other things happening out of malice.

Thus, by doing good a person can assure they will interpret as good, those acts in their lives which will have consequences to them.

So you see, doing good can be selfish.

link.title: Why should selfish people do good?

entry.title: I'm thankful for what I have
entry.content:
Today, for the first time in 16 years, I opened my eyes from sleep and saw the world clearly. No metaphors here, I started wearing extended wear contacts and can now sleep without taking my eyeballs out.

This made me realize how many things I take for granted. I'm not usually grateful for being able to see, living without pain, being free of debt. Not many days to do I give thanks for being warm, or being able to chew my food.

I'll tell you, I've got a great life. I've got a loving family and amazing friends. I've got my health, food in my belly and a roof over my head. Thank you life you are awesome!!!
