entry.title: Why is Popeye popular in the Netherlands?
entry.content:
Back in June I had to go to Finland for some work. Finland in the summer is amazing, the sun doesn't go down and you always think it's 4 pm. An other amazing thing in Finland is prices. Everything I bought in Finland was brutally expensive.

The coolest part about my Finland trip was I got off work early, and decided I'd spend a night in Amsterdam. The way the connections worked I had an evening and part of a morning in Netherlands Capital. There were no cheap hotels in the city so I decided I'd stay up all night.

In Amsterdam I drank three different liquids, ranked by price these cost:

  • Water 2.50
  • Tea 2.25
  • Beer 1.85

I had several observation in Amsterdam, in no particular order:
  • There are bicycles everywhere
  • There are people everywhere
  • Cops don't have guns.
  • The red light district, which is an amazing place, is worthy of its own blog post.
  • Prostitutes, are professionals.

The most interesting part of my trip happened around 2 am, when I sat down for a rest, and started chatting with a fellow. It turned out he was a 'hard' drug dealer and we spoke for several hours before he abruptly left. The drug dealer really impressed me, he could have been an economics major. Some observations about the drug dealer:
  • Knew his profit margin (33%), and risks of being greedy.
  • Understood the importance of his customers trusting him.
  • Understood at which point the police would get him
  • Understood a product mix, with different margins and support on different products.
  • Explained what the issues where with scalability in his business
  • Was amazed when I explained we don't carry passport in America
  • Had a great memory, was good with numbers. As an example he remembered my age, and did a computation to figure out how old I was at an event in my life.
  • Tried to get someone to leave him alone by giving him a cigarette, when that failed lied saying he was younger and had kids, in hopes the other person would leave a young father alone.
  • He even asked me about Bill Gates retiring.
Now, to the question of why is Popeye popular in the Netherlands? It turns out that you can't advertise selling drugs in Amsterdam, you can only sell them. To come with a logo that would make people think of drugs, a clever merchant thought who has a pipe? Popeye of course. And the Popeye coffee shop franchise was born.

link.title: Why is Popeye popular in the Netherlands?

entry.title: Lift and Support the Freemont Parade
entry.content:
Thursday night I was supposed to meet a friend at the freemont arts council.
When I arrived, Tori had already been put to work sewing something. When Tori
saw me she asked me if I wanted to be a super hero in the freemont parade.

Sure I said, it would be fun. I was instantly put to work making capes. Room was tight, and I ended up using the band stage for my work space. At the same time the band was playing and trying not to trip on me. A great start!

That night, I tried to decide what super hero to be, originally, I wanted to be beard man, but then it occurred to me , I could be "Wonder Bra!" Genius I thought, lift and augment would be my slogan.

Next morning I'm at the parade, black tights, a cape, and a bra stuffed to the brim with socks. Once the parade started, I was one of the blokes that was collecting money.

Lift and support your parade I'd scream, and person after person would throw money in my hat. Everyone loved it. I loved it and I can't wait for my next chance to wear black tights, a giant bra, and support a good cause.

link.title: Lift and Support the Freemont Parade

entry.title: Who needs viagra when you've got a log and a hatchet.
entry.content:
I've always had this fantasy about chopping wood. It's not the pamela anderson and dolly partons feeding me grapes kind of fantasy, but a good fantasy no less.

Last week when we were out camping, I was tasked with buying firewood. Instead Ryan and I stumbled upon a big log. Ryan and I lugged it into my car. It was a montster, probably weighed a 100 lbs. We got it back to the campsite and every one laughed at me, how will you get that into small pieces they laughed?

At my disposal was a crappy coleman camping saw and a crappy coleman hachet. For hours I sawed and hacked at the log - all I really accomplished was a bit of widdling. I brought the log home though, and I look forward to cutting it down to size once I get the right tools. While the pictures are fun, this story is best told with the video we were taking at the campsite, hopefully Ryan will get it posted to the internet shortly.

link.title: Who needs viagra when you've got a log and a hatchet.

entry.title: A stitch in time saves nine.
entry.content:
Sunday I looked at my tire, it was worn and I thought I should replace it.

But, I didn't.

Monday, I was biking to work and bang flat tire! I replaced the flat using the spare tube I carry in my panniers.

Wisely, after the flat, I went to the bike store, and picked up a new inner tube for my panniers. At that point I should have bought a new time

But I didn't.

That night after work I was biking home. 2 miles from home, I got another flat. At this point, I'm tired, cranky and very aggravated, at that point I should have replace my flat,

But I didn't.

Instead I think, it's going to get dark in 30 minutes so I'll just walk home, and replace my tube and tire in a few days. As luck would have it 20 minutes of walking later my tire is completely flat and my wheel is bouncing against the pavement, causing wheel damage. At this
point I have no choice but to change the tire, (for the second time in one day). To make matters worse, since I waited, now it's dark and I have to change the tire in dark. Thankfully, my light batteries were charged.


Today, no fooling around, I bought new tires. I replaced my old tires, and not quick enough, since there was already another puncture in my rear tire.

Hopefully I'll learn something from this, but some how I doubt it.

link.title: A stitch in time saves nine.

entry.title: Wallace Falls - Batteries not included.
entry.content:
I've been on a camping crusade this summer. It's barely June and we've got 3 camping trips to our name. Unfortunately I keep forgetting my camera or my batteries. My only pictures from this crusade are from the trip to Bainbridge which I'll blog about later.

This weekend's trip was to Wallace Falls, a nice campsite and waterfall hike just past the Sultan Bakery. There are only 7 campsites, but even though we arrived noon on Saturday there were still two sites available.

The hiking trail to Wallace Lake was great, but at 11 miles round trip , it's long. I'd recommend only hiking to the top of falls, You still get most of the views but without those extra 4 miles.

On this trip I lit my first fire, it took several tries and involved the complete dulling of a leatherman. After much trial and many errors I finally figured it out. Hopefully next time it'll be easier. I Also learned a valuable lesson about keeping my shoes in the vestibule if it might rain.

Next time I promise I'll bring my batteries.

entry.title: What the world needs now are Buy Bans!
entry.content:
When I lived in Phoenix, pollution used to be nasty, and the city would institute a ban on burning things, garbage, firewood, you name it. Until the air quality got better, you couldn't burn anything.


In my life consumerism is nasty. Quality of life suffers from our disposable society, our shrink wrapped meals , our desire to own things and the way these things warp our world. With that in mind I've decided I'd institute a Buy Ban. Yesterday and Today I'm refusing to by anything. If it goes well, I'll have more and longer buy bans.

link.title: What the world needs now are Buy Bans!

entry.title: After the side walk ends
entry.content:
Not content with reaching the end of the sidewalk, I hopped on a ferry and explored Vashon island. Vashon island is a neat place, it has a population of ~ 10,000 people and connects to the mainland only by ferry. Likely due to the lack of bridges, there isn't much traffic on Vashon, which makes biking a dream. Well, it would be a dream if it wasn't for the hills. The elevation on Vashon is a killer, I'm curious if I'll be able to ride my bike to work tomorrow.

You can see my planned route here , except, I seem to have got lost a few times, as I ended up riding 50 miles even.

The coolest thing I saw was a group of exercise bikes overlooking the water. Vashon is cool well worth another ride.

Sometimes, you think stuff is completely busted, but all you are missing is a bit of lube.

entry.title: Socio-Economics and biking
entry.content:
Being rich means having stuff, with having stuff comes a desire not to lose stuff, and it's this desire that makes me feel safe biking through rich neighborhoods.


Today I biked through some poor neighborhoods, it reminded me of the slums I biked through in Phoenix. The ones where they had no plumbing. Imagine a modern city without plumbing.

Nothing very exciting happened, I hit a patch of dirt and wiped out, I was fine, but my bike computer was not so lucky. There will be some duct tape in its future :)

It's getting chilly now, so I wear my biking ear muffs. Ear muffs rock for biking because they keep your head warm, and also keep down the sound of the wind. Here's to a long winter of biking.

entry.title: Bandera Mountain - 3.5 Mile Hike + 0.5 Liters of Water = Very Dehydrated.
entry.content:
Saturday I went for a hike with some friends up Bandera mountain. It started as a fun hike, but very quickly I realized I didn't have enough water. Once I got used to being thirsty, I was thrilled to discover that that last 3/4 miles of Bandera is a hands and knees hike, going up at a 40 - 50 degree slope. A pretty cool view from the top though.

My favorite part of the hike came on the my way down when I came upon a water fall. I'm not sure if the water was bad for me, but it felt wonderful to scoop the water into my mouth. It was cool and refreshing, the best tasting water I've had in a long time.

All in all, not an easy first hike, but it was fun. I'll be bringing more water on my hike next week.

link.title: Bandera Mountain - 3.5 Mile Hike + 0.5 Liters of Water = Very Dehydrated.

entry.title: Consumption vs Production
entry.content:
I'm not talking about production in the sense of Marx or Wealth of Nations, instead I'm talking about making stuff, baking a pie, or rebuilding an engine. In the same vein consumption means using things other people produced. Eating an apple or watching a movie for example.

It seems logical that consumption is what makes us happy. Eating a nice cheese cake, or watching a funny comedian makes us happy. But if we think about it more, after we've consumed, we feel empty. This often leads us to the "we want to consume again feeling."

A concrete example, when we buy something we're happy. But then after we've taken it home, the thrill of buying it wears off, and we're no longer happy. We want to go shopping again.

On the other hand production gives us a sense of worth and pride, and brings true long term happiness. Who isn't proud of a painting they created, of a yard they maintained, of a garden they planted? An even better example of production, who isn't proud of their children?


Production takes effort, it is more difficult than consumption, but it is what brings us happiness. If we try to find happiness in consumption we'll be left wanting more and more but having less and less.

entry.title: Have you been ComposicaGoogalized?
entry.content:
Today I went in search of an old friend of mine named Micheal Lacroix. To do this I typed his name into google. It turns out the first hit in google was a musical composer. Normally I wouldn't care about this, but when you search for my name in google you find a composer that has my name.

I've decided this is a serious condition. As any person who has discovered a serious condition, I want to name this condition. I hear by declare the name of this condition to be ComposicaGoogalized.


To be added to the world's dictionaries:

ComposicaGoogalized - To have your identity on google replaced by a composer.

entry.title: Do you believe in mind monsters?
entry.content:
Last night I was having trouble sleeping so I plopped down on the couch to watch infomercials. The infomercial I picked was religious in nature, and was talking about mind monsters.
At first I was laughing out load, laughing at how gullible people must be to believe in this stuff. Mind Monsters - what a silly idea - sheesh. Then I started listening. The mind monsters this evangelist was describing were the negative emotions we all have. Negative emotions like anger, and ego. This evangelist was preaching the same ideas any good book on Buddhism and Taoism often discusses.
What the preacher said next sounded funny at first, but after some contemplation I realized I liked it. The preacher proceeded to tell this parable:
Say you have a prize horse that you're training to win the Kentucky derby. Do you feed this horse ketchup and peanut butter? Of course not - you need this horse to win so you feed it the highest quality oats you can find.
Now, isn't your mind far more important than a race horse? Surely you shouldn't be focusing on silly things like anger and ego.

That parable reminded me that I've been spending too much time focusing on silly things like being critical. Since a rose by any other name still smells as sweet, I have to say, I believe in mind monsters.

----
There's a great poem on the topic by the author of Search Inside Yourself (Chade-Meng Tang) 

My monsters.
Greed, hatred, envy, anger, agitation, egoistic pride, lust, etc. 
They come in different forms, shapes, colors and sizes.
Over the years, I have learned to deal with them. 
I do that by letting go.
First, I let go of my wish to control or suppress them.
When they arrive, I acknowledge them.
I let them be.
Next, I let go of my instinct to vilify them.
I seek to understand them.
I see them for who they are. 
They are merely creations of my body and mind.
I humor them a little.
I joke with them.
I joke about them.
I let them play.
And then, I let go of my desire to feed them.
They may play here all they want.
But they get no food from me.
They are free to stay here hungry, if they want.
And I continue to let them be.
And then they get really hungry.
And sometimes they leave.
Finally, I let go of my desire to hold on to them.
They are free to leave as they wish.
I let them go.
I am free.
For now.
I do not overcome them. 
They do not overcome me.
And we live together.
In harmony.

link.title: Do you believe in mind monsters?

entry.title: Who wants to hear me talking to myself?
entry.content:
Isn't that all this is, me talking to myself? Really that's all a blog is. I expect my mom and dad want to here the little voices in my head, but I can't think of that many other people this would interest.

But, I've never much cared for the opinions of others - in fact, the people I care about are my family, friends and self. Just imagine in a few years, when I can't see my toes, I'll be able to sit back and read about my not so exciting adventures. Even better a few years after that my grandchildren might be able to giggle when they read the story of how their Zeda met their grandma.

I've always believed writing should end with a clever closing sentence, but since nothing clever is coming to mind, I'll have to end with a funny picture.

link.title: Who wants to hear me talking to myself?

entry.title: Reduce and Reuse - Don't Recycle!
entry.content:
I go a little batty when folks praise the merits of recycling. Far too often, recycling is used as a justification for our unbounded wastefulness. Compared to reducing and reusing recycling is a terrible choice. There is so much we can do with our "disposable" items. Here's a great example of someone reusing paper grocery bags for gift wrapping. Not only are they reusing, but even better, they're reducing the amount of trash they'd have produced by buying wrapping paper.

Great Job - On behalf of all the trees I know - Thank you.

entry.title: Caught on the bridge.
entry.content:
Last night I was walking home across a draw bridge. As I was about a 1/4 across I saw the gauds coming down, and then I heard the bridge moving. Getting a bit concerned I started running across the bridge. Luckily the bridge operator saw me, and stopped opening the bridge. I jumped the middle and crossed safely. After I got off the bridge, I watched as the bridge opened and the two halves of the bridge went vertical. Kind of scary.

2 morals to this story.
1) don't wander on draw bridges at night when you're wearing all black
2) If you're caught on a draw bridge that is opening, run to the closest end. Do not run across the middle ;)

entry.title: A Helping Hand
entry.content:
Last night as I was walking back to my car at the grocery store I was approached by a panicked older woman.

"Help Me " she said.
"How can I be of assistance ma'am" , I replied, thinking something terrible had happened.

"My car, I cant' get into my car. The car parked beside mine is too close." she said in frenzied voice.

"No problem Ma'am, I can take care of that for you", I said.

I then took the woman’s keys and pulled her car out of the spot for her.

After driving the car out of the parking spot, I wished the woman a good day. The woman was very grateful, and still slightly shocked as I drove away.

entry.title: The Machine Ate My Card
entry.content:
Today I needed some money so I went to the bank machine. I inserted by debit card, typed in that I wanted 80 $ and waited. Suddenly, the machine printed: " Error, card expired - card will not be returned".

I was in shock. "The machine ate my card" I mumbled in disbelief. "My coworker asked me what happend. I explained that the machine said my card was expired and would not be returned.

My coworker told me how that was good security, the bank wouldn't want an expired card in use.

I thought about it a while, and thought yes, that is good security.

Later on, I called the bank. I told the nice lady at the bank what happened. I asked when my card had expired. The lady at the bank told me the machine had malfunctioned and my card would not expire till 2007.

My new card is in the mail.

entry.title: Wink Wink Nudge Nudge, Another Police Story.
entry.content:
It seems everytime I go out with my white male friend, we always seem to get noticed by the police.

This time, my friend and I were getting ready for a dive in a not quite legal location. To keep the story readable we'll call this location mukilteo. I've given at mukilteo on several occasions, and I've never been bothred by the police.

However, as I was pulling on my hood, I was blinded by the lights of a police car. The police officer exits his vehicle and begins telling us in an aggravated voice that if we don't get out of here, we'll be facing upwards of a 1000 dollars in fines.

My dive buddy and I fully dressed in our dive gear hop in his truck, and start to zoom off. Before we can exit the location, another police car fires up his siren , and stops us.

This time, another officer comes out of his car. The officer flashes us with his flashlight, and say "Divers? Geez we've got a rookie on tonight, he doesn't know what is going on". I ask the officer if we are allowed to dive here. The office replies " Well, you know, "No" wink wink nudge nudge. Clear as mud right?"

We laugh, thank the officer and drive off.

link.title: Wink Wink Nudge Nudge, Another Police Story.

entry.title: Police Warnings and Racial Profiling
entry.content:
Today I had a funny.

My white male friend and I got stopped by the police . The police man said we were only getting a warning, but he would have to write it up because of racial profiling.

I asked the policeman about this racial profiling. The policeman explained that he had to write up all warnings to prove that he didn't racial profile. He explained that the demographic that gets the most tickets depends on your geographic location. He continued that in north seattle, he mostly pulls over white females, as they are the majority of drivers.

We thanked the officer for not giving us a ticket, and proceeded on our way. Later after the policecar had pulled away I read over the warning. It said Ethnicty: W , Gender: F.

entry.title: In South Africa we were told to watch out for this...
entry.content: In South Africa we were told to watch out for this happening, b/c crooks rig the machines to take your card after you have punched in your PIN. Then you walk away to get help or something and the crook takes money out of your account. So in order to make sure the ATM works, you put in your card, cancel the transaction before putting in your PIN, and then if the card comes out, put the card back in and continue with the transaction....

entry.title:
Learning from our elders.

Here I am in prag...
entry.content:
Learning from our elders.

Here I am in prague, kicking back my beer at a local drinking establishment. With no english on the menu, I had no choice but to order the first thing on the menu, and another beer. As I revel in my survival skills this 80 year old woman walks in and sits down beside us. She orders a 0.5 L beer and whips out a book and starts reading. Over the next few hours as I watched a hockey game and my octoganarian friend read her book, I think she drank us under the table.

entry.title:
Things to remember before going somewhere

P...
entry.content:
Things to remember before going somewhere

Print out the address to your hotel. Me - I didn´t think that would be necessary and spent my first 2 hours in barcelona hunting for my hotel. The random spiral theory is not optimal for this sort of thing.

Don´t pack suspiciously. I set off a full blown bomb threat, when my spiral notebook ( antenna coil on an xray) and my ipod connector ( bomb connector on an xray) where packed at right angles closely in my bag. On seeing this on the xray machine my security line was shutdown, the police were summoned, and I was sent for chemical investigation. All clear in time to catch my flight though - yippy!

Barcelona is nice! It´s warmer then eastern europe and it has a very pretty beach complete with chinup bar!

entry.title:
A 34 Euro Lesson.

Weakened by hunger, our d...
entry.content:
A 34 Euro Lesson.

Weakened by hunger, our defenses were down. We looked at a menu and a beautiful woman
accosted slabodan, suggesting we should come inside it´s only 9 euros.


Before we had a chance to look at the menu, they had us order drinks. Drinks ordered, I looked at the menu and it sucked. We could leave now, but we´d ordered drinks. I thought we could just have our drinks and split, but we were famished. Oh well atleast it was only 9 euros.

When ordering Slobodan asked for a recommendation. The waiter said he didn´t really know, as he didn´t eat here, he just worked here.


The meal wasn´t disgusting, but I could imagine slobodan cooking tastier. The bestest part was to come in the finalle, the check. Our drinks were 7 euros each.


Ah well, a 34 euro lesson. If someone tries to get you into a restaurant - don´t go. On the bright side they had had an excellent picture for the mens bathroom. I´ll post it when I get back.

entry.title:
An explorer, like an army crawls on its belly.
...
entry.content:
An explorer, like an army crawls on its belly.

With out local support , and being cheap, we´ve ended up eating many not so tasty meals. A shame. Like failed conquerors
we´ll stick our tail between our legs and return to germany where we can enjoy nice cheap beer.


Today was grey, and this worked well as we spent most of the day in museums. Most paintings don´t intersest me, but the spanish national art gallery did have a section called erotic art. It was funny - basically a collection of penii and vaginas that could be found on many american bathroom stall.

We also saw a castle, it was big , but we were hungy so we gave up and hunted for food.

i´ve been doing some deep thinking , along with tooting you are my sunshine on the harmonica, and i´ve concluded my natural vacation is:

spend euro --------------- walk ---------------- repeat

i guess there is some sleep involved but it complicates the picture.

entry.title: I have *got* to start waking up earlier. How do I ...
entry.content: I have *got* to start waking up earlier. How do I do that?

entry.title: Waking up early is like jumping into a lake in the...
entry.content:
Waking up early is like jumping into a lake in the middle of winter - it seems like a terrible idea, but as soon as you've done you feel empowered.

I have a few strategies:
1) Have morning appointments (7am burly men show up at my house to make me run)
2) Set my alarm and look at what I'm supposed to wake up several time (I use my phone) :)
3) Be realistic, if I'm going to bed at 2am, I'll move my alarm forward.
4) Focus on the benefits of eating worms.
